HEADLINE: Saddam's Offensive 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM SAFIRE; E-mail: safire@nytimes.com

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
Sixty Islamic terrorists, trained in Afghanistan by Osama bin Laden, are holed up in the town of Biyara in northern Iraq, guests of Saddam Hussein. Their assignment is to infiltrate the no-flight zone and to kill the Kurdish leaders, who Saddam assumes will be allied with the U.S. in his overthrow.
 This is the same assignment that Al Qaeda performed for the Taliban last Sept. 9, when a terrorist suicide team murdered the most popular Afghan leader, Ahmed Massoud. That assassination was intended to weaken anti-Taliban forces if the U.S. responded to the Sept. 11 attacks by hitting Osama's base in Afghanistan. 
 Ten days ago, a suicide team of three terrorists was dispatched by Saddam's Qaeda affiliate into the Kurdish area of Iraq protected by the U.S. and British air forces. A Kurdish leader, Jalal Talabani (no kin to the Taliban), was meeting in Sulaimaniya with the U.S. diplomats Ryan Crocker and David Pearce. 
With that meeting guarded by scores of Kurdish pesh merga fighters, the terrorists targeted the home of Barham Salih, 41, the pro-Western regional prime minister. Their grenades and gunfire missed his appearance at his front door by 10 seconds. Five Kurdish guards were killed and two of the assassins died in the return fire. 
The third terrorist was wounded and caught. "I came to kill and be killed," he pleaded, but the pesh merga -- many of whose relatives were ambushed, captured and beheaded by Saddam's Islamic surrogates two months ago -- saved him for interrogation. He is the source of the intelligence about the 60 Qaeda terrorists in Biyara carrying out Saddam's assassination plans.
That intelligence seems of little interest to our C.I.A., which failed to inform members of the National Security Council of this incident until my query two days ago. Maybe it has no agents on the ground (though our diplomats were); maybe its director is distracted by his high-visibility diplomatic chores; maybe it is sulking because the journalist Jeffrey Goldberg of The New Yorker went where no spook had gone before. 
Whatever the excuse, it's unlikely that one dollar of our $30 billion intelligence budget (which includes covert operations) has gone to provide one automatic rifle, one mortar, or one anti-tank rocket to the 70,000 Kurdish fighters who would make up our most dependable indigenous ally in any coalition to overthrow Saddam. 
President Bush constantly evokes Saddam's poison gas attack in 1988 on the Kurds in Halabja, killing many thousands of innocents, as evidence of the dictator's willingness to use weapons of mass destruction. Understandably, neither he nor Colin Powell wants to recall the elder Bush's blunder that allowed Saddam to keep his gunships and slaughter Kurds who trusted us to support their uprising after our Persian Gulf victory. 
Ever since that debacle, we have protected the Kurds and they are grateful for our air cover. As a result, they have built the only democratic government and rudimentary free-enterprise system in the Middle East since the birth of Israel. Contrast the Kurds' recent progress with that of Palestinians -- a people burdened with corrupt leaders, kept in squalid refugee camps for generations by Arab despots and fed a diet of hatred. 
Afflicted by tribal tensions at the start of their decade of freedom, the two Kurdish factions have come together. After Saddam's recent assassination attempt, the urbane Jalal (let's use his first name) was embraced by Massoud Barzani, as 100,000 Kurds marched through a heavy rain at the murdered guards' funeral. Kurds now dream of an autonomous region within a democratic Iraq, which would be acceptable to Turkey with its large Kurdish minority. 
If Bush is serious about overthrowing Saddam before that avatar of arrogance gets the power to obliterate Washington, he cannot count on a colonels' coup or a coat-holding coalition of craven caliphs. We have already had to begin abandoning our bases in Saudi Arabia. Joining us in liberating Iraq will be Brits, Turks and Kurds. 
The Kurds, though fierce fighters, cannot be provided with modern arms and trained to use them overnight. Saddam, allied with bin Ladenesque cadres, has begun his offensive -- diplomatic at the U.N., economic with oil-embargo threats, terrorist to his north. Time is short for our counterattack.

HEADLINE: A First Filing Makes Kirch Bankruptcy Official 

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS, April 8 

 BODY:
After weeks of teetering on the brink, the core companies of the Kirch Group media empire filed for bankruptcy protection in Germany today, paving the way for the banks that hold the bulk of Kirch's debt to reorganize its many activities.
 Representatives of Kirch's creditor banks said that KirchMedia, the unit that holds valuable broadcast rights to Hollywood films and World Cup soccer and stakes in German private television, had filed for protection. They also said a second unit, KirchPayTV, in which the Rupert Murdoch company British Sky Broadcasting holds a 22 percent stake, had also filed for protection. But executives at KirchPayTV denied this, and rumors circulated this evening that a last-minute move by an unnamed investor might make it possible for KirchPayTV to sidestep bankruptcy. 
 The creditor banks decided to push KirchMedia into bankruptcy today for a similar purpose, to open the way for outside investors to rescue some of the group's substantial assets. Germany has no direct equivalent of Chapter 11 bankruptcy in the United States, under which a company's managers continue to run it while it reorganizes; the filing today means that the court will appoint an administrator to take control.
Kirch Holding, the parent company, is struggling under $5.7 billion in debts, largely amassed in an aggressive push into pay television. It remained unclear this evening which other units of the Kirch group would file for bankruptcy.
Wolfgang Hartmann, a management board member of Commerzbank, speaking for the creditor group, said, "I'd like to emphasize that we will do everything to avoid a breakup" of Kirch. At a news conference in Munich, where Kirch is based, he called it the "biggest case of insolvency in Germany." The banks' goals, Mr. Hartmann said, were to save jobs, cut costs and debt and "avoid an erosion of assets."
Kirch is the third major bankruptcy to rattle Germany in recent weeks, after the Philipp Holzmann construction company and Fairchild Dornier, a builder of regional and business jets. And it could have significant political fallout, with jobs lost and doors opened to foreign investors in the formerly closed world of German television.
Ripples from Kirch's filing are expected to reach as far as Hollywood, where studios are owed about 500 million euros ($440 million), and through the sports world. Kirch paid 1.3 billion Swiss francs for the rights to the 2002 World Cup soccer championship. To shield them from creditors, those rights were transferred today to Kirch Sport A.G., a sibling company based in Zug, Switzerland.
For KirchMedia, whose main asset is a 52 percent stake in Germany's largest private television company, ProSiebenSat.1 Media, today's filing came after a consortium of banks and minority shareholders who were unwilling to throw more good money after bad failed to find a solution for saving the group. But the consortium -- including Commerzbank; the government-controlled Bayerische Landesbank; the HVB Group; and DZ Bank -- said it had agreed on a broad framework to keep some of Kirch's healthy businesses operating.
Among Kirch's other holdings are Kirch Beteiligung, which manages rights, and KirchPayTV, which includes the hugely unprofitable pay channel Premiere.
Wolfgang van Betteray, a lawyer for Kirch, said that KirchPay TV would probably also file for insolvency. But a spokesman for the unit said talks were continuing with minority shareholders "over ways of averting insolvency," and a spokesman for the bankruptcy court in Munich said the unit had not filed for protection today.
The outcome is crucial to Mr. Murdoch, because his British Sky Broadcasting holds an option to force Kirch to buy its shares back in October for $1.7 billion. Meeting that commitment would bankrupt Kirch, a turn of events that could play into Mr. Murdoch's plans by allowing him to cherry-pick assets, bankers in London and Frankfurt said.
British Sky Broadcasting has already written off the value of that option, suggesting that Mr. Murdoch is using it as a bargaining tool to get what he wants. Ultimately that could be ProSiebenSat.1 Media and, to a lesser extent, Premiere.
Mr. Hartmann said that the banks would have to come up with somewhat less than $1 billion in fresh money to keep Kirch going, but that they would seek to involve some of Kirch's minority shareholders, including both German and foreign investors.
The bank plan emerged after the failure of talks with Mr. Murdoch and another Kirch shareholder, the Mediaset group owned by the Italian prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi.
Mediaset executives have said that they are interested in a role. Mr. Betteray, the Kirch lawyer, said that "the question whether Mediaset wants to be part of the new Kirch Media has to be asked by Mediaset itself, as by every investor."
Essentially, Kirch came down because it did not have the $3 billion it needed to make debt payments from now to October. At least eight banks have loans of more than $100 million outstanding to Kirch.
The solution sought by the banks involves selling unprofitable businesses, bringing in new investors, perhaps including the big German publishers WAZ Gruppe and Axel Springer, and an exchange of new stock for the debts the banks hold.
"It means an interruption," Mr. Hartmann said, "but from the point of view of the financing banks, not an end but a turning point."
Today's filing represents an end for Leo Kirch, 75, the entrepreneur who built the group with a keen eye for the value of media properties and strong help from conservative politicians like Helmut Kohl, the former chancellor, and Edmund Stoiber, the governor of Bavaria and the conservative standard-bearer in German elections in September.
Mr. Kirch began in 1959, borrowing money to buy the rights to "La Strada," Federico Fellini's film, and reselling them to TV stations. Over the years, Mr. Kirch, who is partly blind from diabetes, contributed heavily to the Christian Democratic party of Mr. Kohl and Mr. Stoiber. Critics have accused him of parlaying that aid into political favors when German television opened to private investment in the 1980's.
The German chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, has sought to exploit Kirch's woes in his re-election campaign against Mr. Stoiber. At a news conference in Berlin today, Mr. Schroder said the decision by the Bayerische Landesbank, which is 50 percent owned by the Bavarian government, to pump money into Kirch amounted to "economic incompetence."
But Mr. Schroder also stands to suffer from Kirch's troubles if, as labor leaders predict, some 4,000 jobs are eliminated, hollowing the chancellor's pledges to reduce unemployment.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTING CANCER: SCIENTIST AT WORK -- PETER GOTZSCHE; 
A Career That Bristles With Against-the-Grain Conclusions

BYLINE:  By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: COPENHAGEN 

 BODY:
Seated at an eerily neat desk in a modern office on the grounds of Denmark's state hospital, Dr. Peter C. Gotzsche does not seem a man whose bite is much worse than his very gentle bark.
 But this tall, gray-haired statistician is sending some eminent doctors into fits of apoplexy as he quietly implies that they've wasted their lives defending old wives' tales, maltreated their patients or assisted in frauds that perhaps ought to land them in jail. 
 Most recently, he has made headlines for a study published in The Lancet in October concluding that the major studies of mammography do not show that mammograms can reduce death from breast cancer.
Earlier last year, in The New England Journal of Medicine, he purported to pop the old shibboleth known as the placebo effect. Many doctors who have for years repeated what they had learned in medical school -- that about 35 percent of patients improve if you give them only a sugar pill -- learned that Dr. Gotzsche felt they had fallen for a theory as grounded in hard evidence as the one that swamp gas causes malaria. 
In 1999, in The Journal of the American Medical Association, he argued that the research behind the Food and Drug Administration approval of fluconazole, an expensive and highly touted anti-fungal drug, was based on cooked books.
Before he was director of the Nordic Cochrane Center here and paid to make trouble like this, he was in private research. There, he asserted that a multinational drug company was deliberately overdosing AIDS patients with AZT because it was profitable to do so.
His critics say he is too harsh, rejecting important studies with small but acceptable data-collection flaws. 
Dr. Gotzsche replies that he does not go around looking for trouble, but it seems to come looking for him.
"We had no preconceptions about mammograms when we were asked by a government agency to look into this," he said in an interview in his blue and white office, where a thick stack of mammogram data fills drawer space. "It just wasn't one of my interests."
"Now I've received more than 2,000" -- he stops, and checks his computer -- "I've received 2,276 e-mails about this. It's incredible what we've unleashed."
Cancer researchers who still endorse mammograms have loudly attacked the work he did with his colleague Dr. Ole Olsen.
The seven landmark studies that back the use of mammograms for early cancer detection were begun between 1962 and 1982 in New York, Canada and Sweden. Dr. Gotzsche's specialty, meta-analysis, blends multiple study results. But he and Dr. Olsen found five too flawed to use; the remaining two showed no benefit.
Dr. Anthony B. Miller at the German Cancer Research Center said some of the five were precipitously thrown out because the authors couldn't or wouldn't answer all of Dr. Gotzsche's questions about their data.
Attacks on him have come from three groups, Dr. Gotzsche said: disinterested experts, oncologists who spent careers recommending mammograms, and those who earn money in the $1 billion screening industry.
The first group, he said, are "academic and reasonable," the rest have vested interests "and want to shoot the messenger."
Dr. Gotzsche was born 53 years ago in Naestved, near Copenhagen, where his mother taught mathematics and home economics.
Her father, a doctor, was his role model. "He was very bright," Dr. Gotzsche said. "I never succeeded in beating him in chess."
His own grandfather never once let him win?
"No," he answered, looking perplexed. "Fairness and honesty were important values in the family. I would have found it unfair if he lost to me on purpose."
His first job was a paper route, and he planned to be a doctor, too, "until I realized when I was 17 that many of my grandfather's patients really weren't ill."
They were affluent women," he said. "Seeing the doctor was a social event, so I decided it was a waste of time. I wanted to be a biologist and walk in rain forests."
Instead, as a biologist, he went to work doing clinical trials for Astra Pharmaceuticals. But, disillusioned by its glowing pitches for the arthritis drug he tested, he started medical school in 1978. By 1990, he had a medical degree and a doctorate. His thesis: "Bias in Double-Blind Trials."
"It was provocative," he said quietly. "In 1990, the pharmaceutical industry had a good image."
The thesis was read by Dr. Iain Chalmers, an Oxford professor who founded the Cochrane Collaboration, and invited Dr. Gotzsche to direct its Nordic branch.
The self-supporting collective, which has worldwide chapters in 50 medical specialties, was named for Archie Cochrane, author of a history of fatal flaws in medical practice, like the refusal by 19th century doctors to wash their hands between dissecting corpses and examining patients.
Its mission is to question medical tenets by analyzing all the trials of any treatment. It has, for example, compared 1,000 acupuncture studies and concluded there is no evidence it works, even for pain or smoking.
His placebo study, with Dr. Asbjorn Hrobjartsson, was done by hunting down trials that experts thought hardly existed: those with three patient groups, the treatment, a placebo and no treatment. They hoped to find a dozen, but by getting the United States National Library of Medicine to rewrite its software so "Treatment: none" could be searched, they found 130, in everything from herpes to nausea to schizophrenia. Over all, the untreated patients -- those still on the waiting list, for example -- got better at the same rate as those receiving placebos.
"We started the project believing there were important placebo effects," Dr. Gotzsche said. "But when we finished, there wasn't much left."
A small effect may exist in subjective symptoms, like pain, he conceded, but not in doctor-observable ones like swelling.
Dr. James M. Robins, a Harvard epidemiologist who follows Dr. Gotzsche's work, said he would probably have reached different conclusions. Dr. Gotzsche excluded acceptable mammogram studies and averaged pain studies in a way that made the placebo effect seem not to exist, rather than to exist in some studies for unknown reasons.
He called Dr. Gotzsche's harshness toward other people's randomized trial data "unscientific and even bizarre."
"He seems to have a very black-and-white mind," Dr. Robins said. "When he writes, he seems to be saying: 'You've done such terrible things against the pristine world of randomization that you're not going to be allowed in the covenant.' "
Aware of his critics, Dr. Gotzsche said he was "not cooking up difficulties or being nihilistic."
"There are many things in health care that, if you look at them closely, you are disappointed," he said.
His 1999 fluconazole study, done with Dr. Helle Krogh Johansen, his wife, attacked the research backing a drug that sells in the United States for $25 a pill for yeast infections and toenail fungus but also kills funguses that can be fatal to AIDS patients.
He found that studies by Pfizer, fluconazole's patent holder, compared oral doses to mixed results for amphotericin B and nystatin. But amphotericin B should be given intravenously and nystatin doesn't work at all, Dr. Gotzsche said, so the studies were, in effect, rigged.
In a later letter to the medical journal, Pfizer conceded that the comparison drugs did not work and that it would change how it reported results of trials. A Pfizer spokesman, Andrew McCormick, says the company stands by that response.
In 1987, Dr. Gotzsche said, he was the coordinator for all Nordic AIDS drug trials, and found that AZT was just as effective, with fewer side effects, at 400 milligrams as at 1,200 milligrams, the dose recommended by its maker, Burroughs Wellcome. The company, which sold it in 100-milligram pills, did not lower its recommendation, he said. 
Patricia R. Seif, a spokeswoman for GlaxoSmithKline, which now owns the Burroughs Wellcome company, said 1987 was "ancient history" but recalled that the company's recommended AZT dosage was reduced from 1,200 to 600 milligrams in mid-1990, based on studies sponsored by the National Institute of Allergic and Infectious Diseases between 1986 and 1989. About the price-gouging accusation, she said the company cut its price for AZT by 20 percent in 1987 and another 20 percent in 1989.
No one she could find recalled Dr. Gotzsche's Nordic study, she said.
Asked if he had ever confronted Burroughs Wellcome by holding a news conference or getting a forceful group like Act Up into the fray, Dr. Gotzsche said he had not, then added: "Perhaps we should have -- but that was not our style here in the Nordic countries."

ORGANIZATION: NEW ENGLAND JOURNAL OF MEDICINE (56%); AMERICAN MEDICAL ASSOCIATION (55%); FOOD & DRUG ADMINISTRATION (55%)

HEADLINE: The Peril of Too Much Power 

BYLINE:  By Timothy Garton Ash; Timothy Garton Ash is director of the European Studies Centre at St. Antony's College, Oxford, and a senior fellow at the Hoover Institution at Stanford University.

DATELINE: STANFORD, Calif. 

 BODY:
For most of the 20th century, the defining political question was: What do you think of Russia? At the beginning of the 21st century, it is: What do you think of America? Tell me your America and I'll tell you who you are.
 Sitting in sun-dried California, I have been trying to work out exactly what I think. Quite a few European writers caricature America as a dangerous, selfish giant, blundering around the world doing ill, and as an anthology of all that is wrong with capitalism -- in contrast to morally superior European versions. But of course America can't be reduced in this way. Apart from anything else, it is just too large, too diverse, too much a cornucopia of combinations and contradictions to allow any simple interpretation. Here in Stanford there is the post-Sept. 11 "United We Stand" poster on the Japanese-American sushi bar, but also the bookshop that declares itself a "hate-free zone," with a notice in the window deploring attacks on Arab-Americans. There's the gung-ho unilateralism of Fox TV, but also the patient multilateralism of elder statesmen interviewed on CNN. As Walt Whitman wrote: 
 Do I contradict myself? 
Very well then I contradict myself, 
(I am large, I contain multitudes.)
So any simple generalization will be wrong. My own, more complicated conclusion is this: I love this country and I worry about its current role in the world. I use the word love loosely, of course, as we do in our increasingly Americanized English. I love the energy, the openness, the everyday cheerfulness of people in shops and on the street, the sense of freedom you get driving for hours down a California highway under those king-size skies, and the feeling that all people -- whoever they are, wherever they come from -- have a chance to shape their own lives. I love the accuracy of The New York Times, the vigor of television's "Crossfire," the probing tough-mindedness of the best universities in the world and the American activists I've frequently encountered in Eastern Europe and the Balkans who really do want other people to share the freedoms they enjoy.
Most people in the world will have some such list. For America is part of everyone's imaginative life, through movies, music, television and the Web, whether you grow up in Bilbao, Beijing or Bombay. Everyone has a New York in their heads, even if they have never been there -- which is why the destruction of the twin towers had such an impact. This fascination with American culture, in the broadest sense of that term, is part of what Joseph Nye, dean of Harvard's Kennedy School of Government, calls America's "soft power."
So why I am worried about this wonderful country's current role in the world? Partly because until President Bush changed tack last week, I feared that if the United States were to attack Iraq without taking the lead in negotiating a settlement of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, the Islamic world would be united against the West while Europe would be divided from America, with disastrous consequences for years to come.
But my concern goes deeper than simply a worry about the Middle Eastern policy of a particular administration. The fundamental problem is that America today has too much power for anyone's good, including its own. It has that matchless, global soft power in all of our heads. In economic power its only rival is the European Union. In military power it has no rival. Its military expenditure is greater than that of the next eight largest military powers combined. Not since Rome has a single power enjoyed such superiority -- but the Roman colossus only bestrode one part of the world. Stripped of its anti-American overtones, the French foreign minister Hubert Vedrine's term "hyperpower" is apt.
Contrary to what many Europeans think, the problem with American power is not that it is American. The problem is simply the power. It would be dangerous even for an archangel to wield so much power. The writers of the American Constitution wisely determined that no single locus of power, however benign, should predominate; for even the best could be led into temptation. Every power should therefore be checked by at least one other. That also applies in world politics. 
Of course it helps that such power is exercised by leaders under the scrutiny of a developed and self-critical democracy. But even democracy brings its own temptations when it exists in a hyperpower. That temptation is illustrated by the Bush administration's recent imposition of unjustified tariffs on steel imports, threatening the international framework of free trade in order to win votes in steel-producing states.
And when a nation has so much power, what it doesn't do is as fateful as what it does. Thus, the Bush administration came into office determined not to get dragged into close mediation between Israelis and Palestinians, as former President Bill Clinton had been. The horrors of the suicide bombings of Israeli civilians and the siege of the West Bank are at least in part a result of this policy, which might be called partisan disengagement. Critical Europeans generally see the United States as misusing its power by intervening, as in the cases of American actions in Cambodia and Nicaragua. But as often, the problem is that the hyperpower does not intervene -- as we saw in the agony of Bosnia until the United States finally stepped in to stop the bloodshed.
Who, then, should check and complement American power? International agencies, starting with the United Nations, and transnational nongovernmental organizations are a place to start. But they alone are not enough. My answer is Europe -- Europe as an economic equal to the United States and Europe as a close-knit group of states with long diplomatic and military experience. The European Union is already a major force in trade and foreign aid, and it is slowly acquiring more diplomatic coherence. But the gulf between its military capacity and that of the United States grows ever wider.
The complicated double task for us pro-American Europeans is to strengthen Europe's capacity to act outside its own borders while disentangling the idea of a stronger Europe from its sticky anti-American integument. We need to build a Europe that sees itself not as a rival superpower to the United States, but as America's most important partner in a world community of liberal democracies. Americans, in their own enlightened self-interest, should want Europe to succeed. Otherwise they will be left to cope alone with the loneliness of the long-distance hyperpower.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Market Shakes Off I.B.M. Warning; Nasdaq Rises 15.84

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Technology stocks rose yesterday, even as I.B.M. startled the market with its first earnings warning in years.
 I.B.M., the world's largest computer products and services company, said spending cutbacks by corporate customers would cut into its earnings and revenue. The news added to jitters caused by rising oil prices after Iraq said it would withhold oil exports for a month to protest Israel's attacks on the West Bank. 
 But by midsession, the market began to move off its lows as investors digested the I.B.M. news and snapped up downtrodden technology issues. 
"A lot of the technology names like software stocks and semiconductors have already reported, already preannounced or are expected to have decent numbers," said Jon Baranko, director of trading at Strong Capital Management, "so I think people used the weakness of the market as an opportunity."
I.B.M. shares slumped 10 percent, keeping the Dow Jones industrial average in the red. The Dow fell 22.56 points, or 0.22 percent, to 10,249.08.
The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 2.56 points, or 0.23 percent, to close at 1,125.29.
The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index rose 15.84 points, or 0.89 percent, to 1,785.87, after being down early in the session more than 2 percent.
Advancing issues outnumbered those declining on the New York Stock Exchange, 1,836 to 1,331. Volume eased to 1.10 billion shares from 1.12 billion on Friday.
I.B.M. tumbled $9.84, to $87.41, on trading of more than 40 million shares, the most active stock on the Big Board.
"We all knew coming into the first quarter that, especially in technology, the business environment was still weak," said Benjamin Pace, managing director at Deutsche Bank Private Banking, which oversees about $9 billion in investments.
Earnings season moves into high gear next week, and according to Thomson Financial/First Call, corporate profits are expected to fall 9.2 percent from the quarter a year earlier. That is sharper than the 8.8 percent decline forecast on March 28, after a wave of technology companies warned that they would fall short of analysts' estimates.
Among technology stocks yesterday, Electronic Data Systems, the No. 2 supplier of computer services, dropped $1.74, to $51.11. Sun Microsystems, the big networking computer maker, fell 21 cents, to $8.50. But Microsoft recouped declines, closing up $1.35, at $57.22, and Veritas Software rose $1.51, to $36.62.
Oil stocks helped the market move higher as they tracked crude oil prices, which soared at first on the Iraq news and then eased in New York, settling at $26.54 a barrel, up 33 cents. Exxon Mobil, the global oil giant, rose 61 cents, to $43.24, offering support to the Dow industrials. --------------------

Treasury Prices Fall
By Bloomberg News
Treasuries moved lower yesterday after Iraq said it would suspend oil shipments to protest Israeli military action in the Palestinian territories, sending crude oil prices higher and briefly stirring inflation concern.
"We might see some higher inflation," said Tom Donne, who manages about $3 billion in bonds at Banc One Investment Advisers. "Nobody will want the added risk of a longer-dated Treasury in their hands."
Late in the day, the benchmark 10-year Treasury note was down 13/32 , to a price of 97 3/32 . The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.26 percent from 5.20 percent on Friday. The 30-year Treasury bond dropped 20/32 , to 95 9/32 . Its yield rose to 5.71 percent from 5.66 percent.

HEADLINE: So Much for Doctors' Bad Handwriting on Drug Prescriptions 

BYLINE:  By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
An Internet-based system being introduced today will allow doctors to send prescriptions directly to a pharmacy's computer from a hand-held or desk-top computer, wireless telephone or text pager. 
 Using the system, being offered by the Giant supermarket and pharmacy chain and the National Association of Chain Drug Stores, pharmacists can send back information over a two-way network about potentially harmful drug reactions as well as a patient's insurance coverage. 
 Tommy G. Thompson, the health and human services secretary, said that electronic prescriptions, or e-scripts, would help to prevent errors and save time. "Physicians and pharmacists will have more time with patients and more time to focus on health," he said yesterday. 
Giant Food Inc., a unit of Royal Ahold, a supermarket holding company based in the Netherlands, said it was testing the new system at six pharmacies and planned to install it next month in 154 pharmacies. Giant is based in Landover, Md.
The system was developed by physicians at InstantDx, a software company in Gaithersburg, Md. It will be available to 30,000 doctors who use the physicians' office software of the NDCHealth Corporation in New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Delaware, Maryland, Virginia and Washington.
Doctors will pay a monthly subscription fee of about $30 for the services, and pharmacies will pay a transaction fee, said a spokeswoman for the drugstore association, which represents chains with 100,000 stores.
Technology analysts said the new system was the latest foray on a hotly contested health care battleground. "There are billions of dollars in drug sales in play," said Michael J. Barrett, a health care analyst at Forrester Research. The object is to influence doctors' decision at the moment they order a drug for a patient, he said, through advertisements on the Internet ordering system or references to health plan lists of preferred drugs.
Health insurance plans, pharmacy benefit management companies and drug manufacturers are all hoping to gain control of the drug-ordering process, Mr. Barrett said. Companies like NDCHealth and WebMD have a head start, he said, because each has longstanding electronic connections to hundreds of thousands of doctors. 
An estimated 200,000 of the nation's 600,000 doctors write most of the prescriptions, said Craig Fuller, president of the National Association of Chain Drug Stores.
The association's system is intended to preserve the current role of pharmacists in matching patients with drugs covered by their health plans. The stores view the pharmacy management companies as commercial enemies who often try to persuade patients to fill prescriptions by mail, said Crystal Wright, a spokeswoman for the association. 
A similar electronic system being developed by ProxyMed Inc., based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., connects some pharmacies of the Walgreen and Eckerd chains in Southern states to a few hundred doctors. 
RxHub, another project that hopes to link doctors and pharmacies, is sponsored by pharmacy benefit managers, including Merck-Medco, Express Scripts and AdvancePCS.

HEADLINE: Front Row 

BYLINE:  By Ginia Bellafante 

 BODY:
Fashion Designers' Ceremony Shrinks
On June 3, the Council of Fashion Designers of America will present its 40th annual awards ceremony, in miniature. Yesterday afternoon, the names of the nominees were announced. 
 Marc Jacobs is a contender in the top three categories: women's-wear designer of the year, men's wear and accessories. Ralph Lauren was also named in the men's and women's categories. For the title of best men's-wear designer, the two men will be facing off against Sean Combs. 
 The list of nominees for the Perry Ellis award, which confers status on a new young fashion talent, seems to include every young designer who has applied needle to thread this year: Rick Owens, Zac Posen, Behnaz Sarafpour and Peter Som.
Only 450 tickets will be issued this year, in contrast to the usual 2,000. The event, which in recent years has been held at Lincoln Center, will move to the Celeste Bartos Forum at the New York Public Library.
"It's a nod to the mood of the country," Stan Herman, the president of the organization, explained. "Every winner had their PR people, their licensing people, their friends and relatives," Mr. Herman said. "And there were freebies going to some of the big names." 
This year, most guests will be paying, $1,750 a ticket, a $250 increase over last year. Peter Arnold, the group's executive director, said the shaky economy had a lot to do with the downsizing of the ceremony. Also, he said, "a lot of members had stopped coming because they felt the event was no longer about them."
The $1,750 ticket buys a fashion lover a sit-down dinner and the opportunity to mingle with nominees. Left out of the party will be fashion students, who often get to attend at the largesse of big companies, which buy up tables at a discount. Fewer press passes will be issued as well. But, Mr. Arnold said, the contraction "isn't meant to exclude any one group or sector."

A Black Model Advances
For a young model occupying any of the various precincts of fashion obscurity, the imprimatur of Steven Meisel almost always means a glamorous reversal of fortune. A few years ago, Sophie Dahl danced in front of him at a party, and before long she was gracing the covers of Italian Vogue and cuddling waterfowl in advertising campaigns for Banana Republic.
More recently, Mr. Meisel has turned his eye to Valery Prince, an 18-year-old from Dallas whom he shot for the May issue of Vogue. Ms. Prince took her book to Mr. Meisel in February, just after the fall 2002 collections in New York, where she had walked for Bill Blass, among a handful of other designers.
"I went to see if he wanted to work with me in the future," Ms. Prince said the other day, "and he said, 'How would you like to work today?' " By the time the European collections got under way a few weeks later, she was appearing in shows for Gucci, Yves Saint Laurent, Christian Dior and Lanvin, among others, her first foray onto the runways of Milan and Paris.
Significantly, Ms. Prince is African-American. "Since Alek Wek, there's been no one," Andre Leon Talley, the Vogue editor, noted, referring to the dearth of black-skinned models who have appeared since Ms. Wek's arrival six years ago. "Black girls don't have the same opportunities," Mr. Talley said. "They have to work 15 times as hard to get a cover try." As recently as two years ago, he said, he would find himself suggesting black models to designers, who would make excuses, saying that the model would not be appropriate for the mood of a particular collection. "And I'd say, 'All those Belgian girls seem to fit,' " he said. African-Americans, he added, "are an afterthought in fashion." 
Ms. Prince, the daughter of a minister and a homemaker, will appear in the June issue of Vogue in a shoot by Steven Klein. She has signed up for a correspondence course at Spelman College in Atlanta, beginning in fall 2003. "You have more urban magazines now, and you are starting to see more black models," Ms. Prince said. "I just got some good news today: my little sister entered a modeling contest and won."
Mr. Talley predicts that African-American models will now get more work. "With the Halle Berry moment and Valery, the gates are going to be open next season."

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TURMOIL: U.S. JEWS; 
Mideast Violence Rouses a Jewish Population With Deep American Roots

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: COLUMBIA, S.C., April 5 

 BODY:
The Jewish population here may no longer be the largest in the nation, as it was three centuries ago when South Carolina was the most religiously tolerant colony in the New World. But just as Jews have long been politically active here, the heirs of those early settlers are keenly following events in the Middle East, no more afraid than their forebears to raise their voices.
 Many Jews here have expressed disappointment with the Bush administration's demand that Israel end its raids into the West Bank. 
 At the same time, other Jewish leaders, many of whom did not support George W. Bush for president, agree with his peacemaking efforts. American Jews can disagree with Israeli policies just as vigorously as Israelis often do, they say, without undermining their support for Israel. 
"I am an American whose religion is Jewish," said Rick Silver, an advertising executive here and former president of the local Jewish Federation. "But I have no trouble disagreeing with American policy on this or any subject -- that's the American value. And in this case, considering that our country is trying to clear out terrorism from its hellhole in Afghanistan, I don't see why there should be a problem when Israel tries to do the same."
Several local Jewish residents agreed with Dr. Stanley Greenberg, a urologist who is the current federation president, that the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, "is not an easy person to love," and that his agenda may not sit well with generally liberal Jewish sensibilities. 
But uneasiness about Mr. Sharon's policies and worries about his long-term goals do not imply a lessening of Jewish support for Israel in this struggle, he said. "There's no honesty or sincerity in the Palestinian leadership," Dr. Greenberg said. "They haven't really accepted a two-state solution -- they want to insidiously destroy Israel as we know it."
It was in the port cities and merchant towns of South Carolina that American Jews first announced they wanted their adopted country to regard them as Americans, not as a separate and insoluble clan.
"Jews are by no means to be considered as a religious sect, tolerated by the government; they constitute a portion of the people," wrote Isaac Harby, one of the state's leading Jewish citizens and a pioneer of Reform Judaism, to Secretary of State James Monroe in 1816. "Quakers and Catholics, Episcopalians and Presbyterians, Baptists and Jews, all constitute one great political family."
That declaration -- the subject of a popular new exhibit here on the state's Jewish history -- is being heard once again among the leading Jews of South Carolina's capital. Many among this city's 3,000 Jews arise early each morning to read the Israeli and Arab newspaper Web sites, write letters and make calls to political leaders. They consider today's foreign news to be essentially local.
Samuel Tenenbaum, a retired steel executive who has long been active in the national Democratic Party, said he recently wrote President Bush to congratulate him on his foreign policy and to support his fight against terrorism in Israel and elsewhere.
"The terrorism we see now is a war against the Jews, just as World War II was," Mr. Tenenbaum said. "If you look at what Hamas says, they're talking about a struggle against the Jews, not just Israelis. So this becomes an existential argument -- my country needs to protect me and other Jews against a war of genocide."
Jewish leaders here say they are aware that some Americans blame the nation's ties to Israel for the attacks on Sept. 11. But Jewish residents here say they are too well established in the area to fear a significant increase in anti-Semitism in response to current events.
"I think from the relationships that we have established here that we feel genuine affection from our neighbors," said Eleanor Niestat, a volunteer whose family has long been active in the area. "It's gone beyond just tolerance." 
Others said that only a nationwide economic depression had the potential to trigger a surge in anti-Semitism, expressing a confidence -- borne out in public opinion polls -- that most Americans blame the Palestinians for the current violence.
That feeling of ease has not always been present. Alan B. Kahn, a local real estate developer, said that many Columbia Jews did not want to speak up about their religion or become civil rights advocates in the 1960's and '70s, fearing they would become entangled in the strong emotions of the period.
As the exhibit at the McKissick Museum of the University of South Carolina indicates, Jews and other white-skinned immigrants were welcomed to the colony to a unusual degree.
The exhibit, titled "A Portion of the People: 300 Years of Southern Jewish Life," shows that South Carolina was the first colony in the nation to grant voting rights to Jews, and they were welcomed as traders and merchants. The nation's first Jewish elected official was Francis Salvador, a member of the First Provincial Congress of South Carolina, and Jews have since been prominent in the state's political and business life. Some were also slaveowners and staunch Confederates, according to the show.
In a state now better known for an active population of conservative Christians, Jews here continue to worry more about intermarriage and a loss of tradition than about religious discrimination.
Regarding Middle East politics, many say they take comfort in the knowledge that most of their evangelical neighbors are fervent supporters of Israel. That support, many Jewish residents say, was only enhanced here and around the nation by the attacks of Sept. 11, and they say they do not believe it will recede, even if the administration needs Arab support for an attack on Iraq.
Nonetheless, with world opinion at stake, Jews say they will not be vocal in their criticism of Mr. Sharon's moves, even as many wonder whether he has a long-term strategy for peace.
"If all of us see Israel as truly threatened, which I think most of us believe to be true now, then that kind of debate stops," Mr. Tenenbaum said. "Israel's survival is paramount, and as hard as it is, a lot of us will hold our tongues even at things we disagree with."

PERSON: Louis Rukeyser 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
Eulogies? No, the Smart Money's Still on a 'Kid' of 69

BYLINE:  By ROBIN FINN 

DATELINE: GREENWICH, Conn. 

 BODY:
ALL alone, and temporarily unemployed, Louis Rukeyser, the deposed host of "Wall Street Week," the money-as-mantra PBS chat-fest that pioneered its genre in 1970, is rattling around his palatial Georgian colonial waiting for the phone to ring.
 The news could be bad: his wife of 40 years, Alexandra, is an ocean away on the Isle of Man tending to a gravely ill parent. Or the news could be good: any minute his lawyers could call to confirm that a new home has been found for his program. In investing, as in life, Mr. Rukeyser insists, "pessimism is the losing strategy." He's raring to return. 
 "It's just down to a few details, and I'm thinking we could be back on the air by the end of the month," he says, sinking into a wing chair in a formal parlor where some dozen chairs and settees hold needlepoint pillows depicting Cavalier King Charles spaniels, his favorite breed. (He once had six spaniels scampering through the house; now he just has the pillows.) Mr. Rukeyser likens the Maryland Public Television executives who canned him to feline ingrates, calling their tactics "low-grade farce."
On a more pleasant farcical note, he judges the tail-wagging contest at the local dog show. "It requires the judgment of Solomon and the diplomacy of Colin Powell," he says, confident he possesses both, along with a no-nonsense knack for spotting economic trends and sizing up stocks. 
"If you say the word 'economics' to the average person, it's pretty true that their eyelids get heavy, but if you say 'money,' their eyes open up and their nostrils flare. I never regarded money as the focus of life; I have never in my life made a career decision for financial reasons," he says. "I learned the best way to keep money in perspective is to gain a knowledge of how to handle it."
That's why his newsletters are hot sellers, as are his two yearly cruises and his annual investment conference in Las Vegas. He says endless speaking engagements and canny investing (he takes his own advice and has yet to lose his shirt), not public television, bought this mansion on four acres, the pair of Mercedes-Benzes in the garage, the swell vintages in the wine cellar. "It won't be necessary to hold any benefits for me," he says. "Many people have prematurely eulogized me: I'm still a kid, and I've got lots more to do." 
It's his feelings, not his finances or future, that took a beating last month when the brass at Maryland Public Television informed him that their idea of reinventing the show he invented 32 years ago was to remove him as host and insert a team from Fortune magazine when his contract expires in June. When he let his viewers in on the plan on March 22, MPT locked the studio door behind him a tad early. Litigation is in the air. So are sour grapes: Mr. Rukeyser chuckles ruthlessly while noting that his 22 regular panelists snubbed MPT's attempt to enlist their expertise on a Lou-less show.
Still, there are bags beneath his "baby blues," and his posture, in lapsed moments, is stooped inside his fancy Brioni suit -- the Fashion Foundation of America calls Mr. Rukeyser, an off-the-rack Barneys shopper, the best-dressed man in finance. Then there's the antique hairdo. When his hair was darker and longer, male viewers often critiqued it. His reply: "Thank you for trying to approve my appearance, but I do not have my hair cut to please other men."
HE can't decide whether to be indignant or amused that, in the stressed weeks since he broadcast his final program, his craggy 69-year-old face is sprouting blemishes of a sort last glimpsed, and battled, as a teenager. How dare the Maryland executives imply that his demeanor and demographics are over the hill: he's got letters from fans in their 20's and 30's "furious with the notion that they're callow idiots who need MTV to show them how to invest." 
His father, the syndicated columnist Merryle Stanley Rukeyser, was a "boy wonder" of financial journalism, and by 11, with an assignment from The Standard Star in New Rochelle, N.Y., Mr. Rukeyser was following in dad's footsteps. He got his first paycheck at 16, was president of the Princeton Press Club, and joined The Baltimore Sun, as a political and later a foreign correspondent in London and Asia, after graduation in 1954. His starting salary was $55 a week. In 1965 he left The Sun for an overseas assignment at ABC News and in 1968 became that network's first national economic commentator. 
"The smart guys said it was a stupid career move, a dead end," Mr. Rukeyser recalls.
In 1970, he began, with ABC's permission, a 30-week moonlighting stint for PBS as host of "Wall Street Week With Louis Rukeyser." Three years later he left ABC and concentrated on marketing himself. It worked then. He can't imagine it won't work now.
When the show marked its 30th anniversary with a Carnegie Hall gala in November 2000 and PBS executives didn't attend, he celebrated without them. "A reporter said, 'Lou, you've given birth to an entire industry,' " he recalls, eager to charm despite keeping one ear tuned to the upstairs phone, "And I said, 'Heck, I don't even have stretch marks.' "

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: IMMIGRATION; 
I.N.S. Proposes New Limits On the Length Of Visas

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 8 

 BODY:
Under intense pressure to regroup after embarrassing lapses involving the Sept. 11 hijackers, the Immigration and Naturalization Service announced several steps today to gain greater control over tourists and visiting students and businessmen.
 The proposed measures would reduce the amount of time granted to most foreign tourists, to 30 days from six months; limit most business travelers to a maximum of six months; and penalize illegal visitors who ignore the agency's orders to turn themselves in within 30 days. 
 Most changes are subject to public review, but one new rule that takes effect immediately makes it more difficult for business travelers or tourists to switch their visa status by enrolling in American schools. 
The student visa system is rife with abuse, Bush administration officials acknowledge. In a breakdown of procedure, the immigration service last month issued notices of student visas to two dead Sept. 11 hijackers. The two men, Mohammed Atta of Egypt and Marwan al-Shehhi of the United Arab Emirates, entered the country as tourists, then began their training at a Florida flight school as they awaited the issuance of their student visas.
James W. Ziglar, the commissioner of immigration and naturalization, said the new rules struck "the appropriate balance between I.N.S.'s mission to ensure that our nation's immigration laws are followed and stop illegal immigration and our desire to welcome legitimate visitors."
Business groups reviewed the proposed changes tonight. Theresa Brown, a spokeswoman for the United States Chamber of Commerce, expressed the hope that they would not cripple tourism and trade.
"Allowing people to come in for business and tourism is a big chunk of our economy," Ms. Brown said.
If the agency "raises the bar, where it's an impediment, we'll have an issue," she said.
Ms. Brown warned that tighter rules could add to the backlog of the immigration service as visitors seek visa extensions. In most cases, applicants would have a chance to make their cases for longer stays.
Effective immediately, individuals planning to study in the United States will be able to receive student status only if they notify the agency of that prospect before entering the country. The change is intended to give federal authorities time to conduct security checks, officials said.
Other changes in the handling of visas include the following plans:
*An illegal immigrant who has been ordered to surrender as part of the deportation process must do so within 30 days or give up the opportunity to legalize his status for 10 years. Nine of every 10 illegal immigrants facing final deportation orders fail to turn themselves in, the agency said.
*Most tourist visas would be good for 30 days, down from six months.
*Business visitors or tourists may extend their stays for up to six months if they can show "unexpected or compelling humanitarian reason," like medical treatment or an impending business deal.

HEADLINE: The Third Oil Crisis? 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; E-mail: krugman@nytimes.com

 BODY:
In 1973 an Arab embargo sent oil prices soaring, and a global recession followed. In 1979 the Iranian revolution provoked a second surge in oil prices, and another global recession.
 Are we now at risk of a third oil crisis? I wish I could say no, but I can't. 
 Oil prices have risen about $10 per barrel since the situation in the Middle East began deteriorating. So even if they stay where they are, this represents a serious shock to the system -- and there could be more to come. 
True, political analysts assure us that despite Iraq's decision to stop oil exports for a month, no broader, 1973-style oil embargo is likely. Let's hope they're right. But the 1979 oil crisis wasn't the result of a deliberate embargo.
Economists have never reached a consensus about what happened in 1979, but my interpretation is that it was similar to the recent California electricity crisis. In both cases the key was the combination of a tight market and demand that wasn't very responsive to price. Under those circumstances, individual producers -- power companies in California, oil-producing countries in 1979 -- have a lot of market power. That is, it is in each producer's interest to cut back production to drive prices higher. The result is a price surge, even though there is no real capacity shortage. 
Are world oil markets that tight? Not yet -- the world still has about seven million barrels' worth of spare capacity each day. So Iraq, by taking away its two million barrels a day, cannot create a crisis by itself. But the remaining slack in the system is just about equal to the combined production of Iran and Libya, which have also proposed an embargo.
The point is that it would not take much worsening in the political situation to produce markets so tight that the logic of market power kicks in and countries decide that, quite aside from politics, their financial interest lies in reducing, not increasing, their output.
If an oil crisis can happen so easily, why haven't we had one since 1979? The answer is that we made ourselves crisis-proof for a while, then became complacent. After the oil crises of the 1970's, Western economies sharply increased their energy efficiency: the U.S. economy was a third bigger in 1985 than it was in 1973, but it consumed less oil. The result was the marginalization of the danger zone: in 1985, the Persian Gulf produced only 18 percent of the world's oil, less than half of its share in 1973. But rapidly growing oil consumption in the S.U.V. era was met, inevitably, by increased Persian Gulf production. So oil prices are once again hostage to Middle Eastern politics.
If oil prices do surge, will this have the same disastrous effects as the price spike in 1979? No, but it may have different disastrous effects.
In 1979 the clear and present danger from soaring oil prices was that they would send already inflation-prone Western economies into an out-of-control inflationary spiral. To fight that, all the leading economies raised interest rates -- which controlled inflation, but also generated a nasty recession.
Today, after a decade of price stability, fears of inflation are much more muted. Instead, the main concern is the drag of oil prices on purchasing power. Each $10-per-barrel increase in the price of oil is like a $70 billion tax increase, one that falls most heavily on middle- and lower-income families. 
And this is not a good time to slash purchasing power. Business investment, which plunged last year, has still not recovered; optimistic economic forecasts depend on the assumption that buoyant consumer spending will keep the economy afloat until businesses do decide to invest again. If consumers are made poorer by higher oil prices and cut back instead, that assumption goes out the window. And the Fed can't respond with another big round of interest rate cuts: since it has already reduced rates from 6.5 to 1.75 percent, it doesn't have much ammunition left.
So I'm sorry to say that under current conditions, a third oil crisis could indeed happen. It doesn't have to happen: a diplomatic breakthrough could calm oil markets, and even if oil prices rise, the U.S. economy may be more robust than I fear. But it's easier to tell a downbeat, even scary, story than any of us would like.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Tigers Dismiss Garner And Smith

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
The Detroit Tigers, continuing to move in reverse after squandering the economic advantage of a new park, fired their general manager and manager yesterday. Losses in the team's first six games hastened what had appeared to be an inevitable development.
 Randy Smith, the general manager, and Phil Garner, the manager, were most likely in jeopardy as soon as Dave Dombrowski became the Tigers' president and chief executive last November. 
 "We haven't started off well, but it's not the only thing," Dombrowski said by telephone from Detroit. "We've been evaluating the team. I thought if we were going to proceed to the championship level we'd have to make some changes. There's never a good time to do this, but it was just time to make the change." 
Smith, 38, was in his seventh season as the Tigers' general manager. In three of his first six seasons, they had a worse record than the year before. They never had a winning record, and in four seasons they did not reach 70 victories.
Garner, 52, became the Tigers' manager in October 1999, not long after he was dismissed as the Milwaukee Brewers' manager after seven successive losing seasons. 
The Tigers were so eager to hire Garner that they offered him $1.2 million a year for four years. They hired Garner before they informed the outgoing manager, Larry Parrish, that he was being fired, and they hired him without following Commissioner Bud Selig's directive to interview members of minority groups for major vacancies. With his two losing seasons in Detroit, Garner had nine straight losing records. Only Connie Mack, who owned the Philadelphia Athletics and managed them, had that long a losing streak.
According to the Elias Sports Bureau, Garner's dismissal after six games matches the earliest firing during a season. The Orioles fired Cal Ripken Sr. after Baltimore lost its first six games in 1988. If that precedent serves as an omen, though, the Tigers are in for more trouble. Frank Robinson replaced Ripken, and the Orioles ran their losing streak to 21 before gaining their first victory. 
Dombrowski named Luis Pujols, the team's bench coach, as the interim manager.
"He will be one of the people we interview," Dombrowski said, discussing his plans to hire a manager. "We would like to start the interview process as quickly as possible."
Felipe Alou, who was a manager in the Montreal minor league system when Dombrowski worked for the Expos, was one of the first possibilities mentioned, but he does not appear to be on Dombrowski's list of candidates.
Dombrowski said he had the utmost respect for Alou but added, "Whoever we hire I would hope would be our manager for the next 10 years." Alou will be 67 next month.
Michael Ilitch, the Tigers' owner, hired Dombrowski last Nov. 5 to replace John McHale Jr., who had moved to the Tampa Bay Devil Rays last season at Selig's request to clean up a mushrooming mess. Dombrowski, 45, had been president and general manager of the Florida Marlins. He will assume the general manager's duties with the Tigers.
Smith was general manager of the San Diego Padres for three seasons before taking the Tigers' job.
Smith failed to build the Tigers into a competitive, let alone contending, team. They moved into Comerica Park in 2000 and drew 2.5 million fans, their second-highest total. But last season the attendance plunged with the victory total, falling to 1.9 million. 
Many of Smith's trades did not work out. The one he will probably be remembered for most notoriously was the deal that sent Luis Gonzalez to Arizona for Karim Garcia in December 1998. Gonzalez batted .325, hit 57 home runs and drove in 142 runs for the Diamondbacks last year. He also got the hit that beat the Yankees in Game 7 of the World Series.
Garcia played in 20 games for the Cleveland Indians last season.
Smith and Garner are not the first general manager-manager tandem to be fired this year. The new owners of the Boston Red Sox dismissed Dan Duquette and Joe Kerrigan in spring training.

HEADLINE: ON THE ROAD; 
Taming the Unruly Business Fare

BYLINE:  By Joe Sharkey; The On the Road column appears each Tuesday. E-mail: jsharkey@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
LIKE many business travelers these days, I am quite pleased with my resourcefulness. Planning a business trip to San Francisco, I went online the other day, certain that I would find an impressively cheap fare. 
 I clicked onto Orbitz.com. On a typical business trip, one booked on a few days' notice, my round-trip coach fare between Newark and San Francisco would cost about $2,500. But my trip was more than two weeks away, meaning that I could book a cheaper advance-purchase fare. Orbitz quickly yielded 250 separate fares in that category, from $302 to $1,369, most requiring stopovers. But Continental Airlines had a selection of nonstops that fit my itinerary -- all at $309. 
 So I went to Continental's Web site and, bada-bing, as they say in Jersey, I booked that $309 fare -- aware that I would also probably be upgraded to first class to boot because I flew over 25,000 miles with Continental last year.
Total time spent online, researching and booking the trip: 10 minutes.
Such small acts, repeated tens of thousands times a day by business travelers, are striking fear into the heart of the airline industry, which operates on an economic model that depends on business travelers not flying across the country and back for $309. 
That we are now doing so, and frequently, is partly attributable to the wealth of instant, comprehensive price information available on Internet booking sites like Orbitz.com, Expedia.com, Travelocity.com and others, including company-operated intranet portals.
But it's also much attributable to a rebellion that has now become an insurrection among business travelers and the companies that pay their way. Their target: airline fare structures that everyone concedes are intended to squeeze top dollar out of business travelers, while indirectly subsidizing leisure travel.
Right now, corporate travel managers are at the table, negotiating new airline deals with the ferocity of the old coal miners' union. Firmly, the airlines are being told to reform their business-fare structures or else. 
They have two options, according to Kevin P. Mitchell, the chairman of the Business Travel Coalition, a trade group that represents major corporate buyers of air travel.
"There's Plan A, which is a fundamental reform of the existing fare system" in which companies now commit themselves to airline contracts that offer volume discounts on a big range of fares that airlines can raise at will, he said. 
"And then there's Plan B," he added. Plan B is the "or else." Under this option, companies would expand their relatively new relationships with travel-management companies and distributors who manage internal online booking portals. Existing airline contracts would disappear or greatly diminish in scope, and employees would book far more travel through the company portal, with access to a wide range of fares and conditions, including all discount fares. 
It's a tough choice for the airline business, where most executives remember the financial beating the whole industry took in 1992 when American Airlines, responding to corporate demands, tried to simplify business fares and competitors jumped into the fray with a discounting free-for-all that left everyone bruised.
To allay those concerns, under Plan A corporations would enter new "ironclad agreements" with selected airlines to thwart competitive sabotage, Mr. Mitchell said.
He said that airlines needed to accept the fact that the plunge in business-travel revenue, which began more than a year ago, was not just a reversible consequence of a flagging economy. Rather, he said, it is partly a manifestation of a revolutionary shift in the way business travelers fly, especially the trend toward booking more trips well in advance and taking advantage of cheap fares.
Airline executives have begun to acknowledge the revolt over business fares. Airlines fare structures are "confusing, unfair and broken," and corporate customers are "showing signs of fatigue" with airline business-fare pricing by buying cheaper nonrefundable fares, Rono Dutta, the president of United Airlines, conceded to travel managers in late March at a corporate conference sponsored by Business Travel News, a trade publication.
American Express, which monitors average business fares, said that business travelers scooped up cheap nonrefundable fares from among the leisure-fare discounts that flooded the market after Sept. 11. As a result, American Express said, the average business fare paid in the fourth quarter of 2001 was 6 percent lower than the average in the comparable period of 2000, even though the average posted business fare itself was 1 percent higher. 
"The current system is unworkable," said Peter Buchheit, the director of travel and meeting services for the Black & Decker Corporation. 
Mr. Buchheit said that he had been amazed at the growth in employee use of nonrefundable fares, many purchased on the company's internal Web booking portal, managed by GetThere Inc. In 2000, when the trend acquired traction, cheaper nonrefundable fares accounted for 65 percent of all air tickets, he said. Last year, it was 77 percent. "And so far this year, it's 82 percent," he added.
Mr. Buchheit said he envisioned a system in which some airline flat-fare contracts would remain in place, greatly augmented by a company-managed online booking portal that would enable employees with flexible itinerary demands to choose from among a far greater range of fares and conditions than currently available.
Already, because of those capabilities, he said, "there is no more leisure fare versus business fare -- there's just a fare."
He added: "It's not like we want to squeeze every last penny out of the airlines. We want them to make a reasonable profit. We need a viable airline system. But we don't want to continue subsidizing leisure fares, which we've been doing for years."

HEADLINE: The Big City; 
Try Giving Legislators A New Job

BYLINE:  By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
A NEW YORK mayor wants control of the schools; a few state legislators don't want to give it to him. This is a familiar scenario, and until now it has ended badly for the mayors and the city. When you have a seat for life, as state legislators typically do, you don't need to compromise with a mayor no matter how much bipartisan support he has within the city.
 But maybe this time Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg could improve his chances with a tactic suggested by one of his predecessors, Edward I. Koch. Mr. Koch's idea is simply to get rid of the legislators, or at least threaten them with the prospect of unemployment. 
 "I think you could scare the hell out of them," Mr. Koch said. "The mayor could create a committee of prominent Democrats, Republicans, conservatives, liberals and independents. If a legislator refused to support legislation giving the mayor control of the schools, the committee would promise to support an opponent to that legislator in the next election. I'd be glad to be on the committee."
Children may not benefit when authority for schools is diffused among members of the central school board and community boards, but legislators appreciate the system because it provides them with patronage opportunities and maintains the power of the teachers' union. Aside from dying or being indicted, displeasing the teachers' union is considered about the only way for a legislator in Albany to be unseated. 
Other cities have been trying to make schools more accountable by putting the mayor in charge, as in Chicago, or giving parents vouchers, as in Milwaukee and Cleveland. In New York, though, such ideas have long been dismissed as the fantasies of political naifs. When New York journalists write about a successful reform in other cities, they ritualistically include a paragraph explaining why it could never happen here. 
The explanation usually involves two Democrats from Manhattan: Sheldon Silver, the speaker of the Assembly, and Steven Sanders, the chairman of the Assembly Education Committee. Mr. Sanders reiterated his determination yesterday to retain some form of the Board of Education, which Mr. Bloomberg would like to abolish so that he could run the schools directly, the way the Police Department is run. 
"What the mayor has proposed would eliminate public debate over education," Mr. Sanders said. "We need to have a Board of Education. We shouldn't allow two or three people in City Hall to make decisions without any public debate."
But even if a mayor ran the schools without an advisory board, he would face plenty of public debate, just as he already faces public debate over the performance of the police. Members of City Council would hardly be silent, and voters would make the mayor's handling of schools one of the major issues in any election. 
AS it is, the one place where education policy is made behind closed doors by two or three people is the State Capitol, where nothing even gets to the floor of the Senate or the House without the approval of the leaders. The fate of New York schools is determined by a few men who don't suffer any obvious consequences for their decisions.
Mr. Silver and Mr. Sanders don't suffer personal consequences, since they have no children in the city's public schools. (Mr. Silver chose private schools for his children; Mr. Sanders has no children.) Nor do they suffer political consequences at election time, since Democratic legislators in New York City can expect at most token opposition. Even a wildly unpopular move with city voters doesn't seem to matter, as Mr. Silver demonstrated by being re-elected even after siding with suburbanites against his own constituents in voting to eliminate the commuter tax.
As mayor, Mr. Koch tried to change this calculus when legislators were about to order an increase in pension benefits for city employees, thereby scoring political points for themselves with the city's money. Mr. Koch threatened to make the legislators accountable for the budget deficit they were creating. 
"I threatened to issue public bulletins at election time listing all the city workers and programs in each legislator's district that had to be cut because of the legislator's vote on the pension bill," Mr. Koch recalled. "I wasn't able to stop the pension increase, but they did agree to reduce it by $70 million if I'd shut up. Just the threat of a problem at election was enough to worry them. The most important thing in any legislator's mind is being re-elected. Nothing else comes even close."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: AID FOR BUSINESS; 
Citing Construction Slump, Bush Pushes Bill to Protect Insurers From Terrorism Losses

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON with JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 8 

 BODY:
Attributing a sharp decline in the nation's construction projects to a lack of insurance, President Bush tried today to revive stalled legislation that would protect insurers from losses from terrorist attacks.
 In remarks to a group of business executives and labor leaders, Mr. Bush urged Congress to adopt a measure to counter the insurance problem caused by last September's terrorist attacks. He said the problem was contributing to unemployment and limiting economic growth. 
 "The pace of new construction is dropping dramatically in America," the president said, surrounded by 10 workers in hard hats and speaking before a group that included James P. Hoffa, president of the Teamsters, and Edward C. Sullivan, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s Building and Construction Trades Department.
"Banks and investors and others," he said, "will not finance construction projects that do not have terrorism insurance. In order to build a project, in order to employ people, you've got to borrow money, and you can't borrow money unless there's adequate terrorism insurance. And that's not being provided today."
The effort by the White House to revive the legislation by using the political influence of organized labor, a traditional ally of Democrats, appeared to be aimed at countering another Democratic ally, the trial lawyers. They have joined consumer groups in criticizing the administration's proposal as making it harder for victims of attacks to file lawsuits against insurers and businesses.
The administration has endorsed a measure that passed the House in a vote largely along party lines last November that would provide as much as $100 billion in government loans to the insurance industry to cover future attacks. The measure has slowed in the Senate because of provisions, included at the administration's request, that would sharply restrict the ability of victims of future attacks to collect damages from insurers and other business.
The proposed revisions to the nation's tort law system have provoked widespread criticism from Democrats, who have said the administration has tried to use the terrorism insurance measure to impose broad restrictions on victims and protect big businesses from lawsuits. Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary, suggested that the administration was not interested in yielding on the issue, telling reporters that "you cannot have terrorism insurance passed without legal reform."
There is no consensus that the lack of terrorism insurance is having as wide an effect as the administration has said. The Consumer Federation of America and some executives in banking, real estate and insurance said terrorism insurance was becoming increasingly available at increasingly lower prices.
They said they believed the biggest push for government aid to the insurers was from a few of the biggest banks, insurers and property owners that wield enormous political influence.
"For the vast majority of real estate deals, terrorism insurance hasn't been the huge issue that most people thought it would be," said John B. Levy, the president of John B. Levy & Company, a real estate investment banking firm in Richmond, Va., that does business around the country.
"In most cases, terrorism insurance is not only available," Mr. Levy said, "but it is available at a price that doesn't knock anybody out of the box."
Insurance brokers say the number of insurers offering terrorism coverage has jumped from zero immediately after the September attacks to more than a dozen. Allianz A.G. and Zurich Financial Services recently announced a joint venture to provide terrorism coverage in the United States and elsewhere.
Early this year, insurance companies were demanding premiums for terrorism coverage 10 to 20 times as high as standard commercial property insurance. But Gary Mathieson, a senior executive at Willis Group Holdings, a big insurance broker, said most clients could get terrorism coverage now for about 20 percent of their overall insurance costs.
For most businesses, those with revenues of $500 million or less, terrorism coverage is not an issue at all, Mr. Mathieson said. After weighing the risks, he said, most insurers have begun including terrorism coverage for those businesses along with property coverage, as they did before the September attacks. The insurers lost an estimated $50 billion in the attacks and that has driven up prices for all coverages, he said.
The businesses having to pay the highest prices for terrorism coverage and having to negotiate the hardest to get the coverage are those with the biggest, most prominent buildings in the cities like New York, Chicago and Los Angeles. But even the cost for those so-called trophy buildings is rarely more than one or two times the premium for general coverage, Mr. Mathieson said.
Mr. Bush said nothing today about the debate over liability issues other than to repeat his often used comment ridiculing lawyers and terrorists.
"They must have miscalculated," he said, speaking of the hijackers. "They hit us and thought we were so weak that all we would do is probably file a lawsuit."
White House officials and other participants at today's meeting described many problems in obtaining financing for new construction projects. The president noted, for instance, that the Hyatt Corporation had been unable to get money to begin work on a 1.5 million-square-foot office building in Chicago because of inadequate terrorism insurance. A $2 billion resort in Nevada had similar problems, he said.
J. Willard Marriott Jr., the chairman and chief executive of Marriott International, said the company was having trouble finding money for $6 billion in construction of new hotels that would provide more than 35,000 rooms. For existing buildings, Mr. Marriott said, the company is facing premium increases of as much as 300 percent.
But in most cases, insurance brokers said, coverage has been available, but executives have been unwilling to pay the price. Now, Mr. Mathieson said, "every day it is getting more affordable."
