HEADLINE: Mideast and Venezuela Turmoil Sends Oil Prices Into Wild Swing 

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

 BODY:
Oil prices, already up 40 percent this year, swung wildly yesterday, with political turmoil from the Middle East to Venezuela threatening to crimp energy supplies just as seasonal demand in the United States is starting to rise.
 Prices jumped almost 4 percent on the New York Mercantile Exchange after the Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein, said in a television address that he would halt his country's oil exports for 30 days to protest Israel's military action on the West Bank. Page A12. 
 Energy markets also were responding to events in Venezuela, a major supplier of oil to the United States, where a simmering labor protest at the state oil company seemed poised to spread, with a nationwide general strike called for today. Page A3. 
By late yesterday afternoon in New York, crude oil prices fell back to settle at $26.54, up 33 cents, after Ali Rodriguez, the secretary general of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, reassured the markets that there were sufficient worldwide production and supplies of oil to soften any losses from Iraq's temporary embargo. The Venezuelan government denied reports that its refineries had drastically reduced output.
But many industry experts said yesterday that disruptions had occurred, and warned that if they were prolonged -- and if oil prices continued to rise as a result -- the economic recovery in the United States could be hobbled. 
The nation is approaching the warm-weather driving season, when gasoline consumption jumps, and the increase could be particularly sharp this year as a result of the growing numbers of gasoline-hungry light trucks and sport utility vehicles, the sales of which surpassed those of automobiles for the first time last year.
"This summer, you will see the impact of Detroit's zero percent finance rate," said Philip K. Verleger Jr., an independent oil analyst based in Newport Beach, Calif., alluding to the automobile industry financing programs that increased the sales of sport utilities and other vehicles last fall. "All these S.U.V.'s will be on the road and demand will be up."
At a news conference yesterday, the Energy Department painted a more optimistic picture, projecting that average gasoline prices this summer would be $1.46 a gallon nationwide, or about 8 cents less than last summer, despite a 20 percent increase in prices over the last month. But the estimate relies in part on the assumption that the Iraqi embargo will not spread to other countries and that other OPEC members will make up the difference. 
The Saudis and other members of OPEC have said that they will not impose oil embargoes in the hope of swaying Washington's policy in the Middle East. But the leaders of Muslim countries that represent 80 percent of OPEC's production face growing pressure from their people to stand up to the United States over policies that that many Muslims regard as too sympathetic to Israel while ignoring the concerns of the Palestinians.
"This puts Arab members of OPEC in an extremely difficult position," said Yasser Elguindi, managing director at Medley Global Advisors, a New York consulting firm. "On the one hand, they have to be extremely subtle in getting the message out that they want to stabilize oil markets, but they don't want to seem as if they are at the beck and call of the U.S. This will be very hard, given how their local populations feel."
Over the last 16 months, Iraq has twice suspended oil exports for various political purposes, and Saudi Arabia, among the few countries with extra production capacity to bring on line, has stepped up its production to compensate. 
Even with those interruptions -- and despite the bitter differences between Baghdad and Washington going back to the Persian Gulf war of 1990-91 -- Iraq last year was the sixth-largest oil supplier to the United States, according to the Energy Information Administration, the analytical arm of the Energy Department. 
Iraq exports its oil under the United Nations' oil-for-food program, with the proceeds going into an escrow account overseen by the United Nations to buy essential goods for the Iraqi people. But oil industry experts said that rampant oil smuggling outside the United Nations-approved system had padded Iraq's treasury. 
The proceeds, and the escrow account, experts said, give Mr. Hussein leeway to use an embargo to burnish his popularity in the Arab world and tweak his regional rivals.
"He has everything to gain politically and nothing to lose," said Lawrence J. Goldstein, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation. "He's been trying for the last several years to be seen as the leader sensitive to global Arab politics, and this puts additional pressure on the Saudis. The message may not be to the oil markets, but to the Arab people."
Mr. Hussein said that he would re-evaluate his embargo in 30 days. It will take at least that long for refiners and consumers to feel the pain, if any, from the embargo, given that oil travels from the Persian Gulf to American gas stations over four to six weeks. 
But the impact of political turmoil in Venezuela, the third-largest exporter of crude oil and petroleum products to the United States, could be felt in eight days or so, said Charles T. Maxwell, senior oil analyst for the brokerage house of Weeden & Company. 
Over the last five weeks or so, employees of the state-run oil company, Petroleos de Venezuela, have orchestrated a successful work slow-down to protest moves by President Hugo Chavez to exert greater control over the company and to divert more of its profit to the national treasury. 
The largest Venezuelan refinery is operating at 50 percent of its capacity, and others have shut down, according to workers' groups and independent experts. But the Venezuelan government denied yesterday that such disruptions had occurred. 
The strikes seem poised to spread far beyond the oil industry. People with long involvement in Venezuelan affairs said that a broad range of the nation's citizens -- from business people to laborers to clerics -- had banded together against what they regard as Mr. Chavez's autocratic rule.
The president has pledged to quash the one-day nationwide work stoppage called for today by the opposition, and many analysts fear an intensification of the social conflict.
"This has brought together large swaths of society, and they see it as an opportunity to get rid of Chavez," said Moises Naim, a former Venezuelan trade minister who is now editor of Foreign Policy magazine in Washington. "But Chavez won't go quietly. If the strike is successful or it lasts for more than a day, you can expect troubles."

HEADLINE: Pulitzers Focus on Sept. 11, and The Times Wins 7 

BYLINE:  By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
The New York Times won a record seven Pulitzer Prizes yesterday, including six for its news coverage of the terrorist attack of Sept. 11, its victims, its causes and its aftermath, all transformative events in the modern history of the United States. The attacks and the war on terrorism were the focus of 8 of the 14 Pulitzer Prizes awarded for journalism.
 The staff of The Wall Street Journal, which on Sept. 11 was forced to abandon its building across the street from 2 World Trade Center, pick its way through the carnage and gather in small groups around Manhattan and New Jersey, was awarded the prize for breaking news reporting. 
 One of two prizes awarded to The Washington Post yesterday was for its staff's national coverage of the war on terrorism.
The Times's Pulitzers included the public service award for the section A Nation Challenged, which was anchored each day with a full page headed Portraits of Grief, consisting of biographical sketches of those who died at the World Trade Center. The coverage on The Times's Web site was also mentioned in the citation by the Pulitzer board at Columbia University, which administers the prizes. 
The Washington Post and The Los Angeles Times won two prizes apiece. Newsday won the award for criticism for the work of its classical music critic, Justin Davidson.
In the 86 years that the prizes have been awarded, no newspaper has previously won more than three in a single year. 
"We are witness to an extraordinary moment in the history of this newspaper, just an extraordinary moment," said Arthur Sulzberger Jr., the publisher of The Times, addressing hundreds of reporters and editors gathered in the newspaper's newsroom off Times Square. "But it is built on the back of a real tragedy."
He then called for a moment of silence in memory of the nearly 3,000 people killed during the attacks and their aftermath and of Daniel Pearl, the Wall Street Journal reporter who was killed in Pakistan.
Among the seven awards given in the arts category, David McCullough won for biography for a work that burnished the image of the nation's often-criticized second president, John Adams. 
Diane McWhorter received the award in the nonfiction category for her intricately woven portrait of the best and worst of Birmingham's citizens in "Carry Me Home: Birmingham, Alabama, the Climactic Battle of the Civil Rights Revolution."
Six of the eight awards for coverage of terrorism and its consequences were given not to individuals, but to the staff of the newspapers involved -- The Times, The Post and The Journal.
Among the individual awards, Thomas Friedman, the Times columnist, was awarded the Pulitzer Prize for commentary, his third award. Barry Bearak of The Times was awarded a prize for international reporting, "for his deeply affecting and illuminating coverage of daily life in war-torn Afghanistan."
The staff of The Times was awarded the prize in explanatory reporting "for its informed and detailed reporting, before and after the Sept. 11 attacks on America, that profiled the global terrorism network and the threats it posed."
In a rare double award for photography, The Times received prizes in both the breaking news and the feature categories -- breaking news for a portfolio of work by 14 photographers who covered the events of Sept. 11, and feature for 5 photographers' work in Pakistan and Afghanistan.
Of the six journalism prizes awarded for work unrelated to the Sept. 11 attacks, The Los Angeles Times won two, one for Barry Siegel's "haunting and humane" portrait of a Utah man tried for neglect in the death of his son, and one for editorials written by Alex Raksin and Bob Sipchen about the dilemmas presented by mentally ill homeless people. 
Another, for beat reporting, went to Gretchen Morgenson of The Times "for her trenchant and incisive Wall Street coverage," which focused in part on the business conflicts of financial analysts and the firms that employ them, which receive investment banking fees from the companies the analysts cover.
The Washington Post's second prize was for investigative reporting by the reporters Sari Horowitz, Scott Higham and Sarah Cohen on the District of Columbia's "role in the neglect and death of 229 children placed in protective care between 1993 and 2000."
Clay Bennett of The Christian Science Monitor won for his editorial cartoons.
In the arts category, the fiction prize was awarded to Richard Russo for his novel "Empire Falls," (Alfred A. Knopf) about working-class life and aspirations in a small Maine mill town. 
The award for history was won by "The Metaphysical Club: A Story of Ideas in America" by Louis Menand, an examination of the turn-of-the-century pragmatist thinkers Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr., William James, Charles Sanders Pierce and John Dewey. It was published by Farrar, Straus and Giroux.
"Practical Gods," by Carl Dennis, a professor at the State University of New York at Buffalo, won the award for poetry. 
The prize for drama went to "Topdog/Underdog" by Suzan-Lori Parks, which examines the relationship between two brothers. Ms. Parks is the first African-American woman to win a Pulitzer Prize for drama.
The composer Henry Brant won the award for music for his work "Ice Field,"' which opened on Dec. 12, 2001, at Davies Symphony Hall in San Francisco.
Seymour Topping, the administrator of the prizes, said yesterday that the 18-member Pulitzer board "did not set out to dedicate itself to marking the coverage of a single event. It followed its usual practice. It went down category by category looking at the quality of the entry, regardless of the subject."
He agreed, however, that the dominance of a single set of events was "highly unusual."
The breadth of the losses of Sept. 11 lent a somber undercurrent to the celebrations in the newsrooms of The Times, The Journal and The Post -- the newsrooms closest to the attacks themselves. 
Howell Raines, the executive editor of The Times, said to the hundreds of journalists clustered in the third-floor newsroom, "We are ever mindful of the shattering events it was our task to record in our city, nation and world community." 
But, he added, "We have a right to celebrate these days of legend at The New York Times." A minute earlier, Mr. Raines predicted that The Times's reporting in the wake of the attacks "will be studied and taught as long as journalism is studied and practiced."
And in both The Times's newsroom in Midtown Manhattan and at The Journal's temporary newsroom in South Brunswick, N.J., editors celebrating their awards said that the entire newsroom shared them.
Leonard Downie Jr., the executive editor of The Washington Post, said of his newspaper's national reporting award, "This was reporting that brought out information that without the reporting might never have been brought out." He added, "It was wonderful to have Bob Woodward come in Sept. 11 and stay with us and drive that reporting." Mr. Woodward, an assistant managing editor, brought The Post a Pulitzer for its Watergate coverage along with Carl Bernstein.
Mr. Downie added, "What I liked about the Pulitzers as a whole was they really rewarded public service this year. It was public service performed by large newspapers in two cities where attacks occurred. It wasn't individual glory, it was teamwork."
Regional newspapers and smaller-circulation dailies were almost absent from the list of winners in journalism, as five of the six newspapers which won were among the country's 10 leading newspapers in daily circulation.
Mr. Topping said that the board moved one candidate, The Post's series on foster children, from the public service category into the investigative reporting category, meaning that none of the three finalists originally selected by the Pulitzer jury in that group won any award. 
That category had been the focus of a recent controversy as The Wall Street Journal published three attacks on The Seattle Times's entrant -- an examination of cancer trials at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle. 
But, Mr. Topping said, the Seattle series "did not lose out because of the criticism leveled extraneously in the public forum."
Mr. Topping also said he will step down as administrator of the prizes in June, to focus his energies on writing novels.

FICTION
RICHARD RUSSO
"Empire Falls"

In this panoramic novel, a former mill town in Maine becomes the embodiment of the dreams and disappointments of its citizens and of the country itself. As in the author's other fiction about life among the working class, the protagonist is a classic underachiever who is also a figure of some nobility.
Mr. Russo is 52 and a resident of Camden, Me. This is his fifth novel. A new book of short stories, "The Whore's Child," is scheduled to be published this July. 
FINALISTS "The Corrections" by Jonathan Franzen; "John Henry Days" by Colson Whitehead.

GENERAL NONFICTION
DIANE McWHORTER
"Carry Me Home: Birmingham, Alabama, the Climactic Battle of the Civil Rights Revolution"

Ms. McWhorter's book is an exhaustive, meticulously detailed account of the struggle between integration and segregation in Birmingham, Ala., her native city and the scene of one of the worst racist atrocities in American history, the murder of four black girls in a 1963 church bombing carried out by white supremacists.
With that event as her centerpiece, Ms. McWhorter writes a history of segregation in Birmingham and the way it was maintained by an intricate alliance of judges, the police, the Ku Klux Klan and the surrounding complacency of white society. 
FINALISTS "War in a Time of Peace: Bush, Clinton and the Generals," by David Halberstam; and "The Noonday Demon: An Atlas of Depression," by Andrew Solomon.

DRAMA
SUZAN-LORI PARKS
"Topdog/Underdog"

Ms. Parks, 38, became the first African-American woman to win the Pulitzer Prize for drama. "I wish I were the 101st," she said. "You open the door but it's everybody's responsibility to walk through."
Ms. Parks's comic drama, which opened on Broadway on Sunday, explores the tense yet loving relationship between two brothers. Ms. Parks, who lives in Brooklyn and Los Angeles, said waking up to rave reviews and winning the Pulitzer Prize on the same day had left her fairly airborne. "That's why I do yoga," she said, "to handle things like this. So I can keep breathing." 
FINALISTS "The Glory of Living" by Rebecca Gilman; "Yellowman" by Dael Orlandersmith.

POETRY
CARL DENNIS
"Practical Gods"

In his poetry, Mr. Dennis, 62, a professor at the State University of New York at Buffalo, finds the deities everywhere. There is Hermes, for instance, sitting under the stars, sniffing the fragrance of wine and barley blowing on the sea breeze from his temple, who, if you are lucky, might "want, when you die, to offer his services/ As a guide on the shadowy path to the underworld." Mr. Dennis is known for his plain-spoken, deceptively simple work, which has been called by The New York Times "wise, original, and often deeply moving." FINALISTS "The Seven Ages" by Louise Gluck; "The Beforelife" by Franz Wright.

BIOGRAPHY
DAVID McCULLOUGH
"John Adams"

Mr. McCullough won his second Pulitzer Prize for a biography that tells of both the former president's devotion to his wife, Abigail, and his extraordinary diplomatic skill.
Mr. McCullough's first Pulitzer was for "Truman" in 1993. 
"It couldn't have happened on a more appropriate day," Mr. McCullough told The Associated Press as he noted that he received the award on his wife's birthday. 
FINALISTS "An Hour Before Daylight: Memories of a Rural Boyhood" by Jimmy Carter, the former president; "Grant" by Jean Edward Smith.

HISTORY
LOUIS MENAND
"The Metaphysical Club: A Story of Ideas in America"

In 1872, a group of young intellectuals in Cambridge, Mass., formed a conversation society, which in the words of one member was "half-ironically, half-defiantly" called the Metaphysical Club. The club lasted only a few months but its legacy was to create the foundation for pragmatism, the prevailing American philosophy of the early 20th century.
The lives and work of four large personalities -- William James, Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr., Charles Sanders Pierce and their intellectual heir John Dewey -- are at the center of this book by Mr. Menand, a staff writer at The New Yorker magazine, professor of English at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York and a Manhattan resident. But Mr. Menand fans out broadly across the American intellectual landscape, delivering a history of ideas written, as one critic said, with "rare common sense and graceful witty prose." 
FINALISTS "Deep Souths: Delta, Piedmont, and the Sea Island Society in the Age of Segregation" by J. William Harris; "Facing East From Indian Country: A Native History of Early America" by Daniel K. Richter.

MUSIC
HENRY BRANT
"Ice Field"

Mr. Brant is a pioneer of 20th-century spatial music, in which the planned positioning of the performers throughout the hall, as well as on stage, is a basic factor in the composition. Mr. Brant's main works since 1950 have all been spatial compositions.
The San Francisco Symphony played the premiere of "Ice Field" at Davies Symphony Hall in San Francisco on Dec. 12, 2001. 

FINALISTS Peter Lieberson, "Rilke Songs"; David Rakowski, "Ten of a Kind" (Symphony No. 2).

PUBLIC SERVICE
THE NEW YORK TIMES

The New York Times was honored for "A Nation Challenged," a daily special section that reported on the aftermath of Sept. 11, the war in Afghanistan and America's campaign against terrorism. It included "Portraits of Grief," the biographical sketches of the lives of 1,800 of nearly 3,000 people killed in the attacks. The Pulitzer board said the section "coherently and comprehensively covered the tragic events, profiled the victims and tracked the developing story, locally and globally."
FINALISTS The Washington Post for a series exposing the District of Columbia's role in the deaths of 229 children placed in protective care between 1993 and 2000; The Washington Post, coverage of Sept. 11 and its aftermath.

INVESTIGATIVE REPORTING
SARI HORWITZ, SCOTT HIGHAM AND SARAH COHEN
The Washington Post

The Post was honored for its four-part series, "The District's Lost Children." The articles, which took a year to prepare, exposed the District of Columbia's role in the neglect and death of 229 children placed in protective care between 1993 and 2000. The award "is a tribute to the children who lost their lives," said Mr. Higham, who added that "we hope that this prize will put more attention on the issue of abused and neglected children in the future."
FINALISTS The Washington Post, two series that documented systematic abuses in the Prince George's County Police Department; The Seattle Times, an investigation of a local cancer research center; The Dayton Daily News, for its focus on the recruiting of foreign athletes for American schools.

NATIONAL REPORTING
THE WASHINGTON POST

A series of articles relating to the terrorism investigation -- six of them carrying the familiar byline of Bob Woodward -- earned the Washington Post staff recognition for national reporting. The paper was cited for coverage that "regularly brought forth new information together with skilled analysis of unfolding developments."
One article described how Osama bin Laden slipped through the Clinton administration's fingers after the government of Sudan offered to arrest him. Another corrected initial misimpressions of the hijackers as pilots who had blended into the suburban landscape. 
FINALISTS Douglas M. Birch and Gary Cohn of The Baltimore Sun for a series on medical research, and Gregory L. Vistica for a New York Times Magazine story on United States Senator Bob Kerrey's role in a Vietnam War massacre.

INTERNATIONAL REPORTING
BARRY BEARAK
The New York Times

As co-bureau chief in New Delhi, Mr. Bearak traveled extensively in Afghanistan during and after the reign of the Taliban, producing what the Pulitzer committee described as "deeply affecting and illuminating coverage" of ordinary people struggling to endure famine, extremism and war.
"Afghanistan is the world's most beautiful and the world's saddest place, and I only hope some good will come to the people after all these years of intense suffering," Mr. Bearak said. 
FINALISTS Dexter Filkins of The New York Times and The Washington Post staff, all for reporting on Afghanistan.

FEATURE WRITING
BARRY SIEGEL
The Los Angeles Times

Mr. Siegel, 52, won in the feature writing category for his account of a man's trial on negligence charges in the accidental death of his 2-year-old son. Mr. Siegel told the story mainly through the eyes of Judge Robert Hilder, who struggled with the decision to convict the father and then anguished further after the convicted man took his own life.
Judge Hilder had not spoken to other reporters but spent hours discussing his feelings about the case with Mr. Siegel. Mr. Siegel said his reporting often focuses on people struggling with moral and ethical issues, and he writes fictional courtroom dramas on the side. 
FINALISTS Ellen Barry, The Boston Globe, for a portrait of teenage Sudanese boys resettling in the United States; David Maraniss, The Washington Post, a reconstruction of the events of Sept. 11.

BEAT REPORTING
GRETCHEN MORGENSON
The New York Times

Ms. Morgenson, a stockbroker turned journalist, exposed the hidden conflicts of interest that abound among stock analysts. Her articles illuminated a culture in which analysts spent less time on research and more time promoting stocks of companies that did business with their firms. Last year, she was the only reporter to also look at stockbrokers who advised the employees of companies like Microsoft and Worldcom to make risky bets on stock options.
"Individual investors were driven like sheep to the slaughter by analysts looking to line their own pockets," she said.
Ms. Morgenson, 46, joined The Times in 1998 and has been a business reporter for more than 18 years.
FINALISTS Patrick Healy of The Boston Globe, for a series exposing rampant grade inflation at Harvard University; Jack Kelley of USA Today, for coverage of the attack on the World Trade Center.

EXPLANATORY REPORTING
THE NEW YORK TIMES

In the three-part series "Holy Warriors," The Times wrote of a Saudi millionaire whose camps in Afghanistan were molding thousands of militant Muslims into an international network of terrorists waiting only for their orders to strike.
The series was published in January 2001. "Eight months later," the newspaper's editors wrote to the Pulitzer jury, "it all turned horribly real." Their work was cited by the Pulitzer judges as part of the newspaper's "informed and detailed reporting, before and after the Sept. 11 attacks on America, that profiled the global terrorism network and the threats it posed."
FINALISTS -- David Finkel of The Washington Post "for his illuminating series of articles on the lives and journeys of international migrants," and The New York Times staff "for its sustained explanatory reporting on the nature of the structural damage at ground zero."

BREAKING NEWS
THE WALL STREET JOURNAL

The Wall Street Journal won its award for an event that happened right outside its windows. Cater-corner across a multi-lane highway from the World Trade Center, the offices of The Journal were rendered unusable, without power and with most windows blown out by the attack. But within minutes of the time when the first plane hit the trade center, a team of editors was sent to the Journal's backup facilities near Princeton, N.J.
From there, in contact with a group of senior editors huddled in an apartment in Manhattan and fielding e-mail transmissions from reporters around the city and the world, The Journal produced a two-section, 32-page paper, "executed under the most difficult circumstances," according to the Pulitzer committee, which made it to 88 percent of subscribers. The day's articles not only documented the attacks but also accurately analyzed their potential effect on the economy. 
FINALISTS -- The Daily News, New York, coverage of the attack Sept. 11; The New York Times, coverage of the attack Sept. 11.

CRITICISM
JUSTIN DAVIDSON
Newsday

While he won the Pulitzer for criticism, Mr. Davidson, who is Newsday's culture writer at large as well as its classical music critic, is a journalist with eclectic interests. His recent work includes a review of a book of essays on food and a two-part series on guns in America. The Pulitzer committee that singled out his work for the prize described it as "crisp coverage of classical music," which Mr. Davidson attributes to the tight restrictions on space that most journalists work with in an era when articles are shrinking. "It's a challenge, but it's also a discipline," he said. "I don't sacrifice a word because they all count." Mr. Davidson, who is 35, was nominated as a finalist in this category in 1999.
FINALISTS -- John King of The San Francisco Chronicle for his essays on the impact architecture and urban design have on the Bay Area; Joseph Morgenstern of The Wall Street Journal for film criticism.

COMMENTARY
THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN
The New York Times

Mr. Friedman, 48, foreign affairs columnist for The Times, won his third Pulitzer Prize, for his columns examining the worldwide impact of the terrorist threat. The Pulitzer board cited his "clarity of vision, based on extensive reporting."
"This is the biggest story of my life, and the thing that motivated me most was I just really wanted to get it right," Mr. Friedman said. "Get it right not only in terms of who they are but in terms of who we are." 
He shared the Pulitzer for international reporting in 1983 for his work in Lebanon and won again in 1988 for his coverage of Israel. 
FINALISTS -- Michael Daly, The Daily News, New York; and Nat Hentoff, The Village Voice.

EDITORIAL WRITING
ALEX RAKSIN AND BOB SIPCHEN
The Los Angeles Times

Mr. Raksin, 41, an editorial writer with The Los Angeles Times, and Mr. Sipchen, 48, the associate editor of the paper's editorial pages, were cited "for their comprehensive and powerfully written editorials exploring the issues and dilemmas provoked by mentally ill people dwelling on the streets." In 14 editorials, the two wrote that the decison to let hundreds of thousands of people out of mental hospitals had left 50,000 mentally ill people homeless in California. The two editorial writers described the sorry existences of several of these people and urged lawmakers to give the government more power to compel some of them to receive treatment, for their own good as well as the public's.
"Life on the streets is anything but humane," they wrote. 'It's time that we all squarely face the fact that some people who cannot act in their own best interests must be nudged off the streets and into treatment even when they don't think they need it." 
FINALISTS -- William H. Freivogel of The St. Louis Post-Dispatch for editorials opposing the nomination and policies of Attorney General John D. Ashcroft; The Philadelphia Daily News editorial board for a series on behalf of Philadelphia's neglected parks.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TURMOIL: OIL; 
Iraq Halts Petroleum Exports To Put Pressure on Americans

BYLINE:  By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, April 8 

 BODY:
President Saddam Hussein of Iraq halted his country's oil exports temporarily today, saying he would seek to damage the American economy because of Washington's support for Israel, and he repeated his demand -- likely to remain ignored -- that other Middle Eastern oil producers follow suit.
 Shutting off the taps had an immediate impact on oil prices, which shot upward. But it seems unlikely that the move will have any short-term effect on the United Nations program that supervises Iraq's purchase of food, medicine and other goods by siphoning its oil revenue through a special account. 
 Mr. Hussein said Iraq would review the decision to halt exports after a month, or after the Israeli military withdrew unconditionally from Palestinian territory. 
"This decision is essentially aimed against the Zionist entity and the aggressive U.S. policy, not against anyone else," Mr. Hussein said, accusing the United States of backing Israel's sustained military offensive.
The move would clearly be popular among the general Arab population, with demonstrators joining ever larger marches all week, chanting for their leaders to skip the speeches and take some action.
King Abdullah II of Jordan, in his first brief public remarks on the situation, said today that if Israel did not withdraw from the Palestinian territories immediately, relations with his kingdom would be affected. But he did not specify how.
Mr. Hussein said other countries should follow Iraq's example.
"Our Arab and Muslim brethren and all believers will hopefully encourage our move," he said in a televised address, suggesting that all oil exporters take "similar measures."
Despite the day's steep rise in prices after the announcement, oil analysts said other producers like Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, often fearful of the effect of volatile oil prices, were likely to increase production to make up the shortfall. Nations outside the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, like Russia and Norway, can be expected to increase sales to take advantage of high prices.
Iraq exports about two million barrels of oil a day, or 4 percent of global production. The United States in particular ranks among its best customers. The Iraqis say roughly 15 percent of America's imported oil originates in Iraq. The United States says the figure is more like 8 percent.
Mr. Hussein's measure "will have a major impact on the oil market and directly hurt the U.S. economy," Oil Minister Amir Muhammad Rashid told Iraq's satellite television channel.
He said the United States generally bought 1.25 million barrels of oil daily that originated in Iraq and noted that he had contacted other members of OPEC to suggest that they not mitigate the effect of the embargo by raising their production.
Although the leaders of Iran and Libya have supported the idea of reviving the 1973 Arab oil embargo, which resulted in Americans lining up for gasoline, they seem unlikely to join. Iran's economic problems make it heavily dependent on oil revenue -- as is the case with most oil producers -- and Libya only recently began resuming commercial ties with the West.
Although Mr. Hussein has forced the 17 million Iraqi people to weather repeated crises in the past, United Nations officials said the export cutoff probably would not have any immediate effect on the oil-for-food program.
Some $13 billion in outstanding contracts for food, medicine and other supplies is already in the pipeline, said Hasmik Egian, the spokeswoman for the program. But the program has already been suffering from a funding crisis, with no money to back another $2 billion in contracts that have already been approved.
"There is a funding shortfall, so this will further complicate that situation," Ms. Egian said.
She said that Iraq earned some $11 billion from oil last year, but that production was already erratic because the Iraqis stopped exports in June and then slowed them again in December in a dispute with the United Nations over pricing. More stringent price controls were put in place after reports that Iraq was demanding kickbacks from buyers that were deposited outside the United Nations system.
Iraq exports smaller volumes of oil to its neighbors -- Jordan, Syria and Turkey -- with various levels of United Nations approval. While Jordan's economic hardships exempted it from some United Nations controls, the United Nations has queried Syria about opening a long-closed pipeline to help Iraq export. Baghdad did not indicate that any of those sales would be cut.

HEADLINE: Council Seeks Tax Surcharge To Aid Schools 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
The City Council called yesterday for levying a new income tax surcharge to pay for new schools, school libraries and labs, charting a collision course with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg over two political flash points: taxes and budget cuts.
 Gifford Miller, the City Council speaker, announced the council's plan for a new tax, which would be leveraged to pay for $5 billion in new debt, in Corona, Queens, in a temporary classroom that was built in the playground of what he described as the most overcrowded school in the nation. 
 In laying out the plan, Mr. Miller challenged Mr. Bloomberg's oft-repeated position that higher taxes would frighten away businesses. "We have got to keep our middle class, we have got to attract businesses, and we believe that the way to do that, first and foremost, is to have an outstanding public education system," Mr. Miller said. 
The Bloomberg administration was swift to take up the gauntlet. "I'm opposed to raising taxes on anything other than cigarettes, which clearly would save lives if you did," said the mayor, who wants only one tax rise: a $1.42-a-pack increase in the cigarette tax, to as much as $7 a pack. His aides called the Council's proposal unrealistic and "not responsible."
The Council made its push for an education tax surcharge as part of its response, and rebuttal, to Mayor Bloomberg's plan for closing a $4.76 billion budget deficit in the fiscal year beginning in July. 
The Council wants to restore several of the mayor's proposed cuts. They called for restoring all $344 million in education cuts; keeping open seven centers for the elderly that were scheduled to be closed; partly scaling back the cuts to libraries and cultural institutions; and continuing the city's recycling program for cans and bottles, which the mayor says is too inefficient and costly and should be dropped.
To pay for these, the Council proposed a variety of new cuts and tax increases, including $31 million in higher taxes on beer, wine and liquor, and $65 million in a property tax surcharge on absentee landlords with one-to-three family homes. Even absent any tax increases, the council forecasts that the city will collect $445 million more in taxes next year than the mayor does, because it expects the economy to improve more quickly.
But its plan got a cool reaction from the Bloomberg administration. "The Council's financial plan relies on over a billion dollars of unrealistic tax increases," Deputy Mayor Marc V. Shaw said in a statement. "It is not responsible to raise expectations for moneys that are simply not going to materialize."
The mayor is expected to release his executive budget plan later this month, setting off a round of hearings and fevered negotiations and horse trading with the City Council until a final budget is passed in June.
The proposed education tax surcharge would cost $7 a year for people making less than $40,000; $263 a year for people making $100,000 to $150,000; and $14,490 for people making a million dollars. Unlike other recent income tax surcharges, like the one used to hire more police in the 1990's, this proposal contains no sunset clause or date when the surcharge would be phased out.
Over all, the Council said that the tax would bring in almost $400 million a year.
The Council's plan is to borrow $5 billion for education and use the $400 million a year generated by the tax surcharge to pay off that debt. Mr. Miller said that the money would be used to pay for the construction of 10 new high schools, 10 more high schools on City University of New York campuses, 13 elementary schools, 650 new school libraries, 670 new science labs and 136,000 new computers for the schools.
The building would be handled not by the School Construction Authority, which has been widely criticized for inefficiency and cost overruns, but by the Department of Design and Construction, an agency answerable to the mayor.
When Mayor Bloomberg first laid out his budget plan in February, he said that he would oppose a higher income tax on the city's wealthiest people. "Adding a tax to the most mobile people in the city just doesn't make a lot of sense," he said then.
Yesterday, Mr. Miller turned that argument against him, arguing that the city faces a greater danger of losing people who are concerned about its school system than losing people who are against higher taxes. "When people call me and tell me that they are planning to leave New York City, the reason that they always tell me, every single time, is because they don't have faith and confidence in our public school system," he said.
The Council, clearly sensitive to the potential of tax-and-spend criticism, was careful to include several proposed tax cuts and service cuts. They proposed eliminating the commercial rent tax below Houston Street, cutting the sales tax the week of July 4, and trimming more administrative positions from city agencies. And some tax increases that council members had discussed -- such as a stock transfer tax -- were not included.
And while the Council is asking the State Legislature to reinstate the commuter tax, which was levied on people who work in the city but live outside it, it wants to use any proceeds from it and other funds so the city will only have to borrow $1 billion next year. Mr. Bloomberg's budget calls for borrowing $1.5 billion to help close the budget gap.
Reinstating the commuter tax, instituting a personal income tax surcharge, and raising the tax on beer, wine and liquor all require the approval of the State Legislature, which could be difficult in an election year, and without the mayor's support.

HEADLINE: Venezuela Woes Worsen as State Oil Company Calls Strike 

BYLINE:  By JUAN FORERO 

DATELINE: MERIDA, Venezuela, April 8 

 BODY:
A six-week tussle over President Hugo Chavez's management of the state oil company has turned into his most serious crisis, with exports of oil disrupted by a labor slowdown and a general strike called for Tuesday by labor and business leaders.
 "This can only end with the president resigning," Humberto Calderon Berti, a former minister of energy and mines, told a throng of protesting executives from the oil company Petroleos de Venezuela in Caracas. "All Venezuelans from all walks of life, from all social strata, from all the political and ideological sectors, must take part in the stoppage. This is about him or us. It is a choice between democracy or dictatorship." 
 Government ministers said today that exports of oil and refined products remained normal for Venezuela, the world's No. 4 exporter. But analysts and executives from Petroleos de Venezuela said a five-day work slowdown among oil workers and managers had forced a scaling back of operations at several refineries and a cutback in production at wellheads, all of which has disrupted oil shipments to the United States and other countries.
"The reality is you don't have business as usual," said Lawrence J. Goldstein, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, an industry-supported consulting group in New York. "We believe half to two-thirds of their exports have been impacted. But it is literally an hour-by-hour situation."
Latin America's fourth-largest economy may also grind to a halt on Tuesday, as dissident business leaders have promised, in protest against what they see as Mr. Chavez's autocratic style of governing and his treatment of oil company managers. The first such stoppage took place on Dec. 10. Millions of workers stayed home as part of a growing wave of protests aimed at forcing Mr. Chavez from power.
The showdown that has churned up the current crisis began when Mr. Chavez, a left-leaning former army paratrooper who won office in 1998, took on the management of Petroleos de Venezuela, a behemoth with 40,000 employees. Calling it a "state within a state" that sapped resources while benefiting a small number of high-flying executives, Mr. Chavez in February fired the company president, a general whom he had appointed months earlier, and appointed five board members with ties to his administration.
For many of the company's 15,000 office workers, who had long celebrated it as a meritocracy known for efficiency and high standards, the president's management decision was enough. The workers organized protests and slowdowns, which have won the support of leaders from business and labor, as well as from the local media, which report every anti-Chavez protest or pronouncement with relish.
With Mr. Chavez refusing to withdraw his appointments or negotiate with dissident oil executives, the office workers and production workers persisted with their slowdowns, which have intensified since last week. At one drilling site on Thursday, two oil workers were killed when fighting broke out between government supporters and opposition party members.
The exact impact on oil production, refining and the transport of crude and oil products was unclear today. 
But analysts and executives said the Amuay Cardon refinery, which processes 950,000 barrels of crude daily and is a crucial supplier of finished oil products to the United States, had reduced operations. At least two other installations, the Palito refinery on the north-central coast and Puerto La Cruz to the east, halted operations, they said.
Dissident oil executives, reading a statement outside a Petroleos de Venezuela office building in Caracas, said extraction of oil was slowing in the Furrial field in the east while refineries and plants that produce chemicals or distribute natural gas were also ratcheting down.
"Progressively, everything is shutting down," said Alberto Quiroz, an oil analyst and former executive at Petroleos de Venezuela (which is known worldwide by its Spanish acronym, Pdvsa, pronounced peh-deh-VEH-sah).
Top government officials, among them Vice President Diosdado Cabello, Energy and Mines Minister Alvaro Silva, and the oil company president, Gaston Parra, have sought to minimize the effects of the slowdown.
"Everything is normal," Mr. Silva told reporters. "Go to the refineries. Everything is normal. There is a small group protesting, but everything is operating normally." 
The commander of the armed forces, Gen. Lucas Rincon, announced that the military was beefing up its presence at refineries and oil fields, which are routinely protected by the National Guard.
Through it all, Mr. Chavez has refused to back down or acknowledge that the slowdown could hurt Venezuela, whose economy relies on oil for 80 percent of exports and 50 percent of government revenues.
In a long nationally televised address on Sunday, the president said the military could run oil production and refining sites if necessary. He also took the opportunity to announce that he had fired 7 dissident executives and forced 12 more to retire.
Blowing a soccer referee's whistle and calling the executives "off sides," Mr. Chavez warned about a "subversive movement in neckties" trying to destabilize the country. But, he warned, "I can do away with all of them," he said.
Rafael Sandrea, president of the oil committee of Fedecamaras, a powerful business group, said Mr. Chavez's uncompromising approach had only made the opposition that much more defiant.
"The president has closed the door of reconciliation and opened the doors for war," Mr. Sandrea said. "That is what this is now, war, between the people of Pdvsa and the government."

HEADLINE: ARTS IN AMERICA; 
At a Festival, Documentaries as History

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: DURHAM, N.C., April 8 

 BODY:
Traveling theater troupes once gave audiences what Shakespeare called "the abstracts and brief chronicles of the time." Then came an era when encyclopedic historians like Gibbon and Macaulay told people what they wanted to know about history and society. A festival held here last weekend suggests that today, documentary filmmakers are assuming that role.
 Public and cable television networks have spurred a boom in documentary filmmaking over the last few years, resulting in a surge of films that seek to interpret both contemporary events and those long past. 
 The Full Frame Documentary Film Festival here, formerly the DoubleTake Festival, attracted 630 entries this year, far more than in any of its previous four years. Sixty-seven films were chosen to be screened.
Most of the works shown fell into two broad categories. Some were personal stories or video diaries that presented individual lives. Many of the most compelling ones, however, dealt with historical events. Their richness and variety suggest that documentary films have become a vital part of the way Americans learn about what is happening and has happened in the world around them.
"We're part of the great move away from quantitative history toward history that is concerned about the art of presentation as well as the science of information," said Ric Burns, one of the country's most prominent documentary filmmakers, who was here to present his new film, "Ansel Adams," about the photographer. "We want to seduce people imaginatively and give them a sense of what it was like to be there then. We're doing what realistic novelists did in the 19th century. We take the roof off the house and show you what's happening or what happened inside."
"As people become more informed, there's a hunger for insight into other places and other times," Mr. Burns said. "People are asking, 'What went on in his head?' or 'How does she live?' That's part of what accounts for the explosion of interest in documentary filmmaking."
This year's jury prize for a full-length film at the Full Frame festival went to Davis Guggenheim's documentary "The First Year," which portrays the daunting challenges facing novice teachers at some of America's toughest public schools. The audience prize was awarded to "The Last Just Man," a shattering account by Steven Silver of the responsibility shared by the United States, Belgium and the United Nations for the 1994 genocide in Rwanda. It focuses on Gen. Romeo Dallaire, the Canadian officer who commanded the United Nations peacekeeping force there, who is consumed with guilt for his inability to persuade his superiors in New York to allow him to stop the massacres, which took 800,000 lives in a 100-day period.
In an interview Mr. Silver said the burgeoning interest in historical documentaries placed an added burden on filmmakers as reporters. That burden is increased when important figures refuse to cooperate, a problem he faced when both the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, and former Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright turned down his requests for interviews. 
"With so many of these new history-oriented channels using our films, and so many more people watching them, our responsibility to get the story right is heavier than ever," Mr. Silver said. "Today history is being taught on film. That means filmmakers become historians, and it means we have to work and research and look for fairness and truth with the same rigor as any scholar. There's a big weight on our shoulders."
When he accepted the audience award, Mr. Silver said the accompanying $3,000 worth of film donated by Eastman Kodak would "come in very handy, given the economics of our business." Several other filmmakers also said that although there were many more outlets for documentaries now than even a few years ago, they still make little money from their work. Even some of the most successful must still struggle for the relatively modest funds needed for their projects.
Mr. Silver's film also reflects a trend in modern documentary filmmaking, because although it strives for honesty -- or perhaps because it does -- it interprets events and takes a position on them rather than simply presenting points of view. Passion informs his film and many other contemporary documentaries.
Margaret Drain, executive producer of the PBS series "American Experience," said she worried that many Americans were learning history not from documentaries but from feature films, ranging from admittedly fictionalized ones like "A Beautiful Mind" to those that claim authenticity, like "JFK."
"It's the responsibility of documentary filmmakers to counter that," Ms. Drain said. "You're always interpreting facts, but in the documentary business we have to be bound by them and respect them. That certainly isn't the case with feature films."
She was encouraged, though, by the increasing interest in documentaries. "A lot of people do seem to be taking their historical information from documentary films," she said. "More and more historians are finding that they love working with documentary filmmakers, and that's had quite an impact. I was at CBS in the mid-80's when executives there announced that the documentary was dead. Well, guess what? It's alive and well and thriving."
Perhaps inevitably, the Durham festival devoted several programs to films about the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 and their aftermath. Some are directly tied to the disaster, like "The Morning Of," a five-minute short that shows people on Staten Island reacting while the World Trade Center towers are still ablaze, and "Site," a record of visitors' reactions to ground zero. Others probe related issues, like "Afghan Alphabet," a study of the difficulties facing children in Afghanistan as they struggle for an education.
"Television did a very good job of covering the events of Sept. 11," said Nancy Buirski, the festival's executive director. "Documentary films take that to the next level. They probe history and emotions and psychology. They approach experience from so many vantage points, like a prism. If they're well done, there's a fullness to them that you really don't get in any other medium."
Among the filmmakers who came here for the festival was David Van Taylor, co-producer of "Ghosts of Attica," which provides chilling new insights into that 1971 prison uprising in upstate New York. He is now working on a video history of documentary filmmaking.
"We do what historians do, which is to write the second draft of history, to correct what people are told at the time that things happen," Mr. Van Taylor said. "We don't compete with scholars, but we fill an important niche and we take what we do very seriously. Filmmakers definitely have an increasing responsibility, as more people go to films for information that they used to get from the written word."
"I see a lot of very good historical films these days," he said. "They have to be good, because people are becoming more and more sophisticated in gleaning information from visual sources. As superficial as visual information can be, compared to text, it also contains great riches."

HEADLINE: Blue Skies Shining On City Restaurants 

BYLINE:  By MARIAN BURROS 

 BODY:
PREDICTIONS for New York restaurants after Sept. 11 were dire. Business would be so bad, people in the industry feared, that dozens would be forced to close.
 Some of the worries have come true. Corporate spending, the lifeblood of high-end restaurants, is down. And tourism, along with the convention business, is still lagging. Many believe that freewheeling consumption is out of step with the times. 
 Yet few restaurants closed, and many did even better in the first quarter of this year than they did last year. 
The reason? In great part, the weather.
Ordinarily, the seasonal annoyances of cold, snow and slush keep people in the office instead of out to lunch, at home instead of out for dinner. But this past winter the balmy weather proved a bonanza. People kept going to their favorite places; sometimes they even ate outside.
"The threat of snow can change dinner reservations from 250 to 75," Waldy Malouf, the chef at Beacon on West 56th Street, said, "and very cold weather keeps people from going to lunch." 
Other factors played a part. The city and the industry organized two promotional restaurant weeks instead of the usual one, and New Yorkers responded, turning out for $20 prix fixe lunches and $30 prix fixe dinners.
"It brought main-line restaurants pretty nearly back to normal," said Tim Zagat, departing chairman of NYC & Company, the city's tourism marketing agency.
The slowdown in business travel had a flip side, George Faison, a partner in D'Artagnan, the purveyor of luxury meats and foie gras, said. "A lot of New York business travelers stayed home and are eating here." Vendors like Mr. Faison also gave restaurants more time to make payments. "We have to be more lenient to help keep people afloat." In some cases vendors renegotiated contracts. Wholesale wine prices dropped, allowing some restaurants to cut the cost of wines by the glass in half. 
Individual restaurants have instituted their own promotions, giving away wine and bar snacks, offering gift certificates and frequent-eater programs to lure customers back, and even reducing prices. 
Restaurateurs say that unlike the case of Broadway, which had one of the best theater seasons in years with the help of suburbanites and out-of-towners, the speedy rebirth was mainly fueled by New Yorkers.
With the exception of San Francisco, no city was affected more than New York by the recession that began early last year. But the downturn affected restaurants less severely than had been predicted, said E. Charles Hunt, executive vice president of the New York Restaurant Association. Across the country, the National Restaurant Association said, sales returned to pre-attack levels. After declining 2.4 percent in September, sales surged by 7.5 percent for the rest of the year, and though dipping slightly in January, rebounded in February, the last month for which figures are available. 
Despite the good news for New York restaurants, the losses in the fall will not be easy to make up. The terrorist attacks and the recession have forced even the most successful restaurants to take stock, looking for ways to control costs while making customers feel more welcome. 
Even so, some restaurants that were struggling before Sept. 11 have fallen by the wayside, like Quilty's and Palio. Others are still struggling. And many restaurants that have opened since the first of the year have much lower prices. 
Patroon, once one of the most expensive steakhouses in New York, closed last July to renovate and offer a less expensive menu, said its owner, Ken Aretsky. When it reopened in mid-November its prices were 25 percent lower. Mr. Aretsky says business is 12 to 14 percent below last year's levels. "We are trying to be extremely inventive and creative, constantly trying to come up with ways to drive more traffic through the door," he said.
Seven months after the attacks, restaurateurs say, their customers continue to be more relaxed and more convivial, which might have something to do with the increased consumption of alcohol. "When people drink, people are happy and that makes for a nicer atmosphere," Geoffrey Zakarian, owner and chef of Town, said. "People are even talking to people at tables next to them."
What they are drinking is cocktails and lots of them, and more moderately priced wines. Charlie Palmer, owner of Aureole, Alva and Metrazur, says his wine costs are down. "Wine purveyors have been stuck with a glut of wine since 9/11, and people with cash could make a great deal," he said.
Corporate spending is still down. "There's much less extravagance," said Drew Nieporent, who owns Nobu, Montrachet and Tribeca Grill and is about to reopen Layla. "But when there is a business dinner now, they want to build the menu around price; before, price was no object."
Even thriving restaurants have adjusted. For Oceana, which just celebrated its 10th anniversary, business has never been better. "Our February this year is the best we've had," said Rick Moonen, the chef and a partner. "Out of a bad situation we tightened a lot of nuts and bolts we were not paying attention to. It's made us better managers."
Two months ago the restaurant began putting a nut mixture on the bar. The prix fixe dinner remains at $68, but an optional $30 supplement offers three glasses of wine.
The restaurant is not purchasing expensive wines, and it has made do with a smaller staff, things it thought very little about before 2001, Mr. Moonen said. And the linen supplier has agreed to hold off on an increase for six months. 
But prices have not been lowered. "If you do quality work, you need to hold steady," Mr. Moonen said, "and the people will come back."
Much of this is good news for patrons, who are getting more value for their money. At Union Pacific, Rocco DiSpirito, the chef and an owner, redecorated to make the restaurant's rather formal interior warmer and "less intimidating," he said. He also introduced a pre-6 p.m. menu with three courses for $45 and dropped a $12 supplement for the prime strip steak, adding it to the regular prix fixe menu, which has been at $65 for four years. 
And, Mr. DiSpirito said, "we started directing our waiters to bring a surprise to our guests by eavesdropping on what they were thinking about ordering but didn't, like wine or dessert."
"It's the way you stay alive in a competitive time," he added. 
At Mr. Palmer's restaurants, where business is off 4 or 5 percent, the staff has been instructed to be more careful. Glass breakage is down 15 percent; a change in linen suppliers is saving $2,000 a month. "And less people are getting the same work done," Mr. Palmer said.
Some sections of the city are still suffering, like Rockefeller Center, Little Italy, Chinatown and Wall Street. With fewer shows at Radio City Music Hall, there are fewer diners. Chez Louis at West 50th Street has drastically lowered prices. "January was the worst month of my life in the restaurant business," David Liederman, the owner, said. "February was pretty good because there were a lot of shows booked, but March was off 18 percent from a year ago. We have a second-floor lunch for $9.95 and it's only $2 more than McDonald's, and we have problems selling that."
Wall Street-area restaurants that say they were thriving before Sept. 11, like Vine and Bayard's, are off 15 to 20 percent. Delmonico's is down 25 percent, despite the fact that tourists are visiting ground zero.
While the new efficiencies are important, everyone comes back to the same reason for the healthy restaurant scene: the weather. "Usually for the first part of the year," Mr. Zagat said, "one day of three is generally lousy and you aren't going to go out at night. But the astonishingly good weather this winter helped. Whether the economy has turned or people are beginning to feel better, one thing is true: You didn't have snow on the ground and you didn't have to go through slush."

HEADLINE: And to Think That I Ate It on Clinton Street 

BYLINE:  By ERIC ASIMOV 

 BODY:
NOT so long ago, Clinton Street on the Lower East Side was a grim, grafitti-ridden streetscape. By night, bags of heroin were sold by brand name, while prostitutes peddled their wares nearby. Things looked even worse, if possible, under daylight, which shone on Clinton Street like fluorescent lights on a hangover. 
 In a scant few years, though, Clinton Street has undergone the equivalent of a whole body transformation. Restaurants are now the reason to travel there, and the temptations offered for sale are chestnut gnocchi with braised rabbit and lamb spareribs with a fennel seed-coriander rub. 
 Clinton Street's evolution from drug bazaar to a lively Restaurant Row of the Lower East Side is perhaps only one more scene in New York's long-running revitalization show. Clinton Street is the latest in a series of streets -- most recently Smith Street in Boerum Hill and Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, and Fifth Avenue in Park Slope -- where restaurants have led the way to more thriving local economies. 
But on Clinton Street, the transformation can be traced to the arrival of one small 30-seat restaurant, 71 Clinton Fresh Food, which opened in late 1999 near Rivington Street, a notorious drug intersection. Almost immediately, the precise and elegant flavor combinations of the chef, Wylie Dufresne, received critical raves. Within weeks, town cars and limousines were pulling up nightly, depositing patrons from all over the city and beyond. Fresh Food was the beginning. Now, barely two year later, young, attractive crowds flock to Clinton Street to eat on any given night.
The diners stop in at 1492, a noisy brick-walled restaurant, for traditional tapas, like whole grilled prawns seasoned only with sea salt, or dates stuffed with almonds and wrapped with bacon. They drop by Punch and Judy, a dark, romantic lounge where pinot noir or Chateauneuf-du-Pape is served in oversize glasses, the better to swirl and sniff, and the menu includes slices of smoked duck and lobster club sandwiches. At Alias, opened just a few weeks ago, smart-looking diners think little of stepping outside for a smoke -- the drug dealers are long gone. And everybody is awaiting WD50, Mr. Dufresne's new restaurant, to open this fall in a former bodega.
Even by day, a new liveliness is evident on the street. Practically next door to the imposing 1853 Romanesque Revival synagogue housing Congregation Chasam Sopher sits the Clinton St. Baking Company, where diners enjoy freshly baked blueberry muffins, omelets, fat biscuits and soups. Pedestrians stroll under blooming Callery pear trees, while older men sit on benches or play dominoes. Down the block, young people are filling aKa Cafe, perhaps for its signature sandwich of lamb's tongue with almond butter and currant jelly. Across the street, at Cibao, a venerable Dominican restaurant, a Spanish-speaking crowd tucks into chicharrones de pollo, chunks of crisp fried chicken, or downs cups of cafe con leche with plates of glistening flan.
"Clinton was out of it; it was really hard core," said Mark Federman, the third-generation owner of Russ & Daughters, a smoked fish store on Houston Street. "But once they put in 71 Clinton it started to turn."
Henry Hallivis, a neighborhood resident for 30 years and an owner of the building that houses Alias, was more blunt. "They put Clinton Street on the map," Mr. Hallivis said. "The change is unbelievable." 
Of course, Clinton Street was not transformed in a vacuum. The Lower East Side, once a gateway to opportunity for immigrants as well as a hotbed of radical disillusionment, began evolving into a hipster's paradise in the 1990's. Its tenements had, of course, more recently offered inexpensive if grim haven for artists, musicians and other urban pioneers.
In the late 1980's, bars and boutiques on Ludlow Street in particular and on nearby blocks of Stanton and Rivington Streets began to attract a college crowd, but Clinton Street remained largely unaffected by gentrification. Still, it was spiffed up in the 1990's with new sidewalks and the Callery pear trees. In 1997, the Lotus Cafe, by day a coffeehouse for the goatee and laptop set, by night a bar, was the one new touch.
"We're old school," Joe Manuse, an owner of Lotus, said of the cafe. "People come here for sandwiches and salads. They go down the block for cuisine."
 Since 71 Clinton opened, the changes in the neighborhood have been profound. Small shops and boutiques have popped up, and enterprising restaurateurs are hoping to capitalize on the excitement 71 Clinton has generated. Azul, a Mediterranean bistro, arrived in January at the corner of Suffolk and Stanton Streets, a block west of Clinton. Suba, a stylish subterranean restaurant and bar with French and Spanish accents, opened recently on a previously deserted section of Ludlow near Delancey Street. 
"I am a firm believer in upcoming areas," said Fernando Dallorso, who owns Azul with Stefano Villa. "It happened on Smith Street, it happened in SoHo, and the Lower East Side has a lot of potential and a lot of history."
Mr. Dallorso has done pretty well with that theory. He opened Novecento, an Argentine steakhouse in SoHo, more than a decade ago, and followed with Sur, another Argentine restaurant, just as Smith Street was taking off in 1998. 
"As soon as three or four restaurants do good, you get 15," Mr. Dallorso said. "Look at Smith Street."
Back in 1999, when Janet Nelson and her partners were building 71 Clinton, they were simply hoping for a successful neighborhood restaurant. Ms. Nelson -- who has been in the restaurant business for 20 years, involved with places like Tortilla Flats, Grange Hall and Global 33 -- has lived on Rivington Street for 17 years in a building owned by her sister Marybeth Nelson, a partner in Fresh Food. The building is also home to another sister, Susan Nelson, who helps manage the restaurant, and Dewey Dufresne, an original partner whose son, Wylie, happened to be a chef.
"I knew Wylie when he was a teenager," Janet Nelson said. "We thought we were going to be a neighborhood restaurant, but it evolved into a destination."
How could it be otherwise? Wylie Dufresne had spent seven years working for Jean-Georges Vongerichten, and dishes like black sea bass with a crust of crumbled edamame and tiny rye croutons immediately drew attention.
"He was a destination chef," said Michael Batterberry, the publisher of Food Arts magazine. 
The fact that he was on the Lower East Side, with its immigrant and artsy past, added to the attraction. "There's a reverse chic of wanting to be adventurous, eating in the ground floors of what were formerly appalling tenements," said Phillip Lopate, a literary critic and essayist. 
For restaurateurs, the attraction to the Lower East Side is not romance but rent, a barrier that for many young or independent entrepreneurs has become increasingly steep in Manhattan. The lure of cheaper rents drove restaurateurs to Brooklyn -- and to the Lower East Side.
"It's not just the rent; landlords want key money," said Allan Mannarelli, who builds and finances downtown restaurants. "You can't do Avenues B or C anymore because everything's taken. The Lower East Side has the lowest barrier of entry, with the highest upside."
Ms. Nelson and her partners used their contacts to get reasonable rents at two more spaces on Clinton Street. They opened aKa Cafe, a colorful, informal spot that successfully applies the 71 Clinton formula of exceptional ingredients and ambitious combinations to a sandwich and wine bar. A few weeks ago, they opened Alias. Without compromising on cuisine, it stakes out a middle ground between aKa and 71 Clinton, which Mr. Dufresne left in December. His sous-chef, Matt Reguin, is now in charge of the kitchen, while another alumnus, Scott Ehrlich, cooks at both aKa and Alias. 
Clinton Street restaurants have not been an unblemished success story. Sago, a Moroccan restaurant with belly dancers, did not hit the right note and closed, as did Lowly Lady, which had a backwoods theme that was perhaps too rustic for the neighborhood. Nonetheless, Mr. Dufresne's new restaurant, which he is opening with his father and with major-league partners, Phil Suarez and Jean-Georges Vongerichten, is keenly awaited.
WD50, with 65 seats, and 5,000 square feet, will be larger than 71 Clinton, aKa and Alias put together. "We got a very favorable deal," Dewey Dufresne said. "The smaller spaces have doubled in price." 
For Wylie Dufresne, the opportunity to have his own restaurant was irresistible. With construction not quite under way, it's also a chance to dream. "I very much want local people to come in, though I know it's not realistic," he said. "I want children to come in, and elderly people. I want everybody to feel at home."
Surprisingly, in a neighborhood undergoing turmoil and transformation, almost everybody seems pretty much at home. Many residents originally opposed 71 Clinton, fearing an onslaught of bars, noise and rowdy behavior, said Jose Rivera, head of the United Merchants of Clinton Street. "We started to work together, and everything has been quiet," he said.
Still, some people fear that in the long run Clinton Street will not benefit from its restaurants, that the out-of-the-neighborhood people will decamp for the next new thing.
"To saturate Clinton Street with restaurants that nobody can afford to eat in, it just destabilizes the neighborhood and creates constant turnover that's not healthy," said Clayton Patterson, a community advocate and longtime resident. 
Another looming issue is the direction of traffic on Clinton Street. In the mid-1990's, when construction on the Williamsburg Bridge began, traffic on Clinton Street was reversed so that it went north to south. Cars that formerly barreled off the bridge onto Delancey Street and headed north on Clinton were diverted, which Mr. Rivera said harmed longtime businesses, but also created a calm, tranquil block, with easy access from Houston Street. Mr. Rivera and others would like to restore the old traffic pattern, while Mr. Dufresne and other restaurant owners want to keep it as it is.
Nonetheless, Mr. Dufresne sounds as if he's in love with his culinary home.
"It's one of the few streets that's tree-lined," Mr. Dufresne said. "It's absolutely gorgeous, the flowers blooming. I'm really excited about Clinton Street. I'm going to be on that street for a long time to come."

HEADLINE: Optimistic on Recovery 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Your "queasy feeling of slippage and lack of focus" ("Rebuilding Downtown," editorial, April 3), about efforts to revitalize portions of Lower Manhattan affected by terrorist attacks, should dissipate when considering the following accomplishments and prospects. 
 Almost 1.5 million tons of debris have been cleared from ground zero. 
Subway service will be restored on the Nos. 1 and 9 lines by December. A more integrated new downtown PATH station is scheduled for completion by the end of 2003.
New York secured the largest grant in federal HUD's history to retain and attract businesses south of 14th Street, and residential incentives have already played a part in slashing housing vacancy rates south of Chambers Street.
Rather than see the glass as half empty, it would be more accurate to recognize the speed and effectiveness with which public officials, civil servants and business leaders have responded to the worst disaster that New York has ever suffered.

STEVEN SPINOLA
President, Real Estate Board of N.Y.
New York, April 3, 2002
