HEADLINE: Notes From New Orleans; 
A New Mayor and a New Wage

BYLINE:  By Kathy Finn; Kathy Finn, a business writer, has lived in New Orleans for 20 years.

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS 

 BODY:
On a recent morning, New Orleans's mayor-elect, Ray Nagin, an African-American, stood before a gathering of 300 people in a meeting room of a downtown hotel. He told the mostly white and well-heeled audience of his hopes and priorities for the city. One of them was: "We have to develop a strong African-American middle class." 
 Just outside the room, dishes clanged and carts rolled as a few dozen hotel workers, most of them black, cleared the remains of another breakfast meeting. Had they heard Mr. Nagin's message, they might have agreed with its thrust. But chances are they would prefer a quicker economic boost. 
 Hotel workers will be major beneficiaries of a new law that sets the minimum wage in New Orleans one dollar above the federally mandated minimum. If the law withstands court challenges and takes effect as scheduled on May 2, an estimated 35,000 entry-level workers in private and public sector jobs will get a raise to $6.15 an hour, a dollar higher than what their brethren earn just across the city line. The law stipulates that the local wage must remain $1 above the federal minimum in the event of future increases.
Oddly, the wage bill easily won voter approval in a city with a long anti-labor-union history; only one New Orleans hotel has ever been unionized, and that was decades ago. The wage measure was on the same ballot that sent Mr. Nagin -- the only major mayoral candidate to oppose the wage hike -- into a runoff. A month later, voters delivered him a landslide victory. What were they thinking?
The election results were a measure of the frustration that bubbles just below the surface in this town. To the outsider, New Orleans may look like a city that seldom takes itself seriously, while taking big visitor events like Mardi Gras and the Super Bowl in stride. Our easygoing image aside, many residents have had it up to here with the politics of the past.
Local people rich and poor are fuming over the fact that our political leaders have done little to improve economic opportunities in the face of a shifting economy. Ray Nagin played to this frustration as no local political candidate has in decades.
As the general manager credited with turning around a faltering regional cable television franchise of Cox Communications, the 45-year-old Mr. Nagin moves easily among the local business elite. But his hip personal style carries him beyond business circles as well. Throughout his campaign, he kept his distance from the old-line political organizations that have long controlled local elections by playing one race or faction against another. Instead, carrying a Blackberry in his pocket and touting plans for a technological revolution in city government, he told voters a restructured local economy is the best medicine for what ails residents at all income levels. He spoke with the poise of a big-company chief executive and the sincerity of a preacher. Voters were captivated.
But now Mr. Nagin, who will take office May 6, faces public expectations he admits "are in the stratosphere." Depending on how the minimum wage fares with Louisiana's highest court, he may also face the thorny problem of rising costs for those doing business in New Orleans.
For local labor and community organizers and the close to 30 percent of the city's population who live below the federal poverty level, the new wage law is a long-sought prize. Six years ago the Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now gathered 25,000 petition signatures to support a "living wage" ballot proposal. But the City Council stalled it, and state lawmakers in 1997 passed a new law barring local jurisdictions from setting their own wage floors.
Challenges to that state law were rebuffed until an appeals court ruled that the law couldn't be tested until local voters actually approved a wage ordinance; the court, in effect, ordered that the wage increase go to a vote.
New Orleans restaurant and hotel associations, along with other business groups, fought the wage hike. They said increased labor costs would drive New Orleans employers to the suburbs or even farther. And they predicted any wage boost would make it harder to attract new industries that could help diversify the local economy.
Louisiana's primary economic driver, the oil and gas industry, has shrunk in the last two decades as corporate mergers sucked high-paying jobs out of downtown New Orleans office towers. Another major industry, the maritime business, has had its ups and downs stemming from fluctuations in global trade.
Meanwhile, multiple expansions of the local convention center have fueled hotel construction and a slew of new restaurants. But as service jobs grew, so did the nagging feeling that economic expansion elsewhere in the country had left New Orleans in the dust. Overall job growth here plodded at an annual rate of less than 1 percent in the late 1990's, while some Southern cities had job growth rates of 4 percent to 6 percent.
With too many low-wage jobs at one end and too few high-paying jobs at the other, the New Orleans economy is clearly out of whack. Ray Nagin didn't plan on using a higher minimum wage to help fix what's wrong with the economy, but he may have no choice.
The new wage law was upheld on March 25, when a New Orleans civil district judge turned back the first challenge to its constitutionality. Opponents are now asking the state Supreme Court to prevent implementation of the wage law until it can give their appeal a full hearing.
A higher local minimum wage may not be the best linchpin for building a new economy. Then again, the tens of thousands of workers who would feel the effect of the pay hike may see it as a pretty good start.

HEADLINE: Bulldozing Hope in the Mideast 

 BODY:
One tragic consequence of this month's Israeli military offensive across the West Bank has been the heavy blow it inflicted on a Palestinian economy and civil society that had begun to show signs of life. If these two proud and talented peoples are ever to live side by side in peace and cooperation, one obvious prerequisite will be a Palestinian economy that generates jobs and prosperity for its people and civil institutions that can broaden debate and begin to supplant the paramilitary secular and Islamist groups that now monopolize Palestinian political activity. 
 Israel's long-term interest lies in nurturing Palestinian development, not demolishing it. While Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's determination to strike back at terrorists is understandable, Israel's destruction of Palestinian homes, businesses and public utilities is not. Knocking down houses, destroying electricity pylons and interfering with health care, as Israeli forces have done across the West Bank, cannot be justified by any compelling military need. 
 The Palestinians are among the most educated and entrepreneurial people in the Arab world. Yet economic progress was disappointingly slow in the first years after the Oslo peace agreement. Official corruption, Israeli military blockades of Palestinian towns and uncertainty about the future all worked to discourage investment and disrupt commerce. Several years ago, promising signs of improvement appeared, helped by aid from the United States, the European Union, the Arab League and international organizations. Industrial parks and malls began to sprout, including some financed by Palestinian-Americans. There was a successful casino in Jericho and a new airport in Gaza. 
These gains have been obliterated by the past 19 months of conflict, with the greatest damage concentrated in the past two weeks. Yasir Arafat bears much of the blame. Now Israel claims to have proof that he has not only failed to oppose terrorism but has directly authorized it. Still, Israeli military tactics are responsible for much of the civilian destruction. 
While the ostensible goal of Israel's offensive is capturing terrorists and uprooting their organizations, it has resulted in a prolonged siege affecting hundreds of thousands of civilians trying to go about their everyday lives. Mr. Sharon needs to make it clear to his commanders that Palestinian civilians are not Israel's enemy and that their lives, livelihoods and property deserve respect.
Better yet, with Secretary of State Colin Powell in Israel, Mr. Sharon should belatedly heed President Bush's call for immediate withdrawal. Continuing this offensive may yield more terrorist arrests, but at grievous cost to Israel's long-term interests.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
A Turnabout for North Jersey Rentals

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
A 41-story, 538-unit rental complex atop the Palisades cliffs in Fort Lee, N.J., is the latest addition to the Hudson River waterfront in Bergen County. The complex, called the Palisades, opened for leasing last month at a time when industry professionals say there is a surfeit of rentals on the waterfront stretch from Edgewater to Fort Lee. 
 It joins several local developments under way or completed in the last few years that total over 2,000 rental apartments. And the number of existing vacant rentals has grown to 200 from 3 in February 2001, according to Lennard Schwartz-Charles, owner of Smart Realty of Edgewater, who cited figures from the Multiple Listing Service of New Jersey. 
 Leasing has slowed and developers are offering concessions, like a month's free rent, which will further hold down rents that in the last year dropped by 15 percent, Mr. Charles said. 
"The number of vacant units in some of the newer buildings is scary," he added. "Developers have to pull out all the bells and whistles to get tenants."
The developers of the Palisades, the Applied Development Company of Hoboken in partnership with Vornado Realty Trust of Saddle Brook, said its size and location, less than a quarter of a mile from the George Washington Bridge, will distinguish it from its competitors, as will what they call its condominium-style amenities and finishes. The developers are also offering one month's rent free.
Costas Kondylis of Manhattan designed the complex, which has a 12-story base that contains 80 more units and a 1,008-car garage. On top of one part of the base is a 29-story tower with 438 units and on another part are 20 town house-style apartments.
"The long-term fundamentals are strong for high-end luxury rentals in Fort Lee, where most towers are condos or co-ops," said Allen F. Goldman, a senior vice president of Applied Development Company. "We created a viable alternative for people who don't want to buy and who want to live outside Manhattan."
So far nearly 100 of the one- to three-bedroom apartments have been leased for $30 a square foot a year, Mr. Goldman said. He added that 18 percent of the renters are from Manhattan, where, he said, a comparable apartment would lease for $50 to $55 a square foot. 
The units, including penthouses, have 756 to 1,796 square feet and rent for $1,795 to $8,950 a month. The 20 town houses, with 2,148 to 2,326 square feet, rent for $5,500 to $8,900. Amenities include a 1.4-acre landscaped plaza, a health club and outdoor pool.
The only other new rental project in the last 25 years in Fort Lee is the 351-unit Avalon Crest, which opened on an inland site in 1999. Its developer, AvalonBay Communities, based in Alexandria, Va., is now leasing a second project, with 408 apartments in two four-story buildings on River Road in Edgewater. 
"While the oversupply has caused a bottleneck in leasing, it will ease," said Stella M. Madison, a senior portfolio director at Avalon, noting that her company was offering a month's rent free.
Monthly rents for the one- to three-bedroom units at Avalon Crest are $1,710 to $2,520. Its occupancy rate has crept to 92 percent after falling to 88 percent last fall, Ms. Madison said.
At Avalon at Edgewater, the one- to three-bedroom apartments have 766 to 1,316 square feet and rent for $1,727 to $2,922 a month. While "leasing is not going gangbusters, we are meeting our expectations," she said, noting that 261 of the 408 apartments have been rented since leasing began last year.
On the water side of River Road in Edgewater there are two rental complexes that also offer retail space. One, called the Edgewater Towne Centre, with 64 units atop 74,000 square feet of stores, is complete; construction of the other, the Promenade, is under way and it will ultimately have 434 rentals, 54 condominiums and 160,000 square feet of retail space, assuming the market for rental housing is strong enough. The developer of both is G. Heller Enterprises of Edgewater. 
The Promenade came under scrutiny last summer by state environmental regulators concerned over how the site was being simultaneously developed and cleaned of pollution. Construction is proceeding as the developer and state officials hammer out a cleanup plan, both sides said. 
Monthly rents at Edgewater Towne Centre are $1,300 to $2,200 for studios to two-bedroom units with 720 to 1,125 square feet; at the Promenade they are $1,800 to $2,600 for the 108 completed, one- and two-bedroom rentals with 850 to 1,450 square feet on a pier. The 326 rentals under way on the site's uplands are similar in size and price, said Tod Heller, vice president for marketing and leasing at Heller Enterprises.
The hope is that the economy will improve when the rentals are completed later this year, he said, but it is possible that some or all the units at the two projects will be switched to condominiums, which currently have a stronger market.

HEADLINE: Enclave Links Its Political Fate to Its Rich History 

BYLINE:  By SHAILA K. DEWAN 

 BODY:
No one has ever seen a State Assembly district line drawn on the ground. And yet they can seem as real as fences. At a recent round of redistricting hearings, people from all over the state fought to move their lines, citing reasons as diverse as racial balance and the omission of a particular park or school.
 But the tiny neighborhood of Vinegar Hill, which consists of just a few blocks of 19th-century row houses that emerge from the industrial buildings and parking lots near the Brooklyn Navy Yard like a ghost town in the desert, found an argument that redistricting officials said they had not heard before. It wanted to stay with other districts that are concerned with historic preservation. 
 Residents wrote letters, appeared at a hearing with a poster-sized color map and submitted a historic booklet on the waterfront. A Brooklyn newspaper took to calling the current district's assemblywoman, Joan L. Millman, "Brownstone Joan."
Ms. Millman's district encompasses Brooklyn's oldest neighborhoods, of which Vinegar Hill -- named for a battle against the British in Ireland -- is one. It includes six city-designated historic districts including Brooklyn Heights and Fulton Ferry Landing, where Brooklyn farmers once shuttled their produce to Manhattan.
Another neighborhood in the district, Dumbo (which stands for Down Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass), is on the state and national registers of historic places.
The argument for preserving a historic district has been made at least once before, Ms. Millman said. In 1982, Brooklyn Heights, which was the first neighborhood in the city to be made a historic district, fought off redistricting proposals to divide it in two.
Representing historic districts can be difficult, she said, although she quickly added that she welcomed the challenge. "People tend to be very civic minded, very community minded, and they reach out to their elected officials," she said. "They have a concern, they pick up the phone and tell you what it is, and they expect you to do something about it."
Gary Vanderputten, a resident of Fulton Ferry Landing, said Ms. Millman has supported their preservation efforts. "We are always fighting the same battles, always on the same side," he said.
The Legislature's first redistricting proposal would have severed Vinegar Hill, lumping it with Fort Greene, Williamsburg and Greenpoint, which include two historic districts but are communities of a different character.
Vinegar Hill and its neighbors in Dumbo and Fulton Ferry argued that they belonged together. And in a process often fueled by political self-preservation, the arguments seemed authentic, said Assemblyman William Parment, who heads the redistricting process for the Assembly.
Those neighborhoods were once the bustling working-class heart of Brooklyn, said Marcia Reiss, who is writing a series of neighborhood guides for the Brooklyn Historical Society.
It was there, Ms. Reiss said, that Walt Whitman worked as a newspaper editor for The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, that the men who built the Brooklyn Bridge signed their charter, that the smell of roasting coffee beans once filled the air, and it was there that children used to linger outside the Eskimo Pie factory in hopes of ice cream alms. After World War II, when the Navy Yard's activity slowed and the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway cut off the area, it went into decline.
The area's current residents have worked together to control development and influence the design of a planned waterfront park.
"We don't want a South Street Seaport kind of development in our neighborhood," said Per-Olof Odman, a retired photographer. He and his wife, Monique Denoncin, began the effort to preserve the last remnants of Vinegar Hill after a 19th-century gothic church across the street from their house was demolished in 1992.
"We want a more cultural, historical development," Mr. Odman said. "The state and the city can help us largely in making sure that it doesn't become too commercial."
When the Legislature released its new plan this week, Vinegar Hill and its neighbors were reunited.
Given that only 150 people live in Vinegar Hill, it was likely to be one of the easier requests for the redistricting task force to grant. Still, the success surprised and delighted historians and preservationists.
"So often," said Simeon Bankoff, the executive director of the Historic Districts Council, "district lines are broken up along economic lines or along racial lines." He said, "Preservation has become a demographic" -- like race or class -- and it "is really kind of exciting."

HEADLINE: Fuel Costs Push Imports Higher 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11 

 BODY:
Prices of goods imported into the United States in March rose at the fastest pace in a year and a half, the Labor Department reported today, led by a surge in the cost of oil.
 A 1.1 percent increase in the import price index reflected the biggest gain in energy costs since April 1999, the department said. 
It followed a 0.1 percent decline in February. 
 "A larger share of households' wallets will go to energy at the expense of other types of goods," said Lynn Reaser, chief economist at Banc of America Capital Management in St. Louis. That "will damp overall economic growth," she said, "but shouldn't push us back into recession."
Unemployment may also keep spending from picking up. The number of workers continuing to collect state jobless benefits in the last week was the most since March 1983, a separate Labor Department report showed. Continuing claims rose to 3.78 million, up from 3.63 million the week before.
Applications for benefits have been inflated since mid-March by a law permitting unemployed workers whose 26 weeks of assistance had run out to apply for an additional 13 weeks of help. Initial jobless claims, which rose by 103,000 in the two weeks after the legislation was passed, fell by 55,000, to 438,000, in the week ended Saturday.
In the import price report, an index excluding energy costs was unchanged in March after a 0.4 percent decline in February. That gauge of import prices has not risen for 14 months. "Outside of oil, inflation still looks pretty tame," said James O'Sullivan, a senior economist at UBS Warburg in Stamford, Conn.
The March rise in import prices was the largest since a 1.2 percent increase in September 2000.

HEADLINE: Israelis and Arabs: Time to Start Anew 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 "Attacks Turn Palestinian Plans Into Bent Metal and Piles of Dust" (front page, April 11) puts the lie to the Palestinians' claim that they were getting nothing out of the Oslo process. As you point out, the economy of the West Bank was beginning to flourish, with large international investment and a 6 percent rate of growth. 
 Yasir Arafat put a halt to that progress when he turned his back on peace at Camp David and resumed the violence. It is sad that average Palestinians must pay the price for the folly of their leaders.
It will be to everyone's gain if the Palestinians can find a leader who truly seeks peace. When that happens, Israelis will extend a hand to help them rebuild their society.

DAN FENDEL
Piedmont, Calif., April 11, 2002

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Expert Lists Goals of a Microsoft Penalty

BYLINE:  By AMY HARMON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11 

 BODY:
Antitrust sanctions against the Microsoft Corporation should seek to repair the damage the company's illegal conduct did to competition and consumers in addition to preventing a repetition of its misdeeds, an economics expert told a federal judge yesterday.
 Prof. Carl Shapiro, an economist who served as the expert witness for nine states seeking broader regulations of Microsoft's business practices, spelled out for the first time in the current hearing the economic rationale behind several of the states' proposals. 
 "We simply cannot replicate the powerful combination of factors that threatened Microsoft's Windows monopoly six years ago," Professor Shapiro said. "The clear implication: A broader remedy is required to truly restore competition." 
But Professor Shapiro conspicuously withheld his support from the states' proposal that Microsoft be forced to let computer makers remove various Microsoft programs from the Windows operating system, a remedy that the states have promoted perhaps more aggressively than any other.
"You don't believe the unbinding remedy proposed by the states will help competition?" asked Microsoft's lawyer, Michael Lacovara.
"It's a difficult call; I don't know the answer," replied Mr. Shapiro, an economics professor at the University of California at Berkeley who served as the deputy assistant attorney general for economics during the Clinton administration.
The hearing follows an appeals court ruling last June that Microsoft illegally stifled nascent threats to its monopoly in computer operating systems posed by the Netscape Web browser and the Java programming language of Sun Microsystems.
Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly of the Federal District Court must decide whether to approve a settlement endorsed earlier by Microsoft, the Justice Department and nine other states, or adopt the more restrictive proposals of the coalition of state attorneys general still pursuing the four-year-old antitrust case.
Professor Shapiro argued that the court should impose rules that would lower the barrier to competition in the operating system market by approximately the same amount that Microsoft's illegal acts had raised it.
To that end, he said he supported requiring Microsoft to release the source code to its Internet Explorer browser and to license its popular word processing and spreadsheet programs to run on other operating systems like Linux. 
He also advocated a "parity principle" that would require Microsoft to publish information about Windows that would ensure that rivals in new technologies can develop software that works as well with Microsoft's operating system as the company's own programs.
The virtue of such a regime, Professor Shapiro said, is that consumers would benefit from the pressure on Microsoft to innovate, whether or not competition was restored.
But Mr. Lacovara accused Professor Shapiro of advocating a form of "rough justice." The appeals court had found that the Netscape browser and Java were only potential threats to the operating system, Mr. Lacovara argued, and since it was impossible to measure how much damage Microsoft had done to competition, there was no rationale for a broad remedy.
"There is no direct evidence in this case on which you have relied that any of the unlawful conduct taken by Microsoft had an effect on its monopoly power," Mr. Lacovara said.
In his written testimony, Professor Shapiro characterized that position as "extreme," arguing that to assume that Microsoft's current monopoly position was unaffected by its illegal acts disregarded the findings of the appeals court that Netscape and Java showed potential as threats to the operating system.
Yesterday, Professor Shapiro acknowledged that there was no way to know what would have happened had Microsoft not acted illegally. But he noted that Netscape and Java had had momentum: "The nature of these markets is that when these things take off they can really go and when they get knocked off, they can really crash," Professor Shapiro said. "I think something significant is needed, and I don't think the Microsoft remedy gets us anywhere near there."
When hearings resume Monday, Microsoft will continue to question Professor Shapiro before beginning to call its own witnesses. Bill Gates, chairman of Microsoft, is expected to testify before the hearings end next month.

HEADLINE: University of Arkansas Receives $300 Million Pledge 

BYLINE:  By JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
The University of Arkansas announced yesterday that it had received a commitment for a $300 million gift from the Walton family, heirs of the founder of the Wal-Mart chain. The donation would more than double the size of the university's endowment (most recently valued at $234 million) and is believed to be the largest contribution pledged to a public university.
 University officials said they planned to use the gift to create an honors college at the main Fayetteville campus to attract top undergraduates who might otherwise choose universities outside the state, and to strengthen graduate programs in disciplines like business, engineering and basic sciences. 
 "What the Walton family has done today will improve life in Arkansas for generations to come," the university chancellor, John A. White, said in a statement. "Our state cannot compete in a global economy without a better-educated citizenry." 
Mr. White said Arkansas ranked 49th among the 50 states in the percentage of adults with bachelor's and advanced degrees.
Rob Walton, the chairman of Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and a 1966 graduate of the university, said in a statement that the gift, made by his family's charitable foundation, was intended "to improve the standard of living for everyone" in the state and "to develop a vibrant social and cultural life as well."
Wal-Mart, which was founded by Rob Walton's father, Sam, is based in Bentonville, Ark.
The gift, if received in full, would eclipse the $250 million worth of stock committed to the University of Colorado in 2001 by William T. Coleman III, the chairman of BEA Systems Inc., and his wife, Claudia. The Chronicle of Higher Education ranks that commitment as the largest private gift to a public university. It also would eclipse the $150 million bequeathed this year to the University of Texas by John A. Jackson, a retired oil industry executive.
The largest donation pledged to a private institution, the Chronicle says, is $600 million, which was promised last year to the California Institute of Technology by Gordon Moore, the longtime chairman of the Intel Corporation, and his wife, Betty.
Arkansas officials said the Walton gift would enable them to increase the undergraduate enrollment of the Fayetteville campus to 17,000, from 12,500, by 2010. About 2,000 of those students, recruited from both within the state and without, would be enrolled at the proposed honors college, and nearly all would be absolved of paying the $10,000 that the university charges Arkansas residents for annual tuition, room and board.
"Wherever they come from," the university said in a news release, "their matriculation at the University of Arkansas greatly increases the likelihood that they will live in Arkansas after graduation."

GRAPHIC: Photo: John A. White, chancellor the University of Arkansas, yesterday announced a $300 million pledge from the family of Wal-Mart's founder. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Sales Lag Nestle's Goal for Quarter 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, April 11 

 BODY:
Nestle S.A., the world's biggest food and beverage company, said today that its first-quarter sales had increased but not by as much as the company had hoped. The disappointing report took the luster off the company's stock, which had been among the best performing in Switzerland.
 Over all, Nestle said, sales were $13.1 billion, up 10.1 percent from the first quarter of 2001, but three-quarters of the increase came from the acquisition of Ralston Purina, the American pet food maker. Excluding acquisitions, currency effects and price changes, the company said, sales were 3.3 percent higher than a year ago. 
 "We are confident that we will again reach our real internal growth target of 4 percent, and that Nestle will once more improve sales and profits for 2002," the company's chief executive, Peter Brabeck, told shareholders at the company's annual meeting in Lausanne. 
Nestle, based in Vevey, Switzerland, has a worldwide stable of brands including Nestea teas, Taster's Choice and Nescafe coffees and Kit Kat candy bars. Its pet care division nearly doubled in size when it bought Ralston Purina of St. Louis for $11.2 billion last year.
The deal, engineered by Mr. Brabeck, has positioned Nestle to become the largest global pet food maker. Nestle entered the industry in 1985 by buying the Friskies cat food brand and added Alpo in 1994 and Spillers of Britain in 1998. 
Relatively new business lines like bottled water were the brightest spots in the quarter for Nestle, where it posted better performance than its rival, Unilever of the Netherlands. 
Nestle's water sales rose 12 percent, to $10.5 billion, riding the tide of American demand for its well-known brands, including Perrier, Poland Spring, San Pelegrino and Vittel. 
Older business lines performed much more weakly. 
Sales of its traditional chocolate and confectionery products increased 1.3 percent, to $1.6 billion, while sales of ready-made foods and cooking aids rose 4.4 percent. The division that sells dairy products, ice cream and baby food recorded a 5.6 percent increase, but much of it came from buying out its partner in a joint venture to distribute Haagen-Dazs ice cream in the United States.
Alcon, Nestle's eye-care company in America, chalked up an 11 percent increase in revenue in the quarter, to $783 million. Last month, Nestle raised about $3 billion by selling almost a quarter of Alcon in an initial offering on the New York Stock Exchange.
Food processing companies like Nestle are often favored by investors when the economic climate is weak because demand for their products is seen as relatively recession-proof. 
But analysts said today that Nestle's report signaled that consumer spending was soft in much of the developed world. Its shares fell 1.3 percent, to 375 Swiss francs ($226) in trading today in Switzerland.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Nestle shareholders attending the annual meeting yesterday in Lausanne, Switzerland, were told the company was confident that it would improve sales and reach its goal of 4 percent growth this year. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: End the Options Game 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Leave Options Alone" (Op-Ed, April 5), by John Doerr and Frederick W. Smith: What if, in the mid-1990's, accounting-rule makers had not caved in to lobbyists and instead had forced companies to recognize options as a compensation expense on financial statements? 
 There would still have been a technology boom, a bear market and a period of recession. 
Such cycles are immutable. But there may have been less of the accounting gamesmanship that is now the object of government investigation and investor ire. 
Options should count as an expense to the corporation, and the ability to exercise them should be based on stock performance that exceeds an index of peers.

STEPHEN BARR
Metuchen, N.J., April 5, 2002

The writer is senior contributing editor of CFO magazine.

HEADLINE: Who Controls Schools: Fight Eases, on the Surface 

BYLINE:  By ABBY GOODNOUGH and JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Over the last few days, the debate over whether Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg should gain control of the school system has seemingly cooled to a simmer, with City Hall and the Legislature both claiming to have ceded ground and predicting a deal in the near future.
 But in fact, several large obstacles remain. Even as Mr. Bloomberg and Sheldon Silver, the Assembly speaker, put a sanguine public face on the negotiations this week, other players are maneuvering behind the scenes to ensure their political needs are taken care of in whatever deal comes to pass. Those players -- including the Black, Puerto Rican and Hispanic Legislative Caucus and Randi Weingarten, president of the city teachers' union -- may well try to stall or quash a deal if it does not serve their purposes. 
 Everyone remotely involved -- from state lawmakers to City Council members, from city business leaders to labor unions -- wants to be able to claim victory. The question is whether Mr. Silver and Mr. Bloomberg can persuade the various stakeholders -- or whether the stakeholders can persuade them -- that certain goals can be abandoned in the interest of 1.1 million schoolchildren.
"I'm not taking out the Champagne yet," said Eva S. Moskowitz, chairwoman of the Council's Education Committee, who is pressuring both sides to allow a weakened Board of Education with a limited policy-making role. "I think there was good news this week, but it's still tenuous and could still unravel."
Yesterday, leaders of the Black, Puerto Rican and Hispanic Legislative Caucus were smarting over Mr. Silver's public statements that he no longer expected Mr. Bloomberg to promise not to cut the city's share of the schools budget.
Many state legislators, especially those representing poor inner-city neighborhoods, have insisted that any deal include such an assurance. They say the city often uses even small increases in state education aid as an excuse to trim its own share of school financing.
Assemblyman Roger L. Green, the chairman of the caucus, said yesterday that a refusal by Mr. Bloomberg to protect education spending from one year to the next could be "a deal breaker." The caucus members want either a tightening of the current state law that assures "maintenance of effort" on the city's part, Mr. Green said, or the city to dedicate its yearly education aid from the state to a fund used only for instruction, not for school administration. Mr. Bloomberg dislikes both proposals because he fears they would dangerously limit spending flexibility, especially during tough economic times.
"We honestly believe there is not any vote to do the things the mayor wants if there is no commitment on money," Mr. Green said in an interview. 
While it is unclear just how much clout Mr. Green and his caucus have in this debate, they were instrumental in blocking a coup attempt against Mr. Silver in 2000, and as a result, Mr. Silver is unlikely to go against their wishes. Mr. Bloomberg, too, is clearly trying to win Mr. Green and other caucus members to his cause: the mayor yesterday visited Benjamin Banneker Academy, a high school that Mr. Green helped start in Fort Greene.
While Mr. Green said he was honored by the mayor's visit to Banneker, he said he was not pleased with the answers Mr. Bloomberg offered students who asked -- perhaps at the urging of parents and lawmakers -- why he had proposed cutting the schools budget by $358 million.
"The students would say, 'You're cutting the schools budget,' and the mayor would respond, 'Yes, but I'm cutting everything,' " Mr. Green said. "In the African-American communities I represent, that's not acceptable. The people believe that the schools should always be the exception to the rule."
In another behind-the-scenes conflict, aides to Mr. Bloomberg and Mr. Silver are still wrangling over what powers and how many members a reconfigured board should have, and even what the board should be called. The mayor wants any board's role to be "advisory," a word that makes state legislative leaders see red. They want a board to "set policy," a phrase that irritates the Bloomberg administration, because lawmakers have yet to define the difference between policy-making and administrative control.
Ms. Moskowitz and Gifford Miller, the Council speaker, are pushing a compromise that would expand the board from 7 to 11 members -- five appointed by the borough presidents, the majority by the mayor -- but allow it to vote only on broad policy changes, not specific administrative actions. The problem then becomes defining in legislation what constitutes a broad policy change.
"It's important to get the law right and not write it up some night at midnight," Ms. Moskowitz said. "We can't say on paper that the mayor has control, but in effect not give it to him."
Yet another potential stumbling block involves the New York City teachers' union, whose members have gone 17 months without a contract. Ms. Weingarten, the union president, is increasingly frustrated that politicians are obsessing over the governance issue instead of working out a teachers' contract. Although she publicly insists that governance and a contract should not be linked, Ms. Weingarten may be pressuring state lawmakers not to yield to Mr. Bloomberg unless his own concessions include a quick resolution to their negotiations.
Ms. Weingarten also has reason to push legislators to extract a promise from Mr. Bloomberg not to cut the schools budget: if the $358 million in proposed cuts go through, the school system will have less money to grant teachers a raise.
Ms. Weingarten, who was backed up this week by a fact-finding panel that recommended a 15 percent raise over 27 months, indicated on Wednesday that she indeed feared being left out in the cold if and when a governance deal was reached.
"Governance and the contract should not be tied together, but they should be proceeding on separate but parallel tracks," she said on Wednesday. "The mayor is a smart, agile guy who is capable of multitasking, so I'm sure he can do both at the same time."

HEADLINE: Ex-Official's Sizable Expenses Renew Debate About Controls 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
The inquiry into whether a politically connected Giuliani appointee improperly charged up to a quarter of a million dollars in expenses to a city housing corporation has raised new questions about the level of public scrutiny that such corporations receive.
 The appointee under investigation, Russell A. Harding, was the president of the New York City Housing Development Corporation, a public benefit corporation with the power to provide tax-exempt financing for low- and middle-income housing. 
 Such public benefit corporations, which have multiplied in recent decades, are neither fish nor fowl: they are created by government, often to do the work of government, but they are not bound by all the checks and balances of government.
"These quasi-governmental agencies have proliferated, and still appear to be doing public functions without public accountability," said Peter Bienstock, a former executive director of the state's Commission on Government Integrity, which published a 1990 report, "Underground Government," on the corporations. 
So who has oversight? Both the city comptroller's office and the state comptroller's office have the power to audit the housing corporation, but because it is not a city or state agency, neither is required to. The city comptroller's office last audited the housing corporation in 1983, the state comptroller's office in 1990.
And although the corporation is required by state law to file an audited annual report with the city comptroller within 90 days of the end of its fiscal year, which is Oct. 31, it has yet to file its 2001 report, officials said yesterday. Sarah Miles, a spokeswoman for the corporation, said the report was late because it can take the corporation 90 days to get its financial statements audited by Ernst & Young, its auditor.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the case highlights the need to reexamine the safeguards at the agency.
"I think that even the allegations -- and who knows how the investigation is going to turn out -- give us new impetus to make sure that we have appropriate safeguards in place and enough scrutiny and auditing capabilities to make sure that the public gets government that is honest, and spending their moneys wisely," he said.
The Housing Development Corporation has found itself under a great deal of scrutiny since Tuesday, when The Village Voice reported that its former president, Mr. Harding, had filed more than $250,000 in expenses ranging from stays in four-star hotels, fancy meals and expensive gifts for friends to his morning bagels.
The report prompted an inquiry by the city's Department of Investigation, officials said.
Mr. Harding was appointed to his post in 1998 by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani although he had not completed college and had no housing experience. Because his father, Raymond B. Harding, the leader of the Liberal Party, was one of Mr. Giuliani's most important supporters, his appointment was criticized as a patronage hire.
Russell Harding issued a statement saying that he has reimbursed the corporation for more than $50,000 in expenses, and that he will repay more if needed.
It is far from clear whether the questionable expense filings would have been caught in a government audit. And information about the housing corporation is not hard to come by; data is readily accessible on its Web site, www.nychdc.com, where, even though the 2001 annual report is late, its audited financial statement for 2001 can be found.
But several government watchdogs said yesterday that the case highlights the lack of oversight of public benefit corporations in general. That lack of oversight is, in a way, part of their reason for being.
Governments often create public benefit corporations using the argument that their tasks -- stimulating housing, or economic development, or whatever they may be -- cannot be performed efficiently by heavily regulated government agencies.
But government watchdog groups have long complained that such corporations still need more oversight. The 1990 "Underground Government" report said the corporations are generally exempt from controls designed to prevent abuses ranging from favoritism to "corruption, fraud, waste and misuse of government funds."

HEADLINE: Generals Revolt in Venezuela After 10 Protesters Are Killed 

BYLINE:  By JUAN FORERO 

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Friday, April 12 

 BODY:
A group of high-ranking generals broke ranks Thursday night to demand the resignation of President Hugo Chavez after at least 10 people were killed and more than 100 wounded when hundreds of thousands of protesters marched on the presidential palace. 
 Among those who rebelled was the army commander, Gen. Efrain Vasquez Velasco. "Mr. President, I was loyal to the end, but today's deaths cannot be tolerated," he said in a news conference this evening. 
 Late Thursday night, a National Guard general, Alberto Camacho Kairuz, announced that Mr. Chavez's government was out of power and that the armed forces were now in control of the country, one of the top suppliers of oil to the United States.
"The government has abandoned its functions," he said. But early this morning it was unclear who was actually in charge.
Mr. Chavez, a mercurial left-leaning leader whose policies had antagonized much of Venezuelan society, had appeared on national television on Thursday, defiantly telling viewers he would remain in power. 
Early this morning the 24-hour television news station, Globovision, reported that Mr. Chavez had reached out to military officials to negotiate the terms of his resignation.
Local news reports also said that a number of top government ministers had resigned, among them the defense minister, Jose Vicente Rangell, and the finance minister, Gen. Francisco Uson Ramirez.
In the heart of Caracas, young men who support Mr. Chavez roamed the streets Thursday night carrying large sticks and bottles, which they threw at passing cars. It appeared that they were positioned to prevent outsiders from passing along the trash-strewn streets to Miraflores, the presidential palace.
Earlier, Mr. Chavez, in an improvised address that was televised nationally in the midst of pitched street battles between police and demonstrators, scoffed at the possibility that he could be ousted from power. But as he embarked on a long, rambling speech, popular opposition and disgust with his administration was swelling in the wake of the violence against the antigovernment protesters.
The bloodshed came on the third day of a general strike called by labor and business leaders against Mr. Chavez, a populist whose autocratic style had turned much of Venezuela against him in recent months.
It brought a sudden and sharp escalation to Venezuela's turmoil, which had already contributed to wild swings in world oil prices this week. Venezuela, Latin America's only OPEC member, is the world's fourth-largest oil producer and supplies about 15 percent of oil imports to the United States. 
Mr. Chavez also outraged Venezuelans when he ordered five private television stations shut down, charging that they were inciting violence by broadcasting news about the protests. Tanks and troops were then seen moving throughout the outskirts of the city.
In his televised address on Thursday, the president played down the troubles and accused private television stations of urging Venezuelans to try to oust him. At least one of the five stations that he had ordered closed continued to broadcast images of the protests.
"They have put themselves outside the law to instigate violence, knowing there is an insurrectional plan, a crazy plan, a diabolic plan, an irrational plan," said Mr. Chavez, wearing a suit and tie and sitting at a desk with a portrait of the South American liberator, Simon Bolivar, behind him.
In his monologue, Mr. Chavez questioned the strength of the strike, saying, "What stoppage?" But then, alluding to the protesters in the streets, he said, "I am worried about the situation, of course. How could I not be?"
The president said he had ordered troops to surround the presidential palace, "to have a cushion" to protect people inside and pro-government protesters just outside.
By late Thursday afternoon, confusion and panic reigned in the streets of Caracas.
Police threw tear gas canisters to disperse demonstrators and shots started to ring out, some apparently from rooftops. Venezuelan television showed plainclothes gunmen firing wildly, using semiautomatic handguns, as people scrambled in fear through streets shrouded by the police tear gas.
Gen. Carlos Martinez of the National Guard said in a news conference that his troops had witnessed the shootings. He said the gunmen who had fired on the protesters were from the Bolivarian Circles, pro-government neighborhood groups.
"They used violence on the other protesters," he said.
The mayor of Caracas, Alfredo Pena, a strident opponent of the president, said the government had "unleashed their Dobermans," charging that the gunmen came from the pro-Chavez district of Libertador.
"They began to shoot like they were hunting, just firing away," Mr. Pena said in a televised interview.
Many of the wounded, shot as they ran through the streets, were taken to the Jose Maria Vargas Hospital in downtown Caracas, a trauma center that was filled with bloodied protesters and frantic doctors. 
"We had a complete collapse," said Dr. Pablo Rausseo, the emergency room chief, late in the night as things calmed down. "We were not prepared for so many hurt people." He said, however, that the emergency room's regular team of 10 doctors was beefed up to 60 with the arrival of doctors from other hospitals.
Pedro Aristimuno, the secretary of health for metropolitan Caracas, said that 10 people who suffered mortal wounds in the fracas were brought into the Vargas hospital. "What we noticed was that the most serious wounds were in the cranium and cheek," he said in an interview. "They appeared to be shots from above."
After the violence, a group of generals and other high-ranking officers held a news conference to call for Mr. Chavez to step down. "We cannot allow a tyrant to run the Republic of Venezuela," said Navy Vice Adm. Hector Rafael Ramirez.
The strike organizers calling the work stoppage were angered by Mr. Chavez's management changes at Petroleos de Venezuela, the state-owned oil behemoth that is the economic pillar of the country. The strike shuttered many of Venezuela's offices and factories and severely hobbled the oil company.
Mr. Chavez's defiant refusal to talk with the protesters, whom he called "traitors" and "subversives," further antagonized his opponents.
"Chavez get out!" Carlos Ortega, president of the million-member Venezuelan Workers Confederation, shouted in a street rally. "We do not want you! We reject you!"
Mr. Chavez seemed to give his opponents a peace offering at the end of his televised talk, announcing the creation of two commissions to deal with the conflict at Petroleos de Venezuela and to address other concerns about his government.
Pedro Carmona, leader of the powerful Fedecamaras business group, and Mr. Ortega, the labor confederation president, were meeting into the evening and had not responded to the president's announcement.
Observers, though, said that they did not believe that there could be a negotiated solution now.
In an unusual announcement, Gen. Lucas Rincon, the armed forces chief, went on national television Thursday afternoon and denied rumors that Mr. Chavez had been asked to resign by the military or was in the custody of the army.
"The situation in the country is normal," said General Rincon. "We call on the Venezuelan people to maintain calm."

HEADLINE: Elton John Plays the Capitol, for AIDS Money 

BYLINE:  By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11 

 BODY:
First came Bono. Now, Elton John.
 Continuing in the steps of the Irish rock star who dazzled official Washington last month while pleading for more money to fight international poverty and AIDS, Sir Elton swept through Capitol Hill today to prod lawmakers and the Bush administration to increase financing to eradicate the worldwide AIDS epidemic. 
 His hair was the color of a sunburst. His suit was appropriately conservative -- navy blue Versace, complete with matching shoes. (The distinctive gold emblems on the heels were a dead giveaway.)
His hosts, a few of whom received him in a private meeting before he testified in the Senate, were starstruck on a bipartisan basis.
"I've been an admirer for years," said Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the Utah Republican and occasional songwriter, whose own tunes tend toward the religious.
Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, told Sir Elton he was "absolutely fantastic" at a private concert during the recent World Economic Forum in New York. Mr. Leahy then produced an expensive set of Elton John compact discs for the witness to sign.
"A boxed set!" Sir Elton exclaimed, reaching for a pen.
Sir Elton's appearance before the Senate health committee, at the invitation of its chairman, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, came as Congress considers measures that would appropriate anywhere from $500 million to $2.5 billion for the global fight against AIDS next year. 
A spokesman for Mr. Kennedy said the senator wanted to "raise visibility and awareness of this issue" while lawmakers deliberate.
The White House has pledged $800 million in international AIDS spending for 2003, including $200 million to a new global fund to fight AIDS. But Kofi Annan, the secretary general of the United Nations, has said $10 billion a year is needed.
Advocates for people with AIDS and some lawmakers, including Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York, are calling for the United States to contribute a quarter of that, or $2.5 billion a year.
"I don't think we've stepped up and given our fair share," Senator Clinton said today.
Sir Elton, whose Elton John AIDS Foundation has raised $35 million in the last 10 years to help patients in 55 countries, did not mention a specific amount in his testimony today. 
In an interview before his appearance, he said he had never testified in front of a government body before -- "I've never been asked," he explained -- and confessed to being a bit nervous. But he said he would "use my celebrity" if it could do some good.
Later, Sir Elton told the lawmakers that they had a moral obligation to act. 
"No nation, corporation, foundation or individual has the money you have. No one even comes close," he said. "I am no student of government, but I understand there are two ends to Pennsylvania Avenue, and this end controls the money."
Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, replied, "Tell that to the other end."

HEADLINE: Investor Discontent 

BYLINE:  By PATRICK McGEEHAN 

 BODY:
For several months, Wall Street firms and securities regulators have been rewriting the rules of stock research in an effort to regain some of the credibility that evaporated when the technology bubble burst. But suddenly, that patchwork approach looks like it may not hold off the critical masses. 
 The attorney general of New York, Eliot L. Spitzer, is attacking Wall Street's most glaring conflict of interest with a vengeance. In taking on Merrill Lynch, the biggest brokerage firm, he has insisted that more footnotes in research reports will not satisfy him. He wants more distance between investment bankers and the analysts who are supposed to be making independent judgments about stocks. 
 In negotiations with Merrill Lynch's lawyers, Mr. Spitzer and his staff demanded that Merrill split off its research department as a separate unit. Officials at Merrill and other Wall Street firms scoffed at the idea as naive, but Mr. Spitzer has not backed down.
He has pledged to make Henry Blodget, Merrill's former star Internet stock analyst, and others testify in public. He has issued subpoenas to several other firms and has said he might also file criminal fraud charges.
David Pottruck, co-chief executive of Charles Schwab, sees Mr. Spitzer trying to tap into a keg of investor discontent that has been a long time brewing. Mr. Pottruck has been railing for years against the conflicts of the big brokerage houses that Schwab competes with, but even he does not foresee a breakup of the financial conglomerates that have come to dominate Wall Street.
Still, he said, something must be done before investors lose faith. "It's a little disheartening to see companies tout the depths of their wisdom and then put out research that is so incredibly flawed," Mr. Pottruck said. "This doesn't just hurt a company, it hurts our industry. No company, no matter what their business model, is immune from the dissatisfaction, mistrust and disappointment investors are feeling. We see it as investors' being angry."
Mr. Pottruck said he did not expect the sort of wholesale changes that Mr. Spitzer was calling for, but he said more change was needed to assuage irate investors.
That rage has not yet registered with everyone on Wall Street. Yesterday, as Merrill was being granted another week to make court-ordered changes to its stock reports, the industry's main trade group was arguing against proposed reforms.
Stuart Kaswell, general counsel of the Securities Industry Association, said the group was preparing to weigh in against a proposed requirement from securities regulators that analysts disclose details of any banking relationships their employers had with the companies they were rating. He said the requirement would be too costly and would not help investors evaluate the research.
It should be sufficient, Mr. Kaswell said, for the firms to state, as many already do, that they may have done or hope to do some investment banking for a particular company. Saying more would run the risk of disclosing confidential information about an investment banking client, which could be illegal, he argued. "Our best answer to that is a plain-English disclosure that says we may have received money from this company and you should know that," Mr. Kaswell said.
Mr. Pottruck disagreed. "I think these new proposals are completely inadequate to solve the problems," he said.
Mr. Spitzer has already persuaded a judge in New York State Supreme Court to make Merrill do more. In an order whose deadline was extended yesterday until the end of next week, Merrill was told to start disclosing whether it had or was seeking financial ties to companies its analysts covered.
Merrill pleaded for more time but has already made some changes. Research notes it published this week included footnotes about opinions the firm had been paid to deliver on the fairness of certain mergers and acquisitions.
Those footnotes were probably not read as widely as the internal e-mail messages Mr. Spitzer collected and filed with the court on Monday. Mr. Spitzer said the messages showed that Merrill analysts had much more negative opinions about companies' prospects than they were sharing with Merrill customers. They caught analysts discussing the pressure they felt to overrate companies that Merrill had landed or hoped to land as investment banking clients.
That conflict has been apparent to Wall Street insiders and some sophisticated investors for many years. Most major brokerage firms -- including Merrill, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, Salomon Smith Barney and UBS PaineWebber -- live under the same roof with investment banks. 
Despite what Mr. Spitzer called "dramatic evidence" to the contrary, Mr. Kaswell insisted that most analysts were unbiased and that securities firms knew better than to risk compromising the integrity of research to make more money.
Their research is "the crown jewel of the brands of those firms," Mr. Kaswell said. "It's just not credible to think that senior management would tolerate an institutional pressuring of one of their major franchises to get the next transaction."
Mr. Kaswell said many people, including analysts, became too exuberant about stocks in the late 90's. "That doesn't mean they were corrupt," he said. "It means they were wrong. Being wrong isn't criminal."
Either way, problems are bound to arise when people try to serve two masters, Mr. Pottruck said. He suggested that banks should be banned from distributing research on their corporate clients. "The real issue isn't good or bad people," he said. "The real issue is the organization's DNA."
There is a pervasive conflict, he said, that comes from focusing on the needs of institutional clients while treating brokerage customers as "the end point in a distribution chain of investment products."
Mr. Pottruck said, "Individual investors ought to have certain rights and a system that serves their interests, that's invented around them, that protects them, where they're at the center."

HEADLINE: McCall and Cuomo Pull Back From Council's Call for Taxes 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
The two Democratic candidates for New York governor have distanced themselves from a proposal by City Council Democrats to raise taxes to balance the city's budget and pay for education programs, warning that tax increases might harm the city at a time when it is struggling through difficult fiscal times.
 The remarks by the candidates, H. Carl McCall and Andrew M. Cuomo, put them closer to the views of Michael R. Bloomberg, the Republican mayor, than those of Gifford Miller, the Democratic speaker of the Council. Mr. Bloomberg flatly rejected the Council's proposal for, among other things, an income tax surcharge, reinstitution of a commuter tax, and a tax on alcoholic beverages. The Council urged the steps as a way to head off spending cuts that the mayor has sought. 
 Of the two Democratic candidates seeking the nomination to run against Gov. George E. Pataki, Mr. Cuomo was more definitive in ruling out support for any tax increases. Mr. McCall was more measured, saying he would prefer programs that foster economic development, and thus tax revenues, rather than imposing any increase in tax rates.
"I am not at this time looking at taxes," Mr. McCall said on Tuesday, after winning the support of more than 23 members of the City Council, in response to questions about Mr. Miller's proposal. "I'm looking at other ways of increasing revenue, at this time." 
As for the Council plan, Mr. McCall, who is the state comptroller, said: "I'm looking at their proposal. I know they've come forward with a proposal that's important, but we've got to find the best way to increase revenue in this state." 
Mr. Cuomo was more forceful in rejecting the proposal. Mr. Pataki defeated his father, Mario M. Cuomo, in 1994, by repeatedly painting him as a proponent of high taxes, and the defeat has clearly influenced Mr. Cuomo's own position on issues of taxes and spending.
"We are in a very precarious position right now -- it's still a fragile situation," Mr. Cuomo said, adding: "I think it's the wrong time to come up with a new tax package. People are mobile, people can make decisions, and one of the main factors in making these locational determinations is taxes."
One of the main elements of Mr. Miller's plan was to call on the State Legislature to reinstitute a tax on commuters it eliminated over the objection of New York City officials. While such a step might be popular among some city residents, it would clearly be disliked in the suburbs. In any event, few people believe it has any chance of being reinstated in this election year.
Mr. McCall declined to offer his opinion on whether the tax should be reinstated. 
Mr. Cuomo said he believed ending it was a mistake but would not support reinstating it now.
Mr. Miller, through a spokesman, said he was not concerned with the prospect of both gubernatorial candidates opposing his plan. His chief of staff, Forrest R. Taylor, said, "If any of the gubernatorial candidates, Democrat or Republicans, have another way to tackle this problem, we'd be delighted to hear it."

HEADLINE: ENRON'S MANY STRANDS: THE ENERGY MARKET; 
Enron Trading Gave Prices Artificial Lift, Panel Is Told

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11 

 BODY:
A top California regulator told Congress today that the Enron Corporation engaged in sham transactions in late 2000 that drove up electricity prices and helped worsen the energy crisis that plagued the West for more than a year.
 Testifying to a subcommittee of the Senate Commerce Committee, Loretta Lynch, president of the California Public Utilities Commission, said regulators had studied Enron's actions in the fourth quarter of 2000 and had determined that five subsidiaries traded large volumes of electricity contracts among themselves in an effort to push up prices. 
 Ms. Lynch said the effect of the trading was to set prices throughout the wholesale electricity market in California far above what was justified. "I believe these trades were sham transactions," Ms. Lynch said. The company, she said, "would trade among itself to drive the price up." 
Enron said that it had not manipulated prices and that the problems in California were a result of a flawed deregulation system combined with other factors like a drought in the Northwest and a temporary decline in generating capacity.
"We have and we will continue to cooperate with the committee's investigation," a spokesman for Enron, Mark Palmer, said. "We have cooperated with numerous previous investigations, all of which found that the market structure was the cause of California's energy crisis, not Enron." The committee did not invite Enron to send a representative to the hearing.
Other witnesses from California, including S. David Freeman, the chairman of the California Power Authority; and Joseph Dunn, a state senator who is leading an inquiry into the power crisis, concurred with Ms. Lynch that Enron, with other energy companies, had manipulated prices.
"We must recognize that the so-called invisible hand of Adam Smith was Enron and their fellow gougers picking the pockets of Californians to the tune of billions of dollars," Mr. Freeman said. "Prices were skyrocketing in California in late 2000 and early 2001 as a direct result of Enron's influence and participation."
Today's hearing continued a battle between Enron and many of California's most prominent officeholders and appointees -- most of them Democrats -- over who is to blame for the spike in electricity rates.
The crisis, which eased last summer after the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission intervened, briefly hobbled the state's economy, threw its politics into turmoil and left California taxpayers and consumers with a multibillion-dollar hangover.
Senator Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California, said Enron "used us as a cash cow to keep that company afloat, to keep the stock price high so insiders could cash out."
But some Republicans suggested that Enron was being used as a whipping boy by Californians for their botched effort at deregulating their electricity market. Senator Peter G. Fitzgerald, Republican of Illinois, told the hearing that he was "skeptical" that Enron had anything to do with the problem, which also afflicted other Western states.
Some witnesses at today's hearing said it was difficult to know precisely what Enron's role had been in influencing prices because the data available about transactions in energy markets was hard to interpret.
But they said there was considerable evidence that Enron planned to drive prices up and profit in a variety of ways. Robert McCullough, an energy analyst from Portland, Ore., who has studied Enron's activities, told the panel that the company sold a site for a power plant in Oregon in 1999 in a deal that suggested the company knew electricity prices would rise sharply.
Mr. McCullough said the deal ended with the site being 50 percent owned by LJM2, an investment partnership managed by a senior Enron executive that is at the heart of the problems that pushed the company into bankruptcy protection last year. Internal Enron documents, he said, showed that LJM2 anticipated a 22 percent return on investment from the project even as Enron was telling the Oregon Public Utilities Commission that it expected 15 percent.
"LJM2 apparently was able to either operate in the same markets with vastly more expertise than Enron," Mr. McCullough said, "or LJM2's estimate showed foreknowledge of the events to come."
Ms. Lynch said an examination of electricity trading by Enron affiliates and subsidiaries in the fourth quarter of 2000 showed that about 30 percent of the transactions were among themselves. She said her analysis was based on data supplied by Enron to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. She did not address the possibility that the trades reflected market pressures driving prices upward.
The Enron-related companies -- the New Power Company, Enron Energy Services, Enron Energy Marketing, Enron Power Marketing and Portland General Electric -- traded nearly 12 million megawatt-hours of electricity in the period at prices ranging from 5 cents a megawatt-hour to $3,322 an hour, she said.
A megawatt-hour is enough to run 1,000 room air-conditioners for about an hour. Before deregulation, utilities typically bought and sold electricity at around $30 a megawatt-hour.
"Enron was selling the same megawatts back and forth to itself, causing the price to rise with each sale, all under the rules it had helped to create," Ms. Lynch said in her prepared testimony. "The selling back and forth also created the illusion of an active, volatile market."
Because Enron booked as revenue the value of each trade, the transactions allowed the company "to create false value," she said. And because Enron reported the trades on its online trading system, she said, they created an artificially high benchmark price for other companies buying and selling power. In addition to benefiting directly from the trades at higher prices, she said, Enron profited by creating the appearance that transmission lines would be overburdened by huge flows of electricity among various power sources.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: SANCTIONS; 
How Blocking Assets Erased a Wisp of Prosperity

BYLINE:  By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: MOGADISHU, Somalia 

 BODY:
Al Barakaat's headquarters here is a white three-story building on a street jammed with decrepit trucks and donkey carts, and guarded by young men lounging on the sidewalk with their AK-47's.
 Inside, the first floor is split between the cellphone subsidiary, which now offers only local calls, and the former leading branch of the bank, which is now closed, its tall teller chairs empty behind dusty counters. 
 Ali Bashi Ugas, 40, a jobless former cabby, stood outside. His extended family, he said, used to get up to $500 a month from relatives working as taxi drivers and cooks in America, and now he begs from neighbors to feed his children. 
"Sometimes, we boil water and tell them we are preparing food," he said. "If we get some food, we put it in. If the children fall asleep, we take the pot off the fire."
Al Barakaat is not some shady money-changer; it is Somalia's biggest employer. In a land devastated by civil war and drought, it ran the biggest bank, the biggest phone system and the only water-purification plant.
Though the Bush administration says the company has secret links to Al Qaeda and Osama bin Laden, its open corporate links were to Citibank for money transfers and to AT&T for international calls, and it was negotiating with Coca-Cola to become a bottler.
When Washington froze Al Barakaat's assets, it crippled the company, forcing it to lay off 700 employees. Thousands lost their deposits, and those awaiting money from relatives in Europe and the United States were cut off. 
The United Nations estimates that Somalia received $700 million in remittances a year, while foreign aid from the West, after administrative expenses, amounts to about $25 million a year, Andre Le Sage, a Somalia scholar, estimated.
Hundreds of former doctors, lawyers and engineers whose government jobs disappeared in a decade of civil war found work as Barakaat cashiers and phone technicians, Mr. Le Sage said. They are now jobless. 
"I am a veterinarian, a specialist in anatomy and physiology," said Abdulahi Basto, 47. "I worked at Barakaat for six years. It was a good job -- $600 a month. I have 20 children by three wives. Now I am jobless. I have no ability to feed them."
Even Afghanistan was treated better, he insists.
"Before the U.S. went to bomb," Mr. Basto said, "they sent a message -- give us bin Laden, or we will bomb. But they didn't send any message to us." 
Other banks will not hire him, he said, and Abdullah Nur, local manager for a rival bank, Dahab Shiil, confirmed this. "We don't hire Barakaat employees," Mr. Nur said. "We're afraid of the U.S."
His business was up 35 percent since Barakaat's assets were frozen, Mr. Nur said, and he has opened eight new branches. With his biggest competitor gone, he can charge 5 percent on each money transfer; Al Barakaat charged 3 percent.
The freeze of assets also brought hardship outside the economy.
Malnutrition rates among children in the southern Gedo region were at "very alarming levels" in January, said Laura Melo, a World Food Program spokeswoman, because of a combination of poor rains, a ban on cattle and camel exports for health reasons, runaway inflation and the abrupt cutoff of Al Barakaat remittances.

HEADLINE: Index of Prices At Wholesale Is Up Sharply 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 12 

 BODY:
Sharply higher gasoline costs drove up wholesale prices in March by the largest amount in 14 months, the government reported today. In addition, shoppers, hit by higher energy bills, spent modestly on other items. 
 The government reports released today suggested that the economy was hitting some rough patches. Though many economists believe that the surge in energy prices is temporary and note that oil prices have retreated, the increase helped make consumers less willing to spend. 
 The 1 percent jump in the Labor Department's Producer Price Index, which measures inflation pressures before they reach consumers, followed a 0.2 percent increase in February, and reflected a sharp increase in energy prices, especially gasoline. 
Excluding the volatile energy and food prices, the core rate of wholesale inflation nudged up just 0.1 percent in March after being flat in February, suggesting most other prices are remaining well behaved. For the 12 months ending in March, wholesale prices fell 1.4 percent. 
At the same time, the Commerce Department said, sales at retailers rose a modest 0.2 percent in March for the second consecutive month. 
While the increase was smaller than expected, analysts said it showed that consumers, whose spending accounts for two-thirds of all economic activity in the United States, were still buying. 
Consumers bought electronics and appliances, building and garden supplies and sporting goods. They cut back on cars, home furnishings and clothes, and ate out less often. 
Sales at car dealers fell 0.4 percent last month after rising 0.7 percent in February. Sales at furniture and home furnishings stores fell 0.2 percent after a 1 percent gain.
"The consumer is still buying, but the pace is moderate, not exuberant," said Joel L. Naroff of Naroff Economic Advisors. 
Consumers' confidence in the economy has edged lower, according to the University of Michigan's monthly survey of consumer sentiment, falling to 94.4 in April from 95.7 in March. 
Energy prices accounted for most of the volatility, and concern, in March. The 5.5 percent jump in energy prices was the largest monthly jump since June 2000. Gas prices rose 21.3 percent in March, the biggest jump in nearly three years.
Economists said today's reports raised the odds that the Federal Reserve would wait until after May to begin raising interest rates. Citing signs of a turnaround, the Fed had opted to leave rates alone in January and March.

HEADLINE: NASA Says 2004 Mission Will Include Schoolteacher 

BYLINE:  By WARREN E. LEARY 

 BODY:
Outlining a modest vision for the NASA of the future, the space agency's new administrator said yesterday that it would concentrate on research and education -- including finally sending a schoolteacher into space in 2004.
 Sean O'Keefe, who took over as director of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in December, said the agency needed to return to its fundamentals as a research agency, emphasizing the development of technology that could improve space exploration or promote national security. He called for more science-based exploration of the solar system and for inspiring future scientists and explorers through an education initiative. 
 "What we have done in our vision of the future and its mission road map is to make education a core mission element," he said in a speech at Syracuse University, where he is an alumnus. "This is not only self-sustaining for our own mission, but also a very real necessity for the country if we are to remain economically secure."
Mr. O'Keefe, a former White House budget official, was selected by President Bush with a mandate to straighten out budget problems and improve NASA's management. The visionary language of past administrators was largely absent from his speech.
To emphasize the importance of education and spur young people's interest in space, Mr. O'Keefe said it was time for NASA to complete the unfinished business of sending a teacher into space.
Barbara Morgan, a former third-grade teacher from McCall, Idaho, will be part of a space shuttle mission, and possibly visit the International Space Station, in 2004, he said. Mrs. Morgan, 50, has been in training as an astronaut at the Johnson Space Center in Houston since 1998.
Mrs. Morgan was the backup for Christa McAuliffe, the first teacher-in-space candidate, who died with six other astronauts in the 1986 Challenger explosion. After the accident, the teacher program was canceled, but Mrs. Morgan was admitted as an astronaut candidate in 1998 and designated the first educator mission specialist.
Mr. O'Keefe said the educator program would be expanded and, with the help of the Department of Education, other teachers would be sought to be trained as astronauts who also had expertise in teaching from space or developing new kinds of space-based education programs.
NASA should develop nuclear propulsion technology to speed the flight of spacecraft for deep space exploration, Mr. O'Keefe said, and work with other agencies on earth studies and security issues, such as improving airplane safety and making transportation systems more efficient and secure.
As he has said on other occasions, Mr. O'Keefe said he would push NASA to develop a management style that emphasized competition, ending duplication and promoting better financial accountability. This includes tighter management of the space station program, he said, where American expenditures are more than $4.8 billion over an original $17 billion budget.
Dr. John Logsdon, director of the Space Policy Institute at George Washington University, said Mr. O'Keefe's remarks showed a shift in emphasis at NASA rather than in fundamentals.
"There is more emphasis on earth applications, security in collaboration with other agencies and education and less stress on exotic technologies and far-reaching goals," Dr. Logsdon said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sean O'Keefe, the new administrator of NASA, has outlined his goals for the space agency. (Reuters)
