HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE; 
Showing The Flag Of Culture (Or Not)

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL Z. WISE 

 BODY:
WITH a steeply raked glass facade that appears to fall like the blade of a guillotine, the Austrian Cultural Forum is one of the most striking buildings to have gone up in New York in decades. It's also a dramatic, 24-story, $29 million embodiment of how nations use culture to polish their image.
 Cultural prestige has always followed troops and trade as a measure of a nation's influence. Even when once-great powers lose political and economic dominion, they still yearn to hold sway in the cultural realm. Austria is a prime example: the collapse of the Austro-Hungarian Empire in 1918 may have relegated the surviving Austrian Republic to the bush leagues of international politics, but fervid promotion of its artistic heritage has enabled this small Alpine nation to retain cultural renown. 
 For decades Austria has bankrolled national treasures like the Vienna State Opera, the Vienna Philharmonic and the Salzburg Festival. Now, on Friday, it will dedicate its towering new American outpost, designed by the Austrian-born architect Raimund Abraham. The building, on 52nd Street between Madison and Fifth Avenues, contains galleries, a library and a theater as well as offices. But it doesn't stand alone; it's only the latest in a flurry of gestures by foreign nations to show their cultural bona fides in New York. 
Several countries are opening cultural centers to capture the imagination of the American public and reflect glory back home; still more are lending state support for performances and exhibitions involving their native artists at American institutions.
Yet the phenomenon is mostly one-sided. While many nations have embraced cultural diplomacy and made New York the focal point of it, the United States has been reluctant to use art to communicate American objectives overseas at a time of broad American reach. The end of the cold war and the global scope of satellite broadcasting and the Internet have helped the United States attain not only vast new political power but also an increasingly dominating cultural influence that both attracts and repels. And many officials believe that popular culture can be a potent weapon in the American arsenal, a view cannily underlined by Secretary of State Colin Powell's appearance on MTV in February in which he defended the American campaign against terrorism before a worldwide audience of young people. But American politicians have shown little appetite for using state auspices to export a broader range of American arts than is available through market incentives.
The opposite is happening in Europe. Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway and Sweden have helped finance construction of the new six-story Scandinavia House on Park Avenue, run by a nonprofit foundation as a kind of permanent World's Fair pavilion for Nordic art exhibitions, concerts, lectures and films. Spain will open a $19 million arts center on East 49th Street. The Italian Cultural Institute, now operating out of a stately but shabby 1919 mansion on Park Avenue, plans to move by the end of 2003 to more up-to-date Midtown premises, where it can greatly expand its programming.
The lavishness of these facilities attests to their home countries' belief in the importance of culture as a tool of diplomacy. "It's a powerful way for governments and nations to gain positive attention," says Curtis Barlow, director of cultural affairs for Canada's Department of Foreign Affairs and International Trade. "At the senior level of government, there is a growing recognition of the utility and importance of this kind of work."
Foreign diplomats and arts administrators alike say that using culture for international understanding has taken on heightened significance. "Since Sept. 11, people are more conscious of the fact that we live in one world and that culture can help bridge our differences," said Karen Brooks Hopkins, president of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, one of many New York institutions that benefit from foreign governments' promotional efforts.
Schuyler Chapin, the New York City Commissioner for Cultural Affairs from 1994 to 2001, said: "Propaganda has nasty connotations as a word, but putting a country's strengths and cultural resources in front of people is a very persuasive argument about the legitimacy and general artistic energy that may be found in country X. New York is in many ways the cultural capital of the Western world, so it's natural that countries wishing to represent themselves from the standpoint of cultural life would gravitate to this city."
New York has been a stage for a wealth of foreign-supported cultural initiatives in the last two years. A partial list includes the Lincoln Center Festival performance of the Dutch opera "Writing to Vermeer," a retrospective of the Spanish director Luis Bunuel's films at the Museum of Modern Art, French dance performances at the Joyce Theater, a workshop featuring the German composer Helmut Lachenmann at Columbia University, a symposium on 20th-century Swedish design by the Bard Graduate Center and an evening of Canadian comedy at the 92nd Street Y presented by Michael J. Fox. All were at least partly supported by the nations whose art was on display.
Why would envoys of the Ottawa government help organize an evening of Canadian comedy? "Most people think of Canada in terms of Peter Jennings or cold weather," said Kevin O'Shea, a diplomat who was involved. In an attempt "to get across a more vibrant image," he said, Canada has recently tripled its budget for arts promotion in New York.
The goal of erasing stereotypes comes up repeatedly. Paolo Riani, director of the Italian Cultural Institute, is intent on "presenting an image of the country that is not just Mafia, not just fashion." Flavio Perri, the Brazilian consul general, wants "to show we are more than Carnival."
Explaining why Israel is helping defray the cost of the Batsheva Dance Company's appearance at the Brooklyn Academy of Music later this month, the cultural attache, Ofra Ben-Yaacov, says: "We are too much in the news because of events. It's important to see that we don't only fight, that we have better channels." Max Imgrugh, chairman of the Swiss Institute, which receives part of its financing from the government, aspires "to show that there's more to Switzerland than bank accounts and the Holocaust."
Similar thinking in the mid-1980's led to the attention-getting Austrian Cultural Forum. Austria wanted to break out of the international isolation that had been caused by the revelations of President Kurt Waldheim's service in a German army unit involved in Nazi war crimes. One way to cast the country in a more favorable light, it was decided, would be to erect an arresting, architecturally significant building in the middle Manhattan. But it's not an approach every nation is prepared to take.
How to make a mark on New York's jam-packed arts scene through less concrete measures is the challenge facing dozens of foreign cultural representatives. "It's useless to be gallery No. 1,428 or to make a small concert when it's the 27th on a given night," says Stephan Nobbe, director of the Goethe Institut. For this reason, the $7.5 million that the institute spends each year to promote German culture in the United States -- largely provided by the German Foreign Ministry -- is frequently used to help stage events at local institutions like the Guggenheim Museum or the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center rather than to finance presentations at the Goethe Institut itself, on upper Fifth Avenue.
Less prosperous countries are also resourceful at beating their artistic drums. Mongolia staged a citywide festival in 2000 that included wrestling and archery displays in Central Park and a show of dinosaur relics at the American Museum of Natural History, all of which coincided with the Metropolitan Museum of Art's exhibition on the theme of the Mongolian horse.
European powers like Germany and France are old hands at cultural diplomacy. The Goethe Institut was founded before World War II and rapidly became enmeshed in Nazi ideology. But its postwar activities have greatly reinforced the democratic credentials of today's Federal Republic. France, which employs 85 people in 10 offices around the United States to promote French culture, created the Alliance Francaise in 1883 to help regain national prestige after its defeat in the Franco-Prussian War. Since then, France has believed that acquainting foreigners with its intellectual and cultural traditions buys sympathy for its political and economic policies.
The official use of culture can backfire. Chinese interference in the aborted American premiere of the opera "Peony Pavilion" at the 1998 Lincoln Center Festival demonstrated the perils. After agreeing to send the epic work to the festival, Shanghai officials saw a preview of the production and denounced it as "feudal," "absurd" and "pornographic." They then refused to allow performers to travel to New York. (The director pursued other avenues and the opera was staged in 1999.)
But curators and artistic directors say they can recall no other recent instance of overt state intervention in a cultural endeavor here.
While New York arts institutions insist that their bookings are based on artistic criteria, they often rely on cultural attaches to bring new artists and productions to their attention. Foreign governments will also foot the bill for curators and presenters to travel abroad to see the work. "They provide us with a knowledge base," said Robert Harth, artistic director of Carnegie Hall, which does not accept subsidized trips.
The degree to which United States arts institutions receive help from foreign nations varies widely. Ms. Hopkins of the Brooklyn Academy says "it would be tough" for the Academy to keep up its high level of international programming without diplomatic backing. At the Museum of Modern Art, foreign financing has been modest in contrast to the overall cost of any exhibition, says the director, Glenn Lowry. But state support for shows like the recent Giacometti retrospective, backed by Switzerland, helped gain additional money from foundations and private donors.
Once government backing is lined up, cultural attaches often go further, acting as go-betweens to find corporate sponsors from their own countries. Jean-Rene Gehan, the French cultural counselor, said he had helped arrange sponsorships by the media giant Vivendi Universal, the aircraft manufacturer Dassault and the Societe Generale bank.
Officially supported culture used to flow more readily across the Atlantic. During the 1950's and 60's, the United States Information Agency flooded Europe with American orchestras, dance groups, art exhibits and jazz performances as well as the Broadway musicals "Porgy and Bess" and "My Fair Lady." 
No sooner had the communist threat waned after 1991, however, than United States initiatives were cut back severely. In 1999, the U.S.I.A. itself was folded into the State Department. The United States dropped out of Expo 2000 in Hanover, Germany. The network of American libraries and reading rooms overseas has been reduced to 168, from a high of 254 in 1963. Only 22 percent are traditional lending libraries; these "information resource centers," as they're now called, often consist of a single computer terminal.
Sept. 11 and its aftermath raise the question whether slashing cultural diplomacy was prudent. Editorial writers are asking how best to combat distortions about the United States, and the film critic David Denby, among others, has urged that cultural diplomacy be revived in the Islamic world. Writing in the online magazine Slate, he advocated sending a wider range of films abroad as well as dispatching poets, professors and cultural journalists: "We can do it not by boasting or exhorting, but by describing, illustrating, embodying -- that is, by showing up."
America has long had an aversion to official involvement in the arts. Although most foreign countries have national ministries of culture and regard protection of their artistic heritage as a public responsibility, Americans have been wary of such bureaucratic control. From the Depression-era Works Projects Administration through more recent upheavals involving the National Endowment for the Arts, federal support of culture has set off heated debate. 
Patricia Harrison, the assistant secretary of state for Educational and Cultural Affairs, agrees that there's a need to refocus cultural diplomacy to correct misperceptions abroad. Along with cultural programming, Ms. Harrison oversees the Fulbright Program, which offers 4,500 grants a year to foreigners to study in the United States and to Americans to go abroad. "We need more opportunities for dialogue," she said, but she cautioned that that it could take years for any new cultural programs to have an impact. Ms. Harrison said the Bush administration had not substantially reversed the cuts in cultural diplomacy, but added, "We have put a tourniquet on the hemorrhaging." 
Joseph S. Nye Jr., dean of the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, argues that America's commercial cultural exports already make up a form of "soft power" that influences other societies by implicitly promoting American values like personal freedom, upward mobility and democratic openness. But he also believes that the government can't do much to offset the hostility that popular products like "Baywatch" or Britney Spears videos can provoke. "Efforts to balance the scene by supporting exports of American high culture -- libraries and art exhibits -- are at best a useful palliative," Professor Nye said. 
To be sure, advocates of reviving American cultural diplomacy do not suggest that Washington merely trumpet the upper reaches of American artistic achievement. "We can't simply say we have great novelists and great architects," said the historian Richard Pells, author of "Not Like Us: How Europeans Have Loved, Hated and Transformed American Culture Since World War II."
"But we need to engage people abroad on why they feel uncomfortable when they encounter America in their own living rooms," Professor Pells said. "Many people interpret America in terms of its most visible artifacts -- the Golden Arches or Mickey Mouse. American cultural diplomacy could demystify these artifacts and engage in a dialogue on why they're so popular."

HEADLINE: Calling in Europe 

 BODY:
To the Editor: "More Overseas Choices for Cellphone Users" (Travel Advisory, March 31) omits what may be the most economical plan: do as the Europeans do and simply purchase a phone from one of the many phone stores that dot European cities.
 The reason it's cheaper: there are no contracts to sign; you simply buy a phone and as many minutes as you'd like to use. 
Even better (unless you're roaming in another country), there are no airtime charges for incoming calls, whether they originate next door or overseas. 
 In Ireland last July, I bought a Speakeasy phone for the equivalent of $55, which included a $34 credit for calls (local calls are charged at 60 cents a minute daytime and 20 cents a minute evening and weekend).
In conjunction with the phone I also chose an international calling option of $23 for about 40 minutes of calls to the United States).
I can use this same phone anywhere in Europe (and in several other places as well, including Canada), although at a pricey, out-of-Ireland roaming charge of $1.75 per minute for outgoing calls and $1.20 for incoming calls.

CHARLES H. LYONS
Greensboro, N.C.

HEADLINE: ART; 
Bold Enigma, From Varied Themes

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM ZIMMER 

 BODY:
"UN in the U.S." is the 146th exhibition in the Wadsworth Atheneum's showcase for innovative contemporary art known as Matrix.
 Most Matrix shows feature a single artist, but this one, which is headier than most, is a collaboration between a Dutch architect, Ben van Berkel, and an art historian, Caroline Bos. 
 UN stands for United Network, the name of their partnership, which began in 1988. Its mission is to recognize all of the factors that go into the practice of architecture; while designers and technologists are indispensable, "clients, investors and users" are also essential. 
This outlook is brought down from the theoretical level to a visual one for specific projects through a series of large "high resolution photographic prints on polyester cloth." 
The pair applied their way of thinking to their installation here, and decided that a classical museum look was best. The large, bold yet enigmatic pictures, which evidently are realized after a long time, are certainly seductive. "Work," whose dates are 1997-2002, features mannequins who look very feminine but also like automatons on an assembly line. "The Bridge Master's View" (1995-2002) is a cage-like structure under a romantic sky. "Exhibitions" (1995-2002) is a reminder that a contemporary museum exhibition involves works of art, but that fashion and glamour are nearby. 
Although the works are very clear and intriguing visually, they need explanation, or at least some background. These are provided in a brochure by Nicholas Baume, the museum's curator of contemporary art, who is responsible for Matrix. In explaining the function of UN Studio, Mr. Baume invokes the concept of "deep planning," which means taking into account "infrastructure, urbanism, economics and program."
An intended consequence of this way of working is to thwart the star system in which the architect reigns supreme. Yet it seems that anarchy and chaos might result if someone is not at the head. 
UN studio has taken care of this through another practice called "coherence." Mr. Baume uses collage as a model; its essence is that disparate elements are juxtaposed to become a whole.
The name of the practice, United Network, might seem to be a redundancy at first. Any network, if working right, is united. 
Mr. van Berkel and Ms. Bos perhaps want to emphasize the hoped-for absolute seamlessness of their concepts. 
Mr. van Berkel and Ms. Bos are more than visionaries. They are builders, their most famous project being the Erasmus Bridge in Rotterdam, with its striking profile. 
Although asymetrical, it has been called swanlike.
One reason that UN studio is featured in Matrix is that the studio has been commissioned by the Wadsworth Atheneum to produce a plan for the museum's planned renovation, coherently linking a complex of historic but disparate buildings. 
"UN in the U.S." is at the Wadsworth Atheneum through April 28. Information: (860) 278-2670

HEADLINE: Q. & A.; 
A Tenant and a Rent Overcharge

 BODY:
 Q. I live in a rent-controlled apartment in Manhattan. The State Division of Housing and Community Renewal recently revoked a rent increase for all rent-controlled and rent-stabilized apartments in my building. The state agency also ordered the landlord to repay an overcharge to those tenants within one month of the division's order. Although three months have elapsed since the order, the landlord has neither adjusted the rent nor returned the overcharge. Since the order, I have been paying the reduced rent, but the landlord continues to bill me at the higher rate and counts my deductions as arrears on my rent statement. Am I within my legal rights to pay the reduced rent? Can I deduct the full amount of the overcharge the landlord was ordered by the agency to repay? . . . Jacqueline Ancess, Manhattan.

A. Colleen F. McGuire, a Manhattan tenant lawyer, said it appears that the letter writer is entitled to pay the reduced rent and to deduct the overcharge. "She should be cautious in doing so, however, because the landlord might be appealing the decision," Ms. McGuire said. She explained that when an order is issued by the rent administrator after the first stage of a Division of Housing and Community Renewal proceeding, the landlord has 35 days to file a petition for administrative review.
 "Since three months have already elapsed, it is likely that there has not been an appeal filed by the landlord,' Ms. McGuire said. "But the tenant should confirm this with the state agency." (The agency's Office of Rent Administration can be reached at (718) 739-6400.)
If it turns out that the landlord has filed an appeal, Ms. McGuire said, and the decision is reversed, the tenant would likely be responsible for any rent or overcharges that had been deducted. As a result, Ms. McGuire said, if an appeal has been filed and the letter writer continues to deduct amounts from her rent, it would be wise to set aside the money until the matter is resolved.
She added that if the rent reduction was ordered because of violations at the property, and the landlord makes the necessary repairs, it is likely he will apply for a rent restoration order. 
If the agency grants the landlord's application, Ms. McGuire said, it will restore the rent retroactively to the date of the application. So, she said, once the letter writer receives a copy of the application, the letter writer should set aside the difference between the reduced rent and the legal rent so the money is available.

Paying Interest On Escrow Accounts

Q. Before last year, the mortgage on my condominium was held by a large New York-based bank. Each year, the bank paid a small amount of interest on the money it held in escrow to pay my property taxes. Last year, the bank sold my mortgage to another large bank, in Wichita, Kan. That bank now tells me that it does not pay interest on mortgage escrow accounts. Is the bank required to pay interest on the money it is holding in escrow? . . . Raymond W. Townsend, Manhattan.

A. Joel E. Abramson, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, said that under Section 5-601 of New York State's General Obligations Law, banks that are subject to the state's Banking Department -- basically, any bank licensed to do business in the state -- are required to pay interest on escrow accounts. "The banking board sets the interest rate," he said. "The current rate is 2 percent per year."
Mr. Abramson said that even though the holder of the letter writer's mortgage is based in Kansas, there is a good possibility that the bank is subject to New York State's Banking Department since many large lenders are licensed in New York. If, however, the new lender is not subject to the New York Banking Department, it would not be required to pay interest on escrow accounts. 
The letter writer can determine whether the new lender is licensed in New York by contacting the department at (800) 522-3330.

HEADLINE: Boatmen Fear New Federal Catch Limits 

BYLINE:  By STUART MARKUS 

 BODY:
WHEN the members of the Mid-Atlantic Fisheries Management Council met in Montauk for three days last month, they passed routine resolutions about the management of flounder, scup and squid from Long Island to North Carolina, but their minds were really focused on Rhode Island, Massachusetts and Maine. 
 At issue is a proposal by the National Marine Fisheries Service to impose even tighter restrictions on the boats that fish for cod, haddock and hake off the New England coast. Long Island fishermen fear that a clampdown there will push more boats southward to the waters off New York and New Jersey, putting pressure on fish stocks and competing with a local industry still recovering from years of low catches and lost jobs. 
 "There'd be an exodus from New England for a lot of boats to our waters," said Bill Grimm, 49, a fishing boat owner and a partner in Montauk Inlet Seafood, which transfers fish to wholesalers and processors. The company says it is the largest such operation in New York. 
The Mid-Atlantic Fisheries Management Council is one of eight regional councils -- each state gets three representatives -- that advise the National Marine Fisheries Service on setting policy. The federal agency's proposal would limit boats with groundfish permits -- a category that includes cod, haddock, fluke, flounder and sole -- to 11 days at sea from May through July. During that period, each day at sea would count twice against the annual limit of 88 days. In the Gulf of Maine, the restrictions would extend from May through October.
The federal permits cover the area from three to 200 miles off the coast. Fishing inside the three-mile limit is regulated by the states.
The proposed federal limits stem from a 1999 lawsuit by several environmental groups, including the Conservation Law Foundation, Ocean Conservancy, Oceana, National Resource Defense Council and National Audubon Society. The plaintiffs contend that the fisheries service has not adequately enforced the Magnuson-Stevens Fisheries Conservation Act of 1996, which set target population levels for dozens of species and a time frame for reaching them. Lax enforcement, the environmentalists charge, has kept the fish populations from rebounding as much as they should.
Judge Gladys Kessler of Federal District Court in Washington agreed in December, prompting both sides to propose tighter restrictions. Five days of mediation ended Tuesday without agreement. The judge has given the parties until tomorrow to file additional briefs and has indicated that she expects to rule in the case by May 1, the beginning of the fishing year and the starting point for counting days at sea.
Sema Freierman, 49, the general manager of Montauk Inlet Seafood and a member of the State Department of Environmental Conservation's Marine Regional Advisory Council, said: "What's happening is, these enviro-glomerates are putting their feet to the fire. They haven't seen this many codfish in 7 to 10 years, yet they're taking away people's days at sea."
While acknowledging that some species still need stringent protection, she accused the environmentalists of playing a "numbers-crunching game" that does not acknowledge that fish populations are generally increasing or that fishermen need to make a living.
If catches are limited for groundfish, then trawlers may turn to other species. "They will have no choice but to hit on some of the mid-Atlantic species that they might not bother with," Ms. Freierman said. Many boats that fish the New England waters have mid-Atlantic permits that they don't usually use, she said.
Mr. Grimm, the boat owner, noted that seven years ago, groundfishing days at sea were cut from 250 to 88. "The overfishing problem has really been taken care of," he said. "There's a tremendous amount of fish around."
In 2001, 69,200 metric tons of groundfish were caught off New England, more than twice the 32,600 metric tons caught in 1998.
Anthony Chatwin, a marine scientist with the Conservation Law Foundation in Boston, acknowledged that some species have rebounded significantly, but he said said that cod was not one of them. He contends that the cod population is still only a third of what it should be and that the populations of white hake, American plaice and redfish, also known as ocean perch, are also severely depressed.
Douglas Hopkins, the senior lawyer in Environmental Defense's Boston office and a member of the New England Fisheries Management Council, is concerned about what could happen if all the boats with groundfishing permits actually fished as much as their permits allow. He said that 1,700 boats in New England have permits with nearly 150,000 days at sea available; of these, about 65,000 were used in 2000. 
"That's just not sustainable," Dr. Chatwin said. He put the sustainable figure at 45,000 days at sea. 
Long Island has 261 boats with permits to fish in federally regulated waters, and of these only 172 actively fished in 2001. The government is not issuing any new permits. The permits, which were free, were issued to particular boats, not to individuals, and they remain with the boat when it is sold.
A recent $10 million federal buy-back program induced 245 boat owners to give up their permits. The government accepted bids ranging from $1,400 to $127,000.
Dr. Chatwin agreed that if the New England boats come to local waters, local fishermen and fish populations could be hurt. "I think that's a very legitimate concern, and I think that's a problem with the government's proposal," he said. 
Teri Frady, a spokeswoman for the fisheries service, said she could not speculate about how many New England boat owners might sail southward to Long Island. "It's like 1,700 small businesses," she said. "That the potential is there is certainly correct, but it's hard to estimate for whom it's going to be a good business decision."
Mr. Grimm and Ms. Freierman also questioned the federal agency's estimates for fish populations. Research boats haul nets like the ones commercial fishermen use, and by counting the number and kinds of fish they catch, government scientists come up with the estimates of fish populations that are used to adjust quotas and fishing seasons. In side-by-side tests in March and September last year using commercial and research boats, Mr. Grimm said, "what they come up with in their nets is nowhere near what we come up with," suggesting that fish populations are higher than government estimates.
Ms. Frady acknowledged the discrepancies, but said the research boats used the same equipment they started with in 1963, for comparison purposes. In gauging populations, the agency looks at the ages and sizes of the fish, along with evidence of reproductive activity and total commercial and recreational hauls. 
Dr. Chatwin said, "We would expect commercial vessels to catch more fish than the research vessels because they use more efficient equipment." 
But local fishermen have environmentalists on their side, too. Emerson Hasbrouk, a specialist with the Cornell Cooperative Extension's Fisheries and Marine Environmental Issues program in Southold, said the 1996 law sets unrealistic goals, because maximum sustainable yields are listed for all species. "You can't have both predator and prey at maximum levels," he said. 
The Magnuson-Stevens law also requires the fisheries service to consider the economic impact of regulations, and that, he says, has taken a back seat to population figures. 
Anthony DiLernio, a professor of marine technology at Kingsborough Community College and a member of the mid-Atlantic council, said the proposed restrictions could prompt some fishermen to avoid the double-counted days from May through July, pushing their working season into the winter. And that, he contends, would violate a clause in the law that calls for the promotion of safety at sea. "While the environmental community was well intentioned," he said, "it appears they're being inflexible in their resolution."

HEADLINE: HEALTH CARE; 
Wanted: Nurses. Benefits? Just Ask.

BYLINE:  By MERRI ROSENBERG 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS 

 BODY:
SIGNING bonuses. Flex time. Tuition benefits and scholarships. 
Are these enticements from Fortune 500 corporations for prospective new hires?
 No, these lures are for nurses. 
 With a dearth of professional nurses in the wards, as well as student nurses in the pipeline, small wonder that hospitals, nursing homes and nursing schools are seeking ways to recruit and retain prospects. 
Whether it's dangling financial incentives to recent and prospective nursing school graduates, sending recruiters into middle and high schools to entice more students to consider nursing or redesigning career-changing programs, various organizations in the county are doing what they can to cope with the nursing shortage.
Enrollment in registered nursing school programs declined by 4.6 percent in the fall of 1999, representing the fifth consecutive decline in as many years, according to a report from the American Association of Colleges of Nursing.
Recently, White Plains Hospital began the White Plains Hospital Center Nursing Award program, an incentive aimed at attracting nurses. Under the program, $55,000 in scholarships have been made available to 11 nursing students and graduates from Westchester Community College who promise to join the hospital's staff. The hospital's goal is to develop a million-dollar scholarship fund that will ultimately sponsor 20 to 25 students annually. The award program will give $5,000 for up to two years. Each recipient agrees to work for the hospital for one year for each year of aid. 
Florence Younkin, vice president for nursing at White Plains Hospital Center, said: "There are not enough nursing school graduates to fill all the openings that Westchester hospitals have. Last year, there were 200 graduates from all the Westchester nursing programs. One hospital could have taken all the graduates." 
Among the scholarship recipients is Catherine Latson, a mother of two, who said she was attracted to nursing after working as an emergency medical technician. 
"When I was on the ambulance, I missed the patient contact, and what happened to the people afterward," she said about her decision to return to school to get a nursing degree. She had earned a bachelor's degree in biology and art from Macalester College in St. Paul, Minn., and had spent more than 20 years as a scenic artist painting backgrounds for sets in films and television. 
Tina Dubose-O'Hagan, a former social worker and the mother of a 14-year-old and a 3-year-old, said: "I borrowed for this semester, and charged my books on my credit card. My husband and I talked about it. We decided the sacrifice was worth it. But the scholarship helps, and it eases my mind about having a job and not getting stuck." 
Frustrated with working environments or lured by opportunities in pharmaceuticals or insurance, increasing numbers of registered nurses have left the field. Those who have remained are getting older; the average age is now 45. 
"The demands and responsibility have increased, and the numbers of patients who are more ill have increased," said Dr. Kathleen Dirschel, director of the Cochran Nursing School and vice president of education at St. John's Riverside Hospital in Yonkers. "Nurses stay at the bedside more. They now need to have skills in care, organization, teaching, management and computers." 
Few expect a short-term solution to a problem that has been in the making for more than a decade. 
"During the 1990's, with managed care and consolidation, and more focus on the bottom line, nurses were forced to do more while support services were cut back," Mark Genovese, a spokesman for the New York State Nurses Association. "Nurses were leaving the profession. The hospitals were trying to squeeze more out of their nursing staff. Now some hospitals are doing recruitment, but that's only half of it. They have to make it worthwhile for the nurses." 
At a career fair last month at Pace University in Pleasantville, recruiters from more than 60 employers including the military, nursing homes, rehabilitation centers, psychiatric centers, assisted living residences and local and tri-state hospitals often seemed to outnumber the prospects. 
Recruiters offered T-shirts, tote bags and coffee mugs along with bulging information packets. 
The situation is starting to improve slightly, with a 30 percent increase in applications reported for next year at both the Lienhard School of Nursing at Pace and the Cochran Nursing School at St. John's Riverside Hospital. The Lienhard School has expanded its career-changers program so that students with a bachelor's degree can earn a nursing degree in one year. 
With starting salaries in the mid-$50,000 range for registered nurses at top Manhattan medical centers and from $43,000 to $46,000 at hospitals in Westchester and Rockland Counties, the field is attracting people from other occupations, especially in areas hit by the economic slowdown. 
"We were losing ground for a couple of years there," said Dr. Donna Demarest, dean of the School of Nursing at the College of New Rochelle. "Last year, we stopped the decline. For fall of 2001, we had a class of 22 freshmen. For next year, our applicant pool has doubled. We would be very happy with a freshman class of 40.
"We're finding there's heavy recruitment of our seniors," she added. "The community used to reserve recruitment to those who had experience, but now they're willing to work with brand-new graduates. It's definitely the graduates' market."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A career fair at Pace University in Pleasantville, where recruiters representing more than 60 employers looking for nurses met with prospective candidates. (Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: 2001 Manhattan Condominium Market; 
Fewer Sales, Higher Prices

 BODY:
The median price per square foot of the 3,739 condominium apartments that were sold in Manhattan rose 17 percent last year, according to the annual report of the Real Estate Board of New York. The median price per square foot of a prewar unit rose to $590 in 2001 from $503 in 2000, while the postwar-unit median price increased to $600 from $511. 
 The median square footage for a prewar condo sold last year was 5 percent higher than the previous year, at 1,135 square feet, and for a postwar condo was up 7 percent, at 877. 
 According to Gregory Heym, the chief economist of the Real Estate Board, the median sales price last year for a two-bedroom prewar condo was $817,500, compared with $668,250 in 2000, while that for a two-bedroom postwar condo was $885,000, compared with $750,000 in 2000.
The terrorist attacks hurt sales somewhat, at least south of 42nd Street, the report said, and the vast majority of the year's sales were completed by Sept. 11. The 23 percent fall in the number of prewar apartments sold and the 15 percent drop in the sale of postwar condos were largely attributed to the recession and the scarcity of available condos. Sales of prewar condos fell to 1,071 last year from 1,399 in 2000, while sales of postwar apartments totaled 2,668, down from 3,140 in 2000.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut; 
A Project for Active Adults Near the Fairfield Border

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
THIRTY years ago, Dr. James Mooney bought 635 acres of land on Riggs Street in the town of Oxford. "Real estate was booming with corporate headquarters and we thought we could get some of that," he said. "We got a zone change from residential to industrial, ran ads and had multiple brokers. We got a few bites, but people wanted to be in Fairfield County."
 Until five years ago, the property was a haven for snowmobilers, hunters and horseback riders. Dr. Mooney was semiretired and anxious to be rid of it. "We came up with the idea of an over-55 community with a golf course," he said. "Two-thirds of property taxes goes for education, so by eliminating children under 18 we created a situation that was good for everybody -- and the town went for it." 
 The zoning was changed to allow a planned residential golf community and approved by town boards and commissions, at which point Dr. Mooney contracted to sell the land and concept to Andrew Tedford, Robert Smith and Phil Craft, principals in Timberlake Development Partners L.L.C. of Milford. 
This fall, the new partners will break ground for the Oxford Greens Estates and Golf Club, a $150 million gated community of 400 homes for active adults age 55 and older, and an 18-hole golf course designed by Cornish, Silva & Mungeam. The project will cover half of the property, leaving the rest as open space.
Children will not be permitted except as visitors or on college breaks. One person in the household must be 55 or older, but 20 percent of the homes can be occupied by people 40 and older.
"We saw an unfulfilled niche," Mr. Tedford said, "to build housing for active adult baby boomers in Fairfield County, where a portion of the 13 percent population growth in Oxford was coming from. Maybe not Greenwich, but from Fairfield towns and greater New Haven."
The development's two-bedroom, two-bath homes with ground-floor master bedrooms are expected to sell for $300,000 to $400,000, and the 18-hole, par-72 golf course will be open to the public, but residents will have preferred access. A heated outdoor pool and tennis courts will be built, and a fitness center and indoor pool and spa will be housed in an 11,000-square-foot community building, accessible only to homeowners. The golf clubhouse will have a pro shop, lockers and dining room. 
Four models of homes will range from 1,754 to 2,645 square feet, with eat-in kitchens, laundry rooms, separate dining rooms, cathedral-ceilinged great rooms, two-car garages and front porches. Two additional bedrooms and one additional bath are optional in lofts, second stories or walkout basements. 
The first of four phases of construction will include models and 100 homes to be completed in the spring of 2003. The golf course is to be finished in 2004. Residents will own their houses, but lawns and all common areas will be owned and maintained by a homeowners' association.
Active adult communities are a growing segment of housing for older people who are not necessarily retired but want a relaxed, semiresort style of living. According to Myril Axelrod, president of Marketing Directions of New Fairfield, "the concept is flourishing because so many people are rattling around in large homes with children grown and gone; they are isolated in their own communities where young families have replaced former neighbors. 
"The reality of assisted living is living with people who are in much worse shape than you are. One gentleman who moved into an assisted living complex told me he was the only one not on a walker. There is a sense of the end of life."
Joanne Carroll, president of the Fairfield County Home Builders Association, added: "It is true that people don't like combining active and assisted living. A lot of boomers who turned 55 last year feel that assisted living is an institutional environment."
But Jon Spooner, public relations manager for Athena Communities, which has eight assisted living and continuing care complexes in Connecticut, out of about 55 statewide, said, "We have many active adults needing no assistance and we haven't gotten any feedback on people feeling uncomfortable about being with others who are less active."
About 20 active adult communities exist in the state, ranging from modular home complexes where prices are $70,000 to $150,000 to luxury projects in Farmington, Cromwell, West Hartford and Milford, priced at $300,000 to $700,000. According to Ms. Axelrod, the industry is recognizing that the rush to the Sun Belt, where most of the country's active adult communities were built, failed to consider the fact that people from 55 to 64 are probably still working and want to be near friends and relatives.
"There are 314,000 people in the state in that age group," said Paul Emrath, assistant vice president for housing research at the National Association of Home Builders, "and only about 6.7 percent move in a given year. Three-fourths move within the state, and half within the county. You need to build something attractive enough to get them away from what is probably a very nice situation."
IN terms of location, Oxford is something of a wild card -- a bit remote from shopping and cultural activities. As one of the Naugatuck Valley towns, Oxford -- like Waterbury, Seymour, Naugatuck, Derby and Ansonia -- was once part of the industrial engine of the state. When industry fled south, the valley fell into deep decline in the 1960's. "The valley is still very blue collar," Ms. Carroll said. "Towns like Oxford carry that connotation."
Mr. Tedford disagrees. "The demographics do not support the concept of Oxford being a blue-collar town," he said. Indeed, Oxford's estimated median income for 1997, supplied by Queens College, was $70,236, up from $56,966 in 1990, and currently higher than neighboring, upwardly mobile Southbury with $62,110.
Moreover, Oxford's prevailing house prices in the $300,000's to mid-$400,000's cannot be classified as blue collar. 
Southbury and Oxford, bordering Fairfield County, and Middlebury, adjacent to Litchfield County, have been luring developers with their open land, lower construction costs and ease of east-west travel on Interstate 84 and north-south travel on Route 8. "A lot of builders are moving up here from Fairfield because they are running out of land," said Lisa Giordano, sales manager of the William Pitt Real Estate office in Southbury. 
Leslie Marks, executive director of the National Council on Senior Housing, an affiliate of the National Association of Home Builders, said: "People who buy active adult housing have money, they are healthy and they know what they want. It's our area of expertise, because that's what our builders do -- single-family homes. Assisted living is not what we focus on."
Ruth Murphy, owner of Murphy Real Estate in Southbury, says prices in the region had increased markedly since 1998. "Most of what's available is brand new and we are seeing people who live or work in Fairfield County come here because it's more affordable. We have almost no starter homes anymore -- anything around $130,000 has disappeared."
David Robinson Sr., chairman of Oxford's Planning and Zoning Commission, said: "The town has changed drastically from 10 years ago. We had a population of about 7,500, now it's close to 10,000. Houses that cost $250,000 in the mid-80's cost in the high $300,000's today. Two houses have been built here for between $3 million and $10 million. There's talk about extending natural gas lines and increasing the minimum lot size from one and a half acres to two acres." 
Since it was first settled in 1678 as part of Derby, Oxford was home to produce and sheep farmers, grist mill and saw mill operators and later small industries. Today, it is a sparsely populated community of 33 square miles that include a volunteer fire department, a police department of three resident state troopers and six officers (two work part time), several parks, the Waterbury-Oxford Airport, a combined Town Hall and Public Library, and organizations like the Oxford Grange, Oxford Historical Society, Horse and Livestock Association, Horseshoe Club and a local newspaper called Voices.
Most people in town are optimistic that Oxford Greens Estates will be beneficial. Joseph Andreana, executive director of the Oxford Economic Development Corporation, said: "I think everyone views it as a win-win situation. It will provide tax revenues and the kind of amenities that will bring in the kind of people we want.
"What has fueled our growth to date has been small businesses. We have about 2,500 acres of industrial-zoned land and we welcome development proposals. Industrial growth will keep residential taxes in balance and help the town build a new library, a new senior center and a high school Oxford students attend Seymour High School . I think it's safe to assume that we are going to see the same level of growth over the next 10 years."

HEADLINE: New Jersey Makes, the World Takes 

BYLINE:  By SUSAN WARNER 

 BODY:
FROM the docks in Elizabeth and Camden, from cargo flights out of Newark International Airport and on rails extending to Canada and Mexico, New Jersey is extending its reach far into the global economy.
 Blueberry wine to Tokyo and cranberry juice to the Caribbean. Typhoid tests to Bangladesh. Valves for rocket launchers and fiber-optic switches for Europe. For that matter, the world's entire supply of Calvin Klein cologne is exported from Mount Olive. 
 While New Jersey is typically viewed as a state of bedroom communities and shopping malls, it is every bit a major player in the international economy, supporting an estimated 600,000 jobs with global trade. 
It is not difficult to see why, when the state is situated on the Atlantic coast, with its well-developed ports and air cargo facilities, making it a convenient launching pad into overseas markets.
The numbers tell much of the story. For instance, New Jersey ranks eighth among states in the dollar value of its exports at $25.93 billion in 2001, according to data provided by the United States Commerce Department. To be sure, a strong dollar and a sluggish economy overseas drove exports down 9.88 percent in 2001 after a major boom in the late 1990's. But that was after a 36.9 percent increase in 2000 from $21 billion in 1999.
"It's clear that New Jersey is a powerhouse when it comes to international business and international trade," said Joe Gonzalez, president of the New Jersey Business and Industry Association. 
The state's leading exports last year were chemicals and pharmaceuticals with $7.22 billion in sales, followed by computers and electronic equipment valued at $5.97 billion.
Canada, the state's largest foreign market, received $4.21 billion in New Jersey exports last year. It was followed by Japan with $2.27 billion and Mexico with $2.19 billion.
"New Jersey's economy is more closely tied to the global economy than most states, both as a pass-through and in production," said Gus Faucher, senior economist at Economy.com, an economic forecasting company in West Chester, Pa. "These places employ a lot of folks even if it is just taking production from other states and exporting overseas."
And the numbers keep telling the story. For example, wholesale trade now accounts for 7.1 percent of all employment in the state as against 5.3 percent nationwide, Mr. Faucher said.
"We had a slump in 2001 which reflects the U.S. recession and the fact that our chief trading partners have been in a recession," said George Nagle, secretary of the state's Council of Economic Advisors. "We had a coordinated slowdown around the world and our numbers did slide, but New Jersey production probably didn't drop as much as it would if we didn't have that international trade."
New Jersey also has a place in the global economy as host to foreign companies that have based their United States headquarters or manufacturing operations in the state. Foreign companies invested $35.3 billion in plants, equipment and offices in New Jersey as of 1999, making it, again, eighth among the states. Germany and Japan were tied with 16.5 percent each of the state's total foreign investment followed by Switzerland with 13.2 percent.

Foreign Investment Is Slowing
Mr. Gonzalez spelled it out this way: There are 1,300 companies from 40 countries doing business in New Jersey, with more than 245,000 jobs being supported by foreign investment in 1999.
Moreover, foreign investment usually represents cutting-edge industry that sells at a premium price, supporting high-end jobs. "You're not going to make an investment half-way around the world unless you've got a product that is technologically advanced," said Mr. Nagle.
Still, foreign investment in the state is slowing, he cautioned, in part as a result to the creation of trading blocs in Europe, Latin America and North America that have brought down trade barriers around the world.
"Everybody is rethinking where they should be and how they're going to access different markets," Mr. Nagle said. 
The way it was explained by Axel Velden, chairman of the New Jersey District Export Council, who retired 18 months ago as director of the export division at Johnson & Johnson, trading blocs were transforming export patterns.
Mr. Velden said Johnson & Johnson now exported less raw material from the United States because production that was once split among many countries to make the best of trade and tariff rules had been consolidated. In the meantime, that consolidation created enough volume to support the development of local suppliers.
"We used to ship chemicals to Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay and Chile because they all manufactured locally," he said. "Now with a common market, a major part of that has gone away."
Nonetheless, high-end products are still made in the United States, he said, including sutures in Somerville.
Under the North American Free Trade Agreement, Mr. Velden said that some goods once made in Mexico and Canada because of import rules and duties were now being manufactured in the United States. But some labor-intensive products like medical supplies were being made in Mexico and shipped back to the United States for sterilization and distribution.
On the other hand, China's entry in the World Trade Organization has yet to have much effect, said Mr. Faucher.
"People tend to oversell the benefits of free trade with China," he said. "It's still very much a developing economy."
While the state is still home to large multinational corporations, those operations are increasingly focused on research or administrative work. For now, the core of New Jersey's export growth is among small to mid-sized companies, many of which were founded by refugees from the state's business giants who have found specialized markets in every corner of the world.
Indeed, Mr. Gonzalez said that with the Internet, smaller companies now have better access to information about global markets and are often faster to seize opportunities than larger companies.
"It's all in these niches," said Mr. Gonzalez. "These are smart people, who may have started working for Allied Signal or American Cyanamid where they got a fix on a product. There are so many of these small companies, 100 or 150 employees. It adds up."
Michael Katz first traveled outside the United States in the 1970's when he was working for a large medical diagnostics company that was branching into Europe through a joint venture in Finland.
"What quickly came to my eye was that that the pastoral image of Europe was a tourist image, never a business image," Mr. Katz said. "These companies were roaring. These were business people with traits developed over centuries. They were adept at selling products from anywhere in the world. I had my eyes opened."

Exporting Goods and Services
In 1981 he struck out on his own, founding Cenogenics, a manufacturer and distributor of medical tests for everything from pregnancy to arthritis, to strep and colon cancer. 
In 1990, Cenogenics, in Morganville, was named the National Exporter of the Year by the Small Business Administration.
Today, exports make up 63 percent of company sales, Mr. Katz said, though competition from abroad is forcing the company to focus more on the domestic market.
"The margins are dropping in export markets,"he said. "The competition is intense right now, and the prices are being driven down very hard."
Beyond the export of hard goods, the state also is a major exporter of services. For example, it is home to several large engineering and construction companies that have evolved from building roads to power plants to high-tech production plants for companies around the world.
The state's experience with hazardous waste and Superfund remediation has also made it a leader in the export of environmental consulting, a business that began to take off in developing countries in the 1990's, said Derish Wolff, chairman of Louis Berger Group in East Orange.
Mr. Wolff said that Louis Berger, which began working overseas in the 1950's as an engineering firm, now brings in a third of its overseas revenue from such services as design and consulting.
"A lot of what is happening in construction is on the soft side," said Mr. Wolff. "To build a clean room for Intel is not that expensive, but it is very hard to design these things, and California and New Jersey do it very well."
Mr. Wolff said the company had also evolved from building roads to building societies. For example, it is to develop poverty programs and other economic assistance plans on contract for governments and development agencies. The company has done this work in Peru, Russia, and Macedonia recently. Louis Berger was an advisor to the pre-Taliban government in Afghanistan, and in January the company announced it was reopening a Kabul office with a new contract for the Asian Development Bank.
He recalled New Jersey's reach into Lebanon in the mid-1980's when he and members of his company were working on a reconstruction plan for the war-torn country. They came under shelling from the battleship New Jersey and were evacuated to Cyprus by the troop ship Trenton.
Military might aside, Mr. Wolff said that New Jersey's stature as a research-intensive state also makes it a breeding ground for new niche products that can be sold globally.
"The state is perceived by people in other countries as a place where important things happen," he said.
But the might of the American dollar has become a major obstacle to exporters, said Tom Schaefer, vice president of sales and marketing at Hatco Corp. in Fords, which makes esters used in windshields and in high-performance lubricants. For instance, Mr. Schaefer said 60 percent of the world's jet engines used Hatco lubricants.
"It's been very difficult in recent years because of the strong dollar," he said. "We've held our own, but growth has been difficult."
Mr. Schaefer said to get around that problem, the company had formed a joint venture with a German chemical-maker, Celanese AG, to build a new ester plant in Germany.
He said that while the new plant would not lead to less production in Fords, it would siphon off expansion that might otherwise have occurred in New Jersey.
Still, overseas markets also can provide comfort during a downturn at home.
"If you look at the U.S. telecom industry, it's going through a very difficult time at the moment, and that's not as true in other parts of the world," said Harry Carr, chief executive of Tellium Inc., a manufacturer of telecommunications equipment in Oceanport with 540 employees.
Mr. Carr said Tellium's goal was to go global when it was founded five years ago by optical networking experts from Bell Communications Research. The company's target customers are the 25 largest carriers in the world, most of whom are oveseas.
"In telecom you have to understand that to be a significant player you can't just be U.S.-based," he said.
The state's high-tech exporters are also facing strict regulations on the transfer of technology because of security concerns on the part of the government officials, said Tom Marotta, chief executive of Marotta Scientific Controls -- a family-controlled company with 200 workers in Montville -- which makes complex control valves used on satellite rocket launchers and in defense on ships and submarines.
"The whole high-tech industry here has been slowed down by the amount of scrutiny we're getting," said Mr. Marotta. He said the government intensified its scrutiny even before Sept. 11 -- near the end of the Clinton administration -- primarily out of concern over China.
Mr. Marotta said that despite its size, the company was not at a disadvantage when competing with multinational corporations. "We can operate more quickly. We have more innovative people and we're stronger in our niche markets. We're clear on where we're going."
Many New Jersey exporters rely heavily on relationships with distributors and importers to shepherd their products into foreign lands.
Charles Tomasello, president of the Tomasello Winery in Hammonton, said his company began exporting blueberry and other fruit wines to Japan four years ago when Japanese consumers became obsessed with the health benefits of blueberries. The winery now ships several thousand cases of wine a year to Tokyo. 
"It's absolutely, definitely a niche," said Mr. Tomasello. "That's the key. It's such an obscure little niche you find clientele that are very interested in it."
In addition, Mr. Tomasello said that the fruit wines seemed to blend into Asian cooking styles. 
"Culture is always an issue," he said. "Your ultimate consumer in those countries has to be able to make your product fit into their cooking, lifestyle and cultural perception of taste. A lot of times our perception of what the level of sweetness should be is one thing and our importer's view is another. Consequently we defer to their judgment because they live there. You have to accept the fact that they have a better sense of the consumer."
With such current obstacles as the aftermath of the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, in the way of cracking foreign markets, exporters said they were concerned that state support for export programs was waning.
Mr. Katz, the medical tests exporter, said state programs in his early days in business led him to helpful federal programs and paid several hundred dollars for overseas medical trade shows that were crucial in connecting with new customers.
"If we had not been led to those markets when we had the bad economic conditions in the late 1980's and early 1990's," he said, "we would not have continued to grow. We would have been laying off people."

Tough Times Spur Business
But Mr. Katz said he was worried about the future. "If we're battling other companies in other states who are getting this kind of information, who's going to win? That is the dilemma New Jersey business has."
Mr. Velden, the chairman of the district export council, said last year the council supported six bills in the legislature aimed at export promotion, but all died.
"I think that what happens is when the economy is good people are not so interested in exporting because they can sell what they want here," he said. "But when times get tough and markets in the U.S. get tough, all of a sudden people are interested in export. I don't know if this recession has been long enough for that."
Rodney Stuart, director of the Trenton Export Assistance Center for the Commerce Department's commercial service, said New Jersey promotion budgets had been cut.
"Among the states with higher trade promotion budgets than New Jersey were Mississippi, Kansas and Iowa," Mr. Stuart said, noting that New Jersey fell behind 23 other states in export promotion.
Mr. Gonzalez said business people around the state were eager to see what direction the state's Commerce and Economic Growth Commission took under its new chief executive, William D. Watley.
"Right now it's still early on," said Karen Wolfe, a spokeswoman for the commission. "We'll be reviewing our strategies to make sure they're cost-effective and address New Jersey's business needs."
Mr. Stuart said the state has five Foreign Trade Zones, where businesses received certain tax and tariff breaks, but added that they played a small role in the state's export volume.
For now, he said the climate for export seemed to be improving.
"Since Sept. 11 we saw a noticeable decline, but since then it picked up dramatically, and I'd say we have seen many more requests for information from numerous companies that seem to have been successful."
Mr. Faucher, the economist, said most forecasts called for an improvement in the overall economic environment.
"The economy has slowed worldwide, but we're expecting to see a pickup toward the end of this year," he said. "That will help boost U.S. exports, and strong U.S. growth is going to spill over into New Jersey."

HEADLINE: Executive Life; 
To Conquer Burnout, Think Smaller

BYLINE:  By MELINDA LIGOS 

 BODY:
IT was the defining moment of Mary Lou Quinlan's career: While in a taxi on her way to work two years ago, Ms. Quinlan, then chief executive of the N. W. Ayer ad agency in Manhattan, fantasized about breaking all her limbs in a traffic accident -- or at least a leg or two. "I thought to myself, 'Maybe if I jump in front of this cab, I can go the hospital and finally get some peace and quiet,' " she said.
 That dark thought jolted her out of the rat race. "After 20 years of manic working," she said, "I realized I had hit total burnout." 
 She received permission for a five-week sabbatical, and for the first time in two decades, she said, she felt like a human being again.
"For once, I was able to wake up and drink my morning coffee after the sun had already risen, instead of before," she said. "I began living life the way normal people do."
When the five weeks were up, she resigned from the agency, which had 500 employees, to start her own company, Just Ask a Woman, a low-key marketing company in Manhattan with a staff of a dozen. She says she has never looked back.
Ms. Quinlan is somewhat of a trend setter, career experts say. In the recently rocky economy, burnout among managers has been rising -- so much so that many have quit jobs without the slightest clue as to what they will do next.
A study by Challenger, Gray & Christmas, the outplacement firm in Chicago, showed that more than 470 chief executives of major companies left their jobs in the first half of 2001, up 22 percent from a year earlier. Though poor performance can never be ruled out, many of the chiefs cited stress and burnout as reasons for their departures.
"The pressure managers feel to perform is higher than it's ever been," said William C. Byham, chief executive of Development Dimensions International, a human resources consulting firm in Pittsburgh. "It used to be that you'd have a couple of years to make mistakes before you were really under the gun. Now, you're under immediate pressure to show results."
George Ludwig remembers fretting that his days were numbered. As a national sales manager at Johnson & Johnson from 1992 to January of last year, he led a team of 35 people that specialized in advanced sterilization products. "There was enormous pressure for us to be successful," he said.
As the economy softened, Mr. Ludwig said, his fear that his team would not meet its sales goals kept him awake at night. Instead of waiting to be dismissed, he quit his job and became a motivational speaker and consultant. Based in Cary, Ill., he now advises managers from Fortune 500 companies on avoiding burnout by developing a social life outside work, creating outlets to unload pressure and, in some cases, pursuing less stressful careers.
David N. Rosen also escaped from the rat race. As the technical team leader of the technology consulting division at Oracle, he had been working for a year and a half on a project that required him to fly every week from Los Angeles to Portland, Ore.
Working through the night at the client's office early last year, he witnessed the emotional meltdown of a colleague at 2 a.m. The project was not going well, and the client had complained to Oracle's top management. The two men had a talk, and the colleague "basically had a nervous breakdown," Mr. Rosen said.
"He sank into the wall and began crying and saying he couldn't take it anymore," Mr. Rosen said. "All that was running through my mind was, 'This could be me soon.' "
Within days, Mr. Rosen persuaded his companion, Stacy Van Heusen, to leave her management position at an ad agency in Los Angeles and go with him to Italy. They spent five months drinking red wine, trolling farmers' markets and discussing their next career moves. They recently moved back to the Los Angeles area, set up a television production company, Stubs the Cat Productions, and have vowed never to return to work as executives at large companies.
"We were both washed up in our late 20's," said Ms. Van Heusen, 28, who worked 100-hour weeks creating campaigns for Levi Strauss. "We knew something had to change."
Taking a breather can help managers put their careers in perspective. Joseph R. Weintraub, an organizational psychologist and management professor at Babson College in Wellesley, Mass., recommends that executives on the verge of burnout take a few weeks off before making any drastic moves. "Don't do anything intellectual," he said. "Relax, get some exercise and try to see things in a new light."
He also urged managers to do some soul-searching to make sure that the stress is not self-inflicted.
Such an exercise in introspection paid off for Nan Napier, president of Tres Mariposas, a clothing store in El Paso. She was thinking of dropping her 23-year career because of stress, but she examined her management style. "I realized nobody but me was making me work as hard as I was," she said, acknowledging that she often became bogged down in problems that one of her 25 employees could have handled easily.
Now Ms. Napier has taken a step back. "If there's a minor problem, I just walk out the door, gritting my teeth and hoping someone will fix it by the end of the day," she said. The tactic has given her more time at home with her two teenagers.
MANAGERS who change to more tranquil careers should be wary of falling back into old ways. Ms. Quinlan, the ad executive, realized that her inability to say no had also hurt her. "Now I say no a lot, and I have a lot more energy, which I use to garden instead of sitting in some meeting," she said.
Mr. Rosen and Ms. Van Heusen now force themselves to do yoga several mornings a week and to take weekends off.
"It took us a lot of personal upheaval to get where we are," he said. "We're not about to go back to being the maniacs we used to be."

SECTION: Section 11; Column 1; Real Estate Desk; Pg. 6

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/New Jersey; 
A Flood of Office Space Is Offered for Subleasing

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN 

 BODY:
SEPT. 11 continues to have a major effect on the New Jersey office market, in exactly the opposite way real-estate experts' instincts initially indicated.
 "There's a ton of sublet space out there now," said Ken Flynn Jr., a vice president of the commercial broker Trammell Crow, "as there has been since 9/11, when just about anything that was empty was put on the market." 
 A total of 13 million square feet of office space is available in north and central New Jersey -- 2 million square feet of that Class A space -- according to Cushman & Wakefield's first quarter report. Thirty-five percent of the space on the market is sublease space, whereas a year ago sublease space accounted for only 26 percent of the total available.
The sublease glut has helped to drive the overall vacancy rate to 18 percent or more in northern and central New Jersey, according to various quarterly reports. Cushman & Wakefield said that an increase of a full percentage point came in the first quarter of 2002. 
For larger Class A office spaces -- anything over 75,000 square feet -- the overall current vacancy rate is 17 percent, according to Robert Rudin, an Insignia/ESG managing director who represents corporate tenants seeking such blocks.
For direct leases, by comparison, the vacancy rate remains stable at 9 percent, various statistical sources agree. 
"What we have is continuing negative net absorption -- more sublease space coming on the market than is being taken up," Mr. Rudin said, "and that is a bad thing for landlords." In some prime spots, he noted, there is top-quality office space that has been sitting vacant for a year or more.
Given all this, some landlord representatives have moved to seize the bull by the horns, or perhaps wrestling a bear is the better metaphor under the circumstances. "It's now a tenant's market," Mr. Flynn said flatly, "and any landlord that isn't offering tenant incentives better start."
Mr. Flynn recently brokered the sublease of 30,400 square feet of space at the Basking Ridge Corporate Plaza One for the master tenant, United Health Care. Trammell Crow had taken over marketing the space -- and another chunk roughly the same size -- last August, three weeks before the terrorist attack on New York. 
The total 60,000 square feet of Class A space had been offered at $29 per square foot by the previous broker. But it had remained empty for more than six months. 
Then, the attack came, and there was a "thin wave" of subleasing to displaced New York City firms in New Jersey, as Mr. Flynn put it, and a huge wave of sublease space thrown on the market.
"Most companies put any space they could out to sublease after 9/11," Mr. Flynn said. "Some were truly altruistic and opened up any floor that was empty for New York companies that lost their space. Other decisions were based on practicality, as in, 'We need to downsize, and here's an opportunity.' "
In any case, Jersey City, directly across the river from the Financial District, had its vacancy rate plunge to nearly nil -- but mainly with short-term leases. The impact elsewhere in the region was scattered and slight, according to all quarterly real estate reports issued since.
By October, Trammell Crow advised United Health Care that if it really wanted to sublease the Basking Ridge space, it needed to pull out the stops.
"We told the landlord that you've got to price very aggressively in this situation," Mr. Flynn said. "We said you've got to be prepared to make aggressive concessions on the terms of lease."
Trammell Crow drew up a list of prospective tenants -- whether or not they had expressed interest in the property -- and drew up sublease proposals providing as many concessions as possible. "We directly solicited tenants with letters," he said. "We held open houses. We generated as much interest as we could."
BY February, the 30,400-square-foot space was leased for $22.50 per square foot, $6.50 per square foot less than had originally been asked. 
Furthermore, a 1 percent bonus fee was awarded to the broker who brought in the tenant, the One Beacon Insurance Company.
"This is what you need to do," Mr. Flynn said after the deal was struck, "if you want to sublease space." 
Other brokers do not go quite so far with their assessment, or their tactics. Some label this a "tenant favored" market or a "market on the precipice." Some say it's "almost" time to step out aggressively with price breaks; others say it is merely time to consider offering a few months' free rent with a long-term lease, not a lower rate.
Still others say the only concession they would support concerns "work orders" -- how much a landlord will absorb of the cost of custom-fitting an office for a sublease tenant. 
But there is not much room for interpretation about which way market trends are headed. In its first-quarter report, Grubb & Ellis says, "We are witnessing the direct impact of this recession on the northern and central New Jersey office market as corporate consolidations have resulted in rising availability." A total of about 900,000 square feet of space was put on the market in the first quarter of this year -- according to Cushman & Wakefield, and more is coming. Toys "R" Us is moving to consolidate its headquarters in the vacant former American Cyanamid building it purchased in Wayne, for example, and marketing its offices in Paramus.
Also, Pharmacia has reportedly agreed to purchase AT&T's former lavish headquarters in Basking Ridge (the asking price was $260 million). While the deal would take 2.7 million square feet out of the pool of unoccupied space, it would lead Pharmacia to sublet three more standard-size office spaces it currently occupies in Peapack, Bedminster and Bridgewater.
"Pharmacia will add another 800,000 square feet," said Daniel J. Tichio, a tenant's broker with Cresa Partners/New Jersey. "If that's not a wake-up call to landlords, nothing will be."
Mr. Tichio said he was already holding five requests from clients to put space on the sublease market before the Pharmacia-ATT negotiation became known last month.
In Parsippany and in the rest of Morris County generally, the office market problems are most acute. The vacancy rate in Parsippany stubbornly remains at 20 percent after the departure of several major companies in the past two years. The Staubach Company of New Jersey has been unable to sublease the "beautiful, barely used" office of Aventis, a pharmaceutical company, for 18 months, said a managing principal, Thomas J. Stanton III.
"When this kind of real estate sits empty," Mr. Stanton said, "there does come a time where ownership will say: if a deal comes, any kind of deal, I want to make it."
Next door in Morristown, the computer company Tycom is marketing both of its new headquarters buildings, one of which it occupies. "The headquarters turns out to be too large to suit Tycom's needs," Mr. Flynn said. "It's a situation where if the building Tycom is in gets rented first, Tycom will move out. You can do that in this market, because you can find a place to go."
He added that the Tycom rental is "a great deal for some tenant" because Tycom is offering its top-grade furniture as part of a lease package.
Some brokers are still not ready to go for broke. "I would say we're tending toward a tenants' market," Mr. Rudin said gingerly. "Everybody with vacant space right now certainly has an obstacle that has to be managed intelligently, but I'm not ready to say everyone has to offer concessions and price breaks yet."
Mr. Rudin said he was paying close attention to how the market goes in the next few months, as several large companies are known to be shopping for space.
"I think these next deals will determine the direction of the market," Mr. Rudin said. Meanwhile, he said, landlords who want to be aggressive have to follow their instincts. He quoted advice given to him by a mentor, the late Edward S. Gordon, who was ESG's founder.
"Always set your price six months out," he said. "Be proactive. Set it where you think it will be six months from now, and you'll be in business."
