HEADLINE: SOAPBOX: CON; 
Reopen Fresh Kills: Brilliant or Boneheaded?

BYLINE:  By MARJORIE J. CLARKE; Marjorie J. Clarke is scientist in residence at Lehman College, the author of many articles on waste management and vice chairwoman of the Citywide Recycling Advisory Board.

 BODY:
New York's garbage disposal is in a mess. The cost of hauling trash to distant landfills is rising fast, and recycling is being reduced. Some have suggested reopening the Fresh Kills landfill in Staten Island, at least until a better plan is devised. Two experts debate the issue: 
 THE city has lurched between hasty schemes to incinerate solid waste or export it. Now comes the idea of reopening Fresh Kills. Here's why it is ill advised. 
 Landfilling is the worst environmental alternative. Fresh Kills, unlike modern landfills, has no protective liner under it, which is why it annually contaminated ground water and wetlands with 1.5 billion gallons of toxic runoff and emitted more than 15 billion cubic feet of greenhouse and carcinogenic gases. Reopening it would require multiple liners, water and air quality controls and numerous permits and environmental reviews. Increasing the dump's height atop slippery liners could make it unstable.
Reduction of waste at the source, along with reuse, recycling and composting are the solutions favored by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency and the city's official citizens' advisory boards. The city has pursued these ideas halfheartedly, continually cutting important programs. Ten years ago, the city came close to building its own recycling plants and was developing local markets for the materials. But it awarded the opportunity to sort and market recyclable items to multinational conglomerates. The city could save tens of millions of dollars with approaches like setting up buy-back centers for recyclables in low-income areas, leaving grass clippings on lawns and offering economic incentives to encourage recycling and reduction of garbage.
Landfilling is a step backward. While the city wasted time and money on ill-conceived plans to export garbage, other cities achieved 50 percent recycling rates without breaking the bank. They collect and market recyclables efficiently. They buy products made of their recyclables. Cities like San Francisco compost food waste, which represents 15 percent of New York's garbage.
New Yorkers want to recycle. Even though the Mayor has proposed ending the city's container recycling program, a recent poll by Channel 11 showed that 84 percent of New Yorkers want the program to continue.
Staten Islanders pushed for the 1996 state law that mandated the closing of Fresh Kills, and they haven't changed their minds. Their feelings are understandable. For the city as a whole, instead of resorting to failed policies of the past, we should create a forward-looking system that is under our own control.

HEADLINE: It Is, for Deer, All Over but The Shooting 

BYLINE:  By JEREMY PEARCE 

DATELINE: BERNARDS TOWNSHIP 

 BODY:
TO shoot or not to shoot. That is no longer the question.
 In New Jersey's rich -- and deer-rich -- suburbs, the guns of winter are now silent, momentarily marking the end of a debate that has pitted neighbor against neighbor and drawn crowds to normally sleepy township meetings. 
 More and more suburbs are ignoring pleas from animal rights supporters and choosing instead to solve problems of shrubbery raids and deer-car collisions by hiring professional sharpshooters. The list of towns that have adopted this approach now includes Summit, Millburn, Bridgewater, Princeton, Scotch Plains, Springfield and Berkeley Heights. In addition, state wildlife officials say they have have fielded inquiries from another 30 towns. 
"They're grappling with these issues, but most townships see shooting as the most efficient and economical solution," said Susan Martka, a wildlife biologist who oversees New Jersey's Community-Based Deer Management Program, which was approved by state legislators two years ago.
Just last month, a state appeals court dismissed a challenge by antihunting groups to overturn the deer program, which sets guidelines for municipal deer hunts. In the past year alone, about 700 deer were shot in local culling programs. 
In Bernards Township, the conflict erupted into a colorful campaign with signs cropping up on front lawns like so many daisies protesting the culling of 93 deer in recent months. The Somerset County community shares a porous border with the Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge, normally closed to hunting and known to harbor deer herds. Opponents of hunting want local officials to consider nonlethal options of transporting deer or darting them with contraceptives.
"Just to shoot for the sake of getting rid of deer, that is a waste," said Al Rome, a Bernards resident who put out a series of protest signs.
For their part, township officials said they reviewed those options but found them impractical. Indeed, the notion of cutting deer numbers through contraception has been waning in academic circles. For the method to work, female deer must be darted two times in the first year of treatment and then once annually -- a task most scientists agree is close to impossible. Other contraceptives introduce chemicals that can harm if the deer is eaten by hunters. As a result, no deer contraceptive yet has won federal drug approval.
"Show me a bottle of the stuff that has F.D.A. approval and we will use it," said Bill Holmes, a member of the Bernards Township Committee who voted for hunting after counting 250 local accidents in the past year involving deer being hit by a vehicle. "Until that day, we're going to keep shooting."
Last week, Millburn ended a second year of deer controls after hiring sharpshooters to remove 160 animals. Complaints of damage to lawns and shrubs prompted the Essex County community -- which includes Short Hills, with large homes and sprawling, landscaped properties -- to shoot 115 deer and trap and transport 45 others out of state.
In Somerset County, Bridgewater did the same thing, hiring sharpshooters to kill 104 deer. Princeton's own hunt ended in February, with a tally of 303 deer that were netted and euthanized. Even so, few towns killed enough deer to meet their target numbers.
"I was disappointed," said Mr. Holmes. "We were hoping to get 500."
Spurred by protestors, all three townships investigated contraception before rejecting it.
"Whatever the animal rights folks say, you couldn't procure a contraceptive even if you wanted one," said Mary McNett, a member of the Millburn Township Committeer.
Bette Nuse, the town clerk in Bridgewater, said: "We looked at all the nonlethal methods. But we wanted to do something now. We've been working on this problem for five years."
The question of just what to do with New Jersey's stubbornly proliferating deer population has indeed attracted a great deal of attention. Monitoring the conflicts, Dr. Larry Katz, a reproductive biologist at Rutgers, called attempts to dart deer with contraceptives absurd and unworkable.
Dr. Katz said that protein injections into female deer were capable of blocking conception, but that such methods, known as immunocontraception, required an annual booster -- and therefore yearly recapture -- at a cost estimated at $1,000 for each deer. Permanent sterilization through a single vaccination has not been developed.
"Deer are destroying our ecosystem," said Dr. Katz. "Realistically speaking, that means culling is the only way to save the environment."
Other scientists say deer crowding is a matter of perspective. Dr. Allen Rutberg, senior research scientist of the Humane Society of the United States, argued that complaints of overcrowding were more a question of human behavior, better handled with road warnings, animal repellants and barriers.
As New Jersey's suburbs strive to reach a density of 20 deer to a square mile -- a number advocated by the state division of fish and wildlife -- Dr. Rutberg said that any limit was arbitrary.
"Biologists have recorded deer concentrations as high as 185 to the square mile in Union County's Watchung Reservation," he said. "Densities of 60 to 80 deer are considered to be relatively common. You could equally well argue that theres a human overpopulation."
Yet out of the conflict has risen an entrepreneur with a shotgun.
Don Barwick, a Linden police officer and erstwhile hunter, answered a call for volunteer shooters when the Watchung Reservation began reducing its deer herd five years ago. Anticipating wider demand, Mr. Barwick founded Deer Management Systems Inc., a company of professional sharpshooters, in Hunterdon County. This year, the compnay signed up Bernards Township, Summit, Millburn and Bridgewater.
Following state guidelines, Mr. Barwick baits deer with corn, erecting tree stands for shooters to conceal themselves above the bait piles. The company's sharpshooters use shotguns and solid projectiles called slugs to lower the risk of injuries to the public. State rules do allow professional hunters to use rifles, but few sharpshooters have chosen the more powerful weapons because of their longer range and risk of ricochet.
Though confined to a shooting season that runs from October to April, Mr. Barwick said the demand for deer control had nonetheless soared. Deer Management Systems removed 330 deer this year at a cost to the township of $190 for each animal. All venison is donated to food banks. In the infant business of New Jersey deer control, the chief competitor is White Buffalo, a Connecticut company hired this year by Princeton.
"There are some days when there are no deer, when you are making three dollars an hour," said Mr. Barwick. "Then again, we do no advertising. We don't have to." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Signs like the one put up by James Cummings of Basking Ridge are protesting the culling of deer. (Nancy Wegard for The New York Times)(pg. 10)

HEADLINE: LAW AND ORDER; 
Where Are the Troopers When They're Wanted?

BYLINE:  By GEORGE JAMES 

 BODY:
IT was in December 1921 that the first group of New Jersey state troopers fanned out to patrol the rural hamlets and small towns that did not have police departments. Today, the state's police are being called back.
 Of those original 81 troopers, about 60 patrolled on horseback, primarily in the southern part of the state, while the rest rode motorcycles throughout central and northern New Jersey. 
 For nearly 81 years, the service was provided at no cost to the towns. But now the state -- more urbanized and with the highest population density in the nation -- has come upon some difficult financial choices. 
Indeed, to try to close a $5.3 billion deficit, Governor McGreevey is proposing as part of his $23.7 billion budget that the 98 municipalities benefiting from full or part-time state police coverage pay for it.
Officials say they expect the plan to save $11.7 million in the first year alone, though many mayors contend the notion is penny-wise and pound foolish.
It is an odd turn of events, since the mayors thought they had a friend in Mr. McGreevey, who as mayor of Woodbridge had to grapple with the same issues -- keeping property taxes down.
One of them, John Palovits, a 79-year old retired bus driver who has been the mayor of the Morris County borough of Victory Gardens for 12 years, said bluntly, "I think the man's crazy; he's going ape."
And Mr. Palovits is a fellow Democrat.
Mayor Palovits had nothing but praise for the state police, though he said he saw cars on patrol once a day at most. "We have a mile and a quarter to go around in," he said. "It only takes 10 minutes at most."
By contrast, Knowlton Township is a rambling 27 square miles, a sparsely settled community in Warren County where the occasional transgression is a bear filching a pie from somebody's kitchen. The mayor, Frank VanHorn, said he knew and liked Mr. McGreevey and sympathized with his economic concerns but added, "We think it's a bonehead idea."
Another fellow Democrat heard from.
Mr. VanHorn, who noted more than once that he grew up on a farm milking cows, said rural communities already paid double to the state what they get back in return. He added: "We've only 2,900 people here, so crime is very low. And how often do the state police come into rural communities?"
The New Jersey State League of Municipalities, which lobbies for the state's 566 communities, has come out strongly against the plan. So has Robert E. Littell, a Sussex County Republican who is co-chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, which will have to act on the measure, since 13 towns in Sussex are patrolled by the state police.
To William G. Dressel Jr., executive director of the League of Municipalities, it was not difficult to understand why local officials were so upset. Mr. Dressel said that the municipalities would have to pay the fee, create their own departments, seek help from the county or enter into shared service agreements with neighboring towns, probably resulting in a property tax increase.
By comparison, it cost Califon, a borough of about 1,000 residents in Hunterdon County, $89,315 in the current budget to finance its part-time police force of two, said Mayor Merwin Grimes. "We're in better shape than some of the surrounding communities because we do have a part-time police department," Mayor Grimes said.
Even as Governor McGreevey pursues his plan, neighboring states continue to provide policing services to communities without charge, an additional irritant.
The primary duty of the Pennsylvania State Police -- created in 1905 as the first statewide police agency -- is to patrol the rural and small towns that constitute 85 percent of the state. In Connecticut, nearly 50 percent the state's 169 municipalities are covered at no charge by the state police.
New Jersey's 98 communities that are under the gaze of the state police are situated in 14 of the state's 21 counties; Atlantic County has 6 municipalities that now get part- or full-state police service; Burlington has 14; Cape May 3; Cumberland 11; Gloucester 1; Hunterdon 16; Mercer 1; Monmouth 6; Morris 1; Ocean 2; Salem 8; Somerset 2; Sussex 13 and Warren 14.
It currently costs $70 million a year for the state police to provide services to 24 communities that have part-time police departments of their own and 74 that have none, said Ralph Siegel, a spokesman for the state Department of the Treasury.
The assessment to towns is $23.5 million. But because the state budgets follow the fiscal year, which begins July 1, and localities follow the calendar year, towns will be assessed beginning Jan. 1, 2003, and the first six months will cost $11.7 million. But the mayors have yet to learn how that will be broken down.
"I don't know what the numbers are going to mean to the borough and whether it will be reasonable enough for the services provided or whether it's going to create a burden for the high percentage of seniors in town," said Mayor Brian A. Nolan of Rocky Hill, a borough of 600 residents.
Mr. Siegel said that once the budget was approved, the reimbursement rate for each community would be determined by the treasurer, the Attorney General, and the commissioner of the Department of Community Affairs. "The governor takes this seriously in that the proposal is for three cabinet-level officials to work on a formula together," Mr. Siegel said.
Senator Littell was not impressed, and said that the measure would not pass if he had anything to say about it, noting that a similar proposal made during the administration of Gov. William T. Cahill in the 1970's had failed. "Most of these towns are small towns and needy and have at least one state highway running through the center and some times two," said Senator Littell. "So it is the responsibility of the state."
But George L. Kelling, a professor at the Rutgers School of Criminal Justice, said it might be time for communities to pay for coverage.
Professor Kelling said the first state police departments -- Pennsylvania, New York State, Michigan and New Jersey -- grew out of the progressive movement in politics that wanted to do away with corrupt city departments and establish a centralized police department -- above reproach -- at the state level. The first step was for the state police to provide services to rural areas and then take over the cities. 
"But that agenda never happened and now we have the situation in New Jersey of rural areas being policed by the state police," he said. "We have this historical oddity and it seems to me that what the governor is doing is facing up to that."
Thomas A. Reppetto, the author of "The Blue Parade," a history of policing published in 1978, said, "Sometimes there's more cost in upsetting established procedure than gain."

HEADLINE: CITIES; 
Closing A Door on Open Space

BYLINE:  By WENDY GINSBERG 

DATELINE: MILLVILLE 

 BODY:
AT a time when civic leaders are stampeding to get their piece of the $1 billion the state has set aside to preserve open space, elected officials in this rough-hewn little city, where bald eagles soar over shuttered factories, have done the unthinkable: They have asked the state for a moratorium on open space preservation.
 The move, which bucks the growing trend to participate in the state's popular farmland preservation programs, is what officials here say is a wake-up call to the administrators in Trenton who might not notice the effects that overly aggressive land acquisition have wreaked on this 44-square-mile city in Cumberland County. 
 "We wanted to shock the state," Vice Mayor W. James Parent said about a resolution approved by the city. "We wanted this to be like hitting them over the head with a two-by-four." 
The state Department of Environmental Protection declined to comment except to say that representatives were willing to talk with officials in Millville, where nearly 22 percent of the land is owned by the state or by environmental non-profit organizations. Another 15 percent of the land is undevelopable wetlands.
Around the state, voters are approving open space taxes by a ratio of nearly two-to-one in most referendums, said Judy Jengo, executive director of the Garden State Preservation Trust.
"More than 175 New Jersey towns currently participate in the state's open space programs, ten times more than participated just five years ago," Ms. Jengo said. "The city commission's rebuff of the program marks one of the first times a town has passed legislation criticizing the state's preservation efforts."
What local officials want to attract are businesses and industries that will add to the town's tax base without greatly flooding the schools or impeding trash collection.
While there is more than $66 million in taxable businesses in the city, that is about $2 million lower than previous years. And earlier this year, nearly $10 million in taxable land was purchased by the growing school district and stricken from the tax records.
To guard against losing more taxable land, the five-member city commission approved in February a resolution that told the state that open space preservation could have a detrimental effect on economic development and job creation, and asked that a moratorium be imposed on such purchases.
"We agree that there are certain open spaces that should be preserved," said Mayor James F. Quinn. "But we have to have tax ratables, too. If land is taken by a state agency, that land is gone forever. We have to make sure we think about the future of this town."
For his part, Mr. Quinn said he wanted the state and the nonprofit organizations to slow down their land acquisition efforts or raise the price they pay.
Although most people here believe that the commissioners had the town's best interest in mind when they passed the resolution, residents and environmentalists have nonetheless criticized the measure, calling it out of step and ill-advised.
"Every city needs ratables, but you have to remember that Millville is not a dying town," said Paul R. Porreca, a farmer and former city commissioner here. "The resolution just doesn't address the problem."
Millville is a post-industrial city that was once in the heart of New Jersey's glass-making mecca. Though many large companies have fled, T-Fal, which makes pots and pans, and Durand, a manufacturer of fine glassware, are still situated here. The southwest section of the city is home to a 916-acre airport, and the north end has the large manmade Union Lake.
Just a mile from the Pinelands National Reserve, Millville is home to acres of habitat for endangered species as well as the environmentally sensitive Maurice River.
Yet the city is also one of the state's 30 poorest school districts, known as Abbott Districts. The commission's latest idea for rejuvenating the city has the downtown -- which is nearly vacant -- transforming itself into an arts district.
"More than 25 storefronts on the town's main street have been sold over the past two years," Mr. Quinn said.
Local officials are also toying with the notion of luring a race track to the southern end of the city. They originally hoped to attract a Nascar event to the site, but the racing league expressed no interest -- preferring Atlantic City or sites in North Jersey. Now the commission hopes to attract luxury racing car owners to a $35 million race track, of which about $10 million would be publicly financed, Mr. Quinn said.
"Theyll come for a weekend, stay at our hotels and spend money is our downtown," Mr. Parent said. "Why Millville? Well, why not?"
City estimates show slightly more than 4,000 acres are ready for development, with water and sewer lines nearby. But some of that land is being considered for a crucial habitat designation because the endangered bald eagle, which nests in parts of the city, has been seen flying to the area.
Donald S. Ayres, director of economic development here, said he feared that the bald eagle's flying radius could be wide enough to allow most of the city to be considered a crucial habitat area.
"We just want to be told what they're planning to do," Mr. Ayres said. "And we want the state to make concessions when they build on land we think is developable."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST SIDE -- BUZZ; 
Happy Days Are Here Again, Rich Are Buying Rollses Again

BYLINE:  By DENNY LEE 

 BODY:
THE SETTING -- The home of Bentley Manhattan, the dealer of $300,000 automobiles, at Madison Avenue and 49th Street. Of the 2,000 Bentleys and Rolls-Royces made each year in Crewe, England, this store sells about 100.
 Last Wednesday, amid reports of an easing recession, there seemed to be slightly less sticker shock at the shop. Six cars sparkled in the showroom, teasing nearby office workers on lunch break. Visitors were not afraid to indulge their fantasies as they drooled over burr walnut dashboards and 420-horsepower engines. 

THE BUZZ -- "The last six weeks have been very busy," said Steven A. Schneir, the manager of the showroom. "We probably sold 15 in the last six weeks. It's a slightly better economic outlook."
Like most car dealers, Mr. Schneir, who this day wore a taupe double-breasted suit and a slicked-back mullet, has a game plan. 
"I give everybody 90 seconds," he said. "If the price doesn't make them run out the door, I offer them my assistance."
Jerome Brownstein walked straight up to a Continental R Mulliner, a "pre-owned special" for $245,000. He did not flinch. "Once you've bought one, you're sucked into the fantasy," he said, reminiscing about a Rolls he gave up in 1972.
But Mr. Brownstein, a retired lawyer, had no intention of buying. "My limo is now yellow, and my driver speaks Farsi." He left with a $160 souvenir pen.
The showroom attracted more oglers than walk-ins. By midafternoon, the store windows were smudged with sweaty palms. "They're the most flashiest right now," said Jermell Simmons of Harlem. "These are the Puff Daddy cars."
Mr. Daddy's, or Mr. Diddy's, people had called recently about another Bentley, his fourth. Not to drop names, but Chris Rock and Ralph Lauren are also in Mr. Schneir's Rolodex. "Our average demographic earns $14.4 million a year and owns five cars, 3.5 homes and part of an aircraft," he said. "Eighty-five percent pay in cash."
No one left that day with car keys, but one showroom regular stopped by to eat lunch in the "commissioning booth," or sales office. 
"The Bentley is a Fifth Avenue apartment on wheels," said Eitan Goldman, who owns a diamond company and, until he swapped it for a Porsche 911 Turbo, a 1999 Bentley Arnage. "I'm optimistic. The market is going to go up." DENNY LEE

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM; 
Black Heritage Vanishing, One Frayed Icon at a Time

BYLINE:  By JUDITH MATLOFF 

 BODY:
Over the past century, the red-brick Dwyer warehouse was a majestic fixture on the Harlem landscape, commanding the intersection of 123rd Street and St. Nicholas Avenue. Its stature as an architectural beacon never dimmed, even when it frayed into an abandoned, water-scarred shell. 
 Despite being eyed by preservationists, the nine-story structure never won landmark status -- and it certainly won't now. On April 2, a ceiling collapsed during work to convert the property into luxury lofts, killing a construction worker. The building is now slated for partial demolition. 
 Champions of Harlem heritage bemoan the loss. More important, they fear they will lose many more historic buildings to neglect or developers, who want to tear down or alter local architectural icons in the wake of gentrification.
"People come from around the world to discover the fable of Harlem," said Michael Henry Adams, an architectural historian and one of the neighborhood's most prominent defenders. "Increasingly, they are coming here and discovering that Harlem is being destroyed."
Large parts of Harlem, with its swaths of intact rowhouses, are virtually unchanged from the 19th century. And as the nation's black cultural capital, its history is rich and fertile.
The Landmarks Preservation Commission says it has made strides in recent years to landmark more property in the area above 96th Street, where 1,190 -- or 11 percent -- of Manhattan's 10,728 designated buildings are situated. This includes more than 900 buildings in Harlem, mainly in unspoiled pockets of Mount Morris, Hamilton Heights and Striver's Row.
But Mr. Adams wants 2,000 more Harlem properties protected, including the former residences of the artist Norman Rockwell, the musician Scott Joplin and the magician Harry Houdini, along with apartment buildings, synagogues, churches and blocks upon blocks of town houses. 
Paradoxically, some of the worst offenders in the preservationists' eyes are churches, like the powerful Abyssinian Baptist Church and the Convent Avenue Baptist Church, which have amassed, but not protected, property in the name of local economic improvement.
In a February resolution requesting emergency designation for four structures, Community Board 10 urged the city to reverse what it called a "long-term pattern of neglect." Some preservationists note that affluent areas like Greenwich Village tend to enjoy a high level of landmarking. 
Sherida E. Paulsen, the Landmarks Commission's chairwoman, noted that over the past two fiscal years her agency designated 380 buildings in the Hamilton Heights-Sugar Hill area and was considering many others. 
"We take three things into account -- architectural, historical and cultural," she said. "If Harlem is where we should be, we will be there." JUDITH MATLOFF

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2003 Honda Civic Hybrid; 
Getting Environmental Kicks on Route 66

BYLINE:  By CHERYL JENSEN 

DATELINE: AMARILLO, Tex. 

 BODY:
WE have traced Route 66 for two days, but our adventures haven't measured up to those of Buz and Tod in the television series of the early 1960's. We have enountered no lynch mobs, game poachers or Las Vegas showgirls.
 Maybe it's the times. Maybe it's us. Maybe it's the car. 
 The boys of "Route 66" had an eye-catching Corvette convertible. My husband and I are driving an unassuming 2003 Honda Civic Hybrid. They got more admiring glances. We are getting better fuel economy. 
 Our new-age road trip is taking us 2,400 miles from Palm Springs, Calif., to our home in Ohio in one of the first truly practical alternative cars. We want to see how easy the Civic Hybrid is to live with, on both high-speed interstates and slower-paced blue highways like the remnants of America's "mother road." We are mostly holding to the speed limit, usually 75 miles an hour in the wide-open West, but we not babying the car to get an unrealistic economy rating.
The Civic Hybrid, which goes on sale this month, is one of the most fuel-efficient and technologically advanced sedans in America. It uses the second generation of Honda's hybrid-drive technology, which combines a gasoline engine with an electric motor that gives a boost when more power is needed.
The Civic is the third hybrid car on the market. The two-door Honda Insight came first, as a 2000 model, and Toyota imported its Prius sedan for 2001.
Detroit's automakers have yet to offer a hybrid vehicle. Ford is expected to be the first, with a hybrid Escape S.U.V. late next year. DaimlerChrysler says it will start selling a hybrid next year, possibly a Jeep Liberty or a minivan. (The company had originally planned a hybrid version of its big Durango sport utility.) General Motors has promised a hybrid full-size pickup in 2004.
Unlike the Insight or Prius, both designed solely as hybrid cars, the Civic is significant precisely because it is not exotic. Honda has put its advanced powertrain in an existing car that has all the attributes and amenities of any Civic, including room for five people and a respectable trunk. This Civic just happens to get 40 percent better fuel economy.
It is a more expensive Civic, too, with a base price of $20,010, about $2,000 more than a comparably equipped Civic EX. With gas prices at current levels, one is unlikely to save enough on fuel to make up the difference, though that could change if gas prices spike, or if the government offers a green-tax credit for hybrid cars.
 This is not an electric car that one plugs in to charge batteries. It has a 1.3-liter 4-cylinder gasoline engine that gets an assist from a small electric motor. (The regular Civic has a larger, more thirsty 1.7-liter engine.)
When cruising, the car uses the gas engine only. When we slow down, the electric motor converts some of our momentum into electricity, which it sends to a battery pack behind the rear seat. When we need extra power -- to take off from a stoplight, to accelerate onto the highway, to climb a hill -- the electric motor kicks in.
Compared with the continuously variable automatic transmission of our test car, the standard-equipment five-speed manual extracts more power from the electric motor. But even with the variable automatic, the Civic Hybrid does not feel like an underpowered vehicle with a dinky engine.
We left Palm Springs on Thursday afternoon, spent a night in Kingman, Ariz., and arrived here in Amarillo Friday night, having driven 923 miles. We have averaged only 38.3 miles per gallon, a relatively poor showing partly due to the 75 m.p.h. speed limit and partly to our steady climb through much of Arizona.
We have watched a display on the instrument panel show the battery being recharged and discharged. Another display continuously estimates our mileage. We think we are capable of greater things.
The government estimates that the Civic Hybrid will get 48 m.p.g. in town and 47 m.p.g. on the highway with the automatic, and 46 in town and 51 on the highway with the stick shift. A gas-only Civic EX automatic is rated at 30 city, 38 highway.
On Saturday morning, we are at the Cadillac Ranch, a pop art monument on the outskirts of Amarillo. where 10 old Cadillacs are embedded nose-down in concrete, their tailfins punctuating the plains around this automotive Stonehenge. Now covered with graffiti, the cars represent one version of the American dream.
Driving up in a hybrid car adds new layers of symbolism to the site. These old Caddys have gone bumper up. Are hybrids a first step toward turning the internal-combustion engine into a dinosaur?
The Civic Hybrid is a quiet revolutionary, since it doesn't look much different from any other Civic. Although Honda has changed a few things -- making the front bumper more aerodynamic, for instance -- the car doesn't attract any notice as we head to Oklahoma to look for Lucille's, a service station and souvenir stand operated by Lucille Hamons since, we have read, 1941.
But there are other differences. Honda calls the Hybrid not just the highest-technology Civic, but the most refined Civic. The interior is more upscale and there is more standard equipment (antilock brakes, side air bags). Oddly, the color choices do not include green.
The Hybrid also drives better. Although it uses the same parts, the suspension has been firmed up. Putting the batteries in the trunk improves the car's balance, making it feel less nose-heavy and more fun.
It also feels more structurally solid and more stable than the Prius. It leans less on corners.
Because the Civic Hybrid's gas engine is small, it is also quieter and less prone to vibrate than the larger engine in the standard Civic. The new electric power steering is also much more responsive.
As we head to Lucille's, we notice that cutting our speed by 5 miles an hour raises our mileage by about 2 m.p.g. When driving 65 m.p.h., we are getting 44 m.p.g.
These days, there isn't much left of Route 66 or its landmarks. When we finally find Lucille's, just yards from Interstate 40 in Hydro, Okla., we learn that the proprietor has died. A wooden cross serves as a memorial; her little outpost is padlocked.
As we slow down to look around, we realize that we have tuned out the slight engine whine that we originally thought was a distant fire truck.
From St. Louis we picked up U.S. 50 and held to the 50 m.p.h. speed limit. The route crosses flat prairie and runs along the Illinois Central Railroad tracks through small towns, each with its claim to fame. Olney, Ill., for instance, is the Home of the White Squirrels. (The town has a preponderance of albino squirrels.)
Soon we are entering Indiana over the Red Skelton Bridge over the Wabash River. After 134 miles on U.S. 50 at 50 m.p.h., we've averaged 61.3 m.p.g. -- our best mileage of the trip.
Although this 1.3-liter engine is much smoother than the 1.7-liter in the standard Civic, there is a disadvantage to its size. At start-up, with a light foot on the gas pedal, there is some slight vibration, though it fades above 1,500 r.p.m.
The seats aren't very comfortable for long distances, but they are far better than the seats in the Insight, which have virtually no padding. To achieve high mileage, Honda built the Insight to be as light as possible.
After 2,400 miles, it is clear that the Civic Hybrid is not just good for the environment, but good to drive, too, without the discomforts of the rough-riding Insight. You need not give up much to be environmentally friendly, other than 2.9 cubic feet of trunk space taken by the batteries.
Honda expects to sell 24,000 Civic Hybrids a year, and that seems reasonable. A recent survey by J. D. Power & Associates estimated that Americans will be buying 500,000 hybrids a year by 2006, even if gas prices change little. And why not? A car like the Civic Hybrid offers a painless way to be green, even if it doesn't come in green.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
Tough Times Linger for Software Industry

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
COMPUTER software stocks have been shrinking in value. 
 Excluding Microsoft, a group of 116 companies tracked by Morgan Stanley has lost 22 percent of market capitalization since the start of the year. That number is now around $550 billion. 
 Last week, Thomas Siebel, chief executive of Siebel Systems, rattled investors when he said the contraction was not over. At the start of the year, Mr. Siebel was bullish. 
Charles E. Phillips, computer software analyst at Morgan Stanley, talked last week about the difficult conditions in this high-margin business. Following are excerpts from the conversation.

Q. Why were so many people initially optimistic about prospects for software companies?

A. The December quarter was good enough to get people excited. People were allowed to do a lot of year-end budget spending. In hindsight, what went on then was an aberration. It was assumed that an improving economy is a good thing, and that technology spending would closely follow that. But from a profitability standpoint, corporate customers are still under pressure.

Q. What are the prospects for the two broad components of the software business, applications and infrastructure?

A. Applications software is a packaged business process. Intuit, which sells tax software, is an applications company.
Infrastructure is for backup and recovery, tools you need to help back up applications. Companies like Veritas Software, Computer Associates and Oracle are infrastructure software companies. 
During a downturn, infrastructure software tends to do better. Applications software sales are totally dependent on new projects. So the applications guys tend to fall off farther and faster.

Q. What is the outlook for software?

A. The first quarter tends to be the toughest of the year. We do monthly surveys of chief information officers. Those surveys got worse all through last year, stabilized at the end of the year and have gotten a little worse since then.
I don't expect to see much of a recovery until the fourth quarter, with better prospects for 2003. 
When the pickup comes, it won't mean big numbers, but improved numbers. The likelihood of returning to the days of 50 percent growth are pretty much gone. Excluding Microsoft, the independent software companies generate about $90 billion worth of revenues. In the aggregate, we will be lucky to get growth of 10 percent to 12 percent. The industry is maturing.

Q. Is the software business bad everywhere, or just in the United States?

A. Business in the United States has definitely fallen off more, but things are slowing in Europe and Asia now. But the decline there will not be as severe. Those regions did not have the same excess Y2K- and Internet-related buying binge as American customers.

Q. Mr. Siebel predicted that a lot of small software companies would go out of business this year. Would consolidation help?

A. Consolidation will help some, may help margins a little bit, but these small companies weren't relevant anyway. A lot of them shouldn't have been started in the first place.

Q. Are the barriers to entry in software low?

A. Some segments have high barriers. There won't be any new database software companies. Microsoft, I.B.M. and Oracle will battle it out there for years to come. And SAP, PeopleSoft and Oracle have the back-office applications segment for accounting and manufacturing.

Q. Are software stocks attractively priced?

A. The stocks have come off a lot, but they were overvalued. And earnings are less now than they were. For the most part, valuations are in line with where they should be. But the stocks are not bargains. In the near term, most of the sector will be revising guidance on earnings down, and the second-half numbers will be coming down.

Q. Should investors avoid software?

A. The average investor should probably stay away. They are volatile stocks with a lot of risk, too much risk for the average investor.
There are definitely companies that will be around for 10 years, but they could still underperform the market during that time frame. Companies like SAP, PeopleSoft, Oracle, Veritas Software and Computer Associates are going to be viable for years to come.

Q. Do you give any of the the stocks an "overweight" rating, Morgan Stanley's highest?

A. SAP and Peregrine Software, which builds software to track assets in a company, are rated "overweight." Lots of the rest are rated "equal weight," which means they will perform in line with the rest of the market.

HEADLINE: One Small Step for Man, 25 Backward for Women 

BYLINE:  By GINIA BELLAFANTE 

 BODY:
ANYONE keen to argue that America is in the midst of a second wave of feminist backlash doesn't have to work hard to stack the arsenal. A new book, "Creating a Life: Professional Women and the Quest for Children," by the economist Sylvia Ann Hewlett, paints a profoundly gloomy picture for career women (or those merely unattached) who hope to delay life's McClaren stroller phase past the age of 35. Last week the book formed the basis of a "60 Minutes" broadcast and a Time magazine cover story featuring an illustration of a mournful-looking woman cradling a blanket that held a briefcase and a Palm Pilot.
 Such a woman would find little to improve her mood in "The Bachelor," a new reality show on ABC that exists as a hyperbolic reminder of the pernicious view that man-catching at this point in history has odds analogous to hitting the superfecta. On the first episode of the show, which has won healthy ratings on Monday nights in prime time, 25 young women with names like Amber, Angelique and Trista were dispatched to a beach house in Malibu to compete for the attention of a 31-year-old management consultant, the kind of young man to whom the gods have apparently denied nothing. 
 Each week the bachelor, Alex Michel, winnows the group down to an ever more select few. Tomorrow night begins a three-episode final round in which four women parry for the title of Mrs. Right. Or at least that is what they are ostensibly doing. Mr. Michel is under no contractual obligation to propose to any of them, Mike Fleiss, the show's producer, said, though the audience is allowed to nurture the impression that the process will result in marriage. So far, the woman with whom Mr. Michel seems most infatuated is a 24-year-old operations assistant from Dallas named Shannon, who announced to the camera last week during a date at the Four Seasons in Beverly Hills, "I am Pretty Woman!"
Realists would say that this is not the sort of woman that fate would otherwise choose for Mr. Michel. Unlike Rick Rockwell, the discredited orange-toned prospective husband of "Who Wants to Marry a Millionaire" a few seasons back, Mr. Michel is a bachelor of considerable social advantage. Born in the horse country of Charlottesville, Va., he grew up in Darien, Conn., the son of a chief executive. He studied at Harvard and Stanford business school, working in between at C-Net, a San Francisco technology company.
Since "The Bachelor" began, friends of Mr. Michel have been amusedly exchanging e-mail messages and phone calls, and most are not dumbfounded that his path would lead him to such an outing.
"There isn't a wedding I know of from Harvard or Stanford or any of the derivative feeder schools like St. Paul's that Alex isn't invited to," said David DiDomenico, a friend from college and graduate school. "He's an incredibly brilliant guy, and he has a level of charisma that is Clintonesque."
Arguably the most distasteful aspect of "The Bachelor" is a class dynamic that has women from a very different universe vying for Mr. Michel's legitimization. Besides the predictable number of aspiring actresses, the initial group consisted of a bartender, a woman who sold power tools and a dancer for the Miami Heat (who is still very much in the running). In last week's episode, a 23-year-old events planner from Chanute, Kan., who is falling for Mr. Michel declared that he was raising her standards in men.
"We tried to find smart women," explained Mr. Fleiss, already looking hard for another single man for "The Bachelor 2." "They didn't have to be bluebloods. We had at least one Ivy Leaguer. I think we tried to find a good cross section of people." As for the selection of Mr. Michel, Mr. Fleiss said, "He seemed like a real catch, the kind of guy you lose a girl to -- the guy with the good family and money and the handsome grin."
Mr. Michel's friends are quick to say that he has an enormous capacity to appreciate the absurd, and that he should find himself immersed in the bizarre world of reality TV somehow makes sense. When Owen West, an acquaintance from Harvard and Stanford, heard about Mr. Michel's latest adventure, he said, "I was not that surprised." 
Ben Nemo, another Stanford friend, said: "I think the likelihood of his finding a lifelong match from this is not very high. But I've never known Alex as someone who needed to be the center of attention, which makes me think that part of his motivation for this is genuine."
Five years ago, Mr. Michel said, "I would never have done this." He heard about "The Bachelor" from a friend, he said, "and I thought the odds of meeting someone great would be pretty high." He has had serious relationships and spent plenty of time as a dater. 
Producers subjected him to an intensive background check that included a personality inventory, blood tests and interviews with former girlfriends. (No one wanted a repeat of the "Marry a Millionaire" debacle, when Mr. Rockwell turned out to have been the subject of a restraining order for threatening a fiancee.) When Mr. Michel told his parents about his latest project, "they were supportive," he said, "but they were definitely concerned and thought it was a pretty weird thing to do."
Mr. Michel comes across as a genial and affecting suitor, the kind of guy who seems almost squeamish about the process of rejecting. Still it is Mr. Michel who has been letting women go. The chosen ones have the right to turn down his offer to continue toward a proposal of matrimony at the end of each episode, but so far no one has done so. 
Last week, one of the women, a real-estate agent from Texas, fled in tears after having been rejected and experienced a panic attack, on camera, that required medical assistance. "If I had to make a list, he has it all," she said earlier in the episode, even though she had not spent more than half an hour with Mr. Michel. Most of the women received no compensation; the four finalists, who will have taken off from work for five weeks for taping, are promised a few hundred dollars each.
That the conceit of the show is blatantly sexist, that the women seem prepared to defenestrate one another for 10 minutes of time alone with Mr. Michel are observations he objects to. "I think that's overblown," he said. "No one is saying 'this is how dating should be.' " 
"I don't think of these women as desperate," Mr. Michel added.
Meanwhile, Mr. Michel's friends are entertaining themselves with elaborate betting pools that aim to guess who he will keep or cast off at the end of each episode. One, pool, titled "Al Madness," initiated by Mr. Nemo, is formatted on an Excel spreadsheet and modeled after brackets used for betting on the college basketball championships. Tiebreaker questions include "What is the combined weight of the Episode 5 finalists?" Another group of businessmen with a $1,200 pool have been trading options on various contestants. "There was literally a scheduled conference call for this," said one of the participants, who did not want to be named. 
Some of the players might now be wishing they had bought options on a young woman not seen on "The Bachelor" who was spotted holding hands with Mr. Michel in Los Angeles last week, gossip columns reported. "There's no romance," Mr. Michel said on Friday. "She's a friend." A friend, it turns out, from Harvard.

HEADLINE: Business; 
Venture Capitalists See Investors Grow Mutinous

BYLINE:  By AMY CORTESE 

 BODY:
IN March, Battery Ventures, a leading venture capital firm, held an annual meeting in a Florida resort for its limited partners, which include some of the biggest pension funds and endowments. 
 A moment of levity came when Thomas J. Crotty, a Battery executive, awarded a trophy to a limited partner who had won a golf tournament. As he presented the cup, a cheap $100 job, Mr. Crotty said it showed "just how desperate V.C.'s are to give anything to a limited partner these days." 
 The remark drew laughs, but it also reflected the escalating tension between venture capitalists and their investors. In the two years since the Internet bubble burst, venture investors have watched their lush profits shrivel. Yet many venture capitalists are still doing quite well for themselves because of the large management fees they collect from investors. Fees are based on their funds' size, so as funds ballooned over the last few years -- about 40 have at least $1 billion in capital -- so have the fees. 
With typical fees at 2 to 3 percent of a fund, a venture capital firm with a $1 billion fund would collect $20 million to $30 million annually from investors, even if only a small amount of the fund has been invested -- and into money-losing companies at that.
The incongruence is at the heart of a brewing investor rebellion. While limited partners have little legal recourse, many are demanding more information and pushing venture capitalists to make changes, like reducing the size of funds and, therefore, the fees. At least five big firms have scaled back funds this year.
"Limited partners have gone from sullen to mutinous," said Howard Anderson, the senior managing director of YankeeTek Ventures, a venture capital firm in Cambridge, Mass. "What's driving them nuts is that the venture partnerships do well in bad years. If rewards are shared, the pain should be shared, too."
Those tensions have boiled over at some of this season's annual meetings, which began in February but hit full stride this month. They are the one time when venture capitalists formally address all of their investors, and are usually polite affairs where criticism, if any, is reserved. But with the bulk of meetings still to come, venture capitalists are bracing for the worst.
"The limited-partner community is scared, angry and in a mood to be more challenging of their money managers," Mr. Crotty said. Although Battery's performance is better than many, he said, "we weren't sure what kind of audience we were going to face."
Mr. Crotty's colleague, Anthony Abate, put it more colorfully: "We thought they were going to storm the Bastille."
Battery's meeting went better than its investment leaders had expected, they said, partly because they spoke frankly and tried to answer all questions. But meetings at some other firms have been strained.
THE annual meeting of Redpoint Ventures of Menlo Park, Calif., was held in February at a nearby hotel. People at the meeting said one investor stood up and challenged the firm's capacity to invest its $1.25 billion fund prudently. Redpoint partners offered their rationale but, according to one attendee, "the dogs weren't eating the dog food." A month later, Redpoint reduced its fund size by 25 percent.
The most uncomfortable standoff may have been at the meeting of Idealab, the technology incubator, held in March in Pasadena, Calif. The firm has been sued by investors including Dell Computer and Moore Global Investments, who have accused Bill Gross, its founder, of mismanagement. Mr. Gross is fighting the suit. 
The meeting was contentious from the start. Idealab insisted that a court reporter, brought in by some aggrieved investors, leave the meeting. The firm distributed rules of conduct for the meeting, stating that it could stop discussions that exceeded two minutes, used derogatory references or concerned confidential information related to the lawsuit.
Presentations by Marcia Goodstein, who is the president and chief operating officer and Mr. Gross's fiancee, and by a director, Robert Kavner, a former executive vice president at AT&T, were among those prompting pointed questions, according to two people who attended. Idealab said it invested about $1 million a month but spent twice that much a month to operate its fledgling companies. The largest operating expense, it disclosed, goes to salary and benefits: Mr. Gross's compensation, including salary and bonus, exceeded $750,000 in 2002, up from $250,000 in 2000. During that same period, the plaintiffs charge, Idealab lost half their $1 billion investment. Idealab says some of the money was invested in companies that are still going concerns. Several investors walked out early.
The mood is a far cry from that of the late 1990's, when the meetings were more like lovefests and investors didn't care to hear the details because the cash was flowing in. 
"Limited partners are forcing the general partners to go back and rethink whether they can invest their money within a reasonable amount of time," said Jonathan Axelrad, a lawyer at Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosati, a law firm that represents technology companies. "This is a unique set of circumstances the venture industry has not faced before. People are casting about for creative solutions."
That partly explains the fund-cutting in the venture world. Some prominent firms, like Mohr, Davidow Ventures and Kleiner Perkins Caufield Byers, have voluntarily reduced size and averted investor criticism. "If you see this palace revolt coming, maybe you head it off and take some action," Mr. Anderson of YankeeTek said. 
The cuts have pressured other venture capitalists to trim funds or split them up. Fund size is "an area of significant concern to limited partners, and properly so," said Alan Austin, chief operating officer at Accel Partners, which has proposed splitting its $1 billion fund into two. That would reduce some management fees but still lock up investors' capital. It is unclear if Accel investors, who voted on the change by mail, have approved it; results will be tallied in time for annual meeting on April 25. If it is defeated, the meeting "could be a real food fight," one investor said.
Few regulations cover what venture capital firms must disclose, and the level of information they provide to their investors varies widely. Some gloss over details at their meetings, but that approach is not going over well this year. To some extent, the funds are feeling the same pressures for openness that has roiled the broader investing world since the collapse of Enron.
Battery Ventures spent months preparing for its meeting, where it dissected the firm's performance, good and bad. It detailed write-downs and write-offs and went over a "watch list" of troubled investments. (Three were shut down, three received more financing and one was sold for $350 million.) Battery also told investors that the 2001 revenue of its 27 portfolio companies was $275 million less than it had forecast.
From an investor's point of view, such transparency is helpful in difficult times.
"We want as much information as possible," said Richard J. Hayes, a senior investment officer at Calpers, the huge pension fund. "Most of our partners are getting into the nitty-gritty details of their investments. That's what we want."

GRAPHIC: Photo: General partners in Battery Ventures -- Thomas J. Crotty, left, Todd Dagres, center, and Oliver Curme -- reported the good and bad to investors at a meeting last month. (Rick Friedman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Memory Maker 

BYLINE:  By CONSTANCE ROSENBLUM 

 BODY:
DOZENS of times a day, every day of the year, for half a century, a little drama played itself out in a three-story red-brick building on East Kingsbridge Road just off the Grand Concourse in the Bronx. 
 In a second-floor apartment that had been transformed into a photography studio, a neatly dressed man with haunted eyes ducked under a black velvet cloth. You could hear him rustling around, adjusting the 8-by-10-inch Kodak studio camera perched on the three-legged mahogany stand. As he peered through the camera, a miniature image of a family stared back at him, the children wriggling slightly in their starched clothes, waiting solemnly in the glare from two enormous floor lamps for the signal to smile. 
 Silently, photographer and subject regarded one another. Then a slender hand emerged and squeezed the terra cotta-colored rubber bulb, preserving for posterity the image of yet another Bronx family. 
The man in the white shirt and tie was Kourken Hovsepian, who reigned for half a century, from the mid-1920's to the late 1970's, as one of the borough's premier studio photographers. 
Mr. Kirk, as he was known to everyone from Yankee Stadium up to Van Cortlandt Park, would never have called himself an artist. "For him it was making a living," said his daughter, Mimi Vang Olsen, a small, effervescent woman who saved all her father's work. But in the process of making a living, this Armenian refugee left a remarkable legacy, creating thousands of images that offer a portrait of a golden place during a golden age, or so it is recalled by those who look back misty eyed. 
The fabled heart of this world was the Grand Concourse, a true boulevard of dreams for the waves of upwardly mobile Jews, and some Irish, who streamed there from lesser addresses around the city, drawn by the street's almost palpable sense of promise. The four-and-a-half-mile-long tree-lined thoroughfare was completed in 1909, and by the mid-1930's it and its environs were as much a state of mind as a geographical destination.
Sleek Art Deco apartment houses had sprouted along the edges of the Concourse, complete with sunken living rooms, airy corner windows and doormen in dashing little capes. Adding to the neighborhood's luster were legendary landmarks, like the 4,000-seat Loew's Paradise. There, real goldfish swam in a marble pool, the decor included $10,000 worth of artificial birds, and virtually every Bronx girl of a certain era got her first real kiss under a ceiling of twinkling stars and drifting vapor clouds. 
The great flowering of this world was well under way when Mr. Kirk made his appearance, and like countless Armenians before him, he arrived with few belongings but considerable psychological baggage, in the form of nightmarish memories of his escape from his ravaged homeland.
In 1913, when he was barely a teenager, marauding Turks wiped out his native town of Harput. They murdered his father and sent his mother, sister and two brothers on a pitiless death march into the scorching desert; Kourken survived only because he escaped over the Caucasus to Russia. In a tape recording made for his daughter near the end of his life, he described the massacre with terrifying clarity: "Bodies melting like wax, floating down the river in the hot sun." 
Thousands of miles away, in Worcester, Mass., America's largest Armenian diaspora, a cousin named Kazar Melikian had already established a thriving photographic studio. It was there that Kourken Hovsepian, who arrived in America in 1920, found his calling. By 1927, newly married to a pretty young Hungarian girl named Lilly, he was proudly ensconced in his own studio at 52 East Kingsbridge Road, just above Spotless Cleaners, taking his place with those other icons of midcentury life in the borough: Sol and Moe's candy store; Brownstein's hardware; Star Drug; G and R Jewish bakery; Fountain Beauty Salon; the Irish bars. 
"He'd tell people it was between the Concourse and Jerome Avenue, even though it was really between Morris and Creston," his daughter recalled. "Everyone knew the Grand Concourse." 
In those years, long before the arrival and subsequent popularity of the Kodak Instamatic, the Polaroid and the photo chains, the local studio photographer was a fixture of life. While the field of commercial photography would produce a number of photo-world stars and was rich with its own traditions and aesthetic, the role of the neighborhood studio was primarily social, the major venue through which, in that era, families recorded milestones large and small.
"The studio photographer created the record of how people wanted themselves seen, how they wanted themselves to be remembered," said Bonnie Yochelson, author of "Berenice Abbott: Changing New York: The Complete WPA Project" (New Press and the Museum of the City of New York, 1997). "He was the one entrusted with creating their legacy. He told the story of ordinary people."
This was a perfect description of Mr. Kirk's role. Over the years, he recorded every variety of ethnic and religious celebration: bar mitzvahs for the Jews, communions and christenings for Irish, Italian, Greek and German clients, and weddings for everyone. Family portraits, the earliest preserved on fragile 8-by-10 glass negatives, trace the evolution of households almost from cradle to grave. In the wedding pictures -- Mr. Kirk's big, taffeta-covered albums were a specialty of the house -- starry-eyed brides emerge triumphant from a sea of attendants, their enormous trains swirling about them like giant organdy fishtails. 
June brought to Mr. Kirk's studio beaming graduates clutching new diplomas. During the war, a parade of soldiers, sailors, Wacs and Waves -- many of whom had trained at the Kingsbridge Armory just up the street -- came by for portraits to give their parents before being shipped overseas. Buried under the pictures of ceremonial events are luscious, creamy-limbed women adrift in chiffon -- aspiring actresses, perhaps; thanks to a trick of focusing, their faces and bodies are gauzy as a dream. 
As you riffle through these photographs, which have been carefully stored in cartons in Ms. Olsen's Hudson Street row house in Greenwich Village, a long-vanished world leaps into life. You can almost hear the buoyant tarantellas, the cantor's lyric chant. You can almost hear the clink of Champagne flutes. Your fingers long to caress the plush Persian lamb coats. You can almost smell the Shalimar.
 THE four-room apartment on East Kingsbridge Road soon housed a family of four; a son, Kirk, was born in 1935, a daughter, Mimi, in 1938. But domestic activities were tucked away in the back bedroom and kitchen, and the remaining two rooms were devoted to the studio. The parents slept there, on a foldout sofa. The children slept in the tiny rear bedroom, in foldout chairs that became beds, and were constantly shushed. A walk-in closet had been converted into a darkroom and retouching area, and in the bathroom, drying negatives hung from a wooden frame above the tub and damp prints dried on a cheesecloth-covered rack.
When customers arrived, Mr. Kirk would wheel over one of his painted backdrops, either the richly colored brocade or the pale, pastoral scene. A family might be grouped in front of the oak plant stand with the claw feet or near the antique library table that now sits in Ms. Olsen's front room. 
Once the subjects were arranged, Mr. Kirk would dip into his drawer of props for the perfect accessory: the velvet stole that made possible the off-the-shoulder look (a girl had to be over 16 for that); the bouquets of dried roses and camellias; the prayer book for confirmation and communion pictures; the snap-on bow tie that made every young man look spiffy. 
"He never diverged from certain poses or certain props," his daughter recalled. "Babies got a tin rattle to shake. Older children got a red rubber ball, a truck or a doll. Sometimes my doll." 
Sunday, the day the brides came, was a madhouse. The entire wedding party, or two or three, descended in full bridal attire after the ceremony, and everyone had a drink in honor of the occasion. Impressionable little Mimi was in heaven. After the last click of the shutter, the participants and Mr. Kirk headed off to a reception at one of the great Bronx ballrooms or restaurants. 
Later, when the place was quieter, Mr. Kirk retreated to his darkroom, where for decades he measured his chemicals using an old-fashioned brass scale fitted with miniature weights, and then to his workbench, to retouch his images and print the best of them. Until the arrival of color photography, he hand-tinted all his pictures, using toothpicks wrapped with wisps of cotton and dabbed in special oil paints, a task his daughter eventually assumed. 
"I was more bold," said Ms. Olsen, who started helping her father when she was 11. "Perhaps it was because he was never trained as a painter. He didn't see a lot of color in black and white photos." 
Or maybe, she suggested, the explanation was more complicated. Looking at Mr. Kirk as he bent earnestly over his light box, his slender frame silhouetted by the light streaming in behind his shoulder, a Lucky Strike dangling from his lips, you might not know how troubled a soul he was. As with so many of his countrymen, the demons of his childhood haunted him until his death. 
The same horrific past may explain why the refrigerator at 52 East Kingsbridge Road was always bursting with rolled grape leaves, salted black olives, lamb meat pies and other tempting Armenian delicacies. And perhaps why he never switched on a radio when he worked, even as the sounds of Sinatra and doo-wop bounced from nearly every corner of the borough.
"He didn't want to leave his apartment, except for photography jobs," his daughter said. "He'd been wandering for so long alone in his youth. He just wanted a safe place with his little family." 
Yet even a home and family could not keep the nightmares at bay. And so he drank, and by the late 1950's he was drinking heavily. Sometimes he slipped downstairs for a few whiskeys with Vinnie Orotelli, who owned the barbershop next door, but more often he drank alone. Liquor made him aggressive, not physically but verbally, as his family remembered all too well. Afterward, he tumbled into bed and slept it off, only to have the cycle repeat itself the next time the past drew too near.
 OF all the milestones preserved in amber in Mr. Kirk's trove of contact sheets, few were more lavish than the 1949 wedding of Betty Kanganis, the daughter of a florist, and Nick Raptis, the nephew of a florist. Their romance was the talk of New York's Greek community, mostly because Betty was really just a child when it began, a sophomore at Walton High School, her Sweet 16 party still a year away. 
Her father, George, ran the florist shop on Kingsbridge Road and Jerome Avenue, with his brother, Charlie. Nick, born in America but raised in Greece, worked for a wholesaler in the flower district.
The two young people met at one of the flower dances held at the Pennsylvania Hotel, an annual ritual for the Greek florist community. One of Betty's aunts had mentioned "a gorgeous hunk of man," and, truth be told, when Nick first asked her to dance, Betty was a little disappointed. But some months later, when Nick announced his intention of returning to Greece, she changed her mind. After a courtship conducted under the watchful eye of Betty's grandmother, the marriage finally took place. The bride was 17, the groom nearly 25. 
The Rev. Basil Efthimiou performed the Greek Orthodox ceremony on Feb. 27, at Holy Trinity Cathedral on East 74th Street. (In a lovely echo, Father Basil's son, Milton, would preside decades later at St. Barbara's in Toms River, N.J., where the couple retired in 1989.)
Betty wore an ivory satin gown from J. Thorpe, hand-trimmed with lace and seed pearls, with a matching beaded crown and her glossy dark braids piled high on her head, giving her the look of a young Greek princess. Her father made her bouquet of orchids and lilies of the valley in his shop. At the reception in the garlanded ballroom of the Concourse Plaza Hotel, 320 guests rumbaed and tangoed to the George Kravas Orchestra, the city's reigning Greek musicians.
Earlier in the day, Mr. Kirk had taken pictures in the Kanganis apartment on East 196th Street: the adjusting of the bride's gown, the arranging of the flowers, the (mock) carrying of the bride over the threshold. But the real prologue to the wedding lies in the dozens of Kanganis family portraits that Mr. Kirk had taken over the previous two decades, pictures that show Betty maturing from a solemn infant to a beautiful woman. 
Here she is at 2, plopped on a chair like a rag doll, all bobbed hair and ruffled yoke, "the best-dressed little girl in town," as she remembered it. At 4, one leg tucked under her in the classic Shirley Temple pose, an enormous bow in her hair. At 6, with a headful of ringlets, courtesy of her patient mother. At 9, in a maroon velvet sailor dress that was her favorite that year, her hair long and flowing, tucked in her mother's embrace. At 10, with her hands stuck adorably in a muff. Her eighth-grade graduation from Public School 86, wearing the white organdy dress she had made in sewing class, arm in arm with her cousin Helen, "closer to me than a sister," who was maid of honor at her wedding. 
Then, newly engaged, displaying the $400 diamond in a white gold setting that Nick had bought in Washington Heights. Nick was earning $30 a week at the time, and though he emptied his bank account, he was still short. A friend offered a loan. Within six months, Nick had paid back every cent.
 BETTY and Nick Raptis longed to live on the Concourse. "Oh, God, we wanted a place on the Concourse so bad!" Mr. Raptis said years later. Nothing in their price range was available just then, and so in 1954 they bought a house in Yonkers, a short commute from the florist shop they now ran. But even as they were packing their bags, powerful currents were beginning to flow that eventually transformed the world of the Concourse. 
Because of complex social and economic forces that echoed far beyond the borough, low-income blacks and Puerto Ricans in the South Bronx began pushing north into neighborhoods that had been rooted, stable and, more to the point, almost entirely white. Crime, much of it drug-related, and urban disarray increased, accelerating in some quarters a never quite disguised racism. When Co-op City opened the first of its nearly 16,000 apartments in the northeast Bronx in 1966, it was as if a sluice gate had opened. Whole buildings seemed to move there en masse. 
Jews, like the Irish, have always been ready to move out of changing neighborhoods. Other groups, like Italians, tend to stay put longer. But across many ethnic lines, the next generation usually yearns to move up and out. If Co-op City had not been built, the exodus of the Jews of the Grand Concourse and the accompanying transformation might have been slower and less convulsive. But who can say it would not have taken place? 
In 1980, Ms. Olsen moved her parents to Starrett City in Brooklyn, where friends had settled. Her father, then 80, died within the year. Her mother died in 1986.
Were Mr. Kirk's ghost to walk the streets of his old neighborhood today, it would come upon a new world. Spotless Cleaners is long departed. Botanica San Lazar, its successor, serves a thriving Latino population that has restored a modicum of the area's earlier stability. Its shelves are lined with pastel potions bearing enticing labels like "Ven a mi" ("Come to me"), "Steadywork," "Dominantemaster" and what sounds best of all, "Jinx removing." A statue of St. Barbara is wreathed with miniature red carnations. "You don't want to leave the saint naked," Sandra, the Brazilian owner, said.
One of the few survivors of the past is Mr. Orotelli, the barber. He retired to New Jersey, but comes back a few days a week to don a crimson jacket and cut a little hair. "After 35 years, you have a lot of memories," he said. But not much else has remained. No one who lived on the block when he arrived is still around, he said. The last holdout, who lived at No. 56, died a couple of years ago. 
Still, there is another survivor of the Bronx of those days: Mr. Kirk's marvelous photographs. The daughter who used to dab color on the black and white prints and who went on to study painting at the School of Visual Arts made sure of that. In an apartment whose layout mirrors the place of her birth -- "It's an identical setup," she said, "I'm so conscious of it" -- she also creates domestic portraits. 
Her subjects too are people, and their pets, in their homes; she creates oil portraits for the well-heeled urban dweller. While she works, tucked away behind Mr. Kirk's oak library table and the little brass scales, boxes and boxes of photographs, glass negatives and faded purple proofs slowly gather dust and memories.

SECTION: Section 4; Column 1; Editorial Desk; Pg. 13

LENGTH: 561 words

HEADLINE: Will Rural America Have a Future? 

BYLINE:  By Chuck Hassebrook; Chuck Hassebrook is executive director of the Center for Rural Affairs in Walthill, Neb.

DATELINE: WALTHILL, Neb. 

 BODY:
As the farm bill continues to be debated in a conference committee seeking a compromise between House and Senate versions, the prospects for a good law are worsening. The choice is simple. Congress can write bigger checks to the nation's biggest farms -- which seems to be where the consensus is heading -- or it can make a significant investment in creating genuine opportunity in rural America. It cannot do both. 
 Opportunity is in short supply in much of rural America. Stretches of Nebraska and the Dakotas include the nation's two lowest-income counties and more than half of the bottom 20. Across a wide swath of rural America, communities are dying and churches and schools are closing. 
 Community decline is driven by agricultural decline. Small and medium-size farms are being driven out by falling prices for farm commodities and aggressive competition from large farms armed with six-figure federal payments. As a study by the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment concluded, "Communities that are surrounded by farms that are larger than can be operated by a family have a bimodal income distribution with a few wealthy elites, a majority of poor laborers and virtually no middle class."
That is not progress. That is social decay.
The farm bill can be a vehicle to restore social progress and economic opportunity in rural America.
But the conference committee reconciling the House and Senate farm bills must resolve two critical issues.
First, conference committee leaders must find the courage to stop subsidizing the large farms in such a way that they are assisted in pushing their smaller neighbors out of business. The Senate bill caps payments to large farms. The House does not.
Farmers and nonfarmers agree on this issue. A recent survey covering 27 states found that 81 percent of farmers polled want farm income support payments carefully targeted to small farms. And my farmer friends will be pleased to learn that nationwide polls find that Americans will support farm payments -- but only if they help small family farms.
Second, we must balance the immediate relief provided by farm income support programs with investment in rural America's future. The budget framework now being developed by farm bill conferees does not do this. Support for agricultural and rural development initiatives has been cut in half from the levels set by the House and Senate bills; such initiatives would get less than 1 percent of the amount spent on farm income support programs.
As a result, programs to assist beginning farmers and bolster research to develop new farming methods that strengthen family farms are in jeopardy.
Financing for the development of cooperatives that help family farmers reach higher-value markets -- markets that offer real opportunity -- is also in danger.
Consumer surveys find that most Americans would pay premium prices for food produced on environmentally responsible family farms. But they can do so only if we build the new cooperatives and markets that link them with the farmers who have what they want.
As matters stand, the prairie land that welcomed my homesteading great-great-grandfather is beginning to look too much like the feudal country he left behind. It does not have to be that way. This Congress can create genuine opportunity in rural America, build stronger communities and serve consumers better. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: The World; 
. . . and How Two Nations Escaped It

BYLINE:  By CRAIG R. WHITNEY

 BODY:
ISRAELIS and Palestinians have been tearing at each other for so long that bloody conflict between them seems almost as foreordained as war between France and Germany seemed a century ago. Yet for nearly 50 years now, France and Germany have lived peacefully together, each the other's largest trading partner, in mutual prosperity.
 So why can't Israelis and Palestinians do it too, especially now that the Arab states have finally agreed to recognize Israel within secure borders, if Israel will accept the reality of a Palestinian state? 
 One difference is that, in separate ways, both Israelis and Palestinians still believe that fighting will allow them to achieve their aims. Fighting between France and Germany went on for hundreds of years, as long as both countries believed that war would enable one of them to dominate the rest of the European continent. So the struggle continued, from Louis XIV to Napoleon to Bismarck to Hitler, until World War II made clear that military logic would lead ultimately only to complete destruction.
Germany accepted its defeat in 1945, and a few years later Konrad Adenauer united with France and the rest of western Europe, economically supported by the United States, against the Soviet threat.
Now the Soviet Union is gone, but Europeans have never had it so good and fighting between France and Germany is literally unthinkable.
For all the horror of suicide bombings and crushing Israeli military sweeps, neither Israelis nor Palestinians have yet reached the low point -- the "zero hour," the Germans call it -- that Europe reached in 1945. Both Israelis and Palestinians see themselves as doomed to violence, and each thinks it can somehow prevail: Israel by military superiority, ensured by the United States, and the Palestinians by wearing down the Israelis with intifadas and suicide bombers.
Europeans gave up irreconcilable claims against each other after World War II and united in the belief that peace and trade with each other, in an alliance with the United States, was their best guarantee of security.
Israelis and Palestinians are still making irreconcilable claims on the land they both occupy. 
And, though both sides trust Washington as an interlocutor, it is hard to imagine that they see the United States as some of the Europeans did in both 1917 and 1945 -- as the only country that could save them from what they could do to themselves.

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD; 
Realizing the American Dream

BYLINE:  By KATHLEEN O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
Homeownership, long a dream of Americans, is more and more a reality. Sixty-eight percent of adult Americans owned their own homes in the fourth quarter of 2001, according to the Census Bureau. 
That is the highest level since the agency began keeping track of such data.
 The highest rate of homeownership is in the Midwest, while the lowest is in the West. The difference can be explained in part by demo-graphics, according to Nicolas P. Retsinas, director of the Joint Center for Housing Studies at Harvard University. The Midwest, he said, generally has an older, more stable population. "The West has been a gateway to immigrants, and they are predominantly young and low income," he said.
 KATHLEEN O'BRIEN
