HEADLINE: INVESTING: DIARY; 
Lower Expectations For the Stock Market

BYLINE:  Compiled by Jeff Sommer 

 BODY:
Affluent investors have scaled down their expectations for the stock market over the next decade to single-digit annual returns, according to a new survey.
The respondents estimated that the annual return for stocks over the next 10 years would be 9.5 percent, compared with projections of 13.5 percent immediately after Sept. 11. 
 "Recent events like the Sept. 11 attacks, the collapse of Enron and other incidents around the world have greatly tempered the previous high level of expectations of affluent Americans, which are now much more grounded in reality," said Elliot Savitzky, senior vice president of the Opinion Research Corporation, which conducted the survey from March 15 to 24. It has a margin for error of plus or minus five percentage points, the company said. 
 Looking at the shorter term, respondents forecast stock market returns of 7.6 percent over the next six months. 
The survey was based on a national sampling of 2,044 adults with investments of at least $100,000. Their average portfolio was $738,000, and their average investment allocation was 37 percent in equities, 20 percent in cash, 13 percent in fixed-income instruments and 30 percent in other investments, including real estate.

HEADLINE: Special-Purpose Entities: Complicated but Useful 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 "The Brick Stood Up Before. But Now?" (March 10) went a long way toward distinguishing between apparent abuses of special-purpose entities and the legitimate uses of these critically important financial structures. S.P.E.'s have been tarred with a broad brush recently, but in fact they represent American financial innovation at its best. 
 S.P.E.'s are a vehicle to which companies sell pools of cash-producing assets, like loans. The entities then issue asset-backed securities to investors and provide businesses with access to new capital, often at a lower cost than is available elsewhere. Consumers also benefit: homeowners, credit card borrowers, students and car buyers gain access to more widely available credit and lower interest rates. Simply put, the beneficial use of these and other types of S.P.E.'s helps America's economy run better and more efficiently.
It is our strong hope that the collective wisdom of Congress, financial regulators and the industry will ensure that remedies developed to address what happened at Enron do not harm the economy, or impair the ability of businesses and the financial markets to operate as efficiently as possible.

MICAH GREEN
New York, March 15

The writer is president of the Bond Market Association.

HEADLINE: FRONT LINES 

BYLINE:  By ANDREA KANNAPELL

 BODY:
MIDEAST -- The second week of Israeli raids aimed at the "Palestinian terror infrastructure" destroyed far more, while U.S. calls for "immediate withdrawal" went unheeded and suicide bombers struck again.
 Fighting left the the centuries-old casbah in Nablus in ruins, and there was vast destruction -- along with rumors of massacres that the Israelis denied -- in Jenin. In many West Bank areas, roadways and buildings were demolished, and families hid inside their houses, running out of food and water. Many injured were untreated; many dead lay unburied. Fire and gunfire damaged the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem, and a priest was wounded by an Israeli sniper trying to pick off one of the 200 Palestinians inside. By week's end, more than 4,000 Palestinians had been at least briefly arrested and an unknown number -- possibly hundreds more -- were dead, while 28 Israeli soldiers had been killed. 
 And shelling by Iranian- and Syrian-backed Hezbollah guerrillas at the Lebanese border prompted Israel to suggest that it might retaliate directly against Syria. 
The Israelis said that 20 suicide-bomb labs had been found in Nablus and that more than 100 men arrested in Jenin were on Israel's "wanted" list. Bomb supplies and disguises for suicide bombers were found in the headquarters of the Palestinian office of preventive security, they said. They gave the U.S. documents that they said linked the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, to Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades, which organizes suicide bombings. At Mr. Sharon's request, his rival on the right, Benjamin Netanyahu, flew to Washington with the message that "Yasir Arafat's terrorist regime must be toppled, not courted." Is reconciliation possible? Page 1. 
Arab protests turned more violent, with a fatality in Egypt and another in Yemen. A fuel truck rammed into a synagogue in Tunis. Turkey, Israel's best friend in the region, called the raids "genocide." Iraq, saying it hoped to disrupt the U.S. economy, stopped its oil exporting, sending oil prices up. 
Meanwhile, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell repeated the calls for withdrawal as he flew from Morocco to Madrid to Egypt, meeting with incensed Arab and European leaders. Shifting alliances, Page 5. He arrived in Israel after the first suicide bombing in 10 days, a bus attack that killed eight, and met with Prime Minister Ariel Sharon, who said the raids would continue. 
Then, another suicide bomber struck near a Jerusalem market, killing six. Mr. Powell postponed a Saturday meeting with Mr. Arafat, insisting on a statement condemning the attack. Yesterday Mr. Arafat complied, and the meeting was scheduled for today. 

AFGHANISTAN -- More than 10,000 Afghan refugees began returning from Pakistan after Afghan poppy farmers ended violent protests against a government program to plow under their fields. But in western Afghanistan, fighting between warlords delayed the start of a U.N.-backed plan to repatriate some two million Afghans living in camps in Iran. A second earthquake in three weeks struck in the north, killing at least 30.
Since late October, the U.S. has dropped more than 22,000 bombs and missiles on Afghanistan, military officials said, and about 75 percent -- a relatively high rate -- hit their targets. Precision-guided weapons, which made up over half the ordnance, had about 90 percent accuracy. That also means that more than a third had a much lower accuracy rate of just over 50 percent and that more than 5,000 bombs went astray. 
Four hundred families gave petitions to the U.S. Embassy in Kabul asking for compensation for the loss of family members and homes. Neither the Defense Department nor the State Department has advised the embassy on how to respond. 
In the eastern city of Jalalabad, a bomb exploded as a crowd waited to greet the defense minister, killing 4 and injuring 18. It was the latest evidence of a campaign to undermine the U.S.-backed interim government. 
The U.N. sent a forensic team to the Bamiyan region, about 80 miles northwest of Kabul, to investigate reports of mass graves. The Taliban long targeted a religious and ethnic minority there, the Hazara. It is the same region that held the two huge 1,500-year-old statues of Buddha, which were destroyed by Taliban soldiers just over a year ago. The interim government hopes to reconstruct at least one of the statues. 

DOMESTICALLY -- Congress took the first steps toward an overhaul of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, which has been faulted for laxness and ineptitude since the Sept. 11 attacks. Does any government agency actually work? Page 4.
The White House tried to defuse a month of tensions by allowing Tom Ridge, the director of homeland security, to brief a House subcommittee. But lawmakers insisted that they should be able to question him at will. The next day, a top administration official said President Bush was considering making Mr. Ridge's position cabinet-level, putting him unambiguously under Congressional oversight. Congress is most interested in how he coordinated the administration's request for an extra $5.1 billion for domestic security this year, and $38 billion for next year. ANDREA KANNAPELL

HEADLINE: China's Growing Deserts Are Suffocating Korea 

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, April 12 

 BODY:
School was called off throughout much of this sprawling city last Monday because of inclement weather.
 It was not a freak spring snow storm, a heat wave or torrential rains. 
 Rather, it was an immense cloud of dust that blew in from China's fast-spreading deserts, about 750 miles away. 
It hid Seoul from view throughout the morning, obscuring the sunrise just as surely as the heaviest of fogs. Clinics overflowed with patients complaining of breathing problems, drugstores experienced a run on cough medicines and face masks that supposedly filter the air, and parks and outdoor malls were nearly empty of pedestrians. 
With the arrival of the huge dust storms for the third consecutive year, Koreans have begun to grimly resign themselves to the addition of an unwelcome fifth season -- already dubbed the season of yellow dust -- to the usual four seasons that any temperate country knows.
Like the harmattan in West Africa, when skies throughout that region turn a soupy gray for weeks at a time because of seasonal wind patterns that bring airborne dust southward from the Sahara, Korea's new season is a disturbing reminder for Asians of global interconnectedness and the perils of environmental degradation.
"There is no way for us to deter this," said Kim Seung Bae, deputy director of South Korea's national weather service. "All we can do is try to forecast the yellow dust storms as early as possible, but with the current technology we can only detect it one day ahead of time at best. For now, our main innovation will be to add predictions of the intensity of the dust to our weather reports."
In Seoul, a measurement of 70 micrograms of dust per cubic meter of air is considered normal during most of the year. At 1,000 micrograms, experts say, serious health warnings are indicated. Earlier this week, in the fourth storm of the season, a record measurement of 2,070 micrograms was reached in this city. Mr. Kim said two or three more storms could hit Korea this month.
Scientists say the dust storms, which are distinctly visible on regional satellite weather maps as gigantic yellow blobs, are the result of the rapid desertification in China and a prolonged drought affecting that country and other parts of Northeast Asia. 
The term yellow dust refers to the color of the sand when it coats parked cars and windows rather than the color of the skies, which all this last week were a thick, acrid gray.
According to China's Environmental Protection Agency, the Gobi grew by 20,000 square miles from 1994 to 1999, and its steadily advancing edge now sits a mere 150 miles north of Beijing. As in West Africa, which weather experts say is the world's leading source of dust, China's environmental changes are accelerating because of overfarming, overgrazing and the widespread destruction of forests.
But unlike West Africa's dust, which is carried to the southern United States by winds known as the tropical easterlies, dust from the Gobi and Taklimakan deserts in rapidly industrializing China is binding with toxic industrial pollutants, including arsenic, cadmium and lead, increasing the health threat.
Changes like these have long made springtime synonymous with respiratory distress in Beijing. 
But as the dust storms have grown, their impact has been spreading rapidly eastward, blighting the air over the Korean peninsula and beyond.
This has been an unusually dusty spring in Tokyo, for example, and fingerlike plumes of the airborne sand now travel 7,000 miles aboard the jet stream reaching Portland, Ore., and San Francisco, where the main effect so far has been to create breathtaking sunsets.
"There is no smoking gun yet that proves that man is causing this," said Charles S. Zender, a professor of earth system science at the University of California at Irvine, "but rather lots of anecdotal evidence."
"The puzzle of Asian dust is a huge question in weather science right now," he said, "and if human activity is proven to be the cause, it stands to reason that this problem is going to keep getting worse."
As a mood of resignation has set in over the persistence of this phenomenon, Koreans have already begun to focus on the economic costs. What was only recently regarded here as a minor nuisance is now seen as posing a serious threat in areas as diverse as public health, travel, retail shopping and even high-tech manufacturing.
This last week, for example, in addition to the school closures, scores of domestic flights have been canceled because of poor visibility. Workplace absenteeism has risen, too, and retail sales have dipped, as a result of people staying indoors.
"I've had a little bit of a cough," said Choi Byoung Su, 30, a businessman who was at a downtown pharmacy stocking up on medicine for a sore throat, which he said was caused by the dust storms. "I'm not too concerned about my health for now, but it is really a hassle for my car," he said, explaining that he needed to have it washed at least once a day now.
Even South Korea's major industries are suddenly complaining about the worsening effects of the storms. Semiconductor manufacturers, for example, which are highly sensitive to contaminants, have reportedly had to change their sophisticated air filters much more frequently and require workers to take longer showers before beginning assembly work. Workers are also being discouraged from entering and exiting the factories any more than is strictly necessary.
Hyundai Motor, meanwhile, a major automobile manufacturer, has reportedly begun to wax its cars differently and shrink wrap them in plastic sheeting before export to protect them from the dust.

HEADLINE: Southeast Asia's Press Is Under Pressure 

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 9 

 BODY:
A bitter fight in Thailand between the government and the press reached a high point recently when a cable station was suddenly interrupted, cutting off a critic of the prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, in midsentence.
 Afterward, the Nation Group, which controls the editorial content of the station, accused the government of deliberately interrupting the transmission of an interview with a former foreign minister, Prasong Soonsiri, a well-known opponent of the current prime minister. 
 The editor of the Nation Group, Thepchai Yong, said he believed the transmission was cut on the orders of the government. 
If so, the blackout was the most obvious of a number of moves against the press in Thailand, particularly against the Nation Group, a major media company, which started a feisty Thai language newspaper last year. As well as attacking the company, the government threatened to expel two journalists who work for the Far Eastern Economic Review, banned an issue of The Economist and ordered the office that combats money laundering to investigate the personal finances of Thai journalists. 
After the shakeout from the Asian financial crisis five years ago, there were high hopes that a more open press would emerge in the region, along with greater transparency in law, banking and commerce. Some believed that one of the lessons of the meltdown would be the need for a better-informed and more vibrant discussion of important issues. 
But across Southeast Asia, governments have shown little patience with press freedom. In the aftermath of Sept. 11, some of those with Muslim populations have objected to the interpretation of Islam in Western magazines and pulled issues from newsstands.
Malaysia, which has repeatedly hamstrung its newspapers, has held up the distribution of issues of Western magazines, including Time. In Bangladesh, an issue of the Far Eastern Economic Review, owned by Dow Jones & Company, was banned this month because it described the nation as a "cocoon of terror." 
Few people assert that an across-the-board crackdown on the press is under way. Rather, they say, a free press is having a hard time establishing permanent roots. 
"What we're seeing is a messy contentious battle with freedom of the press around the region," said Lin Neumann, the Asia consultant for the Committee to Protect Journalists, which is based in New York.
The nervousness about press freedoms comes as Washington is cutting back on support for the media in the region. The war on terror has prompted a retreat from Clinton-era programs that gave American money for journalism training and start-up financing for newspapers as countries moved away from authoritarian forms of government. 
The idea in the 1990's was to help set up newspapers and television outlets that would encourage pluralism, foster debate and plant the seeds of democracy. That policy is now being edged out by a new Bush priority of assisting primary and secondary education, particularly in countries with large Muslim populations, American officials said. 
In Indonesia, for example, Washington is planning to cut back on a nongovernmental group, Inter News, which specialized in training Indonesian journalists, and to increase funding for government-run schools. 
The problem in Indonesia is not so much restrictions on the news media, although the government did bar a prominent Australian correspondent, Lindsay Murdoch of The Sydney Morning Herald, from completing his three-year assignment. 
For the most part, according to Mr. Neumann and some local journalists, Indonesia suffers from too much press of inferior quality. About 600 newspapers, many of them retailers of rumor and innuendo, have opened since the fall of President Suharto in 1998. Gone are the days under President Suharto when the quality newsmagazine, Tempo, was banned. 
Under President Megawati Sukarnoputri, the explosion of newspapers has included tabloids with titles like Wow, Sexxy, Lipstick and Pop. For her part, Mrs. Megawati is suspicious of the press, and recently her staff ruled that reporters covering her must stay at a distance and may not toss impromptu questions at her. 
Since 1999, Indonesia has had a law prohibiting censorship. It contains a provision calling for two years in prison for "standing in the way" of a free press. Some news outlets have taken advantage of the new liberties. On Oct. 9, one newspaper carried a front-page headline that said "Satan America." The same newspaper carried a headline that said "Bush and Blair to the gallows." 
Even though there are rowdy headlines, and often titillating stories about political scandals, the Indonesian press is not as free as it may seem. Often, journalists in Indonesia, many of whom earn less than $100 a month, are paid by politicians or others to slant articles and ignore the facts, according to the Alliance of Independent Journalists in Jakarta. About 80 percent of Indonesian journalists avail themselves of what is known as "envelope journalism," meaning payment of a bribe, the alliance said in a recent report. "Such low wages often lead to justifying the acceptance of bribes or 'envelopes,' which clearly hampers a journalist's integrity and independence," the association said. 
A former Indonesian attorney general, Ali Said, once said: "I fear 10 soldiers more than 100 journalists, from whom I can protect myself through 100 envelopes." 
In Thailand, Mr. Thaksin, a wealthy businessman with a thin skin who became prime minister, has made a concerted effort to tame what he sees as a challenging press. Mr. Thepchai, the editor of the Nation Group, said he viewed the effort to investigate the personal finances of journalists as "government intimidation of the media."
"It doesn't bode well for the media," he said. 
The difficulties for the Nation Group intensified, Mr. Thepchai said, after the Nation newspaper criticized the government for wanting to deport two reporters for the Far Eastern Economic Review. 
"The prime minister is a very successful businessman who doesn't brook any criticism," the editor said. 
The authoritarian rulers of the 1970's did not tolerate dissent either. But, Mr. Thepchai said, the current situation is more disappointing. "Then at least we knew whom we were facing," he said.

HEADLINE: Founder Watches His Educational Charity Move Toward Independence 

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
Evidence of the Rose family's philanthropic largesse abounds in New York, from the Rose Center for Earth and Science at the American Museum of Natural History to the Samuel B. and David Rose Building at Lincoln Center and the Rose Main Reading Room at the New York Public Library. 
 But the cause that has captured Daniel Rose's heart, mind and a hunk of his wealth is the Harlem Educational Activities Fund, a nonprofit program that helps children from Central Harlem and Washington Heights get into the best public high schools and then into college. 
 "Isn't it brilliant?" Mr. Rose clucks proudly, pointing to pictures of national championship chess teams whose members were coached, cajoled and coddled by the fund. "Not the darlings of Dalton, with their expensive private coaches and proud parents, not the Russian kids from Brighton Beach who have chess in their genes, but kids from the inner city, from right here in Harlem." 
Mr. Rose, a senior member of a family that has built a fortune in real estate, speaks with the fervor of a highly educated evangelist and he is indeed on a mission. At 72, Mr. Rose's dearest wish is that the fund, which has relied on him for most of its financial and moral support since he founded it in 1991, comes to stand on its own and that it receives the recognition and independent financing he thinks it deserves. 
"The goal is to not only have it outlive me, but to continue its trajectory of growth and achievement," he said. "I'm embarrassed and concerned that it is seen as a one-man show precisely at the time when it is emerging as such a successful, more disciplined program."
There is no one recipe for the successful transition of the many small nonprofit groups that are the pet projects of philanthropists or inspired founders. Were there such a recipe, Mr. Rose would certainly be following it. Rather, these groups have tried different strategies with different results. There is Studio in a School, the art education program founded by Agnes Gund, which is flourishing since Ms. Gund stepped down. Then there is the Martha Graham Dance Company, which has gasped for breath ever since Miss Graham died. 
"These institutions have had very different experiences institutionalizing themselves," said Richard A. Mittenthal, president of the Conservation Company, which advises nonprofit groups. "There's no one good way of making the transition."
After toiling in relative obscurity for more than a decade, the fund is finally getting some attention. Which explains Mr. Rose's skittishness about granting an interview -- strange for a man who is so talkative that his wife, Joanna, has been known to hold up placards in fund meetings reading, "Shut up, Dan." 
The fund is making its transition in tandem with Sean Scott, its first participant, who will graduate from Robert Wood Johnson Medical School in New Jersey next month. "I knew where I wanted to go, and HEAF gave me what I needed to get there," said Mr. Scott, one of 2,050 students helped by the fund. 
Henry Louis Gates Jr., chairman of African-American studies at Harvard University and a member of the fund's board, recalled his surprise on first meeting Mr. Rose, who pulled a picture of Mr. Scott from his wallet. "He was even carrying a copy of his report card," Professor Gates said. "I was so taken by Dan's enthusiasm and that someone like him had the audacity to think he could do something about public education in New York." 
Mr. Rose's reduced role is already having an impact on the fund. The 15-member board has been organized into formal committees, and all members attended the December meeting, a first, and they are asking tough questions.
"The transition is getting off to a good start, I think," said George Price, a retired general and longtime board member. "This process is going to give HEAF not only a good chance of surviving but of growing and thriving." 
The board's stepped-up involvement has started to pay off. For instance, the staff was concerned about a drop in the academic ability of children joining the fund's program, which they attributed to efforts to draw students from a wider variety of schools. But board members insisted on a full report, and to the staff's surprise, statistics showed no academic difference between newer and older participants. Rather, limited social skills accounted for the differences, and so social workers were hired, saving the fund a costly misallocation of money. The board's new scrutiny "has added a layer of rigor to what we do, and that's challenging," said Courtney Welsh, the executive director. 
The board is trying hard to pare costs. Mr. Rose likes to say that over a decade the fund spends $25,000 on each participant, which consultants say is relatively high. 
The secret to the fund's success may well lie in expenditures beyond those costs. The fund helps pay for everything from driver education classes to a navy blazer for an interview. Every participant goes to college armed with an 800 number to call and gets frequent care packages as well. For younger students there are speech classes, Broadway tickets and dining at fine restaurants. "We're basically doing what middle-class parents do for their kids," Mr. Rose said, "and what our parents would do if they had the wherewithal." 
The board must find a way to maintain that role while reining in costs. Doing that is tricky, said Gary Walker of the research group Public/Private Ventures, because the fund's longterm and intensive dedication to its students is key to its success. "We find very few programs around the country that deal with kids who are as high-risk as those HEAF brings in," he said, "and then sticks with them through college, whatever it takes." 
In a way, the fund's search for a future beyond Mr. Rose's involvement parallels the students' search for a future beyond the fund. "I need to prove to myself that I can do some things without HEAF," said Yasmin Moya, a 2000 graduate of Bryn Mawr who is teaching third grade at her old school, P.S. 192 in Washington Heights. 
The fund is helping her pay for graduate courses, and Mr. Rose has written a recommendation for her application to become an Urban Fellow in New York. There has even been a discussion about whether the fund should help pay for her wedding this summer. "I go back and forth on how much support is too much," Ms. Moya said. "I know I can succeed, but by how much?" 
As Mr. Rose lessens his involvement in the fund, a complicating factor is that contributions, like those to other small nonprofit groups, have fallen as the economy and stock markets have weakened. 
Pressed, Mr. Rose will only say that he and his wife have contributed "what a banker would call mid- to high-seven figures" to the fund over the years. The rest has come from close to 500 other donors, most of whom have given between $1,000 and $10,000. 
Those donations have dropped so much that the fund almost had to cancel a summer camp program that was one of its more controversial projects. The staff originally objected to Mr. Rose's idea of shipping students off to the same camps where Manhattan's wealthy send their children.
He persisted, though, and the program was a huge success, with camps lining up to shoulder a portion of the costs. When the fund moved to eliminate the program earlier this year, the camps agreed to plug the hole in the budget to keep it alive, Mr. Rose said. But why didn't Mr. Rose just write a check himself, as he might have done before he started reducing his role? "It's a weaning process," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Daniel Rose, 72, philanthropist and founder of the Harlem Educational Activities Fund, chatting last week with students helped by the fund. (Alan Chin for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: After Killing Brooklyn Teacher In Poconos, Man Kills Himself 

BYLINE:  By ALAN FEUER 

 BODY:
Less than a day after a man shot his wife to death in Pennsylvania on Thursday, investigators located him in a tiny Brooklyn motel room by tracing his cellular phone calls across state lines, the authorities said yesterday.
 But as the police in Brooklyn crept close to the motel, the Riviera Motor Inn, on Atlantic Avenue in East New York, and prepared to storm the room, they saw through the window that the man they were pursuing was already dead, the victim of a self-inflicted gunshot wound. 
 The suicide of the man, Sean David White, 32, on Friday ended a two-state odyssey that left his estranged wife, Dalvis Small-White, a teaching coordinator in a Brooklyn school, dead inside her home in Smithfield Township, a tiny village in the Pocono region of eastern Pennsylvania. Ignoring an order of protection that his wife had obtained against him in January, Mr. White entered her home early Thursday morning and shot her in the head, arm and leg with a .50-caliber Desert Eagle pistol, the authorities said. 
The couple moved to Pennsylvania from Brooklyn about three years ago, said Mark Pazuhanich, an assistant district attorney in Monroe County, Pa. Mrs. Small-White, 33, left her husband nearly a year ago and was living about a quarter-mile away with her 14-year-old son, Casheem Gaines, Mr. Pazuhanich said.
It was Casheem who called the Pennsylvania State Police on Thursday morning to report that his mother and Mr. White were arguing violently in the house, Mr. Pazuhanich said. He said the troopers who took the call reported hearing gunshots while Casheem was on the line.
While a motive has not yet been established, witnesses saw the couple arguing last week at an H & R Block tax office in Stroudsburg, Pa., Mr. Pazuhanich said..
Mrs. Small-White commuted every morning from the Poconos to Brooklyn, where she had just been promoted from a schoolteacher to a teaching coordinator for District 16, he said. Mr. White was unemployed but was living off the proceeds of a large settlement he had received from the New York Police Department in a civil case, Mr. Pazuhanich said. No further information was available yesterday about the case, but he said Mr. White had expensive audiovisual equipment in his home and drove a luxury sports utility vehicle.
When he fled to Brooklyn after the shooting, he left his own son, Sean Jr., 8, behind in Pennsylvania alone, Mr. Pazuhanich said.
Mr. White was tracked to New York by the High Intensity Drug Trafficking Area Fugitive Task Force, a unit that is made up of both city police officers and federal agents, the police said.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
Memories Would Not Be Enough In Montreal

BYLINE:  By HARVEY ARATON 

 BODY:
IF this is the last go-round, if there is no future for a baseball team that has become more the unwanted property of major league baseball than the city of Montreal's, then what will Claude Raymond tell 4-year-old Thierry when the boy is old enough to ask which team his grandpa played for?
 "I'll say, 'I was the first French-Canadian to play for the Expos,' and he'll say, 'The Expos? Who's that?' " Raymond said in the visitors' clubhouse at Shea Stadium. "And that will break my heart." 
 Weeks before his 65th birthday, at the start of a season heartlessly billed as the probable prelude to extinction, Joseph Claude Marc Raymond has, apparently just in time, made it back into the uniform for the team he pitched for, even when he was in the employ of another major league club. 
It was the winter of 1968-69 when the Expos, an expansion team without a game to its name, called the Atlanta Braves and wondered if they might borrow Raymond, the Braves' veteran relief pitcher by way of St. Jean, Quebec, to help rouse the Montreal business community, a 15-minute drive from where he grew up.
"I made calls and sold tickets and was thrilled to do it for them," Raymond said. "Major league baseball in Montreal was a dream come true." By August of the following season, traded from Atlanta to Montreal, with dozens of his neighbors from St. Jean cramming into old Jarry Park to watch him pitch, Raymond did not want to be pinched.
He was 10 years old when Jackie Robinson played for the old Montreal Royals at Delorimier Yards. Raymond's youth included nights watching the likes of Duke Snider and Don Drysdale pass through French Quebec, on their way to greatness in Dodger blue. "The Royals set minor league attendance records," he said. "Montreal was a great baseball town. Still could be."
Few people, if any, agree with the man who retired from the Expos in 1971 to spend three decades calling their games on radio and television and working in community relations. Now there are no games on TV to call and the community doesn't want to be related to. The Montreal fans went away long before the last owner, Jeffrey Loria, bailed out to take control of the Florida Marlins. Bud Selig, the commissioner on a mission to contract two teams, turned the Expos into the house franchise last winter, guaranteeing them life support for one season under the management of Omar Minaya in the front office and Frank Robinson on the field.
Raymond, given the title of roving coach as spring training began, said: "I can't believe it's the last year. I just can't."
The bespectacled, gray-haired man they call Frenchy can't forget the nights when every seat in Jarry Park was taken, when fans even came out to stand, when peanut vendors could get whiplash from answering all the calls for a bag. "The place had a buzz," Raymond said sadly, knowing that Olympic Stadium, the Expos' poorly conceived home since 1977, now has the reputation of the baseball graveyard it may very well be.
It was the eerie quiet that startled Robinson one night after the Expos drew 34,351 for the home opener with, of all teams, the Marlins. "We had the owner thing going so the fans were into it that night," he said. For Game 2, the announced crowd was 4,771, and Robinson said the place was so quiet he could eavesdrop on box-seat conversations.
He also caught the irony of the Expos' trip to South Florida before they hit New York for the weekend series they evened yesterday with an 11-inning, 9-8 victory. The Marlins drew roughly 23,000 for their home opener. "They ran out of hot dogs and there were no programs," Robinson said. By Thursday night the crowd was 4,466, and Claude Raymond, among others, was asking: "They want to contract us?"
He knows Montreal at least has a history of requited public affection; as recently as 1994 the Expos were in first place with a partial season's attendance of nearly 1.3 million when the players struck. They never recovered, and the selling off of quality players became a virtual death wish, as baseball slipped into the current era of economic imbalance for which there is no remedy in sight.
For years, pro-labor critics have told baseball's big-market owners to share more television revenue with the little guys, the way they do it in football. Turns out the players aren't too keen on that, either. They don't want to discourage the moneyed owners from forever stretching the salary scale. For all of the owners' fudging of their financials, the players refuse to accept much responsibility, if any, for the yawning disparity so apparent already this season in New York, which has been visited, in order, by the budget-challenged likes of Pittsburgh, Tampa Bay and now Montreal.
Raymond hopes that these Expos, who are not without talent, can win enough to attract a new owner and that his team will get a stay of execution, even if it means it is shifted south of the border. "At least the franchise wouldn't die," he said. "At least the players like Steve Rogers and Gary Carter will say, 'That's the team I played for, when it was in Montreal.' "
At least his grandson, who attended opening day and, as Raymond said, "got to see Pappy in his uniform," will know his grandfather dressed for the first major league baseball team in Quebec, and the last.

HEADLINE: For the Crossroads of the World, Far Less Traffic From Foreign Tourists Since Sept. 11 

BYLINE:  By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
The Rev. Richard Watkins, pastor of Mount Neboh Baptist Church, sees the problem in the empty pews and collection plates each Sunday.
 Not so long ago, Harlem churches like Mount Neboh would be packed with hundreds of foreign tourists. The foreign visitors dropped money in the collection plates. The tour operators who brought them also made generous donations. 
 But on a recent Sunday, Mount Neboh, on Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard, had only about 60 foreign guests in the balcony of its sparsely filled sanctuary. 
"Our European clientele has dropped 78 percent since Sept. 11," James Davis, a sales manager at Harlem Spirituals, a tour company, explained while standing in the balcony at Mount Neboh. "We are all hurting."
As many New York businesses report improvements since Sept. 11, and many hotels have fewer vacancies, local businesses that depend on foreign tourism say that they are still in pain. It may be easier to get a ticket to see the Statue of Liberty these days, but city officials say the downturn is terrible for the economy. That is because foreigners make up about 18 percent of the annual tourists to New York, but generate 42 percent of the revenue in the industry, according to NYC & Company, the city's convention and visitors bureau. (The city defines a tourist as anyone who travels at least 50 miles one way or stays overnight, excluding commuters.) 
At the Marriott Marquis Hotel in Times Square, for instance, the usual throngs of Japanese and German tourists are nowhere to be found. .
Along the streets of Chinatown, business leaders say, the American tourists are back but there are not many foreigners looking for discounts. Their absence has even hit the boutiques on the Upper East Side and in SoHo.
According to NYC & Company, the average foreign visitor spends about $1,040 per trip to New York, compared with $319 per visit from domestic tourists. Among tourists who stay in hotels, rather than with friends and relatives, tourism officials say, the difference between foreign and domestic visitors is even greater.
"We are seeing a lot of people from the Midwest and New York," said Robert Ianniello, president of the Little Italy Merchants Association, whose 54 members include Italian and Chinese businesses around Mulberry Street. "They are bringing American dollars to an American city, but international tourists are so important."
Experts have different explanations. "A lot of it has do with what is broadcast on the foreign media, and if you are sitting in some province in the south of Germany and all you are seeing are pictures of ground zero, you are thinking New York is not a place to be right now," said Jeffrey Stewart, vice president at the Travel Business Roundtable, a lobbying and marketing group based in Washington.
Mr. Stewart, who works in New York, also cited cultural differences. "In Japan, part of the reason they are not coming is that they saw our city as going through a mourning period and that it would be disrespectful to come so soon," he said. 
Economic problems in countries that provide the greatest number of high-spenders are contributing as well.
"In a lot of countries we have a double whammy," Dr. Lalia Rach, dean of the Tisch Center for Travel, Tourism and Hospitality at New York University, said of the fears of terrorism and the weak economies in some countries of Europe, Asia and South America. She noted that economic slowdowns are occurring in five of the top six countries for foreign tourism to New York: Germany, France, Japan, Brazil and Italy.
In other countries, like Argentina, that send fewer tourists but some of the most free-wheeling spenders, economic problems and a strong dollar have hurt tourism to the United States. The foreigners most likely to come, officials say, are those who live close to the United States, or those who have already been to the city. 
Catriona Watson, 27, a marketing worker from Melbourne, Australia, is an example of what tourism officials hope catches on quickly. "A lot of people coming here want to see ground zero, and to see the rest of New York at this profound time," Ms. Watson said, explaining the reason for her 10-day trip to the city.
One country that has continued to contribute tourists to New York is England, where a better economy than many other countries and close business and political ties have helped, officials said.
John Hillhouse, 50, a tourist from Chester, England, who was visiting the Morris-Jumel Mansion in Washington Heights recently, put it this way: "We have had terrorism for years. To tell you the truth, we are not going to let things like that bother us. We are brothers in arms, and America deserves support from our country."
But support from the British is not enough for people like Muriel Samama. A French immigrant who has led Harlem Spirituals tours for almost 15 years, Ms. Samama, the president, said her company had been forced to lay off half of its 14 employees, drop contract tour guides and bus drivers and expand its operations in other areas of the city.
"The week after Sept. 11 we registered 4,000 cancellations," she said, adding that foreign visitors made up about 90 percent of her business at the time. In 2000, Harlem Spirituals gave tours to 100,000 people and grossed $2.5 million. "I don't even want to think about this year's numbers," Ms. Samama added.
For Kenneth Woods, the situation is no better. Mr. Woods, a manager at Sylvia's, the Harlem soul food restaurant that in recent years has become a popular stop for foreign tourists, said international business had dropped 80 percent since September. "Normally this time of year we would have a great influx of international tourists," he said from the hardly packed dining room. "We are really hurting."
Even in places like the Upper East Side boutiques and galleries on Madison Avenue, where the drop has been less severe, it has still been noticeable. "I think everyone was concerned," said Matthew Bauer, the president of the Madison Avenue Business Improvement District. "We have luckily been able to weather the storm because much of our clientele comes here often or have apartments here and consider themselves part-time New Yorkers."
City tourism officials are so concerned that Cristyne L. Nicholas, the president of NYC & Company, has devoted an increasing amount of her time to the international market. Ms. Nicholas has played host to travel agents, tour operators, journalists and others from foreign countries, and has traveled to Paris, Berlin and London in recent months. She plans a trip to Tokyo this month as a part of a federal tourism delegation led by Commerce Secretary Donald Evans. 
On her trips, Ms. Nicholas said, her agency has worked to counter perceptions that New York is overpriced or not ready for visitors. 
In many quarters, there is a new sense of appreciation for overseas travelers. On a recent weekend, a group of foreign tourists were warmly greeted by residents along a block in Hamilton Heights. "We are glad that they are back," Edward Ford, 68, said as he walked past a Harlem Spirituals bus full of tourists from Ireland, England, Mexico, Australia and Sweden. "It's good for the economy."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Visitors from France after a Mount Neboh Baptist Church service. "We are all hurting," said a sales manager for Harlem Spirituals tours. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Man Resists Two Robbers And Is Shot In the Village 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
It was like one of those terrifying crimes of 10 or 15 years ago, when the sound of gunshots was common and New Yorkers were wary of their own streets. A young couple came out of a nightclub in Greenwich Village at 2:30 a.m. yesterday and were walking to their car on a dark, deserted street when two robbers confronted them.
 It happened fast. There were only fleeting impressions: they were black men in their early 20's with thin, clean-shaven faces; one had shoulder-length dreadlocks, the other short braids; both wore dark baggy clothing, and one had on a maroon long-sleeved T-shirt. 
 One drew a small black handgun, the police said, and they demanded money. But for some reason -- perhaps pride or a protective instinct -- Kirill Nekrasov, 25, did not comply. Instead, he reached for the gun.
There was a struggle and two shots went off. Mr. Nekrasov, struck in the head and critically wounded, crumpled onto a sidewalk grate in front of the five-story tan brick apartment building at 176 West Houston Street, near Bedford Street. As the assailants ran off, Mr. Nekrasov's companion, Natalya Shimunova, 27, began screaming.
The sound of the shots awoke Richard Benedetti, 57, who retired as a police officer 16 years ago and lives just across West Houston in the Breen Towers. He looked out his second-story bedroom window as the drama unfolded.
"I heard boom, boom!" he said. "It just hit me like that. My instincts kicked in. I knew they were gunshots. Then all of a sudden, I heard a woman start screaming. She was grabbing her cellphone, trying to get help. She was real panicky."
In the shadows -- the nearest streetlamp was 25 yards away -- he saw a man lying on the sidewalk, and beside him the woman stood shrieking into her phone in heavily accented English. He said, "She's shouting, Houston Street, Houston Street," pronouncing it like the Texas city, not HOUSE-ton, the way New Yorkers say it.
"She was screaming, 'He's still breathing! He's still live! Please come! We need help!" Mr. Benedetti said he reached for his own telephone to call 911, but before he could get through he heard the sirens approaching.
Across the Avenue of the Americas, at a firehouse that is home to Engine 24 and Ladder 5, Firefighter Marcel Claes was on duty and heard banging on the front door. He pulled it open.
"A civilian was standing there and said, 'Someone was shot.'
"I said, 'How do you know he was shot?'
"He said, 'I heard it.' "
Firefighter Claes strode across the intersection, where two police cars had already pulled up. More emergency vehicles were wailing closer. "Before I had time, they were already there -- the paramedics, the cops, everybody," Firefighter Claes said. He saw the victim lying on his side, the paramedics kneeling beside him. "I could only see half his face," the firefighter said. He remembered that the man appeared to be wearing a running suit.
The paramedics hooked up an intravenous drip, lifted Mr. Nekrasov onto a stretcher and slid it into the back of an ambulance, which sped away to St. Vincent's Manhattan Hospital a few blocks north. Mr. Nekrasov was listed in critical condition last night.
The detectives took Ms. Shimunova with them to ask her what she remembered of what had happened, as police cars zigzagged through the neighborhood, searching for the vanished assailants.
Aside from Ms. Shimunova, who was not injured, there appeared to be no eyewitnesses. The windows of the apartment building were dark. The real estate office on the ground floor and Z's Basement clothing store, down 12 steps beyond the fire-engine red railing, were both shut, as was the laundry and a cleaners up the block. Only the Quick Stop Gourmet Deli down West Houston was open, but the line-of-sight was bad, and nobody there saw anything, investigators said.
At the high-rise apartment building where Mr. Nekrasov lives, at 303 Beverly Road in the Kensington section of Brooklyn, friends and neighbors said that he was a Russian immigrant who had been brought by his mother, Klara, from what was then Leningrad about 23 years ago, when he was 2.
They said he was a structural engineer who had earned his degree at the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn and worked in Manhattan. They said that he still lived with his mother, and they described Ms. Shimunova as a college friend of Mr. Nekrasov's, not his girlfriend.
"He spends a lot of time with his mother," a cousin, Misha Gutkin, said at the hospital, where Mr. Nekrasov's mother and other relatives and friends gathered in a room to await word from the doctors. Mr. Gutkin said they had been told only that Mr. Nekrasov had been given a blood transfusion and had undergone surgery.
Luba Isayez, a neighbor, called him "a very nice boy, a very smart boy," who was "very good to his mother." She said that mother and son sometimes took walks together in nearby Prospect Park, and added: "He's very quiet. I don't even believe that he was out so late in Manhattan. He doesn't go out very often. He's always with his mother. He loves her very much."
Ms. Isayez said the mother had brought her son to the United States in search of economic, political and religious freedoms. "Everyone was leaving," she said. "They were looking for a better way of life."
Other neighbors said that the Nekrasovs had lived in the building for 10 years and attended a synagogue at East Fifth Street and Church Avenue in Kensington.
After years of declining street crime in New York, the shooting seemed like a throwback to a more dangerous era, when killings and robberies, often a result of the crack cocaine trade, were common and residents thought twice about walking out of doors late at night.
In the light of day, the scene of the crime seemed less menacing. Traffic slid by on Houston and the Avenue of the Americas, and pedestrians were out in droves in the area, a nexus of Greenwich Village and SoHo, with busy restaurants and shops, art theaters like the Film Forum and clubs down the side streets.
Under a spindly, leafless tree, bloodstains still flecked the iron grate where Mr. Nekrasov fell, despite the efforts of Vincente Gamez, the superintendent in charge of maintaining the 22 apartments at 176 West Houston. He had hosed down the sidewalk before the Saturday crowds got up .
"It's a shame," said Mr. Benedetti, the retired police officer. "I hate to say it, but that's the way life is sometimes. Not just in New York but everywhere."

 CORRECTION:
An article on April 14 about a robbery and shooting in Greenwich Village gave an outdated name for the university where the victim earned his engineering degree. An article on April 15 about the police investigation repeated the error. The institution is Polytechnic University, formerly the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn. The university reported the error at the time, but this correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

HEADLINE: Legal Fighting in Paradise: Fury Over Napa Vineyards 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: NAPA, Calif., April 11 

 BODY:
This wine growing region was once considered a vision of rural bliss. It was America's Arcadia, an idyllic blend of commerce and nature, where agriculture was boundlessly profitable and San Francisco's bustle, though just an hour away, was kept safely at bay.
 It still looks that way, with its nearly perfect Mediterranean climate, pastel inns and softly rolling hills, their sides draped with a geometric filigree of trellises. But for many environmentalists and residents here, Napa is another prosperous community on the brink of destruction. 
 It is not just the three million tourists who visit each year, stirring the resentments familiar in destinations that become too popular for their own good. It is also the residue of heavy industry: the 18-wheel wine tankers competing for space on two-lane roads; the removal of Douglas firs and redwoods for ever-larger vineyards; the soil erosion that has clogged the Napa River, once home to salmon and steelhead. 
Napa's alternative to suburbia has itself become the issue, as wine growers and environmental activists fight for control of the valley's trees, fields and streams. Community groups are fighting vineyard sprawl and what they call industrial wineries; grape growers say the groups threaten their livelihoods. 
Environmental lawsuits against the vineyards and the county have tied the hands of Napa's planning commission, which has begun requiring voluminous studies of water, soil, forests and fish before granting permits to expand, replant or open vineyards. Owners say approvals take years if they come at all, costing them dearly. 
The battle has spread with California's wine culture, into neighboring Sonoma and down the Pacific Coast.
"More and more people look at a vineyard and see a quarry," said Lee Hudson, who has cultivated grapes in Napa for 30 years.
Hudson Vineyards has 200 acres of lowlands in the valley and has been trying to expand plantings by 50 percent. County officials have said no. Cows graze the alfalfa and barley on one of Mr. Hudson's prime meadows, where he envisioned grapes for premium chardonnays and syrahs.
He called this madness for wine country, where farmland sells for up to $189,000 an acre. "There are people here who hate the wine industry so much they'd rather I build a feedlot or a slaughterhouse," he said.
While wine has become big business, this conflict has the intensity of a family quarrel. On one side are green, antiurban alumni of the University of California who have come to Napa to live. On the other side are green, antiurban alumni of the University of California who have come to Napa to farm.
Most vineyard owners live amid their vines. Many farm organically and use pesticides sparingly. Agriculture does not get much cleaner, and they resent the charge that they pollute.
It was in fact an alliance between grape growers and environmental activists that prompted Napa to declare itself an agricultural preserve in 1968, the first place in the United States to do so. Wine was merely a hobby then, but the policy kept Napa from becoming another Bay Area bedroom community.
"If I weren't growing grapes I'd probably be a tree hugger," said Charlie Smith, who co-founded Smith-Madrone Vineyard on Spring Mountain in the early 1970's after graduating from the University of California at Berkeley. "But I want the right to use my own land."
Yet environmentalists argue that the wine business has run amok. Vineyard owners have plundered Napa's hillsides, they say. Too many have planted on steep inclines, making for prized Zinfandels but creating erosion. Some vineyard owners cut forests anywhere it suits them, leaving beige scabs where old-growth trees once provided habitat.
"You should hear the thunder when they cut up the hills," said Chris Malan, a community advocate. "The boulders come crashing down, the snakes and bobcats are fleeing, the trees are falling. 
"For anyone who cares about the quality of life, it rocks you."
Ms. Malan is a mental health worker who became an amateur environmentalist after her grape-growing neighbor stripped a ridge in view of her back porch. She began renting planes, taking aerial surveys of vineyards to compare them with blueprints submitted to the county. She kayaks along private stretches of the Russian and Napa Rivers to peer into farmers' backyards.
Though she speaks of the environment with more passion than technical precision, her inquiry formed the basis of a lawsuit backed by the Sierra Club in 1999 against Napa and five vineyards. In a settlement late last year, the county agreed to apply California's rigorous environmental code strictly and assess each vineyard's impact on soil, water and wildlife before issuing permits.
Gridlock ensued. With more than a hundred applications pending, the county has denied permits unless vineyard owners pass lengthy environmental inspections, like those required of chemical manufacturers and oil refineries. Farmers say these cost tens of thousands of dollars for even the smallest operations and could even require them to uproot vines if problems are unearthed.
Ms. Malan and other community leaders have pushed an initiative they hope will appear on the November ballot that would compel vineyards to plant at least 350 feet from prime streams and 1,000 feet from wetlands, a requirement that farmers say could shave 10 percent off their cultivated acreage.
At a well-attended community meeting one recent evening, local residents joined San Franciscans with weekend homes in Napa to discuss the petition. Several people complained that it did not go far enough. They wanted tree cutting to stop completely. Organizers said they would have liked to do that, but were advised by lawyers that only a narrower effort to protect watersheds would withstand legal challenge. No one asked about the effect on grape growers.
Even so, the wine industry is not about to disappear. Napa has 270 vineyards covering 45,000 acres of the most complex and hospitable soil for wine grapes anywhere. While a recent glut has reduced wine prices at the low end of the market, a premium Harlan Estate Cabernet sells for $475 a bottle, and the Napa appellation ensures a premium for even the lowliest table wine.
Moreover, some of the biggest names in Napa, like the corporations behind the Mondavi and Hess brands, remain relatively quiet, their hundreds or even thousands of acres safely "in grapes" on the valley floor. The environmental push poses a bigger threat to boutique vintners who increasingly seek to cultivate on hillsides, sometimes on grades of up to 30 percent, where yields are low but the grapes robust. 
So the dispute has an internecine side, with hillside vineyard owners suspecting that some colleagues in the valley are staying out of the fray -- or even secretly backing environmentalists -- to limit competition and keep a tight lid on the valuable Napa name.
While that may be true, the politics of wine has turned tannic for everyone, including the biggest players. Ms. Malan has set her sights on stopping Australian-owned Beringer Blass Wine Estates from building a 1.5-million-square-foot winery and expanding plantings on 115 acres of what she calls "precious wetlands." In nearby Sonoma, community groups have singled out the industry goliath, E. & J. Gallo Winery.
Gallo bought the Sonoma ranch of the late actor Fred MacMurray -- rocky, heavily forested land that rises over the Russian River. When bulldozers upended trees and rearranged the landscape to ease planting, even some grape growers cried foul. They pressed the county to reject plans for Gallo's two-million-bottle winery and have sought to slow conversion of the ranch.
"There is a revolution going on against the industrial vineyard," said Martin Griffin, a longtime grape grower who helped found Friends of the Russian River. "When you do it like they do it, you might as well build subdivisions."
Like Mr. Griffin, many vineyard owners are environmentalists themselves, and most are apologetic about opposing green groups. They say they have only a few "bad apples," as Tom Gamble of the Napa Farm Bureau put it, who ignore the collateral impact of their work.
But they argue that it is really the environmentalists who have run amok. No one has shown that grape growing drove the fish from the Napa River, they say. Most fish runs ended in the 1950's, long before the wine industry took off. They acknowledge that planting vineyards requires cutting down trees, but say that the Napa Valley remains unusually forested for a prime agricultural area. They also question if trees are the best use of the land under the new world's Bordeaux.
"This is not Yosemite," said John R. Guilliams of Guilliams Vineyards. "Napa is, and should be, about wine."

HEADLINE: Fields of Oil, From Iraq to Alaska 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Iraqi Oil Cutoff Tied to Drilling in Alaska" (news article, April 11): First the Bush administration said drilling for oil in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge was needed to avert the California energy crisis. 
Then it asserted that drilling was needed to prevent terrorist attacks. Now we hear that it is needed because Iraq has cut off oil exports. 
 The fact that the administration's rationale changes from month to month makes me suspect that there isn't any rationale at all.

DAN STYER
Oberlin, Ohio, April 11, 2002

HEADLINE: Wife of a Salesman 

BYLINE:  By David Willis McCullough; David Willis McCullough's most recent book is a historical anthology, "Wars of the Irish Kings."

 BODY:
 SEA GLASS
By Anita Shreve.
378 pp. Boston:
Little, Brown & Company. $25.95.
 WHEN the entire second paragraph of a novel reads: "The year is 1929. A June day. A wedding day. Honora is just 20, Sexton is 24," it is almost impossible not to hear dark background music, an ominous rumbling deep in the string section. Clearly, trouble lies ahead.
Honora had been a teller at a bank in a small town in New Hampshire when she was swept off her feet by Sexton, a handsome stranger, a typewriter salesman with a 1926 Buick whose territory, he says "covers the three P's -- Portland, Portsmouth and Providence -- and everything in between." On their wedding day, they settle into a huge old dilapidated house that had once been a convent and a home for unwed mothers. Located near a dying factory town, it is in a secluded beach community that will be familiar to readers of two of Shreve's previous novels, "Fortune's Rocks" and "The Pilot's Wife." Indeed, the house itself -- now appearing in at least its third Shreve novel -- takes on a strong presence of its own as the couple struggle to save it.
Although it is against company policy for wives to accompany their husbands, Honora is soon on the road with Sexton, demonstrating how fast and easy it is to use a typewriter as he gives his well-practiced sales pitch. Orders pour in. Commissions have never been larger, and by shaving the truth only a little bit (and not telling his wife about that) Sexton is able to get a mortgage for their tumbledown house on the beach. And it is still only Labor Day weekend, a month or so before Wall Street will crash.
Honora is the principal character in "Sea Glass," but other lives become entwined with hers. Each is first presented in isolated chapters telling their individual stories. As the novel progresses, and one by one they meet and come to know one another, the various threads are woven together, not unlike the strands of cloth produced by the imperiled cotton mills not so far from Honora and Sexton's home.
First there is McDermott (no one uses his first name), a 20-year-old millworker who is as direct and honest as Sexton is devious. Having worked among the looms since he was 12, he is all but deaf, but can anyone doubt that -- when the time is right -- he and Honora will fall in love? There is little Alphonse, a French Canadian the age McDermott was when he went to work, who lives with his mother and five brothers and sisters in a grim industrial slum and seems doomed to a life worthy of one of Dickens's blacking-factory boys. And there is wealthy, madcap, not-altogether-sober Vivian, one of the summer people up from the big city, who has an investment adviser smart enough to keep her Depression-proof. Is there any doubt that she will have a heart of gold and generosity to match, once -- of course -- she meets Honora?
Hard times bring these people together. Sexton loses his territory, and the bank is about to foreclose on the house. He is lucky to get a low-paying job at one of the factories. The already hellish living and working conditions in town become worse as some mills close and others desperately cut hours and speed up the machines to get more out of their workers in less time. The call goes out for a strike from McDermott and some of the other union leaders. And what better place for a secret strike headquarters than Sexton's house at the beach? It's huge and besides a wife who knows how to cook, he has an invaluable typewriter and duplicating machine that he never gave back when he lost his sales job.
At first, the strike provides all the fun and excitement of an MGM musical, with Judy and Mickey putting on a show in the barn. Until everything goes tragically wrong, all involved are having the time of their lives. There's drama and tension and more food than most of them can ever remember eating. A strike newspaper has to be published. Even comic relief is provided by two professional organizers from New York, who talk like bad translations of Karl Marx. Shreve's characters are not complex, but what makes the strike scenes so successful is the slowly growing, guilt-ridden realization of these people that they are very much enjoying the sheer fun that is buried in the serious -- and dangerous -- work they are doing.
The elements are here for unabashed soap opera, complete with that overbearing background music. The book's title, for example, refers to worn and polished bits of glass that Honora picks up along the beach and arranges on an antique white platter. The smooth colored shards are contrived to be brought onstage at key moments in the story. Someone always asks what they are. After an all but tangible pause for that unheard music to swell, someone else points out that it is "garbage" or "trash" that through the pounding of the sea has been revealed to be beautiful and tough. Sea glass doesn't break. And this mismatched collection of people that adversity has brought to Honora's endangered home? A reader would have to have a heart of stone to ignore the moral of the tale, the meaning of it all.
But Shreve does not use her characters frivolously. They reveal who they are through their actions, with the author -- who writes with admirable economy -- rarely having to point a finger or underline the obvious. The true power of her novel comes from the appalling social conditions she describes so vividly, the grim but heroic lives her characters live. When members of the old British Labor Party belted out the hymn with William Blake's words about "dark satanic mills," they were singing of the same injustice that Shreve is now writing about with equal fervor. And she makes it very easy to share both her outrage and her sadness about the fates of Honora, McDermott and the rest.
Still, there is something almost quaintly antique about all this, something of a Colonial Williamsburg reconstruction with industrial grit. You wonder what this muckraking spirit would do if it were unleashed on a contemporary social outrage.
