HEADLINE: 'Baywatch: The Bronx'? City's Allure Draws Foreigners as Lifeguards 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA STEWART 

 BODY:
In less than two months, Kinga Drzewiecka, 21, a sociology student at the University of Warsaw in Poland, expects to be perched atop an extremely high chair at a beach or pool in New York, guarding a splashing, shrieking mass of sopping city dwellers. 
 She is trying, without success, to imagine what it will be like. 
 "So many cultures, so many people, no?" Ms. Drzewiecka (pronounced drez-WICK-ah) said from her home in Warsaw. "Chinatown. The Bronx. Harlem. Negroes -- no, I'm sorry -- blacks, yes? Greenpoint -- where Polish people live, no? Imagine -- Polish people in New York!" 
Prezmek Szaniawski, who studies economics at the University of Warsaw, is also going to be a New York lifeguard this summer. While he is here, he said, he intends to look into some tales about New York from friends who have visited the city. 
"I hear that almost everybody has a gun," he said. "I hear everybody has a big car. I have heard that blacks, Chinese and Italians live together, work together, eat together -- so different from Poland, where everybody is white. I want to check this for myself."
Grzesiek Mazurkowski, a lifeguard and student at the Warsaw University of Physical Education, has more specific plans. He wants to watch a Knicks game at Madison Square Garden. Mr. Mazurkowski knows enough about American basketball to know the season will have ended before he arrives, but he is hoping the Knicks might play an exhibition game at the Garden.
"I'm a big fan of basketball," he said. "I am always on the Internet, checking scores. I want to be a basketball trainer, and the basketball books and texts, they all come from the U.S."
The three Polish students are among the first group of lifeguards from overseas hired by the city to supervise New York's pools and beaches. After two months of recruiting foreign students by contacting the East Coast offices of groups like the British Universities North America Club, a nonprofit group that places foreign students in summer jobs in the United States, the city's Parks Department has received inquiries from hundreds of university students from Eastern Europe, South Africa, Australia and Brazil.
Parks Commissioner Adrian Benepe said he had hoped to hire as many as 100 foreign students for lifeguarding jobs this summer, but because recruiting did not start as early as he had hoped, the number may be lower. He said if the project goes well, it will be expanded next year.
The idea of easing the city's chronic shortage of summer lifeguards by looking abroad was broached by Michael R. Bloomberg during his mayoral campaign last year. At the time, some city officials considered it impractical. A former parks commissioner, Betsey Gotbaum, a Democrat who was running for public advocate, called it "outlandish." 
The city has had success recruiting foreign teachers to ease the shortage in the public schools, but critics of the lifeguard plan said that scarce summer jobs should go to New Yorkers. 
But the city has not, within memory, been able to hire the 1,200 qualified lifeguards needed to supervise its 53 pools and 14 miles of beaches. It does not seem to be for lack of trying. The hunt for summer lifeguards starts in September, Mr. Benepe said, when the city sends thousands of fliers and scores of recruiters to high schools, colleges, and community and athletic clubs throughout the New York metropolitan area. (A city residency requirement was dropped years ago.) In a good year, 950 of the 1,200 slots are filled. Last year, 904 were.
"It's terrible," said Richie Scher, who teaches physical education at Bushwick High School and has been a city lifeguard for 44 years. "Nobody knows how to swim on the East Coast, especially in New York City. In the 70's, if a school had a pool, you had to pass a swimming test to graduate. Now pools are empty all year. Cool is basketball and maybe baseball and football. Not swimming."
Each year, the lifeguard shortage forces sections of Rockaway Beach in Queens to be roped off and closed to swimmers, swimming hours to be shortened at most pools, and other pools to be closed for one or two days a week. 
There is not much use in looking to the rest of the country for lifeguards, Mr. Benepe said. The shortage is nationwide. Mr. Scher, who is also a recruiter, said he recently got a call from a municipal official in Florida requesting that surplus New York lifeguard candidates be sent his way. 
Swimming may not be cool in New York, as Mr. Scher said, but elsewhere in the world, it is. Lifeguarding is so prestigious in Australia that guards work for free. In Brazil, New Zealand and, curiously, the wintry countries of Eastern Europe, swimming is taught in schools and is nearly as popular as soccer, Mr. Mazurkowski said.
He said he thought it would be a great adventure, guarding swimmers in "Manhattan, Queens, Bronx, New York places I know from television."
A director of the British Universities North America Club, Jim Buck, called that type of reaction "the 'Baywatch' scenario."
"To be a lifeguard on an American beach for the summer," he said, "it's sexy, let's face it."
"Baywatch," though, was set first in California and later in Hawaii, a far cry from Red Hook or City Island.
"It's all the same to them," Mr. Buck said. "It's all the U.S." 
The three Warsaw students -- among the first group to be hired -- all said their parents were rather uneasy about their summer plans. 
"My mother is really nervous about terrorism," Ms. Drzewiecka said. "And everybody -- when I say I'm going to New York City -- they say: 'Oh my God! Be careful!' But I think about fun, about culture, about visits to places. Not about dangers or terrorists."
Still, ground zero is one place she and the other Polish lifeguards said they wanted to visit. 
"I want to buy some flowers and put them there," Mr. Szaniawski (pronounced zan-ee-AW-ski) said.
Mr. Mazurkowski said the Sept. 11 attacks made him want to see New York even more. 
"I have a lot of feeling about this," he said. "In Poland, I could do nothing. I could only see and hear radio and TV. But I think, to die in a stupid accident like this, it is not so right. I think, I want to do something for these people."
So far, the strongest response has come from Eastern European countries like Russia, Latvia and Yugoslavia. At least 30 students are applying, Mr. Buck said. His and similar nonprofit groups are recruiting from Europe, South America, South Africa and Australia. 
Though all the students must have lifeguard certificates from their own countries, they will also be required to take the city's lifeguard course and pass its test before working. The pay is $10.04 an hour, and rooms at Y.M.C.A.'s are being reserved. The rent is $500. The students will also pay for their travel.
At the very least, Ms. Drzewiecka said, lifeguarding in New York will be vastly superior to waitressing in Spain, her last summer job.
"I think of Central Park -- amazing, no? Such a big city like New York to have parks. People lying on the grass, no? Picnics? In such a big city, that's quite funny to me. And I think about Wall Street -- people smoking, with mobile phones and suitcases. Work, work, work and work.
"New York!" she continued. "I see it on television and read about it in magazines. Is it a great place or a bad place? Dirty or clean? Funny or very sad? It's a new world, America. I don't know anything about it and people are telling me different things. I have to go see it for myself."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Prezmek Szaniawski, left, and Kinga Drzewiecka, in a pool in Warsaw, will be coming to New York City this summer to be lifeguards at the city's pools and beaches. (Piotr Malecki for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TURMOIL: ARAFAT'S COMPOUND; 
Inside a Siege, Signs of Life and Loss

BYLINE:  By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: RAMALLAH, West Bank, April 14 

 BODY:
The one they call "old man" walks the halls of what is left of his once-proud compound here. In the wee hours, Yasir Arafat's followers can hear him prowling past the makeshift quarters where they have been confined by Israeli tanks and snipers for 17 days now, sharing mattresses on the floor.
 "Sometimes he comes down and looks around, and checks the rooms," said Mohamed Masharqa, 42, a journalist who works for a Palestinian daily newspaper, Al Ayam, and has been living in the compound. "He talks to his guys: 'How are you? Don't worry. Take care of yourselves. Stay away from the windows,' he says. 'It's not safe.' We sleep in shifts. I hear his voice sometimes in the morning." 
 The Israeli siege has left Mr. Arafat and a few dozen aides, sympathizers and international peace protesters virtually isolated in a few rooms, often without electricity, water or working plumbing. Secretary of State Colin L. Powell's visit to the compound in a heavily armed and armored motorcade this morning gave outsiders a rare look inside, and it was fairly grim.
"I am down to the last analgesics," said Dr. Zedi Abu Shawish, a surgeon and deputy director of hospitals for the West Bank who said he has been caring for a half dozen wounded Palestinian fighters inside with dwindling supplies left by the Red Cross, performing an amputation below the knee on one man with just local anesthetic. "I need first of all the water. It's the most important here for us, because if I have more diarrhea here, it will be messy."
As Israeli tanks pulled just far enough away to let Secretary Powell's convoy pass, the 14 American journalists traveling with him got only the briefest glimpse inside the compound today, and a sanitized glimpse at that, people staying in the compound said. They said the Israelis had restored water on Saturday just long enough to clean the place up a bit, and flush the toilets, before a tank rumbled over a makeshift supply pipe and left the compound dry again. This morning, the corridors were filled with the sweet smell of disinfectant.
Machine-gun bullet marks pocked the stucco walls outside, at least one of which had a gaping hole in it. A building that Mr. Arafat once used to receive V.I.P.'s stood open to the sky, its rafters bare of red tiles destroyed in a rocket attack, and other walls were charred and streaked with the residue of rocket fire. But a broad courtyard had been cleared of the burned-out cars and rubble that people in the compound said had filled it only days before.
As reporters waited in what had been a small office on the first floor, CNN came beaming live onto a television in the corner, with its correspondent reporting on the visit from a perch back in Jerusalem, and a clutch of Palestinians talked into cellphones that they said suddenly began working the moment Secretary Powell arrived. They minute he left, they said later, the Israeli Army began jamming them again.
The dust was so thick here that the Secretary Powell's bodyguards had to turn on the washers and wipers of their armored Chevrolet Suburbans to see through the polarized, bulletproof windshields. Big loops of concertina wire littered the perimeter of the complex. A radio transmission tower drooped like a gooseneck floor lamp, its guy wires destroyed. A man inside held up a placard with a drawing of a hand making the V-sign for victory, its two upraised fingers adorned with Palestinian flags.
On Israeli orders, the American journalists, held behind a rope and rusting stanchions near the front door, were warned not to photograph Israeli troops positioned in windows of another building not 30 yards away, across an open courtyard, where a couple of stray cats prowled. 
But Israeli soldiers with telephoto lenses trained their sights on Secretary Powell's party, and they pantomimed the motion of clicking a camera shutter when they saw journalists take pictures of posters hung out of windows by a handful of international protesters who had joined Mr. Arafat under siege.
"Occupation is Violence and Terror," read one. "Passivity = Complicity," read another. At one point, a protester, Meta Golan, 30, a therapist born in Tel Aviv who described herself as the only Israeli staying in the compound, crawled out a window with a poster but was forced back inside by State Department security officers wielding submachine guns. The officers had replaced Palestinian guards at the door while Secretary Powell was inside.
Concern about Israeli snipers kept Mr. Arafat himself from even stepping into the doorway of the building, said an aide, Saeb Erekat. "You see the Israeli snipers all around," Mr. Erekat said. "We are not going to take that risk."
But a smaller pool of reporters allowed to see Mr. Arafat briefly inside at the beginning and end of the meeting reported that he looked drawn. Asked after the meeting if there was "hope for peace," Mr. Arafat kept his face fixed in an unrevealing smile.
Mr. Arafat has thrived on presenting himself as an embattled, selfless fighter for his people's national aspirations, and in the view of most Palestinian and many Israeli analysts, the Israeli siege has only enhanced his chosen image. He has been careful not to complain about his own privations, speaking instead about the suffering of Palestinians generally under the Israeli security closures and economic blockade.
Rashid Hilal, 40, who works for Palestinian radio and television and has been living in the compound, said the biggest problems inside were the lack of water and food. Relief organizations have left some supplies, but their access is limited. "Food is a little," he said. "We eat one meal, sometimes just a small cheese and bread, sometimes hummus, one small container of hummus or beans for 10 people."
A senior American official said Mr. Arafat had shared one treat with Secretary Powell: a chocolate cake left two days ago by Norwegian diplomats. Secretary Powell had a bite.
In the days before Mr. Arafat returned to Israel from exile, this compound was the center of the Israeli military administration in Ramallah, and included a jail where Palestinian prisoners were housed. Now, it amounts to Mr. Arafat's own jail.
But in the office where American reporters were held, a bulletin board offered reminders of higher hopes from an earlier time, with a sticker advertising planned celebrations of the new millennium on the West Bank. "Bethlehem 2000," it read. "Follow the Star."

HEADLINE: More Apply To Law School After Shootings On Its Campus 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: GRUNDY, Va., April 14 

 BODY:
Applications to the Appalachian School of Law have increased in the three months since a gunman killed the dean, a professor and a student on campus.
 After the shooting, said Paul Dull, a lawyer in Roanoke, Va., who graduated from the school and leads its alumni association, "one of my biggest fears was that it would have a negative connotation that could essentially ruin a young school." As of April 6, however, the school, in economically depressed central Appalachia, had received 587 applications for admission. At the same time a year ago, 387 people had applied. 
 "We've had applications come from Alaska, from Maine, from all four corners of the continental United States," said Lucius Ellsworth, the school's president. Mr. Ellsworth said the school expected a first-year class of 125 in the fall. That would give it an enrollment of about 300.
Officials say the attention that the shootings on Jan. 16 attracted is one reason for the increase in applications. The attention also publicized the school's mission, to train young lawyers in the Appalachian region.
Some applicants were surprised to learn a law school existed in Grundy, a tiny town in southwestern Virginia, a coal-mining area. They were also surprised to learn that the little law school, which won provisional accreditation last year from the American Bar Association, had attracted faculty members.
Anthony Sutin, a Harvard Law School graduate, left a high-ranking job with the Justice Department to teach law at the school, and he later became dean. He was killed in the Jan. 16 shooting, with Thomas Blackwell, a professor, and Angela Dales, a first-year student. Three other students were wounded.
A former student, Peter Odighizuwa, has been charged with murder in the shootings. The police said Mr. Odighizuwa was angry about flunking out of the school. He is being held without bail, awaiting a hearing on June 20.
School officials say another mission of the school is to improve conditions in the region. The school has drawn many of its students from the mountains of Virginia, West Virginia, Tennessee, Kentucky and North Carolina.
The school requires students to spend 25 hours in community service each semester. In turn, community support for the school has grown stronger since the shooting, Mr. Ellsworth said.
After a memorial service at Grundy Baptist Church that followed the shooting, hundreds of people gathered to place flowers at the base of the school's stone sign.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TURMOIL: DIPLOMACY; 
European Union to Discuss How to Pressure Israel to Pull Back

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, April 14 

 BODY:
The European Union, losing patience with Israel's West Bank offensive, will consider on Monday ways to exert pressure on Prime Minister Ariel Sharon to bring it to an end.
 But already officials are saying that the 15 foreign ministers are not likely to take punitive steps at their meeting in Luxembourg, and certainly not the trade sanctions that have been threatened in recent days. 
 Instead, conscious of the European Union's limited influence, they will support Secretary of State Colin L. Powell's peace mission as the only hope for an end to the violence, participants said. 
"I would like to dampen expectations that anything dramatic will come out of the meeting Monday," said one European Union official.
The European Parliament called last week on the union to suspend a six-year-old treaty with Israel under which Israel enjoys preferential trade terms with the bloc, its biggest trading partner.
The European Union's budget commissioner, Michaele Schreyer, said today that she opposed imposing sanctions on Israel, saying such a step would be "a bad signal."
In an interview with Handelsblatt, a German business newspaper, Ms. Schreyer said the union would continue to support the Palestinian Authority, but would do so "without weakening Israel."
"If the E.U. wants to contribute to finding a peaceful solution to the conflict, it must react in a balanced manner," she said.
The Parliament's resolution was in some measure a bellwether of European public opinion.
Over 20,000 people demonstrated in Germany on Saturday to protest Israel's two-week offensive in Palestinian areas. Burying the Nazi past, Germans have long given unwavering support to Israel.
But the vote is not binding on governments, and of the member nations, only Belgium has openly suggested suspending the trade pact.
There has been slightly more support for an extraordinary meeting of the Association Council -- which oversees the agreement -- to give Israel a dressing-down over its operation.
But this option -- championed by the European Union's executive arm, the European Commission -- is also unlikely because of concern among Israel's closest European allies that it would jeopardize what little influence the bloc has in Middle East affairs.
"Contacts, pressure and dialogue are important right now," said one diplomat, who called proposals for punitive steps against Israel "unhelpful gesture politics."
Germany last week proposed an international "security presence" to guarantee any peace deal after a cease-fire and an Israeli withdrawal. 
Officials said that if the situation deteriorated, the European Union ministers could consider other steps, including delaying negotiations with Israel on trade in farm products and on plans to bolster Israel's participation in the European Union's scientific research programs.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TURMOIL: DIPLOMACY; 
No Cease-Fire Until Withdrawal, Arafat Tells Powell

BYLINE:  By TODD S. PURDUM and JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: RAMALLAH, West Bank, April 14 

 BODY:
Meeting with a top American official for the first time since Israel declared him irrelevant late last year, Yasir Arafat told Secretary of State Colin L. Powell today that no cease-fire was possible until Israel ended its military operation in the West Bank and withdrew from the cities and towns it had recently occupied.
 The meeting itself was a victory for Mr. Arafat and a disappointment for the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, who has sought to isolate the Palestinian leader in his office in Ramallah, where Israeli soldiers warily watched Secretary Powell's arrival today from a mere 30 yards away. The visit by Secretary Powell in a heavily armed and armored motorcade gave outsiders a rare look inside the battered compound. Page A10. 
 A senior administration official said tonight that Secretary Powell had delivered a blunt message to Mr. Arafat, summing it up this way: "It's showtime. You're on a dangerous path and you need to make a change." 
"He took it in," the official said of Mr. Arafat. "We'll see."
Tonight Mr. Sharon met with Secretary Powell and proposed an international summit meeting on the Middle East along the lines of the Madrid conference sponsored in 1991 by the first President Bush. But Mr. Sharon insists that Mr. Arafat not take part in any such meeting.
After months of worsening violence, including Palestinian suicide attacks and Israeli reprisal raids, Mr. Sharon has rejected Mr. Arafat as a potential partner for peace and has urged his exile, hoping instead to cultivate a new generation of Palestinian leaders. 
Despite internal divisions over dealing with Mr. Arafat, the Bush administration continues to regard him as the only Palestinian with enough influence to strike a durable deal with Israel.
A senior American official said Secretary Powell was open to the idea of a summit meeting, viewing it as "part of a mix of ideas" that had promise. 
"I don't think it would be Madrid," the official added, suggesting that it would have narrower scope. The Madrid conference brought together all parties to the Arab-Israeli conflict for the first time, and it established land-for-peace and self-determination as the bases for a broader settlement.
In his meeting with Mr. Sharon, his second since arriving in Israel on Thursday, Secretary Powell pressed President Bush's request for a full Israeli withdrawal, said Richard A. Boucher, the State Department spokesman, who called the discussion "very good and thorough."
Mr. Boucher said Secretary Powell "stressed our serious concerns about the humanitarian situation" of the Palestinians, particularly on the West Bank in Jenin. There, in fierce fighting, Israeli forces have leveled parts of the refugee camp, leaving an unknown number of Palestinians dead and causing others to flee. 
Palestinian and American negotiators were to talk again on Monday, partly to discuss an economic reconstruction package for the ruined Palestinian civil administration.
Also on Monday, Secretary Powell plans to make a hastily arranged day trip to Lebanon and Syria to discuss tensions on Israel's northern border, where near-daily rocket and artillery fire from Hezbollah, the Lebanese militant group, has threatened to provoke a wider war.
After months of backing Mr. Arafat's diplomatic isolation, the Bush administration has altered course as it seeks to build support among Arab states for a possible strike on Iraq, which the administration accuses of developing weapons of mass destruction. Arab nations have told the Bush administration that it is more important to stop the bloodshed here.
Palestinian leaders said they were encouraged by Mr. Arafat's discussion with Secretary Powell today, noting that the Bush administration appeared to be willing now to discuss not merely security matters but substantive political differences between Israelis and Palestinians. Mr. Sharon has repeatedly refused to address such differences until security is assured, arguing that to do otherwise would be to reward terrorism.
"They believe that the security arrangements cannot stand without a political process, that's what he assured us," Yasir Abed Rabbo, the Palestinian minister of information, said of Secretary Powell. Mr. Abed Rabbo took part in today's meeting.
"The main thing is, we want to know how serious this administration is concerning the immediate withdrawal, which the president himself has asked for," Mr. Abed Rabbo said. "It's clear that Sharon intends to continue the war." He added, "We don't doubt the position of the administration, but we still doubt that there is enough pressure."
Secretary Powell called the three hours of intense talks with Mr. Arafat "useful and constructive" but offered no hint of progress toward a truce to end 18 months of violence.
"We exchanged a variety of ideas and discussed steps on how we can move forward," Secretary Powell said as he emerged from the Ramallah compound, where Mr. Arafat has been trapped since early December. For the last 17 days, he has been held in near isolation, with Israeli forces operating within his hearing.
Both Israeli and Palestinian officials said they expected Secretary Powell to meet again with Mr. Arafat, on Tuesday. But the senior American official said no meeting was set. "The secretary was very careful not to promise any more meetings," he said. "We'll make an assessment later."
Israeli officials continued to play down expectations for Secretary Powell's mission, saying Mr. Arafat was unlikely to agree to a cease-fire while he felt that international sympathy and diplomatic support was swinging toward the Palestinians and away from Israel. "He's in euphoria, so why should he give in to the Americans?" asked one Israeli official.
Though Israeli forces have pulled back from some Palestiniancontrolled villages, Mr. Sharon has rebuffed Mr. Bush's requests for a total withdrawal, calling the military mission essential for Israel's self-defense. 
The fighting continued today, though at a less intense pitch. Israeli forces occupy several major Palestinian cities and towns, including Ramallah, Jenin and Bethlehem. As the siege continued in Bethlehem outside the Church of the Nativity, where 200 gunmen have been holed up for almost two weeks, Israeli forces shot and killed a Palestinian who the army said was armed.
The Bush administration has been seeking an end to the Israeli military operation and a crackdown by Mr. Arafat on Palestinian violence. So far, it has received commitments but little action on either front. Mr. Sharon says the military operation is necessary because Mr. Arafat will not act against Palestinian militants; Mr. Arafat says that he cannot do so while the Israeli operation continues.
Mr. Arafat has said he accepts a cease-fire plan brokered by the United States. 
But after the meeting with Secretary Powell this morning, Palestinian officials repeated that Mr. Arafat would move against violence only after Israel withdraws.
"Absolutely, we are fully committed to our obligations emanating from understandings and agreements here, including security obligations," said a Palestinian negotiator, Saeb Erekat. But, referring to Israeli soldiers surrounding the compound, he added, "I'm sure the secretary saw Chairman Arafat's situation, and I believe that once the Israelis complete their withdrawal, we will, as Palestinians, carry out our obligations."
A senior State Department official said Mr. Arafat had begun the meeting with an hourlong monologue in Arabic, outlining Palestinian concerns about the recent Israeli occupation and raids. 
He focused on the standoff at the Church of the Nativity and the killings by Israeli soldiers in the Jenin refugee camp, which Palestinians have called a massacre. 
Israeli soldiers and top officials say the army took great care and put its own men at great risk in distinguishing between gunmen and civilians.
"The presentation from Chairman Arafat was organized, it was serious, he went through methodically his concerns," the official said. Secretary Powell responded with a 45-minute brief of his own, making the American case "that the bombing had to stop," the official said, adding: "The pattern of bombings is a barrier to moving forward. It makes everything more difficult to move forward."
The meeting with Secretary Powell, first set for Saturday but postponed after a Palestinian suicide bomber killed six people and wounded scores in Jerusalem on Friday, finally happened this morning only after Mr. Arafat issued a broad statement on Saturday condemning attacks on civilians. 
The meeting took place in an air of considerable drama.
Secretary Powell's party traveled from Jerusalem in two heavily armored convoys that passed through streets torn to pieces by tank treads and littered with the burned-out remnants of cars, garbage and other debris.

HEADLINE: States Are Set To Rest Case On Penalties For Microsoft 

BYLINE:  By AMY HARMON 

 BODY:
The states pursuing stiff antitrust sanctions against the Microsoft Corporation are preparing to rest their case today, clearing the way for what is expected to be a month of testimony by Microsoft witnesses who will urge a federal judge to apply a lighter touch.
 The coalition of state attorneys general say their proposal will open up competition in emerging technologies that may eventually replace the ubiquitous Windows operating system as the link for consumers to their computing machines. Microsoft and the Justice Department, which have reached a less restrictive settlement, say the states' plan would confuse consumers and bestow unfair advantages on the company's rivals. 
 But for all the predictions about the future from the technology executives, economists and lawyers testifying on both sides of the case, it increasingly appears that the judge's decision may rest on a question about the past. The question is inherently hypothetical: if Microsoft had not violated antitrust laws to maintain its Windows monopoly in the mid-1990's, would consumers have a choice in PC operating systems today? 
Microsoft's expert economist, Kevin Murphy of the University of Chicago, is expected to testify this week that the answer is no. Microsoft has long argued that the company's superior products and the missteps of its competitors, not Microsoft's illegal actions, enabled it to maintain a position of monopoly power.
If there was no measurable damage to competition, Microsoft argues, then legal precedent dictates the court should only narrowly limit the company's future business practices. Even the appeals court ruling, which held the company liable for repeatedly violating antitrust laws, said that it had "causal connection" between Microsoft's illegal conduct and its monopoly position "only through inference."
"The states have acknowledged that this is important, but they've essentially taken a pass on it," said Jim Desler, a Microsoft spokesman. "They didn't meet their burden."
The states acknowledge that their answer to the hypothetical question of operating system competitors can only be "maybe." But they argue that both the original federal district judge, Thomas Penfield Jackson, and the appeals court found that the Netscape Navigator Web browser and Sun Microsystem's Java programming language posed genuine threats to Microsoft's monopoly.
Carl Shapiro, the states' expert economist, testified last week that the notion of "network effects," where software programs that first capture a dominant position are difficult to dislodge, indicates that the combination of Navigator and Java would have evolved into a potent competitor to Windows. To limit the restrictions on Microsoft just because that cannot be definitively proved, he said, would fail to undo the damage of the company's illegal acts.
"The initial disruptive influences of the Internet are past, the element of surprise has been lost, and Microsoft has bolstered its Windows monopoly by gaining control over the browser," Mr. Shapiro said in his written testimony. "Restoring competition must mean more than merely enjoining the prior illegal conduct."
Netscape's browser once held about 80 percent of the market. Today Netscape, which is now part of AOL Time Warner, has 7 percent, while Microsoft's Internet Explorer has more than 85 percent.
The states also argue that a dangerous signal is sent if a monopolist can crush nascent technologies without strong penalties that recognize how quickly the technology landscape -- and therefore the context of competition -- changes.
"Microsoft seems to be suggesting you have to be a full-blown platform threat in order to be a technology that deserves protection," said Tom Greene, a lawyer for the states. "If that's true, then as long as they throttle the baby in the basket it's no problem. Certainly it has enormous policy implications for future antitrust cases in this very important industry."
Microsoft plans to move to dismiss the case based on the states' failure to show they were injured by the company's actions. Federal District Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly in Washington is likely to reserve judgment on the motion until the end of the trial. But Tom Greene, a lawyer for the states, said he expected Microsoft to press the point that without more proof of damage there is no justification for a broad remedy.
The states that are still pursuing the four-year-old antitrust case are California, Connecticut, Florida, Iowa, Kansas, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Utah and West Virginia along with the District of Columbia. Nine other states joined the Justice Department and Microsoft in the proposed settlement.
Throughout the four weeks of testimony by the states' witnesses, Microsoft sought to discredit the states' proposals by suggesting that they were drawn up at the behest of its rivals in emerging markets like hand-held computing and Web services.
Now, the company's witnesses are expected to attack the states' specific proposals. They include allowing computer makers to remove Microsoft programs like the media player and Web browser from Windows, auctioning off the right to develop a version of its popular Office software to run on an alternate operating system and publishing information that would enable rivals to develop programs that work as well with Windows as Microsoft's own programs do.
The question facing Judge Kollar-Kotelly is not just hypothetical.
"This is a perfect example of a new-economy case where the market is continually changing as the case is proceeding," said Robert E. Litan, director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution and a former Justice Department official. "It's unlike the old-economy breakup of oil companies or even the AT&T case, where the market moved but phone service was still phone service. You just have to make up case law as you go along."

HEADLINE: Patents; 
A publicity success, the futuristic Segway scooter may be celebrated for its engine.

BYLINE:  By Teresa Riordan 

 BODY:
DEAN KAMEN'S motorized scooter, conceived as Ginger and christened Segway, has sparked the public imagination like few other inventions in recent memory. A New Yorker cover recently featured Osama bin Laden making a getaway on a Segway. Last week, the television character Niles rode one on "Frasier."
 But recently published patent applications bolster the tantalizing speculation that Mr. Kamen may indeed have something much bigger up his sleeve than the cute scooter, which looks something like a motorized push mower with wheels. 
 Such speculation has been brewing for more than a year now, fueled in part by remarks made by Robert Metcalfe, a buddy of Mr. Kamen's. Dr. Metcalfe is no slouch himself in the invention department; he created, and made a fortune from, the office network technology known as Ethernet.
Dr. Metcalfe has been quoted as saying that the real "It" -- the code name that a journalist, Steve Kemper, used when he sold a book proposal for an insider's account of Kamen's secret new device -- is an invention "bigger than pantyhose," "bigger than the Internet" and "almost as big as cold fusion would have been."
Therefore many people were disappointed when the ostensible unveiling of "It" amounted to no more than Diane Sawyer, of "Good Morning America," tooling around Bryant Park on what appeared to be a glorified scooter. Certainly the Segway seems less of a physics-defying concept than Mr. Kamen's iBot, a stair-climbing wheelchair, which he once used to climb a third of the way up the Eiffel Tower.
The importance of "It," however, may have as much to do with the scooter's future engine as with the scooter itself. Last month, the United States Patent Office published application No. 20020029567 -- with Mr. Kamen named as one of the inventors -- for the manufacturing of a Stirling engine, which can be powered by heat from any fuel and is virtually nonpolluting. Indeed, a profile of Mr. Kamen in the May issue of Vanity Fair says he has produced two small prototypes of such an engine, but offers few details.
Mr. Kamen's wealth and reputation were built on medical patents, but he has patented a wide range of inventions. These include -- somewhat improbably, given that Mr. Kamen, in his early 50's, is a lifelong bachelor -- a cradle that simulates the experience of the womb and a "catemenial container," essentially a disposable version of a 19th-century menstruation receptacle.
At least three Stirling engine patents have already been issued to one of Mr. Kamen's companies, New Power Concepts, which is based in Manchester, N.H. But the interesting thing about the most recent patent application (and it is only an application; the patent hasn't yet been granted), according to several people familiar with Stirling engines, is that it covers the manufacturing of the engine, not just the design.
"This patent was filed by a person who is going into production," said Brent H. Van Arsdell, president of American Stirling, an educational company that sells nonindustrial Stirling engines to physics professors and enthusiasts. "He's fairly confident of his design. This addresses the question of how can we build this economically and faster and reliably after we already have a prototype that costs us millions of dollars."
The Stirling engine is by no means a new concept. Robert Stirling, a minister in Edinburgh, Scotland, applied for a patent in September 1816 for his "economiser." Over the next two centuries many versions of engines inspired by the Stirling design have been built.
Kockums, a Swedish defense contractor, now produces a Stirling engine for submarines. And NASA is said to be developing Stirling engines for space exploration.
But so far no company has successfully produced a mass-market version, although Philips Electronics tried unsuccessfully about three decades ago to introduce a Stirling car engine.
Why would an inexpensive engine potentially be important? Stirling enthusiasts contend that it might easily provide power for people in emerging economies for water purification or even Internet access. In developed countries it might allow people to go off the electrical grid and even wean themselves from a dependency on foreign oil.
A second pending patent application from Mr. Kamen's company, No. 20010032452, suggests that his engine can run on fuels ranging from cow dung to nuclear material and everything in between, including propane, natural gas, methane, butane and petroleum.
A Stirling is essentially an external combustion engine -- as opposed to the familiar internal combustion engines that run everything from automobiles to large factories.
Maureen Toohey, a lawyer for Mr. Kamen, said his company was not yet manufacturing the engines. "We're still in development," she said. But she pointed out that the nonpolluting Stirling engines can be used to power a lot of things other than scooters. "One of the unique things about a Stirling engine is that it's an incredibly versatile platform that one can do many things with," she said.
One of the difficulties in making a Stirling is that its engine cylinder and heat exchangers need to be extremely resistant to high temperatures and thus are usually constructed of the super alloys used in jet engines. These alloys are extremely hard to use in the manufacturing process.
The Kamen engine appears to be not terribly different from other Stirling engines. However, its heat exchanger -- which has projecting "fins" that make it look like a riled porcupine ready to attack -- has been designed so that it can be cast rather than welded, a key efficiency.
"I can design all sorts of beautiful Stirling engines in my mind," said John Brisson, a professor of mechanical engineering at M.I.T. "The nub of the matter is can you build it so that it operates efficiently, and can you build it cheaply?"
Even if Mr. Kamen is able to produce a low-cost Stirling engine, Professor Brisson warns, the hurdles are many for any disruptive technology. "It would be so radically different that mechanics wouldn't know what to do with it," he said. "The infrastructure is totally different. It has to be better by a factor of 10 than what is out there; otherwise no one is going to make the transition."

HEADLINE: Recent Good News for WorldCom May Only Mask Deeper Problems 

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
Things have been looking a bit brighter for WorldCom Inc. in recent weeks. The company won a major contract from the Pentagon. A federal judge in Mississippi dismissed claims that WorldCom defrauded investors. Even the company's announcement that it needed to cut costs by laying off 3,700 employees, or 4 percent of its work force, was not as drastic as analysts had predicted. 
 Yet investors have continued to flee from WorldCom, the nation's second-largest long-distance phone company and one of the most troubled giants in the hard-hit telecommunications sector. Last week, it briefly joined equipment makers like Lucent and Nortel Networks, whose shares traded in the realm of so-called penny stocks, below $5, before rallying to close on Friday at $5.01. 
 WorldCom is still in stronger financial shape than Qwest, another big communications company that, like WorldCom, is being investigated by federal regulators for accounting practices that may have violated securities laws. What Wall Street fears is that WorldCom's problems may run deeper than Qwest's -- and that the company's management, led by Bernard J. Ebbers, is ill equipped to deal with them. 
Critics say that Mr. Ebbers has failed to create a solid foundation for sustained growth from the broad portfolio of phone and data services he accumulated through a long string of acquisitions that culminated in the $37 billion stock deal for MCI Communications in 1998. And questions about WorldCom's accounting, as well as its $30 billion in debt, make it an unattractive merger partner for other large communications companies.
"They may have the best collection of assets out there among the major long-distance companies, but they also have the worst liabilities," said Scott C. Clelland, an analyst at the Precursor Group in Washington. 
Mr. Ebbers, now 60, was one of hundreds of entrepreneurs who plunged into the long-distance phone business in the mid-80's when the court-ordered breakup of AT&T gave them the chance to lease and resell chunks of long-distance capacity at deep discounts. Mr. Ebbers, who had run a small motel chain before entering the phone business, was quicker than most to realize that consolidating the many start-up phone companies could be highly profitable.
By the time WorldCom became a communications giant with the takeover of MCI in the fall of 1998, Mr. Ebbers had completed more than 60 acquisitions. He and a small team of loyal executives led by Scott D. Sullivan, the chief financial officer, were masters at cost cutting and aggressive accounting, which produced profits that dazzled Wall Street. WorldCom's stock climbed to a peak of more than $60 in March 1999. 
Through it all, Mr. Ebbers ran the company from a modest headquarters in tiny Clinton, Miss. He became known for gestures like taking visiting WorldCom executives to the company cafeteria and leaving it to them to pay for their lunch.
Former executives say the deal-making outstripped WorldCom's management skills. 
"WorldCom grew too fast," said Lance B. Boxer, who was chief information officer of MCI at the time of the takeover and one of the many senior executives who quickly left. "They didn't have the experience of operating at that scale."
Mr. Ebbers and other senior WorldCom officials declined to be interviewed for this article. 
Mr. Ebbers has his vigorous defenders. "I always saw Bernie grow into the role with each acquisition," said Steven Dobel, a former senior sales executive. 
When Mr. Dobel joined the company in 1992, it was called LDDS Communications and had $800 million in revenue and operating income of $118 million from reselling long-distance capacity. In 2000, the year Mr. Dobel retired, WorldCom reached its peak operating income of $8.15 billion and record revenue of $39.09 billion. It owned or controlled extensive long-distance, local and Internet networks in this country and overseas, as well as the SkyTel paging network and a variety of communications and data management products it sold to large customers. 
Mr. Ebbers's growth strategy hit a wall that same year when regulators rejected WorldCom's plans to grow even bigger and become a major force in wireless communications by acquiring Sprint in a stock swap valued at $130 billion. WorldCom was forced to stop changing shape long enough for investors to take a closer look at what Mr. Ebbers and Mr. Sullivan had built. The scrutiny occurred in the cold light of a slowing economy and increasing competition. With brief interruptions, WorldCom's stock price has been tumbling ever since.
No investor has been hit harder than Mr. Ebbers. Unlike Gary Winnick, the architect of the bankrupt Global Crossing, Mr. Ebbers did not profit from selling shares in his company before their price declined. In fact, he borrowed money to keep accumulating shares as his stock options matured. 
But any halo he might have earned by remaining faithful to the stock has been tarnished by the extraordinary steps WorldCom's board has taken to help him do so. The board has given Mr. Ebbers loans and loan guarantees that, as of February, were valued at nearly $375 million, arguing that forced sales of his holdings would harm all shareholders.
Mr. Ebbers has said he will repay loans by selling other assets, but he has never identified other sources of wealth large enough to cover his obligations. The loans have led to shareholder lawsuits and fueled longstanding doubts about whether the board is independent enough to function effectively. Restive institutional shareholders like the California Public Employees' Retirement System say they plan to vote against the board members on the compensation committee at the annual meeting on May 23. 
Mr. Ebbers jokingly acknowledged the board's unflinching loyalty in an interview last year with Fortune magazine, where he was quoted as saying, "I've often told my board I may have to fire myself for the sake of my stock." Now, according to Kenneth McGee, a vice president at Gartner, an information technology research firm, "there are 375 million reasons the board won't fire him."
If WorldCom emerges unscathed from the S.E.C. investigation, as the company asserts it will, it still faces widespread doubts about its chances for prosperity. WorldCom's most obvious business burden is its big stake in the land-line long-distance phone market. The company is vulnerable to regional phone giants like Verizon Communications and SBC Communications, which have been allowed by regulators to enter the long-distance business in parts of their home territories. In the meantime, the entire land-line business is shrinking as more callers switch to wireless phones, a sector in which WorldCom has little presence.
Even Jack B. Grubman, a Salomon Smith Barney analyst who has long been one of Mr. Ebbers's biggest boosters, projects no revenue growth in the first half of the year, less than 2 percent for the full year and just 3 percent for 2003. 
Critics of WorldCom acknowledge that market conditions play a major role in the company's troubles. But they argue that WorldCom's predicament is also the legacy of deal making run amok. 
When the deal to acquire MCI closed, Mr. Ebbers told investors, "We will soon be in full stride as one company." In fact, the marriage has been rocky. Much of MCI's senior management left quickly, flush with payouts from stock options. Bert C. Roberts Jr., MCI's chief executive, stayed on as chairman of the merged WorldCom, though he has little involvement with the company.
"They said they bought MCI to serve as the integrating agent," said Mr. McGee, whose practice includes consulting for many of WorldCom's largest customers. "The promises made were interesting, but didn't have the benefit of being possible." 
At a Merrill Lynch conference last month, Mr. Ebbers detailed recent progress in integrating billing systems and other operations. But many networking experts say WorldCom is still notable for the diversity and incompatibility of its networks and supporting technology.
The MCI integration process stumbled right from the beginning, according to executives involved in it. MCI officials had been working for almost a year on plans to merge with British Telecom when WorldCom arrived on the scene with its surprise bid late in 1997. By contrast, MCI managers heard little from WorldCom beyond matters related to winning shareholder and regulatory approvals.
"Nothing really got done with WorldCom until the closing," Mr. Boxer said. After the closing, in September 1998, most parts of the company continued to operate separately, including previously acquired subsidiaries like UUNet, the nation's leading provider of high-capacity Internet backbone networks. In some cases, the lack of coordination resulted in UUNet and other parts of WorldCom bidding against each other to sell Internet service to big customers, according to testimony in a recent lawsuit in Virginia.
When WorldCom, to cut costs, began managing commissions paid to the MCI's sales force in 1999 using the relatively simple software WorldCom had employed for its own, much smaller operations, the system was unable to handle MCI's national accounts, according to William Marcinko, a former MCI technology manager familiar with the operation. 
The software could not track which national-account representatives were falling short of sales goals, so WorldCom was forced to pay commissions as if everyone were meeting the targets -- even though such success rates are never achieved in the communications world, Mr. Marcinko said.
The impact the integration problems had on WorldCom's reported earnings and revenue appears to be a focus of the S.E.C. investigation, judging from the inquiry letter WorldCom received early in March. The class-action suits recently dismissed in Mississippi cite numerous instances where bungled integration may have contributed to double-billing and other practices that inflated earnings. Plaintiffs' lawyers say they plan to appeal the dismissal.
But whatever the courts and regulators say, WorldCom will still be left with the challenge of functioning as a cohesive company.
"Things have improved at the front end in that there is less conflict among the parts of the company marketing different services," said David Willis, vice president of global networking for the META Group in Stamford, Conn., "but many customers are painfully aware that WorldCom is not running a unified infrastructure. That would take massive investment in systems, but they are cutting back on capital spending."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: TERROR NETWORK; 
Spain Arrests Algerian Man Suspected as Qaeda Aide

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

DATELINE: MADRID, April 14 

 BODY:
Spanish authorities said today that they had arrested an Algerian associated with Al Qaeda, Osama bin Laden's network. He is suspected of raising funds for the 1998 attacks on two American Embassies in Africa and helping finance terrorist sleeper cells in Europe.
 Interior Minister Mariano Rajoy called the arrest a "heavy blow" to Al Qaeda's financial organization. He said computers and documents seized at the home of the suspect, Ahmed Brahim, near Barcelona appeared to detail connections ranging across Europe and into Saudi Arabia. 
 "We have discovered a very important part of Al Qaeda's financial network," Mr. Rajoy told reporters in northern Spain.
The arrest was a result of a lengthy investigation involving Spanish, American, French and German authorities. It came just days after Secretary of State Colin L. Powell signed an agreement with Spain in a visit to Madrid that allows American intelligence agencies to take part in joint investigations of Al Qaeda.
An American official in Madrid said that continuing inquiries across Spain were important in the worldwide attempt to unravel Al Qaeda finances, to understand planning for the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon and to foil future attacks.
"Spain is important to the ongoing investigation, and some of the people in custody here may be able to help put the puzzle together," the American official said.
American investigators have been working closely with authorities in Spain, France and Germany since the attacks, trying to unravel the shadowy Qaeda network that grew up in Europe in recent years.
While authorities believe much of the planning for the Sept. 11 attacks occurred in Hamburg, Germany, telephone records, financial transactions and arrests have uncovered loose connections to suspected terrorist cells also operating in France, Italy and Spain.
Though dozens of suspects were rounded up in the first weeks after Sept. 11, none of the cases have yet come to court. The number of arrests has dwindled in recent weeks as investigators struggle to piece together what most describe as a loosely connected network of Islamic militants.
Spain assumed prominence in the investigation in November when a Spanish investigative judge ordered the arrests of eight men suspected of helping to prepare for the Sept. 11 attacks. They are suspected of providing logistical and financial support to the hijackers, including committing crimes to raise money and forging identity documents.
The latest accusations in Spain fit the pattern. The police said that Mr. Brahim, 57, an unemployed Algerian engineer who lived in a Barcelona suburb, played a role in financing the 1998 attacks on the embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, and may have funneled money to Al Qaeda sleeper cells in Europe. The attacks killed 225 people.
Video released by the police showed Mr. Brahim, gray-haired and heavily bearded, being escorted out of his home in handcuffs on Saturday night by police officers whose faces were covered with hoods.
Though his name had not surfaced in public previously, Mr. Brahim's arrest dealt "a heavy blow to the financial apparatus" of Al Qaeda, Mr. Rajoy said. The interior minister described the suspect as "an important member of the network and a collaborator of Osama bin Laden's financial brain."
He was referring to Mamdouh Mahmud Salim, a Sudanese who is awaiting trial in the United States for participation in the embassy bombings.
During a nine-hour search of Mr. Brahim's apartment, the police found computer equipment, bank accounts and different business documents, Mr. Rajoy said. 
Hooded agents removed boxes of confiscated material from the apartment. The police said Mr. Brahim's business activities included buying and selling recreational boats, as well as advertising and public relations. He also sent high-tech computer equipment to several countries, including Saudi Arabia.
Mr. Brahim is being held for questioning under antiterrorist legislation and was brought to Madrid today. Mr. Rajoy said the case would be brought to trial "as quickly as possible." The police were also questioning four people holding French nationality documents who were in Mr. Brahim's apartment at the time of his arrest. 
Mr. Brahim's Finnish wife, Pirjo, told reporters that her husband had lived in Spain for 15 years and that he had nothing to do with Al Qaeda. She said his real work was connected to Saudi Arabia and "things sacred to our prophet," a reference on which she did not elaborate.
The Spanish police are now holding 17 men suspected of involvement with Al Qaeda, including the eight detained in Madrid in November accused of direct involvement with the Sept. 11 attacks. In addition, an Algerian and a Moroccan-born Spaniard who reportedly escaped the Madrid operation were detained in January by the police in Barcelona.
The suspected ringleader of the plot, Imad Eddin Barakat Yarkas, is believed by the Spanish and American authorities to have been a major catch, with connections to the suspected hijackers from the Sept. 11 attacks and other Al Qaeda operatives throughout the world.
A Spanish judge, Baltazar Garzon, said in his report on the case that Mr. Yarkas had contacts with Mohamed Atta, the suspected leader of the hijackers, and three other suspected plotters who shared an apartment with Mr. Atta in Hamburg.
In addition, the judge said Mr. Yarkas traveled to Britain, Europe, Malaysia and elsewhere to meet with Al Qaeda leaders and recruit members for the organization. Spanish investigators also are trying to connect Mr. Yarkas and other members of his group with a visit to Spain last July by Mr. Atta.
It is unclear at this point where Mr. Brahim might fit into the puzzle. His name had not surfaced publicly before his arrest and the evidence behind the accusations against him has not been made public yet.

HEADLINE: Northrop Raises Its Bid for TRW by $758 Million 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

 BODY:
The Northrop Grumman Corporation raised its hostile offer for TRW Inc. by $758 million, to $6.7 billion in stock, last night in a last-ditch effort to pressure TRW to engage in talks.
 TRW, the satellite and missile contractor based in Cleveland, has twice spurned offers from Northrop, the big military contractor based in Los Angeles. Northrop first approached TRW in February with a friendly bid of $5.9 billion, but that offer turned hostile in March after TRW's board rejected the deal. 
 In two weeks, TRW's shareholders are scheduled to vote on the sweetened bid.
TRW, meanwhile, is continuing with its plan to spin off its automotive unit to increase TRW's value without having to be bought by Northrop. Northrop had similarly planned to spin off the automotive unit if it took control of the company.
The latest offer from Northrop -- $53 a share compared with $47 -- may compel TRW's board to come to the table. The offer represents a 13 percent premium over its original bid, but only a 2 percent premium over TRW's closing stock price on Friday of $51.97.
"We strongly encourage TRW shareholders to send a strong message to their board of directors in favor of inviting us to conduct due diligence," said Kent Kresa, Northrop Grumman's chairman and chief executive.
"If the TRW board continues to deny us access, this offer will not proceed," he added.
Mr. Kresa defended Northrop's decision to raise its offer after refusing to do so before by saying that the new bid reflected "improving economic conditions which drive TRW's end markets and continuing positive developments in the defense industry."
Northrop has been aggressively lobbying institutional investors in recent weeks to overturn TRW's defense measures. In particular, Northrop has met recently with Institutional Shareholder Services, the influential advisory firm that most recently played a role in Hewlett-Packard's bid for Compaq Computer by telling clients to vote in favor of a merger.
Institutional Shareholder Services is expected to make its recommendation on Wednesday.
TRW officials could not immediately be reached for comment.
Analysts and industry executives have said that Northrop, like its rivals Lockheed Martin and Boeing, is preparing for a time when more taxpayers' dollars are expected to be sent to military contractors in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks.
The military industry contracted in the 1990's, laying off thousands of workers and closing factories, particularly in Southern California, which was once the center of the industry but is no longer, as many companies have moved away.

HEADLINE: UPRISING IN VENEZUELA: ECONOMICS; 
Nervous Markets Fear Surge in the Price of Oil

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

 BODY:
Crude oil prices are expected to surge when trading begins today after the weekend lull, as oil markets confront the possibility of continuing political instability in Venezuela after the whiplash turn of events that brought President Hugo Chavez back to power.
 Venezuela is the third-largest supplier of imported crude oil and oil products to the United States, and the world's fourth-largest oil exporter, producing about 2.5 million barrels a day. Venezuelan supplies meet about 7 percent of United States needs. 
 After Mr. Chavez was ousted on Thursday evening, crude oil prices plummeted by 6 percent on Friday, to $23.47 a barrel, the steepest decline in five months, on the expectation that Venezuelan exports would return to normal. 
The Venezuelan industry had nearly ground to a halt after workers at the state oil company, Petroleos de Venezuela, staged work stoppages and slowdowns, culminating in nationwide strikes and violent confrontations that hastened Mr. Chavez's departure.
Venezuelan industry officials said on Friday that they expected exports to return to normal early this week. 
With Mr. Chavez now back in the presidency, though, at least for the time being, questions about further strikes and disruptions loom. Any certainty about normalizing exports has been wiped away. 
"The question is whether the workers are willing to go back, with him back in office," said Thomas P. Bentz, senior energy analyst with BNP Paribas in New York. "Are operations coming back? I think we would retrace the losses in the market on Friday, and then some."
Oil analysts estimate that prices could bounce up by $1.50 to $3 a barrel. Such a jump could prove damaging to the nascent economic recovery in the United States if prices remain high over the coming months, which is far from certain.
The drop in prices last week was also stoked by comments from some oil officials who indicated that Venezuela would eventually abandon Mr. Chavez's policy of adhering to production quotas set for the country by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, of which it is a member. Over the last several years, Mr. Chavez's alignment with OPEC helped to reduce global supplies and to bolster prices.
The interim leadership late last week indicated that Venezuela would produce more oil and try to grab a greater market share, which sent prices tumbling. Now that appears unlikely as long as Mr. Chavez is in power.
For years, critics of Mr. Chavez had complained that he was ruining one of the world's best-run state oil companies by larding it with cronies, including some appointed to the board; hobbling its autonomy; and channeling away more money to the government budget, leaving little for the upkeep of the company itself.
Upon returning to office on Sunday, he moved quickly to show opponents at the oil company that he sought reconciliation by dismissing the board. 
"We have to see if Chavez gets it, if in a month he doesn't sack the board of directors again," said Judith Evans, president of JE Analytica, a New York consulting firm specializing in Latin America. "The thing is, Chavez's psychology has always been the wild card in the poker game of Venezuela."

HEADLINE: Senator Running on Family Values Has a Tough Race After Divorce 

BYLINE:  By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 13 

 BODY:
Senator Tim Hutchinson has a problem.
 In 1996 when he first ran for the Senate, he styled himself as a conservative, family-values Republican, an ideological approach intended to appeal to this state's many Christian-right voters. The breakdown of the American family, he said, was a critical national issue. 
 Mr. Hutchinson won fairly comfortably, with 53 percent of the vote, the first Republican since Reconstruction to capture a Senate seat in heavily Democratic Arkansas. 
Now Mr. Hutchinson, a Southern Baptist minister, is seeking a second term, running against a popular Democrat, State Attorney General Mark Pryor.
Again, Mr. Hutchinson is identifying himself as a conservative, family-values Republican. The problem is that in 1999 Mr. Hutchinson, now 52, divorced his wife of 29 years, Donna, with whom he had three sons, and shortly afterward married a former member of his office staff, Randi Fredholm, now 39.
Many of Mr. Hutchinson's most committed supporters, the core of any strong campaign, were disturbed by his divorce and remarriage. 
His poll numbers have slipped as the issue has been raised anew during this election year, though he has publicly apologized to his supporters, telling them that he remains a totally committed family-values man who has been "humbled" and "left less smug about the shortcomings of others" by the breakup of his marriage.
At the same time, Mr. Pryor, 39, the son of former Senator David Pryor, one of Arkansas's most beloved Democratic icons, has seen his poll numbers improve, and the race is essentially too close to call.
As a result, it has become one of the half-dozen most closely watched races in this year's struggle for control of the Senate.
The Cook Political Report, a widely read nonpartisan publication that tracks Congressional elections, labels the race "very competitive." Another closely followed elections publication, The Rothenberg Political Report, also nonpartisan, calls it a tossup.
But Mr. Hutchinson is also facing an opponent in the Republican primary on May 21. He is State Representative Jim Bob Duggar, another conservative Southern Baptist. Mr. Duggar says he was "called by God" to run against Mr. Hutchinson.
Mr. Duggar, 36, the father of 13 children ("14, really, since my wife is pregnant and life begins at conception"), is not regarded as a serious threat to Mr. Hutchinson's renomination. But he is something of an embarrassment, given that very few other senators up for re-election this year have primary challengers. Further, Republicans who abandon Mr. Hutchinson for Mr. Duggar in May may not return to him in November, if they go to the polls at all.
At a Duggar rally a few nights ago, Rod Castle, an advertising sales representative who said he voted for Mr. Hutchinson in 1996, said he would vote for Mr. Duggar this year.
"Tim's lost my support," Mr. Castle said. "For a man to leave his wife and marry a staff member, there has to be underlying things in his character."
Senator Hutchinson was a vocal critic of his fellow Arkansan, President Bill Clinton, in the Monica Lewinsky scandal and, with his brother, Asa, then a Republican member of the House, strongly supported impeachment. When Mr. Hutchinson's divorce and relationship with Ms. Fredholm became news, Democrats called him a hypocrite, though he said his personal situation did not resemble Mr. Clinton's.
Both national parties have become involved in the Arkansas contest. President Bush and Vice President Cheney have held fund-raisers for Mr. Hutchinson. Top Democrats in Washington have promised Mr. Pryor money and workers.
Mr. Pryor and Mr. Hutchinson expect to spend as much as $10 million each by Election Day.
Mr. Pryor is a moderate. He opposes privatizing Social Security, is against new tax breaks for big corporations unless small businesses also get them and would not make abortion a litmus test for judicial appointments.
He contends that Mr. Hutchinson, who strongly supports most of the Bush administration's agenda, especially its opposition to abortion, is "way too conservative for Arkansas," a state that is geographically in the South but has a populist-progressive streak. When he speaks of Mr. Hutchinson's marital problems, Mr. Pryor says: "They are what they are. Let the voters decide."
Mr. Pryor and his wife, Jill, have two children. The Pryors' 10-year-old marriage is the first for each.
Mr. Hutchinson contends that Mr. Pryor is "out of Arkansas's political mainstream" and does not have the experience or stature to represent the state when the nation is "in a war with global terrorism and just beginning to recover from economic hard times."
Some top State Republican Party officials argue that "the only thing Mark Pryor has going is David Pryor." In fact, Mr. Pryor's campaign advertising includes plenty of images of his father. 
Since Mr. Pryor entered the race, he has seldom trailed Mr. Hutchinson by more than a few points in the polls and has been a couple of points ahead a few times. Still, analysts say the race is far from over.
"Ultimately, Hutchinson probably has a bit of an edge in this contest," said Art English, a political scientist at the Little Rock campus of the University of Arkansas. "But he also has that serious divorce problem. So a win is by no means out of reach for Pryor."

HEADLINE: UPRISING IN VENEZUELA: LATIN AMERICA; 
Fear of Loss Of Democracy Led Neighbors To Aid Return

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 14 

 BODY:
Venezuela's neighbors helped pave the way for Hugo Chavez's stunning return to power early today by refusing to accept the legitimacy of the coup that overthrew him and by threatening to impose sanctions, Latin American diplomats say. The efforts opened a breach between the United States and its democratic allies in the Western Hemisphere.
 Until this week, the United States had adopted a policy of restraint, apparently content to let Mr. Chavez collapse under his growing unpopularity. There were no obvious American fingerprints on the plot that unseated Mr. Chavez, unlike coups in Guatemala in 1954 or in Chile in 1973. But Latin American countries are now left with the impression that the Bush administration is selective in its support for democracy. 
 Mr. Chavez's supporters, on the other hand, took heart from an outpouring of criticism by other Latin American governments over the way he was deposed. The initial alarm around the region grew after the military-backed interim president, Pedro Carmona, dissolved Congress and talked of holding presidential elections only after a year had passed -- measures that appeared to contravene the existing Constitution.
"I have been and am a critic of many of the characteristics of the government of Hugo Chavez," said President Alejandro Toledo of Peru. But he added that "we are not defending the democratic characteristics of a particular government, we are defending the principle of the rule of law."
The United States refused to characterize the initial ouster of Mr. Chavez as a coup at all, arguing that he had brought his downfall upon himself. "The government suppressed what was a peaceful demonstration of the people," which "led very quickly to a combustible situation in which Chavez resigned," Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman, said on Friday, before Mr. Chavez staged his comeback. 
Meeting in Washington this weekend, the Organization of American States approved a resolution condemning "the alteration of the constitutional order" in Venezuela and invoked a new "Democratic Charter" approved last fall. That measure is one of several recent regional initiatives that create mechanisms, including sanctions, to isolate and punish governments that take power through nondemocratic means.
After lobbying behind the scenes for softer language, the United States also voted for the measure. "It was necessary to act energetically and decisively in defense of democratic principles, with or without the support of the United States or lose credibility," one South American ambassador said today.
As Mr. Toledo's remarks indicate, Mr. Chavez's leftist populism and his tendency toward demagoguery seem to make most of Latin America's elected leaders uncomfortable. President Fernando Henrique Cardoso of Brazil has been quoted as calling Mr. Chavez an "unconscious authoritarian," and both Colombia and Peru have persistently complained of his support for forces set on undermining their governments.
But the notion of permitting the armed forces of any Latin American country to resume their past role as ultimate arbiter, able to make and unmake elected presidents at will, is even more unpalatable. 
The strongest statements of condemnation of Mr. Chavez's ouster came from countries like Argentina, Paraguay and Peru, which have long histories of military interventions and dictatorships themselves.
President Eduardo Duhalde of Argentina said on Saturday that it was "not good news for the Americas when military coups once again overthrow governments elected by the people." 
The initial American stance on the recent events in Venezuela stand in marked contrast to the Clinton administration's position when a similar military uprising occurred in Ecuador in January 2000. After soldiers and Indians overthrew a pro-American president, Jamil Mahuad, State Department officials called the new junta and told its members that Ecuador would become a pariah state, deprived of all financial aid, unless power was handed over to the civilian vice president -- and it was. 
In Washington today, the Bush administration sought to backtrack slightly from its position without abandoning its criticisms of Mr. Chavez. On the NBC program "Meet the Press," Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser, said this was a "time for national reconciliation" in Venezuela and called on Mr. Chavez to "right his own ship."
"I hope," she added, "that Hugo Chavez takes the message that his people sent him, that his own policies are not working for the Venezuelan people, that he's dealing with them in a highhanded fashion."

BYLINE:  By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
 Another Page
His acting career includes two Tony Awards for best actor in a musical ("City of Angels" and "Chicago"). Among his films are "The Good Mother" and "The Glass Menagerie." Latin Ways
The second year of AmericArtes, the Kennedy Center's celebration of the arts of Latin America, begins at 7:30 tonight at the Eisenhower Theater in Washington with the Brazilian troupe Grupo Galpao's "Romeu e Julieta." Mapping Progress
Since ancient times, when cartographers depicted lands and seas shared with gods and monsters, maps have reflected mankind's understanding of natural boundaries and humans' place on earth. Beginning tomorrow, some of the most historically significant maps of Scandinavia will go on view in Scandinavia House, the Nordic Center in America, at 58 Park Avenue, near 37th Street. Through Aug. 16, "Scandia" includes more than 75 early maps and sea charts, from the first map of the area in 1482 to the detailed maps of the 19th century.
